a: The song "The Sound of Silence" has a rich history and has been covered by various artists over the years. The original version by Simon & Garfunkel was released on their second studio album, "Sounds of Silence," in 1966. However, the song's journey began earlier, as it was first released in an acoustic version on the album "Wednesday Morning, 3 A.M." in 1964. Without the knowledge of the duo's members, Columbia Records staff producer Tom Wilson overdubbed electric guitars, bass, and drums on the song in June 1965, creating a new version that was released as a single in September of the same year. This new version opened the "Sounds of Silence" album and became a major hit, reaching #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Fast forward to 2016, the song was covered by Australian recording artist Dami Im as Australia's entry for the Eurovision Song Contest. Her version, also titled "Sound of Silence," was written by Anthony Egizii and David Musumeci of DNA Songs. The song was leaked a day before its initial release date and went on to become a top 40 hit in more than six countries after the Eurovision Song Contest.

The fact that two different artists, Simon & Garfunkel and Dami Im, have covered "The Sound of Silence" highlights the timeless appeal and versatility of the song. While the original version by Simon & Garfunkel is a classic folk-rock ballad, Dami Im's version is a more contemporary pop take on the song. Both versions have resonated with audiences and have become iconic in their own right. The song's enduring popularity is a testament to its powerful lyrics and melody, which continue to speak to people across generations and cultures.
r1: The original artist of the song sound of silence released in 1966 is Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel. The song had earlier been released in an acoustic version on the album "Wednesday Morning, 3 A.M." which had been produced in 1964. In 2016, Australian recording artist Dami Im recorded a different song by the same name.
r2: There are several songs with the title "Sound of Silence". Sounds of Silence is the second studio album by Simon & Garfunkel, released on January 17, 1966. The album's title is a slight modification of the title of the duo's first major hit, "The Sound of Silence", which was recorded in March 1964 and originally was released as "The Sounds of Silence". Another "Sound of Silence" is a song performed by Australian recording artist Dami Im, and is best known as Australia's entry at the Eurovision Song Contest 2016.

a: The first Apple iPhone was released on June 29, 2007, after several years of development and experimentation by Apple's CEO Steve Jobs and his team. The project began in 2003, when Jobs asked Apple's engineers to explore the use of touchscreen devices and tablet computers. The team investigated the use of touchscreen technology and developed the iPhone's signature multi-touch interface, which allowed users to interact with the device using gestures such as tapping, pinching, and swiping.

In 2005, Apple partnered with Motorola to release the ROKR E1, the first mobile phone to use iTunes. However, Jobs was unhappy with the ROKR, feeling that compromising with a non-Apple designer had prevented Apple from designing the phone they wanted to make. As a result, Apple discontinued support for the ROKR in September 2006 and began working on their own mobile device.

On January 9, 2007, Steve Jobs announced the iPhone at the Macworld convention, receiving extensive media attention. The device was released later that year on June 29, 2007. The iPhone was a revolutionary device that combined the functionality of a mobile phone, an iPod, and an internet communications device into one sleek and user-friendly package. It was the first mobile device to use a multi-touch interface and featured a large 3.5-inch touchscreen display, Wi-Fi connectivity, and a 2-megapixel camera.

The iPhone was a significant departure from traditional mobile phones and was met with both praise and criticism. Some critics praised the device's sleek design and user-friendly interface, while others criticized its lack of 3G connectivity and limited functionality compared to other smartphones on the market. Despite these criticisms, the iPhone was a commercial success and quickly became one of the most popular mobile devices on the market.

In the years following its release, the iPhone has undergone several updates and revisions, including the release of the iPhone 3G in 2008, which added 3G connectivity and GPS functionality. The iPhone has also become a popular platform for developers, with the release of the iPhone Software Development Kit (SDK) in 2008, which allowed developers to create apps for the device. Today, the iPhone remains one of the most popular and influential mobile devices on the market, with new models and features continuing to be released each year.
r1: The iPhone beta was created in 2004 to test the commands of the Apple team, and while technically may have been the first iPhone ever created, it was never released to the public, so this beta was not considered the true first iPhone. After some trial and error, the first iPhone was officially launched and made accessible to the public on June 29, 2007.
r2: There were several Apple iPhones, including the Apple iPhone beta and the Apple iPhone. The first Apple iPhone for beta testing, the Apple iPhone beta, was made in 2004. The iPhone beta was made to test the device and its functions but was never released to the public. The first Apple iPhone 1 was made and the first Apple iPhone was released on June 29, 2007.

a: There are currently 39 state parks in Virginia, which offer a diverse range of outdoor recreational activities and stunning natural beauty. One of these parks, Douthat State Park, is located in the Allegheny Mountains and is one of the original six state parks established in Virginia. The park was donated by the Douthat Land Company in 1933, and the Virginia General Assembly allocated $50,000 for the purchase of land for state parks. The Civilian Conservation Corps, a group of approximately 600 men, developed and constructed the park's modern-day system between 1933 and 1942. Today, Douthat State Park offers visitors a variety of activities, including hiking, camping, fishing, and boating, as well as stunning views of the surrounding mountains and lake. With its rich history and natural beauty, Douthat State Park is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts and families alike, and is just one of many state parks in Virginia that offer unique and memorable experiences for visitors.
r1: When the Virginia state park system was formed on June 15, 1936, there were only six state parks in the entire state. As of 2016, that number had gone up to 38 state parks.
r2: Virginia opened its entire state park system on June 15, 1936 as a six-park system. The six original state parks were Seashore State Park, now First Landing State Park, Westmoreland State Park, Staunton River State Park, Douthat State Park, Fairy Stone State Park, and Hungry Mother State Park. Natural Bridge State Park officially opened on September 24, 2016, making this 38 parks in VA. Today, the park system now oversees 43 parks.

a: The 2018 UEFA Champions League Final was played between Real Madrid and Liverpool at the NSC Olimpiyskiy Stadium in Kiev, Ukraine on May 26, 2018. Real Madrid emerged victorious with a score of 3-1, winning their third consecutive and 13th overall Champions League title. This was the first time a team had achieved three back-to-back titles since Bayern Munich in 1976. Real Madrid's victory also made them the first team to earn the right to play the winners of the 2017-18 UEFA Europa League, Atlético Madrid, in the 2018 UEFA Super Cup, and to enter the semi-finals of the 2018 FIFA Club World Cup. Additionally, they qualified to enter the group stage of the 2018-19 UEFA Champions League, but as they had already qualified through their league performance, the berth was given to the champions of the 2017-18 Czech First League.

The final was a historic one for several reasons. It was the fifth consecutive title for a Spanish side in the Champions League, the longest run for the trophy to be held by teams from the same country since English sides won six consecutive titles between 1977 and 1982. Real Madrid manager Zinedine Zidane became the first manager to win three consecutive Champions League titles, matching Carlo Ancelotti's record of Champions League era wins. This was also the first time a player, Cristiano Ronaldo, had won the Champions League five times, surpassing the record set by Clarence Seedorf in 2007 and by Andrés Iniesta in 2015. Gareth Bale became the first substitute to score two goals in a Champions League final and was named man of the match.

The final was also notable for a controversial tackle by Sergio Ramos on Mohamed Salah, which received mixed reactions from the press and fans on whether it was a deliberate blow or an accident. Egyptian fans responded with anger on social media, including insults that became trending topics on Twitter.

The event was well-attended, with a total of 40,700 tickets available to fans and the general public, including 6,700 tickets available for sale worldwide via UEFA.com. English singer Dua Lipa performed at the opening ceremony preceding the final, joined by Jamaican rapper Sean Paul as a special guest. The 2018 UEFA Women's Champions League Final was held two days earlier, on May 24, 2018, at the Valeriy Lobanovskyi Dynamo Stadium, with Lyon emerging victorious 4-1. The annual UEFA Champions Festival was held between May 24-27, 2018, at the Kiev city centre. However, some fans with allocated tickets had returned them after having trouble finding flights to and accommodation in Kiev, as reported by "The New York Times" in late May.
r1: Real Madrid and Liverpool are the teams that performed in competition at the champions league final 2018. Gareth Bale became the first substitute to score two goals in a Champions League final and was named man of the match. English singer Dua Lipa performed at the opening ceremony preceding the final. r2: Real Madrid and Liverpool were the teams that performed in the 2018 UEFA Champion League Final. a: Of the 29 states in India, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) is currently in power in 21 states, the United Progressive Alliance (UPA) is in power in 3 states and 1 union territory, and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPI(M)) is in power in 1 state. The distribution of states under each alliance is as follows: NDA: Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Chhattisgarh, Goa, Gujarat, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Rajasthan, Sikkim, Tripura, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and West Bengal; UPA: Delhi, Kerala, and Puducherry; CPI(M): Tamil Nadu.

The Governor of each state is appointed by the President for a term of five years and holds office during the pleasure of the President. The Governor is responsible for appointing the Council of Ministers, with the Chief Minister as its head, and advising the Governor in the exercise of his functions. The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the legislative assembly of the state. However, in respect of Nagaland, the Governor has special responsibility under Article 371A of the Constitution with respect to law and order, and can exercise his individual judgment in matters relating to law and order even though it is necessary for him to consult the Council of Ministers.

India's federal system is asymmetric, with special provisions for the state of Jammu and Kashmir and certain northeastern states such as Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Goa, Mizoram, Manipur, Nagaland, and Sikkim. This is due to their unique historical and political circumstances, as well as the desire to address regional aspirations and maintain regional balance. The Constitution also provides for a multi-lingual federalism, with the recognition of 22 official languages and the provision for the use of English as a subsidiary language.

Overall, the distribution of states under different alliances and the special provisions for certain states reflect the complex and diverse nature of Indian federalism, which is characterized by a delicate balance of power between the central government and the states, and a recognition of regional diversity and aspirations.

r2: While India has 28 states, there are additionally 8 union territories, for a total of 36 entities, of which 7 are under congress. Of the 28 states of India, which have their own governments, 5 of the states are under congress. Two of the eight union territories, which are federal territories governed by the Union Government of India, are under congress.

a: Sure! Here is a comprehensive paragraph that answers the question "When did Toronto host the MLB All-Star Game?" and integrates the factoid context:

Toronto hosted the MLB All-Star Game for the first time in 1991, when the 62nd Midsummer Classic was held at SkyDome, the home of the Toronto Blue Jays, on July 9th of that year. This was only the second time that the game was played outside of the United States, following the 1982 game hosted by the National League's Montreal Expos at Olympic Stadium in Montreal, Quebec. The American League defeated the National League 4-2, with the Blue Jays' Jimmy Key earning the win and the Expos' Dennis Martínez taking the loss. This was also the only All-Star Game to be awarded by Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti, who made the announcement on Canada Day 1989. Several players from that game have since been inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame, including Blue Jays legend Rickey Henderson and Expos great Vladimir Guerrero.
r1: Toronto hosted the 1991 Major League Baseball All-Star Game which was the 62nd playing of the midsummer classic on July 9, 1991.
r2: The 1991 Major League Baseball (MLB) All-Star Game was the 62nd playing of the midsummer classic between the all-stars of the American League (AL) and National League (NL), the two leagues comprising Major League Baseball. The venue for each All-Star Game is chosen by an MLB selection committee. Toronto hosted the 1991 MLB All-Star Game on July 9, 1991.

Its lightweight construction and powerful engine, which produced 90 horsepower in its earliest versions and up to 120 horsepower in later models, allowed it to reach speeds of up to 100 mph. Additionally, the car's independent front suspension and live rear axle provided a smooth and responsive ride, making it well-suited for quick maneuvers and tight turns.

Moreover, the Alpine's sleek and aerodynamic design, with its curved lines and minimalist bodywork, made it a stylish and eye-catching vehicle that would be difficult to miss on the road. Its small size and two-seater configuration also made it a more agile and maneuverable car, allowing it to navigate through tight spaces and narrow streets with ease.

Furthermore, the Alpine's history is shrouded in mystery and intrigue, having been featured in the 1955 Alfred Hitchcock film "To Catch a Thief" starring Cary Grant and Grace Kelly. Although the car's true identity in the film was later disputed, the Alpine's association with the iconic movie adds to its allure and mystique.

Additionally, its use of components from other Rootes Group vehicles, such as the Hillman Husky and the Sunbeam Rapier, made it a versatile and reliable car that could be easily serviced and repaired.

Overall, the Sunbeam Alpine's combination of speed, agility, style, and history make it an ideal car to catch a thief, especially in the 1950s and 1960s when it was first produced. a: Here's the comprehensive answer to the question:

Number of branches of Oriental Bank of Commerce (OBC) in India:

Oriental Bank of Commerce (OBC), after acquiring Global Trust Bank (GTB) in 2004, had a significant presence in the southern states of India. GTB had a wide reach in these regions, with 162 branches across eight states. Following the acquisition, OBC gained an increased presence in these areas, with a total of 370 branches in eight states. However, it is important to note that OBC had only ten times the staff and branches than GTB, but only four to five times as much in terms of deposits, investments, or advances. This suggests that OBC had a leaner structure compared to GTB, which may have contributed to its financial challenges.

In contrast, Central Carolina Bank and Trust (CCB), which merged with National Commerce Financial (NCF) in 2002, had a much larger presence in the United States. CCB had 370 branches in eight states, with a market capitalization of about $4.2 billion, combined assets of $15 billion, deposits of $11.3 billion, and 162 National Bank of Commerce (NBC) branches in Tennessee, Georgia, Mississippi, Virginia, West Virginia, Arkansas, and North Carolina. The merger of CCB and NCF created the seventh-largest bank in the United States, with SunTrust as the new parent company.

In conclusion, while OBC had a significant presence in the southern states of India, CCB had a much larger presence in the United States, with a larger number of branches, assets, deposits, and market capitalization.
r1: On 14 August 2004, following the amalgamation of Global Trust Bank, the Oriental Bank of Commerce(OBC) in India increased it's number of branches to 1092. As per the March 2018 – 2019 annual report, that number went up to 2390 branches. After the expected merger with United Bank of India, the number of branches is expected to total 11,437.
r2: In August 2004, Oriental Bank of Commerce in India united with Global Trust Bank, which was a leading private sector bank, the acquisition brought with it 103 branches, which brought OBC's branch total to 1092. According to a March 2018-2019 annual report, it has 2390 branches. On April 1st, 2020, Oriental Bank of Commerce, and United Bank of India merged with Punjab National Bank making it as the second-largest public sector bank in India and brings the total amount of branches to 11,437.

a: The Voortrekkers, as the Dutch-speaking settlers who participated in the Great Trek were known, arrived in South Africa in 1835, specifically in the area now known as Port Natal, after traveling over 650 kilometers from Grahamstown. They had set out on their journey in 1836, seeking to escape the British colonial administration at the Cape and to establish their own autonomous republics in the interior of the country. The Great Trek was motivated by a combination of factors, including tensions between the Boers and the British, as well as a desire to maintain their traditional way of life and to escape the developing administrative complexities of the Cape Colony.

The Voortrekkers traveled eastward, avoiding the coastal route and keeping to the flatter inland terrain, in order to reach their destination more easily. However, their journey was not without its challenges, as they faced rugged terrain, swollen rivers, and hot weather conditions. Despite these obstacles, they persevered and eventually arrived at Port Natal in February 1835, exhausted after their long and arduous journey.

The arrival of the Voortrekkers in South Africa had a significant impact on the region and its inhabitants. The Zulu Empire, which had previously dominated much of the area, was weakened by the arrival of the Voortrekkers, and the Northern Ndebele people were displaced as a result of the Great Trek. The Voortrekkers, who identified themselves as "pioneers" or "pathfinders," went on to establish several autonomous Boer republics, including the South African Republic, the Orange Free State, and the Natalia Republic. These republics were established as a result of the Great Trek and the desire of the Boers to maintain their independence and self-governance.
r1: The Great Trek was an eastward migration of Dutch-speaking settlers who travelled by wagon trains from the Cape Colony into the interior of modern South Africa from 1836 onwards. The exploratory treks however, arrived at the bay of Port Natal in February 1835.
r2: The Voortrekkers' exploratory treks arrived in South Africa in February 1835, and the first wave of Voortrekkers arrived in South Africa in 1836.

a: Sure, here's a comprehensive paragraph that answers the question "When was crude oil first discovered in Nigeria?" while incorporating the provided factoid context:

Crude oil was first discovered in Nigeria in 1953, after decades of exploratory efforts by various companies. The history of oil exploration in Nigeria dates back to 1907, when the Nigerian Bitumen Corporation conducted exploratory work in the country. However, the efforts were disrupted by World War I, and it wasn't until the 1930s that new licenses were granted to companies like D'Arcy Exploration Company and Whitehall Petroleum. Despite their efforts, no commercial quantities of oil were found, and the licenses were eventually returned in 1923. It wasn't until 1937 that Shell D'arcy Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria, a consortium of Shell and British Petroleum, began exploratory work in the country. After several years of drilling, the first test well was drilled in the Owerri area in 1951, and oil was discovered in non-commercial quantities at Akata, near Eket in 1953. Prior to the Akata find, the company had spent around 6 million pounds in exploratory activities in the country. The discovery of crude oil in Nigeria marked the beginning of a booming petroleum industry that would go on to make the country the largest oil and gas producer in Africa. Today, Nigeria's oil and gas industry continues to play a significant role in the country's economy and global energy markets.
r1: Although the history of oil exploration in Nigeria dates back to 1903, non-commercial quantities of oil were not discovered there until 1953. Commercial amounts of crude oil were later discovered in Oloibiri, Nigeria in 1956.
r2: Nigeria is the largest oil and gas producer in Africa. Crude oil from the Niger delta basin comes in two types: light, and comparatively heavy. Oil was discovered in non-commercial quantities at Akata, near Eket in 1953. Shell-BP in the pursuit of commercially available petroleum found oil in Oloibiri, Nigeria in 1956.

0.22916666276529954
a: The authorship of the Second Epistle to the Thessalonians is a topic of ongoing debate among scholars, with some questioning its authenticity and attributing it to a later period, possibly around 80-115 AD. The main arguments against Pauline authorship are differences in style and theology between this letter and the First Epistle to the Thessalonians, as well as the lack of any direct reference to the persecution of Christians in Thessalonica, which is mentioned in the First Epistle. Additionally, the use of the word "parousia" (presence) in 2 Thessalonians 2:1-12, which is not found in the First Epistle, has been cited as evidence of a later composition.

On the other hand, scholars who support Pauline authorship argue that the similarities between the two letters, particularly in terms of language and theology, suggest that they were both written by the same author. Furthermore, the fact that 2 Thessalonians is addressed to the same community as the First Epistle, and that it responds to concerns raised by the Thessalonians in response to the First Epistle, further supports Pauline authorship.

The authenticity of 2 Thessalonians is further complicated by the fact that it addresses a specific issue that arose after the First Epistle was written, namely the question of whether those who had died would share in the parousia. This has led some scholars to suggest that the letter was written by a later author, possibly a follower of Paul, who was attempting to provide a response to this concern.

In conclusion, the authorship of the Second Epistle to the Thessalonians remains a topic of debate among scholars, with both supporting and opposing arguments. While some argue that it was written by Paul, others suggest that it was written by a later author attempting to imitate Paul's style and theology. Ultimately, the authenticity of the letter will continue to be a topic of discussion and debate among scholars.
r1: The first and second thessalonians or 1 Thessalonians and 2 Thessalonians respectively are commonly attributed to Paul the Apostle, however, there are a number of modern scholars who believe that Paul may not have written these books but they may have been written by an associate or disciple of his, perhaps Timothy.
r2: The First Epistle to the Thessalonians, commonly referred to as First Thessalonians or 1 Thessalonians, is a Pauline epistle of the New Testament of the Christian Bible that is attributed to Paul the Apostle. The Second Epistle to the Thessalonians, commonly referred to as Second Thessalonians or 2 Thessalonians is a book from the New Testament of the Christian Bible is traditionally attributed to Paul the Apostle, with Timothy as a co-author. Many modern scholars agree with New Testament Scholar Ehrman that 2 Thessalonians was not written by Paul but by an associate or disciple after his death.

However, Australia did win more gold medals than any other country, with a total of 16 golds. This was a significant achievement for the country, as it was the first time that Australia had hosted the Olympics and the country's athletes were able to perform well on home soil. The 2000 Summer Olympics were also notable for the number of countries that won their first ever Olympic medals, including Cameroon, Colombia, Latvia, Mozambique, and Slovenia, which won a gold medal for the first time in their Olympic histories. Additionally, Vietnam, Barbados, Macedonia, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, and Saudi Arabia won their first ever Olympic medals, with a silver in taekwondo, a bronze in athletics, a bronze in wrestling, and a bronze in judo, respectively. Overall, the 2000 Summer Olympics were a successful event for Australia and for many other countries around the world, with a total of 80 countries winning at least one medal.
r1: During the summer Olympic games in the year 2000, Australia won 17 bronze, 25 silver and 16 gold medals for a total of 58 medals overall.

0.2600896823374691
a: The Vice President of India is elected through an electoral college system, as per the Constitution of India. The election is conducted by the Election Commission of India, and the winner is chosen based on a majority vote. The Vice President serves a five-year term and can serve a maximum of two terms. The Vice President is the ex-officio Chairperson of the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of the Indian Parliament) and functions as its Speaker. In the event of a vacancy in the office of the President, the Vice President assumes the duties of the President for a maximum period of six months.

In 2017, the Vice Presidential election was held on 5 August, and Venkaiah Naidu won the election, taking oath as the 13th Vice President of India on 11 August 2017. Naidu succeeded Mohammad Hamid Ansari, who completed his second term as Vice President and was not offered another term.

Ansari, a seasoned politician and former Ambassador, served as the Vice President of India from 2007 to 2017. He was the first person to be re-elected as Vice President after Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan in 1957. During his tenure, Ansari worked as the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and also served as the President of the Indian Council of World Affairs. Prior to his election as Vice President, Ansari served as the Vice-Chancellor of the Aligarh Muslim University and the Chairman of the National Commission for Minorities.

Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, a former Chief Minister of Rajasthan, was the 11th Vice President of India, serving from 2002 to 2007. He was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and was elected to the Rajya Sabha from Madhya Pradesh in 1973. Shekhawat was known as "Rajasthan ka ek hi Singh" (The only lion of Rajasthan) or "Babosa" (Head of the family of Rajasthan) and entered politics in 1952.

In conclusion, the Vice President of India is elected through an electoral college system and serves a five-year term as the ex-officio Chairperson of the Rajya Sabha. The Vice President assumes the duties of the President in case of a vacancy and plays a crucial role in the functioning of the Indian Parliament. The current Vice President of India is Venkaiah Naidu, who was elected in 2017 and succeeded Mohammad Hamid Ansari, who served two terms as Vice President.
r1: The second highest constitutional office or the position of Vice President in India was held by Bhairon Singh Shekhawat from August 2002 until he resigned on 21 July 2007. From 2007 to 2017, Mohammad Hamid Ansari served two terms as the 12th Vice President after his re-appointment in 2012. On 11 August 2017, the Vice President seat was then held by Venkaiah Naidu after being sworn in as the 13th vice president of the country.
r2: Who is elected as the vice president of India depends on the year. The vice president of India is Venkaiah Naidu. He was elected in the August 5, 2017 election, defeating UPA's candidate Gopalkrishna Gandhi. Mohammad Hamid Ansari was elected to the office on August 11, 2007, and on August 7, 2012, while Bhairon Singh Shekhawat was on August 19, 2002.

0.21212120919450186
a: During World War I, David Lloyd George served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, leading the Wartime Coalition Government from 1916 to 1922. He took over the premiership from H. H. Asquith, who had led the country since 1908 and was the last Prime Minister to lead a majority Liberal government. Lloyd George's tenure as Prime Minister was marked by a significant shift in the country's approach to the war, as he implemented a policy of total war, complete state intervention in public affairs, and introduced new powers through the Defence of the Realm Act 1914. This move away from "business as usual" was a departure from Asquith's more cautious approach and marked a significant turning point in the country's war effort.

Lloyd George's leadership during the war also saw the first aerial bombardments of British cities, and the government responded by increasing propaganda efforts through the media, with the help of journalists such as Charles Masterman and newspaper owners like Lord Beaverbrook. Additionally, the war saw a significant shift in the country's demographics, as women entered the workforce in large numbers for the first time, and the government made concessions to trade unions to address labor shortages.

Despite his success in leading the country through the war, Lloyd George's tenure as Prime Minister was not without controversy. He faced criticism for his support of the war effort, and his leadership was marked by internal party divisions within the Liberal Party. By the 1920s, the party had splintered, and Lloyd George's leadership had become marginalized and mistrusted. He remained a prominent figure in British politics until his death in 1945 but was never able to regain the power and influence he had wielded during the war.

In contrast, H. H. Asquith, who served as Prime Minister from 1908 to 1916, took a more cautious approach to the war, and his leadership was marked by the introduction of major liberal legislation and a reduction of the power of the House of Lords. However, his government was vigorously attacked for the shortage of munitions and the failure at Gallipoli, leading to his resignation in December 1916. Asquith's legacy is complex, with some historians arguing that he was a skilled diplomat and leader who played a crucial role in shaping the modern welfare state, while others criticize his handling of the war and his inability to address the country's growing social and economic problems.

Overall, the leadership of David Lloyd George and H. H. Asquith during World War I marked a significant turning point in British history, as the country transitioned from a more cautious approach to a more interventionist one and saw the introduction of new powers and policies that would shape the course of the war and the country's future.
r1: In August 1914, British statesman and Liberal politician H. H. Asquith took Great Britain and the British Empire into the First World War while he served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1916 to 1922. His successor David Lloyd George took office in 1916 and continued to serve as Prime Minister during the end of the war which ended in November of 1918.
r2: At the start of World War I, England's Prime Minister was Herbert Henry Asquith, the 1st Earl of Oxford and Asquith. Generally known as H. H. Asquith, he was a British statesman and Liberal politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1908 to 1916. At the end of World War I, David Lloyd George, the 1st Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor, was Prime Minister. He was a Welsh statesman and Liberal Party politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1916 to 1922.

a: The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which abolished slavery and involuntary servitude except as punishment for a crime, was ratified by the required number of states on December 6, 1865. The amendment was passed by the Senate on April 8, 1864, and by the House on January 31, 1865, but it was not until nearly a year later that the necessary number of states had ratified it. The amendment was ratified by 27 of the 36 states, including three of the former Confederate states, which had given their assent with certain conditions. Despite these conditions, Secretary of State William H. Seward certified the ratification of the amendment on December 18, 1865. The Thirteenth Amendment became part of the Constitution 61 years after the Twelfth Amendment, making it the longest interval between constitutional amendments.

The ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment had a significant impact on the country, as it abolished slavery and expanded the scope of President Abraham Lincoln's 1863 Emancipation Proclamation to include the entire nation. While many slaves had been declared free by the Emancipation Proclamation, their post-war status was uncertain until the Thirteenth Amendment was ratified. As a result of the amendment, an estimated 65,000 to 100,000 people in Kentucky and 900 people in Delaware became legally free. The ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment marked a major milestone in the struggle for freedom and equality for African Americans, and it paved the way for further civil rights legislation in the years to come.
r1: The Thirteenth Amendment (Amendment XIII) to the United States Constitution to abolish slavery and involuntary servitude passed on January 31, 1865. It however required number (27) of states to implement it, and by the end of February 1865, only 18 states had ratified the amendment. The amendment wasn't fully ratified until December 6, 1865.
r2: The Thirteenth Amendment (Amendment XIII) to the United States Constitution abolished slavery and involuntary servitude, except as punishment for a crime. In Congress, it was passed by the Senate on April 8, 1864, and by the House on January 31, 1865. By the end of February 1865, 18 states had ratified the amendment. At least 27 states had to ratify the amendment for it to come into force, and by December 6, 1865, the amendment was ratified by the required number of states.

0.22047243737832478
a: The 300 mile march to Sacramento, California was led by Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers (UFW) in 1966. The march, known as the "March for Justice," was a pivotal moment in the labor movement and the struggle for farmworkers' rights. The UFW, which was formed by the merger of two workers' rights organizations, the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee (AWOC) and the National Farm Workers Association (NFWA), had been organizing strikes and boycotts in California's San Joaquin Valley to demand better wages and working conditions for farmworkers. The march was a culmination of these efforts and aimed to bring attention to the plight of farmworkers and to pressure the state government to pass legislation that would protect their rights.

The march began on March 17, 1966, in Delano, California, and over the course of 25 days, the protesters, many of whom were farmworkers themselves, walked 300 miles to the state capital of Sacramento. Along the way, they faced harsh weather conditions, including rain and extreme heat, as well as opposition from the growers and law enforcement. Despite these challenges, the marchers remained resolute and determined, and their numbers swelled as they made their way across the state.

The March for Justice was a strategic move by the UFW to mobilize public support for their cause and to put pressure on the state government to take action. The march was well-organized and well-publicized, with supporters from all over the country joining the protesters along the way. The UFW also used nonviolent tactics, such as boycotts and strikes, to further their goals and to draw attention to the injustices faced by farmworkers.

The March for Justice was a turning point in the labor movement and the struggle for farmworkers' rights. It helped to galvanize public support for the UFW and its demands, and it paved the way for significant improvements in working conditions and wages for farmworkers. The march also helped to establish Cesar Chavez as a prominent leader in the labor movement and a powerful voice for the Latino community. Today, Chavez is remembered as a hero and a symbol of hope for workers and marginalized communities, and his legacy continues to inspire activism and social justice movements around the world.
r1: The 300 mile march organized by the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee (AWOC) beginning on September 8, 1965 was led by American labor leader and civil rights activist Cesar Chavez.
r2: The Delano grape strike was a labor strike organized by the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee (AWOC), a predominantly Filipino and AFL-CIO-sponsored labor organization, against table grape growers in Delano, California to fight against the exploitation of farm workers. As the strike began to flag in winter, Cesar Chavez decided on a march of 300 miles to the state capitol at Sacramento. This would pass through dozens of farmworker communities and attract attention for their cause.

a: Based on the provided factoids, the oldest person in the world was Sarah Knauss, an American supercentenarian who lived to the age of 119 years and 30 days. She was born on September 24, 1880, in Hollywood, Pennsylvania, and married Abraham Lincoln Knauss in 1901. Her husband died in 1965, and their only child, Kathryn, died in 2005 at the age of 101. Sarah's longevity was recognized by Guinness World Records, and she became the world's oldest living person in 1998, following the death of Marie-Louise Meilleur, a 117-year-old Canadian.

The Gerontology Research Group (GRG), a global organization of researchers dedicated to studying aging and gerontology, verified Sarah's age and confirmed her as the oldest person in the world. The GRG requires strict documentation to verify the ages of supercentenarians, including birth and death certificates, and other official government identification.

Sarah's remarkable longevity is even more remarkable when considering that she had seven living generations in her family at the time of her death. Her lifespan is a testament to the advances in medical science and technology that have contributed to increased human lifespan over the past century.

It is worth noting that while Sarah Knauss holds the record for the oldest person in the world, her age has been disputed by some researchers. Some have suggested that her age may have been exaggerated or falsified, and there is ongoing debate within the scientific community about the validity of her record. However, based on the available evidence and verification by the GRG, Sarah Knauss remains the oldest person in the world, and her remarkable longevity continues to inspire research and interest in the field of gerontology.

The following year in 1986, Augusta Holtz was validated as the oldest German citizen as she lived 115 years and 79 days by the time of her death in 1986. Skipping forward to 1997, French supercentenarian Jeanne Calment became the oldest human whose age is well-documented at the time of her death in August 1997. However, when it comes to the oldest person in the world whose age is undisputed is Sarah Knauss of the United States who lived to the age of 119 years and 97 days on December 30, 1999.
r2: A supercentenarian is someone who has reached the age of 110. Sarah Knauss, whose age is undisputed, was the oldest person ever from the United States and the second-oldest fully documented person ever. Jeanne Calment was a French supercentenarian and the oldest human whose age is well-documented, with a lifespan of 122 years and 164 days, and was the oldest person in the world as of 1997. 0.24468084715934812
a: The 12th day of Christmas begins on January 5th and ends on January 6th, which is known as Epiphany Eve. This period is also known as Christmastide or the Twelve Days of Christmas, and it is a festive season in Western Christian traditions that celebrates the Nativity of Jesus. The Twelve Days are considered to be a time of celebration and gift-giving, and they are often associated with the traditional Christian Advent season, which runs from the fourth Sunday before Christmas Day until Christmas Day itself.

However, the commercial calendar has influenced the way the Twelve Days of Christmas are perceived in modern times. In the United States, the traditional liturgical seasons of Advent and Christmas have been largely replaced by secular traditions such as Black Friday sales and New Year's Eve parties. As a result, the Twelve Days of Christmas have become obscured, and many Americans assume that they end on Christmas Day.

Despite this, many Christian denominations still observe the Twelve Days of Christmas and celebrate them with special liturgical services and traditions. For example, the Episcopal Church in the US has an invitatory antiphon in the Book of Common Prayer for Matins during the Twelve Days of Christmas. Additionally, some Christians give gifts on each of the Twelve Days, with each day representing a wish for a corresponding month of the new year.

Overall, the 12th day of Christmas begins on January 5th and ends on January 6th, and it is a significant period in Western Christian traditions that celebrates the Nativity of Jesus. While secular traditions have obscured the Twelve Days of Christmas in modern times, many Christian denominations still observe this festive season with special liturgical services and traditions.
r1: In most Western ecclesiastical traditions, the 12th day of christmas is January 5th. The 12 days of christmas begin December 25 to January 5. According to the commercial calendar, the first day of Christmas (December 25) is considered the last day of the "Christmas" marketing season, as demonstrated by the numerous "after-Christmas sales" that commence on 26 December. When it comes to Eastern Christianity i.e. Oriental Orthodox (other than the Armenians), the Eastern Orthodox, and the Eastern Catholics, Christmas and Epiphany are celebrated by these churches on 25 December and 6 January using the Julian calendar, which correspond to 7 January and 19 January using the Gregorian calendar. The Twelve Days, using the Gregorian calendar, end at sunset on 18 January.
r2: The start and end, or 12th day, of the Twelve Days of Christmas are held to be on a number of different dates. In most Western ecclesiastical traditions, Christmas Day is considered the First Day of Christmas and the Twelve Days are 25 December through 5 January, with January 5 being the final and 12th day of Christmas. In Eastern Christianity, the 12th day is held to be on 18 January. Conversely, the commercial calendar holds that the Twelve Days are 14 December to 25 December, with Christmas Day being the 12th day.
=============================43=============================

a: Alabama became a right-to-work state in 2016, when Governor Robert Bentley signed the Alabama Workplace Freedom Act into law. This law prohibits union security agreements between employers and labor unions, which means that employees in unionized workplaces are not required to pay union dues or fees as a condition of employment. The law was enacted as part of a broader effort to attract businesses and jobs to the state, and was seen as a victory for business interests and the Republican-led legislature. The law was signed on February 11, 2016, and went into effect on June 1, 2016.

The passage of the Alabama Workplace Freedom Act was part of a larger trend of right-to-work laws being enacted in states across the country. According to the Legal Defense Foundation, right-to-work laws are currently effective in 27 states, mostly in the Southern, Western, and Midwestern regions of the United States. These laws have been supported by business interests, such as the United States Chamber of Commerce, who argue that they are necessary to promote economic growth and job creation.

However, the passage of right-to-work laws has also been controversial, with opponents arguing that they can lead to lower wages and weaker labor unions. In Alabama, the law was met with opposition from labor unions and Democratic lawmakers, who argued that it would lead to a decline in union membership and a loss of collective bargaining power for workers.

Despite these criticisms, the Alabama Workplace Freedom Act was seen as a significant victory for Governor Bentley and the Republican-led legislature, who had made passing a right-to-work law a priority. The law was also seen as a potential boon for businesses looking to locate in the state, as it was seen as a way to attract new investment and create jobs.

Overall, the passage of the Alabama Workplace Freedom Act was a significant development in the state's labor politics, and was part of a larger trend of right-to-work laws being enacted across the country. While the law has been controversial, it has also been seen as a way to promote economic growth and job creation in the state.
r1: In the context of labor law in the United States, the term "right-to-work laws" refers to state laws that prohibit union security agreements between employers and labor unions. The state of Alabama became a right to work state by adopting statutes in 1953 and by constitutional provision in 2016.
r2: Alabama is a state in the Southeastern region of the United States. In the context of labor law in the United States, the term "right-to-work laws" refers to state laws that prohibit union security agreements between employers and labor unions. Alabama became a "right-to-work" state in 1953 by adopting statutes. By constitutional provision, Alabama became a "right-to-work" state in 2016.

0.2611940258868902
a: The authorship of the books of the New Testament is a complex and longstanding topic of debate among scholars. While traditional attributions of authorship have been passed down through the centuries, many critical scholars today question the accuracy of these ascriptions. According to Bart Ehrman, a prominent New Testament scholar, many of the books of the New Testament were not written by the individuals whose names are attached to them. In fact, he argues that the Gospels were originally anonymous, and names were not ascribed to them until around 185 AD.

One of the most contested issues in New Testament authorship is the identity of the author of the Gospel of Luke and the Acts of the Apostles. While the prefaces of both books attribute them to a person named Theophilus, many scholars believe that these books were written by different authors. Some argue that the Gospel of Luke was written by a Gentile, while others believe that it was written by a Hellenistic Jew. The Acts of the Apostles, on the other hand, is thought to have been written by the same author as the Gospel of Luke, and is therefore referred to as the Lucan texts.

The Pauline epistles, which include the thirteen letters traditionally attributed to Paul of Tarsus, are another area of debate. While many scholars accept the traditional view that these letters were written by Paul, some question whether the first three, called the "Deutero-Pauline Epistles," are authentic. The anonymous Epistle to the Hebrews is also a subject of debate, with many scholars rejecting Pauline authorship.

The Pastoral epistles, which include 1 and 2 Timothy and Titus, are generally considered to be pseudonymous, with most scholars rejecting the traditional view that they were written by Paul. The Epistle to the Laodiceans and the Third Epistle to the Corinthians are also considered to be pseudonymous.

The authorship of the Gospel of John is also a topic of debate, with some scholars arguing that it was written by the Apostle John, while others believe that it was written by a different author. The Epistle of James, which is attributed to James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, is another book whose authorship is contested. While some ancient and modern scholars have argued that the epistle was written by James the Just, others believe that it was written in the late 1st or early 2nd centuries by an unknown author.

In conclusion, the authorship of the books of the New Testament is a complex and multifaceted issue, with many scholars questioning the traditional attributions of authorship. While some books, such as the Pauline epistles and the Gospel of Luke, are generally accepted as being written by the individuals whose names are attached to them, others, such as the Gospel of John and the Epistle of James, are the subject of ongoing debate and discussion. Ultimately, the authorship of the New Testament books is a matter of interpretation and belief, and will likely continue to be a topic of discussion and debate among scholars for years to come.
r1: The books of the New Testament were all or nearly all written by Jewish Christians (Jewish disciples of Christ) who lived in the Roman Empire, however, not all the authors were Jewish Christians. It is believed that disciples Matthew, Mark, Luke, John wrote the gospels of the New Testament. The other books like the Pauline epistles are traditionally attributed to Paul of Tarsus, the Epistle of James is attributed to James (a servant of God), while Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ wrote the First Epistle of Peter. A number of scholars are divided as to whether Luke (who wrote the Gospel of Luke) was a Gentile or a Hellenistic Jew.
r2: The New Testament of the Bible is primarily written in parts with the majority of it written by Jewish disciples of Christ. Matthew, Mark, Luke, John wrote the gospels. The First Epistle of Peter was written by Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, Epistle of James was written by James, a servant of God, and the Pauline Epistles was written by Paul of Tarsus.

0.29268292290303394
a: The repetition of phrases or sentences with similar structures or meanings is called parallel syntax or parallel construction. This rhetorical device is used to emphasize a central theme or idea by repeating it in multiple sentences or clauses, providing a sense of balance and harmony to the text. The repeated phrases or sentences can be identical or slightly varied, creating a sense of repetition with a purpose. This technique is effective in improving the flow of a sentence, making it more concise and direct, and it can also appeal to the reader or listener on multiple levels.

One of the primary benefits of parallel syntax is that it enhances the reader's ability to process the text. Studies have shown that the repetition of clauses can increase the speed at which an individual can process a sentence, and it also decreases the amount of information that needs to be processed, making comprehension easier. Additionally, the emotional appeal of parallel syntax should not be underestimated. Aristotle believed that persuasion can be achieved through the use of parallel syntax, as it creates a sense of repetition that embeds the idea into the listener, making it more memorable and persuasive.

Parallel syntax is closely related to another rhetorical device called schesis onomaton, which involves constructing a sentence using only nouns and adjectives. This technique is often used to emphasize a particular idea or theme, and it can be effective in creating a sense of repetition and balance in the text. However, it is important to note that schesis onomaton can also be used in a more general sense to refer to any series of words that are synonymous expressions, and it is not limited to nouns and adjectives.

In conclusion, parallel syntax is a powerful rhetorical device that can be used to emphasize a central theme or idea, improve the flow of a sentence, and appeal to the reader or listener on multiple levels. It is closely related to other rhetorical devices such as schesis onomaton, and it is an effective tool for any writer or speaker looking to create a sense of balance and harmony in their text.
r1: The difference between Parallel Syntax (also known as parallel construction and parallelism) and Schesis onomaton is that Parallel Syntax is a rhetorical device that consists of repetition among adjacent sentences or clauses while Schesis onomaton is a rhetorical technique used to emphasize an idea by repeating it rapidly using slightly different words that have the same or a very similar meaning.
r2: In rhetoric, Parallel Syntax (also known as parallel construction and parallelism) is a rhetorical device that consists of repetition among adjacent sentences or clauses. The repeated sentences or clauses provides emphasis to a center theme or idea the author is trying to convey. Schesis onomaton is a rhetorical technique used to emphasize an idea by repeating it rapidly using slightly different words that have the same or a very similar meaning.

a: In Act 5, Scene 5 of William Shakespeare's "Macbeth," the titular character delivers a famous soliloquy beginning with the words "Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow." This soliloquy is a poignant reflection on the ravages of time and the toll it has taken on Macbeth's soul. The speaker, once a brave and respected general, has become a tyrannical and guilt-ridden king, consumed by the ambition that drove him to murder his own king and seize the throne.

The soliloquy is delivered as Macbeth hears the cry of a woman, which would once have sent shivers down his spine, but now he is so desensitized to horror and violence that it fails to stir him. This desensitization is a direct result of the bloodbath he has unleashed upon Scotland, and the countless lives he has taken in his quest for power. Macbeth's reflection on the passage of time is a stark contrast to his earlier self, when he was full of "horrors and slaughterous thoughts" (5.5.19).

The soliloquy is also a commentary on the futility of life and the inevitability of death. Macbeth notes that "tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow" (5.5.16) will come and go, but the present moment is all that truly exists. This is a poignant observation, as Macbeth is about to face his own death at the hands of Macduff, and the finality of death is weighing heavily on his mind.

Furthermore, the soliloquy highlights the theme of the corrupting influence of power and ambition. Macbeth's desire for power and his willingness to do whatever it takes to achieve it has led him down a path of destruction and madness. He is now so consumed by his own guilt and paranoia that he is unable to feel any emotion other than a numb acceptance of his fate.

In conclusion, the soliloquy "Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow" is a powerful and poignant moment in "Macbeth," and it highlights the themes of the corrupting influence of power and ambition, the futility of life, and the inevitability of death. Macbeth's reflection on the passage of time is a stark reminder of the toll that his own actions have taken on his soul, and the finality of his own death is a reminder that all human beings are ultimately subject to the same fate.

a: The most points scored in an NBA game is 100 points, achieved by Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia 76ers in a game against the New York Knicks on March 2, 1962. This record has stood the test of time, despite the fact that the game has evolved over the years with changes in rules, player talent, and scoring opportunities. In contrast, Kobe Bryant's 81-point game in 2006, which is the second-highest total in NBA history, was achieved in a game where the Lakers trailed at halftime and Bryant had to create his own shots, unlike Chamberlain's game where he was fed repeatedly by his teammates in a blowout win. Additionally, Chamberlain's record is even more impressive when considering that he accounted for 59% of his team's points, while Bryant only accounted for 66% of the Lakers' 122 points. Other notable records set by Chamberlain in that game include the most points in a quarter (32 in the first quarter), most free throws made (28), and all of his other records set that day still stand. Interestingly, the highest-scoring game in NBA history was not achieved by Chamberlain, but by the San Antonio Spurs and the Milwaukee Bucks in a triple overtime game in 1982, where the two teams combined for 337 points. However, this record was broken just over a year later by the Detroit Pistons and the Denver Nuggets in a game that also went into triple overtime, with a total of 370 points scored.
r1: The most points ever scored in an NBA regular season game came in 1983 when the Pistons defeated the Nuggets 186–184 in a triple overtime game that resulted in a combined score of 370 points. In that same game was another record of the most points scored in an nba game by a single team which came to 186 (Pistons). The most points scored (162) by a single team in a regular season game during regulation was in 1990 when the Warriors defeated the Nuggets 162-158. The most points scored (153) by a single team in a playoff game was in 1992 when the Phoenix Suns defeated the Trail Blazers 153-151. Finally, the most points scored in an NBA game by an individual was done by the Philadelphia Warriors' Wilt Chamberlain who scored an NBA-record 100 points in a single game.
r2: In basketball, points are used to keep track of the score in a game. The most points scored in a NBA game by combined teams is 370, and the most points scored in a NBA game by a single team is 186. The most points scored in a NBA game by an individual is 100. The highest amount of points scored by a single team in regular season games in regulation is 162. The highest amount of points scored by a single team in playoff games is 153.

a: Lipid testing is an essential component of a comprehensive health assessment, and there are several methods used to determine the presence and levels of lipids in the body. The most common method is the lipid profile, which includes a series of blood tests that measure various lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides. The results of this test can provide valuable information about the risk of cardiovascular disease, pancreatitis, and other health conditions. In addition to the lipid profile, the emulsion test is another method used to detect the presence of lipids. This test involves suspending a sample in ethanol, allowing lipids to dissolve, and then adding water to the solution. The resulting cloudy white emulsion indicates the presence of lipids.

The lipid profile typically includes several tests, such as the total cholesterol, LDL or "bad" cholesterol, HDL or "good" cholesterol, and triglycerides. These tests provide information about the balance of lipids in the body and can help identify potential health risks. For example, high levels of LDL cholesterol can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, while low levels of HDL cholesterol can increase the risk of heart disease and stroke. Additionally, the lipid profile can help diagnose certain genetic diseases, such as familial hypercholesterolemia.

The Adult Treatment Panel (ATP) III guidelines recommend screening for lipid disorders in healthy adults with no cardiovascular risk factors every five years. However, individuals with risk factors, such as a family history of heart disease or high blood pressure, may need to be screened more frequently. Children and adolescents are not typically screened for lipid disorders unless they have a family history of these conditions or other risk factors.

In conclusion, lipid testing is an important tool for assessing the balance of lipids in the body and identifying potential health risks. The lipid profile and emulsion test are two common methods used to detect the presence and levels of lipids, and the results of these tests can help guide treatment decisions and preventive measures to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease and other health conditions.
r1: A lipid profile or "lipid panel" is a panel of blood tests that serves as an initial screening tool for abnormalities in lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides in the body. The emulsion test however, is a method to determine the presence of lipids using wet chemistry. This same method can test for lipids in food as well.
r2: Lipid profile or a lipid panel test, is a panel of blood tests that serves as an initial screening tool for abnormalities in lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides, as well as certain genetic diseases. The emulsion test is a method to determine the presence of lipids using wet chemistry. The procedure is for the sample to be suspended in ethanol, allowing lipids present to dissolve. The liquid, which is alcohol with dissolved fat, is then decanted into water. Since lipids do not dissolve in water, when the ethanol is diluted, it falls out of the solution to give a cloudy white emulsion.

"Give Me a Home Among the Gumtrees" is a popular Australian song that was written in 1974 by Wally Johnson and Bob Brown, also known as Captain Rock. The song was originally performed as a satirical number in their comedy act at the Flying Trapeze Cafe in Melbourne and was later recorded on the Captain Rock album "Buried Treasure" in 1975. At the time, the Australian government was holding a contest to find a new national anthem, and "Gumtrees" was Johnson and Brown's response to the contest (it did not win). The song became a hit for the band The Emu, who recorded a cover version in 1982, and it has since been covered by other artists such as John Williamson. The song has become a beloved Australian classic and has been performed at various events, including a memorial service for Steve Irwin in 2006, which was broadcast to a global audience of 300 million viewers. Co-writer Wally Johnson passed away in 1995, but Bob Brown continues to write and perform tongue-in-cheek folk songs, including children's songs and songs that have been covered by other artists.

r2: Home Among the Gumtrees is a popular Australian song written in 1974 by Wally Johnson and Bob Brown, known as Captain Rock. The song has become one of the most frequently recorded Australian compositions of all time and is a standard in Australian folk music. During their final battle, Rita trapped Zordon in a time warp, while Zordon sealed Rita and her minions away in a "Dumpster" on the Moon.

0.17821781932310563
a: Construction on the Sydney Harbour Bridge began on 28 July 1923, with the official turning of the first sod taking place at Milsons Point on the north shore. The construction process started with the building of approaches and approach spans, and by September 1926, concrete piers to support the approach spans were in place on each side of the harbour. The southern end of the bridge was worked on ahead of the northern end to detect any errors and to help with alignment. The cranes would "creep" along the arches as they were constructed, eventually meeting up in the middle. On 26 October 1928, arch construction began, and the two halves of the arch touched for the first time on 19 August 1930. Workers riveted both top and bottom sections of the arch together, and the arch became self-supporting, allowing the support cables to be removed. The joining of the arches was celebrated by flying the flags of Australia and the United Kingdom from the jibs of the creeper cranes. Once the arch was completed, the creeper cranes were worked back down the arches, allowing the roadway and other parts of the bridge to be constructed from the centre out. The vertical hangers were attached to the arch, and these were then joined with horizontal crossbeams. The deck for the roadway and railway were built on top of the crossbeams, with the deck itself being completed by June 1931. The creeper cranes were dismantled, and rails for trains and trams were laid, along with the surfacing of the roadway using concrete topped with asphalt. Power, telephone, water, gas, and drainage pipes were also added to the bridge in 1931. The construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge was a complex and challenging process that required careful planning and execution, but the end result was a magnificent structure that has become an iconic symbol of Sydney and one of the most recognizable landmarks in Australia.
r1: Construction of the sydney harbour bridge started on 28 July 1923 but construction of the Arch did not begin until 26 October 1928.
r2: While construction officially started on the Sydney Harbour Bridge on 28 July 1923, construction of the arch on the bridge didn't begin until 26 October 1928. Work on the bridge itself commenced with the construction of approaches and approach spans.

According to Hyginus, Hector killed 31,000 Greek fighters during the war, a testament to his exceptional bravery and martial prowess.

Founded in 705 AD by Fujiwara Mahito, the hotel has been owned and operated by 52 generations of the same family, including adopted heirs, making it not only the oldest hotel but also one of the oldest companies in existence. Despite its long history, the hotel has undergone only one major renovation in 1997, and it still maintains its traditional Japanese architecture and hot spring water sourced directly from the local Hakuho Springs.

In contrast to modern hotels like the Izmailovo Hotel in Moscow, which boasts 7,500 beds, or the MGM Grand Las Vegas complex with 6,852 rooms, Nishiyama Onsen Keiunkan's 37 rooms provide a more intimate and traditional experience for its guests. The hotel's long history and family ownership have created a sense of continuity and tradition that is rare in today's hospitality industry.

While other hotels may have more rooms or luxurious amenities, Nishiyama Onsen Keiunkan's longevity and family legacy make it a truly unique and special place to stay. The hotel's commitment to preserving traditional Japanese culture and architecture, combined with its stunning natural surroundings, make it a must-visit destination for those seeking a truly authentic and memorable experience.

The U.S. military was also deployed to replace British invasion forces in Iceland. Despite later rumors, there was no advance knowledge of the Japanese plan, and the attack caught the U.S. Pacific Fleet by surprise. The attack on Pearl Harbor was a failure for the Japanese, as the lost battleships were obsolete and the lost planes were soon replaced. However, the attack had the opposite effect on the United States, electrifying public opinion and committing the country to a war to the death against the Japanese Empire. President Franklin D. Roosevelt officially pronounced December 7, 1941, as "a date which will live in infamy" and asked for a declaration of war on Japan before a joint session of Congress on December 8, 1941. The motion passed with only one vote against it, and just three days later, on December 11, 1941, Adolf Hitler declared war on the United States.

The entry of the United States into World War II marked a significant turning point in the conflict, as the country's industrial and military might helped to shift the balance of power in favor of the Allies. The U.S. military, led by General George Marshall and the Army Air Forces under General Hap Arnold, played a crucial role in the war, with over 16 million Americans serving in the military and over 400,000 killed in action. The U.S. also provided significant financial and material support to the Allies, with the Lend-Lease Act providing billions of dollars in aid to Britain and the Soviet Union.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who had been a central figure in the U.S. response to the war, played a key role in shaping the country's wartime strategy and diplomacy. He was a dominant leader of his party and a central figure in world events, implementing his New Deal domestic agenda in response to the Great Depression and building the New Deal Coalition, which realigned American politics into the Fifth Party System. Roosevelt's leadership during the war helped to define American liberalism and cemented his reputation as one of the greatest U.S. presidents, along with George Washington and Abraham Lincoln.
r1: Prior to the United States entering world war II, U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the Lend-Lease Act on 11 March 1941 to ensure the supply of war materials to Britain, the Soviet Union, and China. a: The flower of the dead in Spanish is "cempasúchil," which is also known as "twenty flower" in Nahuatl, the language of the Aztecs. This flower, Tagetes erecta, is widely cultivated and has many cultivars used in gardening as an ornamental plant. It is particularly significant in Mexico, where it is used to decorate altars and tombs during the Day of the Dead celebrations, which take place on November 1st and 2nd. The flower is believed to help guide the spirits of the dead back to their homes and is also used to honor and remember loved ones who have passed away. The essential oil of the flower is also used in the washing of corpses in Honduras, and it has been used for medicinal purposes since pre-Hispanic times. The Cherokee tribe also used the flower for skin washes and as a natural dye. The Day of the Dead is a Mexican holiday celebrated throughout Mexico and by people of Mexican heritage elsewhere, which focuses on gatherings of family and friends to pray for and remember friends and family members who have died. The holiday is associated with October 31st, November 1st, and November 2nd, and traditions include building private altars, honoring the deceased with calaveras, aztec marigolds, and their favorite foods and beverages, and visiting graves with these as gifts.
r1: In conjunction with the November 2nd Mexican holiday (Day of the Dead), the cempasúchil or "flor de muertos" in Spanish and "flower of the dead" in English are used to attract the souls of the dead to the offerings.
r2: Mexican Marigold also known as Cempasúchil, or Aztec Marigold is a native flower to México and was first used by the Aztecs and is used in the Mexican holiday "Dia de Los Muertos" or Day of the Dead. Also called the "Flower of the Dead", it is translated in Spanish as "Flor de Muertos".

a: The President of the Senate in the Texas Legislature is the Lieutenant Governor, who serves as the highest-ranking official in the Senate and has a significant amount of power and influence over the legislative process. The Lieutenant Governor appoints chairs of committees, committee members, and assigns and refers bills to specific committees, and has the power to recognize members during debate and make procedural rulings. Additionally, the Lieutenant Governor may cast a vote in the event of a tie in the Senate floor vote. The Lieutenant Governor is considered one of the most powerful positions in the Texas Senate, and the President Pro Tempore, who presides over the Senate when the Lieutenant Governor is not present or when the legislature is not in regular session, is the second most powerful position. The President Pro Tempore is usually the most senior member of the Senate and is reserved to any political party in the chamber regardless of whether it is a majority or minority.

The current Lieutenant Governor of Texas is Dan Patrick, and the President Pro Tempore is Republican Kel Seliger of District 31 (Amarillo). The name of Bangalore City railway station is Krantivira Sangolli Rayanna railway station, officially known as Bangalore City railway station (SBC). It is the main railway station serving the city of Bengaluru, Karnataka, India, and is the second busiest railway station in South India after Chennai Central in Chennai. The station has 10 platforms and two entrances, with platforms 1 to 7 connecting to the Chennai and Salem railway lines, and platforms 8 to 10 serving trains arriving from Hubballi-Dharwad via Yeshwantpur. Platforms 1 to 4 terminate at Bangalore, while platforms 5 to 10 depart towards Mysuru. There are five railway lines passing through the station, including lines to Hyderabad via Guntakal, Chennai via Krishnarajapuram, Salem via Hosur, Mysuru, and Hubballi-Dharwad via Tumkur and Birur. The Bangalore-Chennai railway line via Bangalore Cantonment and Bangarpet is fully electrified and open for traffic, while the Bangalore-Mysore line is also doubled and electrified. The station is conveniently connected to the rest of the city through the KSR City Railway Station metro station on the Namma Metro's Purple Line, which opened on 30 April 2016.

However, the White Queen's influence can be seen in Alice's dream, as she is portrayed as one of Alice's white cats. This interpretation highlights the blurred lines between reality and fantasy in the story.

In various film and TV adaptations, the White Queen has been portrayed by actresses such as Carol Channing, Penelope Wilton, and Brenda Bruce. In the 2010 adaptation by Tim Burton, the White Queen is renamed "Mirana of Marmoreal" and is portrayed by Anne Hathaway. Burton's interpretation of the character is notable for her delicate exterior and darker undertones, as revealed through her black fingernail polish and the dark circles under her eyes. Her nonchalance about certain potion ingredients also suggests a more complex character beneath the surface.

The White Queen's soldiers, inspired by chess pieces, and the Red Queen's soldiers, made to resemble cards, further emphasize the game-like nature of the story and the themes of power and control. The White Queen's role as a symbol of victory and the Red Queen's role as a symbol of tyranny are reinforced through their respective armies and their interactions with Alice.

Overall, the White Queen is a multifaceted character who adds depth and complexity to the story of "Through the Looking-Glass." Her enigmatic presence and the various interpretations of her character in film and TV adaptations only serve to further highlight the timeless appeal of Lewis Carroll's beloved tale.

a: The downfall of the Inca Empire can be attributed to a combination of factors, including the devastating effects of diseases such as smallpox and typhus, the Spanish conquest and colonization, and the exploitation of the indigenous population through forced labor and the mita system. The Inca Empire was already weakened by internal conflicts and the loss of its leader, Atahualpa, when the Spanish arrived in 1532. The Spanish conquest was brutal and ruthless, with the Spanish killing many Incas and destroying their culture and traditions. The Spanish also brought with them diseases such as smallpox, which spread rapidly throughout the empire and decimated the population.

One of the most significant factors in the downfall of the Inca Empire was the smallpox epidemic of 1546, which killed an estimated 30% of the population. This left the empire weakened and vulnerable to further attacks from the Spanish and other diseases. The Spanish also brought measles, influenza, and diphtheria to the empire, which further devastated the population. The loss of so many people, particularly the leaders and elites of the empire, made it difficult for the Inca to resist the Spanish conquest.

The Spanish colonization also had a significant impact on the Inca Empire. The Spanish imposed their own language, religion, and customs on the indigenous population, leading to the suppression of Inca traditions and culture. The Spanish also established the mita system, which required indigenous people to work in gold and silver mines, often under harsh conditions. This exploitation of the indigenous population further weakened the empire and led to resentment and resistance among the people.

In addition to these factors, the Inca Empire was also affected by internal conflicts and power struggles. After the death of Atahualpa, his brother, Huascar, claimed the throne, leading to a civil war that weakened the empire. The Spanish took advantage of these internal conflicts to further their own goals and expand their empire.

Overall, the downfall of the Inca Empire was the result of a combination of factors, including the devastating effects of diseases, the Spanish conquest and colonization, and the exploitation of the indigenous population. These factors, combined with internal conflicts and power struggles, ultimately led to the downfall of one of the most powerful empires in pre-Columbian America.
r1: During the time of the largest empire in pre-Columbian America (Inca), diseases (primarily the smallpox epidemic) and the invasion of the Spanish conquistadors all contributed to the downfall of the empire.
r2: The downfall of the Incan Empire can be linked to both disease and Spanish conquistadors. The first epidemic was smallpox, followed by other diseases including a probable Typhus outbreak, influenza, diphtheria and measles all of which ravaged the Inca people. Likewise, the long-term effects of the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors on the population of South America were catastrophic. The Incan population suffered an exceptionally dramatic and rapid decline following contact with the Spanish.

a: The Seljuk Empire began in the early 11th century and lasted until the mid-12th century, spanning approximately 60 years. The empire was founded by Tughril, an Oghuz Turk leader, who became the first Sultan of the Seljuk Empire in 1037. Tughril died in 1063, and his death led to a succession crisis, as his nephew Qutalmish challenged the claim of his cousin, Tughril's chosen successor, Suleyman. This conflict culminated in the Battle of Damghan in 1063, which marked the beginning of the Seljuk Civil War. The war lasted for several years and ended with the victory of Malik Shah I, another cousin of Tughril, who became the new Sultan of the Seljuk Empire. The Seljuk Empire reached its peak during the reign of Malik Shah I, who expanded the empire's territories and established a strong centralized government. However, the empire began to decline after Malik Shah I's death in 1092, and it eventually collapsed in the early 12th century, divided into smaller territories ruled by local governors.
r1: The Seljuk Empire was founded in 1037 and began to decline in the 1140s, and by 1194 had been supplanted by the Khwarezmian Empire.
r2: The Seljuk Empire began in 1037 and ended in 1194. It was founded in 1037 by Tughril and his brother Chaghri. It began to decline in the 1140s and by 1194 had been supplanted by the Khwarazmian Empire.
