Ray Charles' version, from his 1993 album "My World," is a soulful and bluesy interpretation, with Charles' gravelly vocals and a stirring piano accompaniment. Karen Carpenter's posthumous version, included on her self-titled solo album in 1996, is a heartfelt and emotive rendition, with Carpenter's soaring vocals and a simple but effective piano accompaniment. Willie Nelson's version, featured on the soundtrack of the 2000 motion picture "Space Cowboys," is a country-tinged take on the song, with Nelson's distinctive twang and a laid-back instrumental arrangement.

Despite these varied interpretations, the core of the song remains intact, with its themes of love, loss, and the passage of time resonating with listeners across generations and musical genres. The fact that Paul Simon's original version of "Still Crazy After All These Years" won two Grammy Awards in 1976, including Album of the Year and Best Male Pop Vocal Performance, is a testament to the enduring power of the song and Simon's skill as a songwriter and performer. Overall, the many covers of "Still Crazy After All These Years" are a testament to the timeless appeal of Paul Simon's music and the enduring influence of his songwriting on generations of musicians and listeners.
r1: The 1975 song Still Crazy After All These Years is the fourth solo studio album by Paul Simon. Since 1975, the title track has been recorded by Rosemary Clooney (on her 1993 album "Still on the Road"), Ray Charles (on his 1993 album "My World"), Karen Carpenter (on her self-titled solo album released posthumously in 1996), and Willie Nelson (on the soundtrack of the 2000 motion picture "Space Cowboys").

0.20253164149575398
a: The United States abandoned the gold standard in 1971, marking a significant shift away from the commodity-based currency system and towards fiat money. This move was prompted by the increasing costs of the Vietnam War and the declining gold reserves of the United States, which made it difficult to maintain the promise of redeeming dollars in gold. The Bretton Woods agreement, which fixed the value of the US dollar to gold at $35 per ounce, was no longer sustainable, and the Nixon Shock of 1971, which included the unilateral cancellation of the direct convertibility of the US dollar to gold, effectively ended the gold standard. This move away from the gold standard was met with opposition from the United States Greenback Party, which termed it as "fiat money" in an 1878 party convention. The shift towards fiat money allowed governments to print more money without the constraint of gold reserves, leading to a period of hyperinflation in some countries, such as the Weimar Republic. Since then, the US dollar has been a fiat currency, with its value determined by supply and demand on foreign exchange markets rather than by any commodity standard.
r1: On June 5, 1933, the US discontinued the gold standard, but still allowed foreign governments to trade gold for dollars. In 1971, the US unilaterally terminated convertibility of the US dollar to gold foreign central banks thus completely severing any links to the gold standard.
r2: The dates the US went off the gold standard and completely severed links to it differ. Upon taking office in March 1933, US President Franklin D. Roosevelt departed from the gold standard. The US went off the gold standard on June 5, 1933, but still allowed foreign governments to trade gold for dollars. It wasn't until 1971 that the US completely severed any link to the gold standard.

0.27884615068093566
a: As blues music migrated into Chicago's South Side, it underwent a significant transformation and evolved into a distinct style known as Chicago blues. This new style was characterized by an electric blues sound that was heavily influenced by the urban environment of Chicago and the experiences of African American musicians who had migrated from the South. Unlike traditional country blues, which often focused on themes such as rural life and hardship, Chicago blues tackled the challenges and struggles of city living, such as poverty, racism, and the struggles of industrial work.

The development of Chicago blues was heavily influenced by Mississippi bluesmen who traveled to Chicago in the early 1940s, bringing with them their unique styles and techniques. These musicians, such as Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, and Willie Dixon, were able to adapt their sound to the urban environment of Chicago, incorporating elements of jazz, swing, and soul music to create a distinctively urban blues sound.

The commercial success of Chicago blues was driven by the promotion of record companies such as Paramount Records, RCA Victor, and Columbia Records, which helped to bring the music to a wider audience. The new style of music eventually reached Europe and the United Kingdom, where it had a profound influence on the development of rock and roll and other popular music genres.

Chicago blues was characterized by its use of electric instruments, such as electric guitars and amplifiers, which gave the music a louder and more energetic sound than traditional acoustic blues. The music also featured a strong emphasis on vocal performance and storytelling, with lyrics that often spoke to the experiences and struggles of urban life.

The legacy of Chicago blues can be heard in the work of many well-known musicians, including Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, Willie Dixon, and Koko Taylor. These musicians, along with many others, helped to shape the sound of Chicago blues and bring it to a wider audience. Today, the music continues to be celebrated and performed by blues musicians around the world, and its influence can be heard in a wide range of popular music genres.
r1: As blues moved into Chicago's south side, an electric blues style of urban blues known as Chicago blues was developed. The promotion of record companies such as Paramount Records, RCA Victor, and Columbia Records drove blues to the international stage and influenced young British musicians, resulting in the British blues movement.
r2: Chicago blues is a form of blues music developed in Chicago, Illinois. It is based on earlier blues idioms, such as Delta blues, but performed in an urban style. The first blues clubs in Chicago were mostly in predominantly black neighborhoods on the South Side, with a few in the smaller black neighborhoods on the West Side. As the new style of music eventually reached Europe and the United Kingdom, young British musicians were highly influenced by Chicago blues, resulting in the British blues movement.

0.28358208491312104
a: The movement of food in the food pipe is called peristalsis. Peristalsis is a wave-like muscular contraction that occurs in the esophagus, which helps to push food down the throat and into the stomach. This process is triggered by the sensation of food in the mouth and in the esophagus itself, and is facilitated by the relaxation of the upper esophageal sphincter and the contraction of the lower esophageal sphincter. The movement of food through the esophagus is also aided by the intrinsic muscles of the tongue, which form a trough at the back of the tongue to contain the food and help it move downwards towards the throat. Additionally, the epiglottis moves backward to cover the larynx, preventing food from entering the trachea, and gastric acid is produced in the stomach to enable food digestion. Overall, the movement of food through the food pipe is a complex process that involves the coordinated action of multiple muscles and nerves to ensure that food is properly digested and absorbed by the body.
r1: Swallowing is the mechanical action that moves food into the esophagus. The autonomic function that moves food from the esophagus to the stomach is known as peristalsis.
r2: The mechanical action that moves food into the esophagus is called swallowing. Swallowing is an important part of eating and drinking. The autonomic function that moves food from the esophagus to the stomach is called peristalsis. In much of a digestive tract such as the human gastrointestinal tract, smooth muscle tissue contracts in sequence to produce a peristaltic wave, which propels a ball of food along the tract.

0.3218390761362135
a: The development of the Gram stain, a widely used method for identifying and classifying bacteria, is attributed to Hans Christian Gram, a Danish bacteriologist who developed the technique in 1884 while working with Carl Friedländer in the morgue of the city hospital in Berlin. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on the physical properties of their cell walls, specifically the presence or absence of peptidoglycan, a substance found in the cell walls of Gram-positive bacteria. Gram-negative bacteria, on the other hand, have a very small layer of peptidoglycan that is dissolved by alcohol, resulting in a different staining pattern. The Gram stain is a valuable diagnostic tool in both clinical and research settings, but it is not infallible and cannot identify bacteria to the species level. Additionally, the Ziehl-Neelsen stain, also known as the acid-fast stain, is used to identify acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is responsible for tuberculosis. This stain is particularly useful for identifying Mycobacterium species that are resistant to the Gram stain. Overall, the development of the Gram stain and the Ziehl-Neelsen stain has significantly advanced our ability to identify and classify bacteria, allowing for more accurate diagnosis and treatment of bacterial infections.
r1: In 1884, Danish bacteriologist Hans Christian Gram developed a useful staining method to identify bacteria in two large groups (a technique known as Gram staining). Another kind of staining known as Ziehl–Neelsen staining is a type of Acid-fast stain was first introduced by German physician and scientist Paul Ehrlich but named after the two German doctors who modified the stain: the bacteriologist Franz Ziehl (1859–1926) and the pathologist Friedrich Neelsen (1854–1898).
r2: Gram stain or Gram staining, also called Gram's method, is a method of staining used to distinguish and classify bacterial species into two large groups, Gram-positive and Gram-negative. The name comes from the Danish bacteriologist Hans Christian Gram, who developed the technique. Ziehl-Neelsen staining is a type of Acid-fast stain, first introduced by Paul Ehrlich. Ziehl–Neelsen staining is a bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria.
=============================95=============================
0.2577319552556064
a: The solid part of the Earth is called the mantle, which is the layer beneath the crust that extends from a depth of about 35 kilometers (22 miles) to a depth of 2,900 kilometers (1,800 miles). The mantle is composed of silicate rocks that are rich in iron and magnesium, and it is divided into two sections: the upper mantle and the lower mantle. The upper mantle is composed of rock that is hot but still solid, while the lower mantle is made up of rock that is molten, or melted. The boundary between the two layers is known as the mantle-core boundary, and it is located at a depth of about 410 kilometers (255 miles).

The mantle is under such intense pressure that it is unable to flow easily, but it does exhibit ductile deformation, meaning that it can be stretched and deformed without breaking. This property allows the mantle to flow over long timescales, driving the process of plate tectonics. The mantle is heated by the primordial heat left over from the planet's formation, as well as by the radioactive decay of uranium, thorium, and potassium in the Earth's crust and mantle.

The inner core of the Earth is a solid, iron-nickel alloy that is located at the center of the planet. It is estimated to be about 1,220 kilometers (760 miles) in radius and is surrounded by the liquid outer core, which is made up of a mixture of molten iron and nickel. The inner core is believed to be composed primarily of iron and nickel, and it is under such intense pressure that it is unable to melt, even at the extremely high temperatures found within the Earth's core. The inner core was discovered in 1936 by Inge Lehmann, and its existence was confirmed by seismic measurements.

Overall, the solid part of the Earth is the mantle, which is composed of hot, ductile rock that flows over long timescales and drives the process of plate tectonics. The inner core is a solid, iron-nickel alloy that is located at the center of the planet and is surrounded by the liquid outer core.
r1: With a radius of ≈1,220 km, the inner core is the solid inner part of the earth. The outer part of earth can be divided into the oceanic and continental lithospheres. This area includes the crust and the uppermost mantle, which constitutes the hard and rigid outer layer of the Earth. The Earth's mantle extends to a depth of 2,890 km, making it the thickest layer of Earth.
r2: There are several solid parts of the Earth. The solid inner part of the Earth is called the inner core, one of two parts of the core. The solid outer part is called the lithosphere, which includes the crust and the uppermost mantle. The solid part of the Earth that was once liquid is called the mantle.

0.25108224689267444
a: The authorship of the first five books of the Torah, also known as the Pentateuch, is a complex and debated topic among biblical scholars. According to rabbinic tradition, these books were written by Moses, who received the teachings directly from God at Mount Sinai and at the Tabernacle. However, the majority of biblical scholars believe that the written books were a product of the Babylonian captivity, based on earlier written and oral traditions that could only have arisen from separate communities within ancient Israel.

The documentary hypothesis, proposed by Julius Wellhausen, suggests that the Pentateuch was composed from four main sources: the Yahwist source, the Elohist source, the Deuteronomist source, and the Priestly source. These sources were combined and edited by a final redactor to create the final form of the Pentateuch.

The Yahwist source is believed to have been written in the 9th or 8th century BCE and is characterized by the use of the name Yahweh (Jehovah) for God. The Elohist source is thought to have been written in the 8th or 7th century BCE and uses the name Elohim (God) for God. The Deuteronomist source is dated to the 7th century BCE and is characterized by its emphasis on the importance of obedience to the law. Finally, the Priestly source is believed to have been written in the 5th or 4th century BCE and is characterized by its focus on ritual and priestly practices.

Despite the debated authorship of the Pentateuch, the Torah remains a central text of Judaism and is considered to be the foundation of Jewish law and tradition. The Torah is written in Hebrew and is read publicly at least once every three days in the presence of a congregation. The meaning of the word "Torah" is "teaching", "doctrine", or "instruction", and it is believed to have been created prior to the creation of the world and used as the blueprint for Creation.

In conclusion, the authorship of the first five books of the Torah is a complex and debated topic among biblical scholars. While rabbinic tradition attributes the authorship to Moses, the majority of scholars believe that the written books were a product of the Babylonian captivity and were composed from multiple sources. Regardless of the authorship, the Torah remains a central text of Judaism and is considered to be the foundation of Jewish law and tradition.
r1: The first five books of Moses in the Hebrew Bible (commonly known as the Written Torah) are believed to have have been written by the prophet Moses. By contrast, the modern scholarly consensus rejects Mosaic authorship and affirms that the Torah has multiple authors, the number of authors involved and the date of each author remain hotly contested, however. In the 1700s, JEDP became considered to be the author of the first five books of Moses. However, the unnamed author is listed as the authors of the first five books of Moses. Later on, German biblical scholar Julius Wellhausen believed that Ezra the Priest is a redactor of the first five books of Moses.
r2: Torah has a range of meanings, and it can most specifically mean the first five books, the Pentateuch or five books of Moses, of the 24 books of the Hebrew Bible. The Talmud holds that the Torah was written by Moses, with the exception of the last eight verses of Deuteronomy, describing his death and burial, being written by Joshua. According to Jewish tradition, the Torah was recompiled by Ezra during Second Temple period, and Wellhausen believed that Ezra was a redactor of the first five books of Moses. In the 1700s, JEDP was considered the author of the first five books of Moses. An unnamed author is listed as the author of the first five books of Moses.

0.2735042692771569
a: The Union victory at the Battle of Philippi in West Virginia on June 3, 1861, marked the first organized land action of the American Civil War and was a significant turning point in the conflict. The battle was fought between Union forces led by Major General George B. McClellan and Confederate forces under the command of Colonel George A. Porterfield. Despite being outnumbered, the Union troops were better trained and equipped, and they utilized a clever strategy to deceive the Confederates into thinking they were heading towards Harpers Ferry, instead of Philippi. This misdirection allowed the Union forces to attack the Confederates from the rear, catching them off guard and causing them to flee with little resistance.

The battle was notable for several reasons. Firstly, it was the first time that Union troops had engaged in a significant battle on Southern soil, and it marked the beginning of a wider campaign to control the western counties of Virginia, which eventually led to the formation of the state of West Virginia. Additionally, the battle was the first to result in battlefield amputations, and it brought overnight fame to McClellan, who was hailed as a hero by the Northern press.

The Union victory at Philippi also had significant consequences for the Confederacy. The defeat forced the western counties of Virginia to consider their allegiance to the Confederate cause, and many began to question whether they should remain part of the secessionist state. This led to the formation of a new Union state government in West Virginia, which further weakened the Confederacy and strengthened the Union's position in the war.

In conclusion, the Battle of Philippi was a significant turning point in the American Civil War. It marked the first organized land action of the conflict, resulted in a Union victory, and had far-reaching consequences for the Confederacy. The battle demonstrated the strategic genius of McClellan and the bravery of the Union troops, and it set the stage for future battles and campaigns in the war.
r1: The 1861 Battle of Philippi during the American Civil War was fought in and around present day West Virginia. The Union victory brought overnight fame to Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan who was accompanied by Thomas A. Morris and Isaac Duval. The units that won this battle were the 1st West Virginia Infantry, 2nd West Virginia Infantry (reserve), 6th, 7th and 9th Indiana Infantries as well as the 14th Ohio Infantry.
r2: The Battle of Philippi formed part of the Western Virginia Campaign of the American Civil War and was fought in and around Philippi, Virginia (now West Virginia), on June 3, 1861. A Union victory, it was the first organized land action of the war and it brought overnight fame to Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan. Alongside Maj. Gen. McClellan were Thomas A. Morris, a Brigadier General of the Indiana Militia and Isaac Duval, also a Brigadier General. Six Union infantries participated in the battle, including 1st West Virginia Infantry, 2nd West Virginia Infantry (reserve), 6th Indiana Infantry, 7th Indiana Infantry, 9th Indiana Infantry and the 14th Ohio Infantry.

a: In the United States, the timing of spring break varies depending on the institution and the state. At the college and university level, spring break typically occurs from March to April, with the exact dates determined by the institution's academic calendar and the timing of the Easter holiday. In general, spring break is around one week long, but some institutions may have a longer break of up to two weeks. At the K-12 level, spring break is often referred to as "Easter Break," "Easter Holidays," or "Easter Vacation" and is typically two weeks long, falling before or after Easter. However, in the states of Massachusetts and Maine, schools schedule spring break for the week of the third Monday in April to coincide with Patriots' Day. In contrast, in Guatemala and Honduras, spring break takes place during Easter, with students receiving a full week off while the staff workforce rests for approximately three days. In Colombia, spring break falls in the first week of April, during the Holy Week until the second week. Overall, the timing of spring break in the US and other countries varies depending on local traditions and academic calendars.
r1: In the United States, spring break for K–12 institutions, universities and colleges can occur between March to April, depending on term dates and when Easter holiday falls. It is usually about one week long and takes place in the weeks before or after Easter. However, in the states of Massachusetts and Maine, schools typically schedule spring break for the week of the third Monday in April to coincide with Patriots' Day.

0.28571428150163775
a: The ancient Chinese civilization began in approximately 1600 BC during the Shang dynasty, which is the earliest known written record of Chinese history. The Shang ruled in the Yellow River valley, which is considered the cradle of Chinese civilization. However, Neolithic civilizations originated at various cultural centers along both the Yellow River and Yangtze River, which existed millennia before the Shang. The Zhou dynasty, which introduced the concept of the Mandate of Heaven, replaced the Shang and began to weaken in the 8th century BC, leading to a period of instability and the eventual splintering of the country into smaller states. During this time, prominent philosophers such as Confucius emerged and offered their ideas on how a state should be run. The seven large and powerful states of the Warring States period were eventually conquered by the state of Qin in 221 BC, which established the Qin dynasty and unified the core of the Han Chinese homeland for the first time. The Qin dynasty quickly collapsed after the death of its leader, Ying Zheng, and was replaced by the Han dynasty in 206 BC, marking the beginning of a golden age of Chinese culture, economy, and military power. The capital of the Han dynasty was initially at Chang'an, but it was later moved to Luoyang in 25 AD in response to a coup.
r1: Ancient chinese civilization began in 2070 BC and ended in 221 BC at the time of the Xia dynasty. The end of this ancient civilization is also referred to as the Warring States period.
r2: China is one of the world's oldest civilizations. The ancient Chinese civilization began in 2070 BC with the Xia dynasty of China, the first dynasty to be described in ancient historical records. By the end of the 5th century, seven prominent states remained and these few states battled each other during the Warring States period. In 221 BC, Qin Shi Huang conquered the various warring states, marking the beginning of imperial China and the end of the ancient Chinese civilization.

a: During his reign in the 13th century, King John made significant modifications to Kenilworth Castle, which is located in the English county of Warwickshire. To protect the castle from potential flooding and provide a water defense system, John dammed the Finham Brook and its tributary, the Canley Brook, creating a lake in the process. This effort was part of a larger plan to fortify the castle and its surroundings, as Kenilworth was an important strategic location during John's reign. The castle's proximity to the brooks and the lake created a natural barrier against potential invaders, and the damming of the brooks allowed for the creation of a water defense system that could be used to flood the surrounding area if necessary. Additionally, the construction of the dam and the lake also provided a source of water for the castle and its inhabitants.

King John's efforts to fortify Kenilworth Castle were not limited to the damming of the brooks. He also built a tiltyard, which was a large open space used for jousting and other martial activities, and a great hall, which was a grand residence for the king and his guests. These additions, along with the damming of the brooks, helped to transform Kenilworth Castle into a formidable stronghold that could withstand potential attacks and provide a secure base of operations for the king.

It is worth noting that King John's reign was marked by a number of significant events and conflicts, including the loss of the Duchy of Normandy and most of his other French lands to King Philip II of France, which contributed to the collapse of the Angevin Empire and the growth of the French Capetian dynasty. Additionally, John's reign was marked by a baronial revolt at the end of his reign, which led to the sealing of the Magna Carta, a document that is sometimes considered an early step in the evolution of the constitution of the United Kingdom. Despite these challenges, however, King John's modifications to Kenilworth Castle demonstrate his commitment to strengthening his defenses and solidifying his power in the region.

0.1825726114515935
a: The song "In the Ghetto" has a rich history, with two different versions recorded by notable artists Elvis Presley and Busta Rhymes. The original version was written by Mac Davis and made famous by Elvis Presley in 1969. The song tells the story of generational poverty and violence in the ghetto, with a narrative that follows a boy born to a mother who already has more children than she can feed. The boy grows up hungry, steals and fights, purchases a gun, and ultimately meets a tragic end just as his own child is born. The song's structure, with its simple and stark phrasing, repetition of the phrase "in the ghetto," and the repetition of the first verse's "and his mama cries" create a feeling of an inescapable cycle of poverty and violence.

On the other hand, Busta Rhymes recorded a remix of the song in 2006, featuring R&B singer Rick James. The remix, produced by DJ Green Lantern and Dr. Dre, samples James' "Ghetto Life" from his "Street Songs" album. The video for the song features cameos from several notable artists, including Snoop Dogg, MC Eiht, Warren G, and Ludacris. The remix adds a new verse by Busta Rhymes and Ludacris, and was released in Ludacris' mixtape, "Pre-Release Therapy".

Interestingly, both versions of the song were recorded by artists who were at different points in their careers. Elvis Presley's version was recorded during his comeback session in 1969, after a period of declining popularity, while Busta Rhymes' version was recorded during the peak of his career. Despite the differences in style and era, both versions of "In the Ghetto" share a common message about the cycle of poverty and violence in the inner city, and the impact it has on the lives of those living there.

Overall, "In the Ghetto" is a powerful and thought-provoking song that has been interpreted in different ways by two distinct artists. While Elvis Presley's version is a classic of the rock and roll genre, Busta Rhymes' remix brings a new perspective to the song with its modern production and featuring of Rick James. Both versions are significant in their own right, and offer a glimpse into the struggles and challenges faced by those living in the inner city.
r1: The 1969 song "In the Ghetto" (originally titled "The Vicious Circle") was recorded by American singer and actor Elvis Presley and written by Mac Davis. Another song by the same title from American rapper and record producer Busta Rhymes' "The Big Bang" album was written by R&B singer Rick James.
r2: Elvis and Busta Rhymes each released a unique song called In The Ghetto. Elvis' 1969 song was written by Mac Davis while Busta Rhymes' 2006 song was written by Rick James.

a: The title of Lorraine Hansberry's play, "A Raisin in the Sun," is inspired by the poem "Harlem" by Langston Hughes, which asks the question "What happens to a dream deferred? Does it dry up like a raisin in the sun?" The poem speaks to the idea that when dreams are put on hold or denied, they can wither away and lose their potential for growth and fulfillment. This theme is central to the play, as the Younger family, the main characters, are struggling to achieve their dreams in the face of poverty, racism, and societal expectations.

The play is set in the Washington Park Subdivision of Chicago's Woodlawn neighborhood, where the Younger family lives in a dilapidated two-bedroom apartment. The family is struggling to make ends meet, and the father, Walter, has a plan to invest in a liquor store in partnership with two street-smart acquaintances. The mother, Ruth, is content with their lot, but Walter is driven by a sense of entitlement and a desire for wealth. The play explores the tensions between Walter's dreams and the realities of their lives, as well as the impact of racism and sexism on the family's experiences.

The title of the play is a metaphor for the dreams of the characters, which are constantly being deferred and put on hold. Just as a raisin in the sun would dry up and lose its flavor, the characters' dreams are in danger of withering away under the weight of their circumstances. The play highlights the importance of pursuing one's dreams and aspirations, even in the face of adversity, and the need to challenge societal norms and expectations in order to achieve true fulfillment.

The fact that the play is set in Chicago and explores the experiences of a black family living under racial segregation is also significant. The play is a powerful commentary on the injustices of racism and the ways in which it affects the lives of black Americans. The title of the play, taken from Langston Hughes' poem, adds a deeper layer of meaning and context to the story, highlighting the importance of dreams and the need to pursue them in order to achieve true happiness and fulfillment.
r1: A Raisin in the Sun is a 1959 play by playwright Lorraine Hansberry. The title of the play was inspired by the poem called "Harlem" (also known as "A Dream Deferred") by American poet Langston Hughes. The story tells of a black family's experiences in south Chicago, as they attempt to improve their financial circumstances with an insurance payout following the death of their father.
r2: A Raisin in the Sun is a play that debuted on Broadway in 1959. The title was inspired by a poem called Harlem, also known as A Dream Deferred, which was written by Langston Hughes. The poem is about a Black family in south Chicago that attempts to improve their financial circumstances.

* Orange Bowl: Miami Hurricanes vs. Wisconsin Badgers
* Cotton Bowl: Notre Dame Fighting Irish vs. Clemson Tigers (this game was played on December 29, 2017, but is still considered a New Year's Six game)
* Peach Bowl: Auburn Tigers vs. Central Florida Knights
* Fiesta Bowl: Penn State Nittany Lions vs. Washington Huskies

These games are played annually on or around New Year's Day, and represent six of the ten oldest bowl games currently played at the FBS level. a: Sure! Here is a comprehensive, well-structured answer to the question "How long is a Rainbow Six Siege game?" that integrates the given factoid context:

A Rainbow Six Siege game typically lasts for four minutes in casual matches and three minutes in ranked matches. This time frame includes a one-minute preparatory period where attackers and defenders choose their spawn points and set up their defenses, followed by a four-minute (or three-minute in ranked) round where players engage in intense, close-quarters combat. During the round, players can use operators, gadgets, and weapons to outmaneuver and eliminate the opposing team. If a player is killed, they can enter "Support Mode" and use drones to scout the map and provide information to their teammates. The match ends when one team achieves the objective or all players on one team are eliminated. The length of each round and the number of rounds played per match can vary depending on the game mode and the skill level of the players. Overall, a typical Rainbow Six Siege game can last anywhere from 20 to 40 minutes, with longer matches typically occurring in ranked play.

r2: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is an online tactical shooter video game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. In online matches, when a round begins the attackers choose one of several spawn points from which to launch their attack while defenders do the same from which to defend from. A one-minute preparatory period will then commence wherein the attackers are then given control over mecanum-wheeled drones to scout the map in search of enemy operators, traps and defensive set-ups in addition to the target objective(s), while the opposition establishes their defences and tries to do so without having the defensive and target objective(s) details being discovered, chiefly through destroying the drones. Matches last only four minutes for a casual match and three minutes for a ranked match.

a: The Rogers Cup, one of the most prestigious tennis tournaments in the world, is held annually in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. Prior to 1968, the tournament was known as the Canadian National Championships and was a major event of the Grand Prix Tennis Tour. Since 1997, the tournament has been sponsored by Rogers Communications, a Canadian communications and media company. The event was previously sponsored by tobacco brands, including Rothmans International and Player's Limited, but federal legislation banning tobacco advertising led to the change in sponsorship. The tournament is held on hard courts at the IGA Stadium, which was built in 1996 and can accommodate 8,000 spectators. The stadium was previously known as Stade Du Maurier and Uniprix Stadium before being renamed in 2018. The Canadian Open is unique in that it is held in two cities, Montreal and Toronto, with the men and women alternating venues each year. The tournament is part of the US Open Series of events leading into the Grand Slam event and features some of the top tennis players in the world. The IGA Stadium is equipped with DecoTurf cushioned acrylic surfaces, the same surface used at the US Open Grand Slam event.
r1: The 1981 Rogers Cup men's tournament was for the first time played at the Jarry Park Stadium in Montreal. The 1996 Rogers Cup was held at the Stade IGA (formerly Stade Du Maurier and Stade Uniprix) stadium, also in Montreal, Quebec.
r2: The Canadian Open, also known as the Canada Masters, and currently branded as the National Bank Open, is an annual tennis tournament held in Canada. Both the men's and women's tournaments were played as a single combined tournament at the National Tennis Centre in Toronto until 1981, when the men's tournament was played at the Jarry Park Stadium in Montreal for the first time. Built in 1996, Stade IGA (formerly Stade Du Maurier and Stade Uniprix) is the main tennis court at the Canadian Open tournament in Montreal, Quebec. In 2005, Rogers Communications became the title sponsor for the men's tournament as it was already the sponsor for the women's event, so both events became known as the Rogers Cup.

a: The film "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" was primarily filmed in Sylva, North Carolina, with additional locations in Black Mountain, North Carolina and Douglas Lake, Tennessee. The iconic billboards that serve as the film's central focus were built by Allison Outdoor Advertising of Sylva and were placed in a pasture near Black Mountain. However, due to the controversial nature of the billboards' message, they were often covered up by locals who found them upsetting. The film's production team had to use a different location for the billboards, and they were eventually dismantled and used for another purpose.

The film's lead actress, Frances McDormand, initially felt that her character Mildred was too young as written and suggested that she be revised as Angela's grandmother. However, the film's writer and director Martin McDonagh disagreed, feeling that it would change the story too much. McDormand's husband Joel Coen ultimately persuaded her to take the role, and she drew inspiration for her character from John Wayne. Sam Rockwell, who plays the role of Jason Dixon, took inspiration for his character from Lee Marvin, who starred alongside Wayne in "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance".

Principal photography began on May 2, 2016, and ran for 33 days, with most of the filming taking place in Sylva and Black Mountain. The Town Pump Tavern in Black Mountain was used as a set and was closed for three days during filming, during which time a pool table and booths were added to the location. The bar's actual sign also appeared in the film.

Overall, the film's unique and thought-provoking story, combined with the strong performances from its cast, have made "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" a critical and commercial success. The film's use of distinctive locations and set design helps to bring the story to life and add depth to the characters and their relationships.

r2: The 2017 film Three Billboards Outside of Ebbing, Missouri, was principally filmed in Sylva, North Carolina, while it was filmed in Black Mountain, North Carolina, for the billboard scenes. Sylva is an incorporated town located in central Jackson County in Western North Carolina's Plott Balsam Mountains, USA. Black Mountain is a town in Buncombe County, North Carolina, in the US.

a: Who played Cowboy Curtis on Pee-wee's Playhouse?

The character of Cowboy Curtis was a recurring figure on the program, often appearing in sketches and interacting with other characters like Pee-wee Herman and Miss Yvonne.

The show's creator, Paul Reubens, sought to create a morally educational show that would teach children the ethics of reciprocity. Reubens believed that children liked the show because it was fast-paced, colorful, and never talked down to them, while parents appreciated the show's nostalgic value and the positive role model that Pee-wee Herman represented.

Pee-wee's Playhouse ran from 1986 to 1990 on Saturday mornings on CBS, and it continues to be a cult classic to this day. The show's success can be attributed to its unique blend of humor, education, and artistry, as well as its memorable characters like Cowboy Curtis, who added depth and variety to the program.

a: In association football, a player can be substituted during a match for a variety of reasons, including fatigue, injury, poor performance, or tactical reasons. The substitute enters the field of play during a stoppage in play and must be granted permission by the referee before doing so. The player being substituted must leave the field of play before the substitute can enter, and the substitute can only enter the field at the halfway line. The team is limited to making a maximum of three substitutions during a normal match, with a fourth substitution allowed in extra time.

The rules regarding substitutions have evolved over time, with the Premier League increasing the number of players on the bench to five in 1996 and allowing seven players on the bench for the 2008-09 season. The Laws of the Game specify that a player who has been substituted may take no further part in the match, and unused substitutes and players who have been substituted remain under the authority of the referee and can be cautioned or punished for misconduct.

The use of substitutes is an important tactical tool for teams, allowing them to bring on fresh players to change the pace of the game or address specific weaknesses in their lineup. However, the substitution rule also provides a mechanism for teams to replace injured or tired players, which can help to prevent injuries and ensure the safety of the players.

In recent years, the use of substitutes has become more common in international tournaments, with the 2016 Summer Olympic Games, the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup, and the 2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup final all allowing a fourth substitution in extra time. The 2018 FIFA World Cup, the UEFA Champions League, and the UEFA Europa League have also approved the use of a fourth substitute in extra time in elimination rounds.

Overall, the substitution rule in association football provides teams with the flexibility to adjust their lineup during a match, while also ensuring the safety and well-being of the players. By allowing teams to bring on fresh players and replace injured or tired players, the rule helps to promote fair play and enhance the overall quality of the game.
r1: In most soccer matches, three substitutions can be made during the game (regulation) and a fourth substitution can be made during extra time. Substitutions are made during a stoppage in play and with the permission of the referee.
r2: In soccer, most games only allow each team to make a maximum of three substitutions during a game and a fourth substitute during extra time, although the rules are more relaxed during less official games. A player can only be substituted during a stoppage in play and with the permission of the referee. If a player was given a red card during the match and is forced to leave the field, the team cannot make a substitution for that player and must work the remaining players on the field.

The term "kettledrums" is also commonly used to refer to the timpani, and is often preferred by English speakers, particularly in informal contexts. The use of the term "timpani" is more formal and is widely adopted in the English language, but it is worth noting that some English speakers may use the term "kettledrums" interchangeably with "timpani." The word "timpani" is derived from the Latin "tympanum," meaning "hand drum," and has been in use in English since the late 19th century.

a: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill, one of the largest environmental disasters in history, has cost BP a staggering $54 billion in clean-up, environmental, and economic damages, and penalties. In November 2012, BP pleaded guilty to 11 counts of manslaughter, two misdemeanors, and a felony count of lying to Congress, and agreed to a record-setting $4.525 billion in fines and other payments. Additionally, the company was temporarily banned from new contracts with the US government. The total cost of the spill, including criminal and civil settlements and payments to a trust fund, reached $42.2 billion.

The ruling in September 2014 by a US District Court judge found that BP was primarily responsible for the oil spill due to its gross negligence and reckless conduct. The judge stated that BP employees took risks that led to the largest environmental disaster in US history and that the company was reckless in its decision-making. This ruling may result in an additional $18 billion in damages, four times the Clean Water Act maximum penalties. BP strongly disagreed with the ruling and filed an immediate appeal.

The Deepwater Horizon oil spill began on April 20, 2010, in the Gulf of Mexico on the BP-operated Macondo Prospect. The spill was estimated to be 8% to 31% larger in volume than the previous largest, the Ixtoc I oil spill. After several failed efforts to contain the flow, the well was declared sealed on September 19, 2010. Reports in early 2012 indicated that the well site was still leaking. A massive response ensued to protect beaches, wetlands, and estuaries from the spreading oil, utilizing skimmer ships, floating booms, controlled burns, and oil dispersant. The spill had extensive damage to marine and wildlife habitats and fishing and tourism industries, with oil cleanup crews working four days a week on Louisiana shoreline throughout 2013.

The misuse of categorical exclusion for National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) compliance, as described in Regulatory Capture, relates to this spill and highlights the need for stricter regulations and accountability for corporations operating in the oil industry. The Deepwater Horizon oil spill has had a profound impact on the environment, the economy, and the reputation of BP, and serves as a cautionary tale for the dangers of prioritizing profits over safety and environmental concerns.

In September 2014, a U.S. District Court judge ruled that BP was primarily responsible for the oil spill because of its gross negligence and reckless conduct, which led to July 2015, BP agreed to pay $18.7 billion in fines, the largest corporate settlement in United States history. a: The origins of music can be traced back to prehistoric times, with the oldest known musical instruments dating back to around 40,000 years ago. The discovery of flutes made from yew wood in a wood-lined pit near Greystones, Ireland, in 2004, and the "Divje Babe Flute", a cave bear femur dated to be approximately 43,500 years old, provide evidence of the existence of music in prehistoric cultures. However, the claim that the femur is indeed a musical instrument is contested by alternative theories, such as the suggestion that it may have been gnawed by carnivores to produce holes.

The prehistoric age is considered to have ended with the development of writing, and with it, the ability to document and preserve music. As a result, the music of this period is largely unknown, and what little is known is based on archaeological evidence and theoretical reconstructions. The oldest known song, written in cuneiform and dating back to 3400 years ago from Ugarit in Syria, provides a glimpse into the musical traditions of ancient civilizations. This song, known as the Hurrian hymn no. 6, was deciphered by Anne Draffkorn Kilmer and was found to be composed in harmonies of thirds, similar to ancient "gymel", and using a Pythagorean tuning of the diatonic scale.

a: During the Reagan Era of the 1980s, modern conservatives sought to reduce the role of government in the economy and society. This was reflected in President Reagan's major policy priorities, which included increasing military spending, cutting taxes, reducing federal spending, and restricting federal regulations. The goal was to stimulate economic growth through tax cuts and deregulation, which would in turn lead to higher revenues and a reduction in the national debt. To achieve this, the Reagan administration introduced the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, which enacted a 27% across-the-board federal income tax cut over three years, as well as a separate bill that reduced federal spending, especially in anti-poverty programs. However, the administration's policies were met with resistance from Democrats, who believed that the tax cuts and increased military spending were exacerbating the national debt and harming social programs. Despite these challenges, the Reagan administration argued that the tax cuts were the primary factor in turning the economy around, and their policies helped to shape the modern conservative movement in the United States.

a: FIFA, or the Fédération Internationale de Football Association, is an international governing body of association football, futsal, and beach soccer that was founded in 1904. Headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland, FIFA is responsible for the organization of football's major international tournaments, including the World Cup and the Women's World Cup. The organization has 211 member countries, each of which must also be a member of one of the six regional confederations into which the world is divided: Africa, Asia, Europe, North & Central America and the Caribbean, Oceania, and South America. While FIFA does not control the rules of football, it is responsible for the organization and promotion of tournaments, which generate revenue from sponsorship. In 2017, FIFA had revenues of over $734 million, with a net loss of $189 million and cash reserves of over $930 million.
r1: The International Federation of Association Football also known as Fédération Internationale de Football Association or simply FIFA, is the highest governing body of association football and numbers 211 member countries worldwide.
r2: FIFA, the Fédération Internationale de Football Association or the International Federation of Association Football, is a non-profit organization that describes itself as an international governing body of association football, futsal, and beach football. Besides its worldwide institutions, there are six confederations recognized by FIFA which oversee the game in the different continents and regions of the world. In total, FIFA recognizes 211 national associations and their associated men's national teams as well as 129 women's national teams.

0.2577319549872463
a: The primary purpose of a traffic circle, also known as a roundabout, is to improve the safety and efficiency of traffic flow at intersections. By permitting traffic to flow in one direction around a central island, roundabouts reduce the likelihood and severity of collisions compared to traditional intersections with stop signs or traffic signals. This is achieved by reducing traffic speeds and minimizing T-bone and head-on collisions. Additionally, roundabouts simplify the pedestrian's visual environment by only allowing traffic to exit in one direction, making it easier for pedestrians to cross the street safely. The slow speed of traffic in roundabouts also allows drivers to visually engage with pedestrians, encouraging deference towards them.

Moreover, roundabouts reduce driver confusion associated with perpendicular junctions and reduce queuing associated with traffic lights. This is because roundabouts eliminate the need for drivers to wait for a green light or stop sign, allowing them to flow smoothly through the intersection. Furthermore, roundabouts allow U-turns within the normal flow of traffic, which is not possible at other forms of junctions. This increased flexibility can help to reduce congestion and improve traffic flow.

Another benefit of roundabouts is that they can lead to less pollution. Since vehicles on average spend less time idling at roundabouts than at signalled intersections, using a roundabout can result in lower emissions and a cleaner environment. Overall, the purpose of a traffic circle is to improve the safety, efficiency, and sustainability of traffic flow at intersections, making it a valuable tool for urban planning and transportation management.
r1: A roundabout is a type of round (about) intersection or junction in which road traffic is permitted to flow in one direction around a central island, and priority is typically given to traffic already in the junction. In terms of safety, it greatly reduces the likelihood and severity of collisions. It also serves an environmental benefit in that it potentially leads to less pollution.
r2: A traffic circle has multiple purposes. In terms of safety, traffic circles reduce the likelihood and severity of collisions greatly. In terms of environmental benefits, it potentially leads to less pollution. Its purpose in how it establishes a flow of traffic is that traffic is permitted to flow in one direction around a central island.
============================135=============================
0.3971631167647503
a: Halley's Comet, officially designated as 1P/Halley, is a short-period comet that is visible from Earth every 75-76 years. The comet's last appearance in the inner parts of the Solar System was in 1986, and it will next appear in mid-2061. Halley's Comet has been observed and recorded by astronomers since at least 240 BC, with clear records made by Chinese, Babylonian, and medieval European chroniclers. However, the comet's periodicity was not recognized until 1705 by English astronomer Edmond Halley, after whom the comet is now named. Halley's Comet is unique among short-period comets in that it is regularly visible to the naked eye from Earth, and is the only naked-eye comet that might appear twice in a human lifetime. The comet's last passage through the inner Solar System in 1986 provided the first opportunity for spacecraft to observe the comet in detail, revealing valuable information about the structure of comet nuclei and the mechanisms of coma and tail formation.
r1: Halley's Comet or Comet Halley, officially designated 1P/Halley, is a short-period comet visible from Earth every 75–76 years. Comet Halley last appeared in 1986 and will next appear in mid-2061.
r2: Halley's Comet or Comet Halley, officially designated 1P/Halley, is a short-period comet visible from Earth every 75–76 years. Halley last appeared in the inner parts of the Solar System in 1986 and will come back around in mid-2061 to 2062.

0.27118643595949443
a: The discovery of a cure for tuberculosis (TB) is a story of persistence and innovation, spanning several centuries and involving the contributions of numerous scientists and researchers. In the early 20th century, procedures such as pneumothorax and surgical interventions were used to treat TB, but it was not until the 1940s and 1950s that the first effective antibiotics were discovered.

In 1944, Albert Schatz, Elizabeth Bugie, and Selman Waksman isolated streptomycin, the first antibiotic effective against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes TB. This discovery marked the beginning of the modern era of TB treatment and paved the way for the development of other effective antibiotics.

However, the true revolution in TB treatment did not begin until the 1950s with the development of isoniazid, the first oral mycobactericidal drug. Isoniazid, along with other antibiotics such as rifampin, significantly reduced the number of TB cases and hastened recovery times.

The advent of these antibiotics was made possible by the discovery of Amycolatopsis rifamycinica, a species of bacteria that produces the rifamycin antibiotics. Amycolatopsis rifamycinica was first isolated from a French soil sample in 1957 and has since been renamed several times. The discovery of this bacterium and the antibiotics it produces has been crucial in the fight against TB and other mycobacterial diseases.

Despite these advances, the search for a cure for TB continues, with ongoing research and development of new antibiotics and treatments to combat drug-resistant strains of the disease. The history of TB treatment is a testament to the power of human ingenuity and the importance of continued scientific inquiry in the face of a persistent and deadly disease.
r1: In the quest to find a cure for tuberculosis, several methods have been developed overtime. The surgical intervention, pneumothorax, which is the collapsing of an infected lung to "rest" it and allow the lesions to heal—was used to treat tuberculosis. In 1834, F.H. Ramadge induced the first successful therapeutic pneumothorax, and reported subsequently the patient was cured. Later, in 1906, Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin developed a drug against tuberculosis from attenuated bovine-strain tuberculosis, the first genuine success in immunizing against tuberculosis. In addition, Albert Schatz, Elizabeth Bugie, and Selman Waksman developed Streptomycin, the first effective antibiotic for tuberculosis and the first effective antibiotic against "M. tuberculosis". Since then, medical researchers Walsh McDermott made his own contribution when he tested the first oral mycobactericidal drug on tuberculosis. Finally, in 1957, scientist Piero Sensi and Maria Teresa Timbal became the first to isolate Rifamycins, a group of antibiotics that particularly effective against mycobacteria, and are therefore used to treat tuberculosis.
r2: Throughout history, the disease tuberculosis has been variously known as consumption, phthisis, and the White Plague. F.H. Ramadge induced the first successful therapeutic pneumothorax in 1834, and reported subsequently the patient was cured. The first genuine success in immunizing against tuberculosis was developed from attenuated bovine-strain tuberculosis by Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin in 1906. In 1944 Albert Schatz, Elizabeth Bugie, and Selman Waksman isolated streptomycin produced by a bacterial strain "Streptomyces griseus." Streptomycin was the first effective antibiotic against "M. tuberculosis". The first oral mycobactericidal drug on tuberculosis was tested by Walsh McDermott. In the 1970, Lepetit Pharmaceuticals and Piero Sensi and MarMaria Teresa Timbal came up with a drug that shortened recovery and reduced cases of tuberculosis.

According to the current chief architect, Jordi Fauli, construction is 70% complete and is expected to be finished by 2026, the centennial of Gaudí's death. The main tasks remaining include the construction of the transept vaults and apse, as well as the decorative elements, which are expected to be complete by 2030 or 2032. The use of modern technologies such as computer-aided design and computerized numerical control (CNC) has enabled faster progress and has helped the construction team to pass the midpoint of the project in 2010. The church, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a minor basilica, has been under construction since 1882 and has been led by various architects, including Antoni Gaudí, who devoted the remainder of his life to the project. Despite interruptions such as the Spanish Civil War, the construction of the Sagrada Familia has continued to progress slowly but surely, relying solely on private donations.

r2: The Sagrada Família, is a large unfinished Roman Catholic minor basilica in the Eixample district of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Designed by the Spanish architect Antoni Gaudí (1852–1926), his work on the building is part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The steeples and most of the church's structure are to be completed by 2026, the centennial of Gaudí's death; as of a 2017 estimate, decorative elements should be complete by 2030 or 2032.

a: The Bill of Rights, initially applied only to the federal government, was later incorporated to apply to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment, which was ratified in 1868. This incorporation doctrine was established in the landmark case of Gitlow v. New York (1925), in which the Supreme Court held that the First Amendment's protection of free speech applied to state governments through the Fourteenth Amendment. The incorporation of the Bill of Rights has been a gradual process, with various portions of the Amendments being applied to the states over time. The Fifteenth Amendment, ratified in 1870, specifically prohibits the federal government and states from denying citizens the right to vote based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude. However, despite the incorporation of the Bill of Rights and the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment, the Supreme Court has historically interpreted these protections narrowly, allowing for the implementation of various barriers to voter registration in southern states during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
r1: The 14th and 15th amendments of 1868 and 1870 respectively, were a ratification to the United States' Constitutional bill of rights that gave more rights to the states and people over time.
r2: By incorporation through both the Fourteenth Amendment in 1868 and the Fifteenth Amendment in 1870, various portions of the Bill of Rights have been held to be applicable to the state and local governments. Incorporation is the doctrine by which portions of the Bill of Rights have been made applicable to the states. When the Bill of Rights was ratified, the courts held that the Bill of Rights did not place limitations on the authority of the state and local governments.

However, since the introduction of the AFL salary cap in 1987, the distribution of premierships has become more even, with 13 clubs winning the championship in the past 30 seasons. This is largely due to the implementation of zoning, which ensures that each club has a exclusive zone from which to recruit players, reducing the dominance of a select few clubs. Additionally, the salary cap has limited the spending power of the richest clubs, allowing other teams to compete more evenly. Notably, Sydney, who struggled for many years, has since become a strong contender, winning two premierships since 2005. Overall, the AFL salary cap and zoning have had a significant impact on the competitiveness of the league, creating a more level playing field and allowing a wider range of clubs to win the premiership.

0.1772151863547509
a: Mother India, a powerful and poignant film directed by Mehboob Khan and starring Nargis, was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film in 1958. Despite being India's first submission for the category and receiving widespread critical acclaim, the film ultimately lost to Federico Fellini's Nights of Cabiria by a single vote. This loss was particularly disappointing for Khan, who believed that his film was superior to the other nominees.

Mother India tells the story of a woman who embodies the spirit of India, struggling to raise her children and maintain her family's well-being in the face of poverty, societal pressures, and personal tragedy. The film was praised for its earthy, realistic portrayal of Indian life and its powerful performances, particularly by Nargis in the title role. The film's success was not limited to its Oscar nomination, as it also won several Filmfare Awards, including Best Film, Best Director for Khan, Best Cinematographer for Faredoon Irani, and Best Sound for R. Kaushik.

In order to appeal to the Academy and increase its chances of winning, the film's international version was edited to 120 minutes and included English subtitles. However, this version was not without controversy, as it dropped Mehboob Productions' logo, which featured the Communist hammer and sickle, to appease the Academy. Despite these efforts, Mother India ultimately lost to Nights of Cabiria, a film that also received widespread critical acclaim and tells the story of a prostitute in Rome searching for true love.

Despite the loss, Mother India remains a landmark film in Indian cinema and a powerful portrayal of the struggles of the common man. Its success and impact on Indian cinema are undeniable, and it continues to be celebrated and studied by film scholars and enthusiasts alike. The film's themes of family, sacrifice, and the power of the human spirit continue to resonate with audiences today, making it a timeless classic that will endure for generations to come.
r1: The 1957 Indian epic drama film Mother India was nominated at the Oscars and came close to winning the Academy Award, but lost to the 1957 Italian drama film "Nights of Cabiria" directed by Federico Fellini.
r2: "Mother India" is a 1957 Indian epic drama film, directed by Mehboob Khan and starring Nargis, Sunil Dutt, Rajendra Kumar, and Raaj Kumar. The interior design of the Bellagio was crafted by Roger Thomas, who is the executive vice president of design for Wynn Design & Development and the principal of the Roger Thomas Collection. 0.2807017508648815
a: The legal drinking age in the United States was raised to 21 across all states in 1986, following the passage of the National Minimum Drinking Age Act in 1984. Prior to this, 12 states had maintained a purchase age of 21 since the repeal of Prohibition, while others had lower ages, with some states raising their ages in response to the growing concern about drunk driving fatalities. The National Minimum Drinking Age Act was a controversial law that withheld federal highway funds from states that did not raise their purchase ages to 21, leading all 50 states and the District of Columbia to comply by mid-1988. The law did not outlaw the consumption of alcohol by those under 21, but rather punished states that allowed persons below 21 to purchase and publicly possess alcoholic beverages. Despite its name, the law did not seek to criminalize alcohol consumption during religious occasions such as communion wines or Kiddush. The current drinking age of 21 remains a point of contention among some Americans, as it is higher than the age of majority and the drinking ages of most other countries. While there have been proposals to lower the drinking age in some states, Guam has raised its drinking age to 21 in 2010. The National Minimum Drinking Age Act has been amended to lower the penalty for non-compliance to 8% of federal highway funds starting from fiscal year 2012.
r1: On July 17, 1984, the United States Congress passed the National Minimum Drinking Age Act, which required states to raise their ages for purchase and public possession of alcoholic beverages to 21 by October 1986 or lose 10% of their federal highway funds.
r2: In the United States, a law was passed on July 17, 1984 making the uniform legal drinking age 21. Known as The National Minimum Drinking Age Act of 1984, it was passed by the United States Congress and was later signed into law by President Ronald Reagan. The states had to have their drinking ages raised to 21 by October 1986.

a: In 1922, Benito Mussolini and his National Fascist Party took control of the Italian government, marking the beginning of the Kingdom of Italy under Fascism. According to Payne (1996), the Fascist government passed through several distinct phases. The first phase, from 1923 to 1925, was characterized by a legally-organized executive dictatorship, while the second phase, from 1925 to 1929, saw the construction of the Fascist dictatorship proper. The third phase, from 1929 to 1934, was marked by less activism, while the fourth phase, from 1935 to 1940, was characterized by an aggressive foreign policy, including the war against Ethiopia and confrontations with the League of Nations. The final phase, from 1940 to 1943, saw the disasters and defeats of the war, and the rump Salò Government under German control. Throughout these phases, the Fascist government imposed totalitarian rule, crushed political and intellectual opposition, and promoted economic modernization, traditional social values, and a rapprochement with the Roman Catholic Church.
r1: The Kingdom of Italy was governed by the National Fascist Party from 1922 to 1943 with Benito Mussolini as prime minister.
r2: In 1922, the National Fascist Party, the faction of the Italian fascists, and leader and prime minister Benito Mussolini took control of the Italian government. The Kingdom of Italy was governed by the National Fascist Party, an Italian political party created by Benito Mussolini, from 1922 to 1943 with Benito Mussolini as prime minister.

Hernandez's perfect game was notable for being the third perfect game of the 2012 season, with the first two being pitched by Philip Humber and Matt Cain earlier in the season.

Hernandez threw 113 pitches, with 77 of them being strikes, and struck out the side in both the sixth and eighth innings. The Rays' starting pitcher, Jeremy Hellickson, allowed one run in seven innings on a run batted in single by Jesús Montero in the third inning. This marked the third time in MLB history that a manager had been ejected from a perfect game, with the previous two being Bob Melvin in 2004 and Lou Piniella in 1996.

0.25306122149104543
a: The question of who was considered the father of the blues is a complex one, as there were several influential musicians who contributed to the development of the genre. However, among them, W. C. Handy, Charley Patton, and Muddy Waters are often cited as the most significant figures in the history of the blues.

W. C. Handy, known as the "Father of the Blues," was a composer and musician who was born in Florence, Alabama in 1873. Handy was an educated musician who used elements of folk music in his compositions, and he was scrupulous in documenting the sources of his works. He took the blues, a regional music style with a limited audience, to a new level of popularity, and his compositions, such as "St. Louis Blues" and "Beale Street Blues," became standards of the genre. Handy's music was characterized by its soulful, emotive quality, and his use of folk elements, such as the slide guitar and the 12-bar structure, helped to define the blues sound.

Charley Patton, considered by many to be the "Father of the Delta Blues," was a musician who created an enduring body of American music and inspired most Delta blues musicians. Patton was born in Hinds County, Mississippi, and lived most of his life in Sunflower County. He was known for his powerful, soulful voice and his skilled guitar playing, and his music was characterized by its raw, emotional intensity. Patton's music was influential in the development of the Delta blues style, and his recordings, such as "Pony Blues" and "High Water Everywhere," are considered classics of the genre.

Muddy Waters, known as the "father of modern Chicago blues," was a blues singer-songwriter and musician who was born in Mississippi in 1913. Waters grew up playing the guitar and harmonica, and he was influenced by local blues artists such as Son House and Robert Johnson. He moved to Chicago in 1943 and began playing professionally, and his recordings with the Chess Records label in the early 1950s, such as "Hoochie Coochie Man" and "I Just Want to Make Love to You," helped to define the modern Chicago blues sound. Waters' music was characterized by its raw, emotional intensity and its use of electric instruments, and he was an important influence on many other blues musicians.

In conclusion, while all three of these musicians are considered to be among the most important figures in the history of the blues, it is difficult to say definitively who was the "father of the blues." Each of these musicians made significant contributions to the development of the genre, and their music continues to be celebrated and enjoyed by audiences around the world.
r1: There are a few musicians called the father of blues in one way or another, like W.C. Handy (William Christopher Handy) who called himself the Father of Blues. Charley Patton, also known as Charlie Patton, is considered to be the Father of the Delta Blues. Muddy Waters’ birth name is McKinley Morganfield and is often called the Father of modern Chicago Blues.
r2: Several musicians are known by variations of the title,"Father of the Blues". William Christopher Handy, a composer and musician, called himself the "Father of the Blues." Charley Patton, an American Delta Blues musician, was considered by many to be the "Father of the Delta Blues." McKinley Morganfield, known professionally as Muddy Waters, was an American Blues singer-songwriter and musician is often cited as the "Father of modern Chicago Blues."

a: The Costa Concordia disaster, which occurred on January 13, 2012, resulted in a significant financial burden for Costa Crociere, the Italian cruise company that owned the ship. The total cost of the disaster, including victims' compensation, refloating, towing, and scrapping costs, is estimated to be around $2 billion, which is more than three times the $612 million construction cost of the ship. This staggering amount includes the cost of the salvage operation, which was one of the biggest maritime salvage operations in history.

The salvage operation, which began on September 16, 2013, involved the use of parbuckle salvage technique, where the ship was set upright on its underwater cradle. This process was completed by early hours of September 17, 2013. The ship was then towed 320 kilometers to its home port of Genoa for scrapping, which was finished in July 2017. The cost of the salvage operation alone was estimated to be around $800 million.

In addition to the salvage costs, Costa Crociere also had to pay compensation to the victims of the disaster, which amounted to around $1.2 billion. The company also faced legal and regulatory penalties, which added to the overall cost of the disaster.

The Costa Concordia disaster was a major setback for Costa Crociere, which had to halt its operations and undergo a major overhaul of its safety procedures. The company also had to invest in new technology and safety measures to prevent such incidents in the future.

In conclusion, the Costa Concordia disaster had a significant financial impact on Costa Crociere, with the total cost of the disaster estimated to be around $2 billion. The salvage operation and victims' compensation were the major contributors to this amount, and the company had to undergo a major overhaul of its safety procedures to prevent such incidents in the future.
r1: The Costa Concordia was a cruise ship operated by Costa Crociere that ran aground, capsized, and later sank in shallow waters after striking an underwater rock off Isola del Giglio, Tuscany on January 13, 2012. The initial estimated cost was $300 Million USD, but ended up costing $1.2 Billion USD. The total cost due to victims' compensation, refloating, towing and scrapping costs made the grand total $2 Billion USD.

a: The present chairman of the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) of the Lok Sabha is Mallikarjun Kharge, who is the leader of the Indian National Congress (INC) in the Lok Sabha. He was re-appointed to a second term in May 2018. The PAC is a crucial parliamentary committee that exercises the power of the legislature to scrutinize the expenditure of the government and ensure that it is being carried out in an efficient and effective manner. The committee is composed of 15 members elected by the Lok Sabha and 7 members elected by the Rajya Sabha, and its chairperson is appointed by the Lok Sabha speaker. The PAC has been an integral part of the Indian parliamentary system since 1921, and it has published a total of 1596 reports from 1950 to April 2018.

The PAC's primary function is to examine the audit report of the Comptroller and Auditor General (C&AG) after it is laid in the Parliament. The C&AG assists the committee during the course of investigation. The PAC also examines the accounts of the government's revenue and expenditure, and it serves as a check on the government's financial management. The committee has the power to summon government officials and ask them questions regarding the government's financial dealings.

In recent years, the PAC has been involved in probing several high-profile cases, including the VVIP case, wherein it decided to call RBI governor Urjit Patel, Finance Secretary Ashok Lavasa, and Economic Affairs Secretary Shaktikanta Das to answer questions regarding the government's sudden demonetization move in 2016. The PAC's oversight process is an essential aspect of India's parliamentary democracy, as it ensures that the government is accountable to the people through their elected representatives in the parliament.

It is worth noting that the PAC has been headed by the leader of the opposition in the Lok Sabha since 1967, with the exception of a few years when the Congress party was not the main opposition party. The committee's chairperson is selected by the Lok Sabha speaker, and the current chairperson, Mallikarjun Kharge, is a member of the INC. The PAC's composition and functions are governed by the Constitution of India and the rules of procedure of the Lok Sabha, and it is an essential component of India's parliamentary system.
r1: The chairman of the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) of Lok Sabha in 2017 was Mallikarjun Kharge. K V Thomas was the chairman in 2015 and both Mallikarjun Kharge and K V Thomas in 2016.
r2: The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) is a committee of selected members of parliament for the purpose of auditing the revenue and the expenditure of the Government of India. The chairperson is appointed by the Lok Sabha speaker. In 2015, K V Thomas was the Chairman of Public Accounts. In 2016, the Chairman was both Mallikarjun Kharge and K V Thomas. In 2017, the Chairman was Mallikarjun Kharge.

a: When did Spain win their first World Cup?

Spain won their first World Cup in the year 2010. The final match was held on July 11th at Soccer City in Johannesburg, South Africa, and Spain defeated the Netherlands 1-0 in extra time, with a goal scored by Andrés Iniesta. This victory marked Spain's first World Cup title, and it was also the first time since England in 1966 that the winners of the final wore their second-choice strip. The match was notable for the high number of yellow cards issued, with a total of 14 in the final and an average of 7.75 per game throughout the tournament. The referee, Howard Webb, set a record for the most yellow cards in a World Cup final, surpassing the previous record of six set in 1986. This victory marked a significant milestone for the Spanish national team, as they had previously never won a World Cup and had only reached the final once before, in 1950.
r1: Spain’s national soccer team won their first world cup at the 2010 FIFA World Cup on 11 July 2010. That was the 19th FIFA World Cup. Spain’s men’s national basketball team won their first FIBA world cup on September 3, 2006, at the 15th FIBA World Championship, called the 2006 FIBA World Championship.
r2: On September 3, 2006, Spain won the the 2006 FIBA World Championship, the 15th FIBA World Championship, which is the international basketball world championship for men's teams. Spain beat Greece in the championship final, 70–47, to finish the tournament having won all nine games played. Spain also won the 2010 FIFA World Cup, the 19th FIFA World Cup, which is the world championship for men's national football teams on 11 July 2010 at Soccer City in Johannesburg, South Africa. Both the Netherlands and Spain were attempting to win their first FIFA World Cup, but Spain defeated the Netherlands 1–0.
