0.31034482375148637
a: The three-point line, a staple of modern basketball, has a rich and varied history that spans over six decades. The first experimentation with the three-point line took place in the collegiate level in 1945, with a 21-foot line, but it was not adopted as a rule. It wasn't until the American Basketball League (ABL) instituted the rule in 1961 that the three-point line began to gain traction. The ABL's three-point line was a radius of 25 feet from the basket, except along the sides. The Eastern Professional Basketball League followed suit in its 1963-64 season. The three-point shot gained popularity in the American Basketball Association (ABA) in the 1970s, where it was used as a marketing tool to compete with the NBA. In 1979, the NBA adopted the three-point line for a one-year trial, and it became a permanent fixture in the league in 1980.

The introduction of the three-point line in the NBA had a significant impact on the game, as it opened up the offense and created new scoring opportunities. The line was initially set at 23 feet, 9 inches, but was later moved to its current distance of 22 feet, 1.75 inches in 1994. The NBA also experimented with a shorter distance in the 1990s, but ultimately returned to the original distance. The three-point line has since become an integral part of the game, and players like Ray Allen have become all-time leaders in career made three-pointers.

The three-point line has not only changed the game of basketball at the professional level, but it has also had a ripple effect on collegiate and high school basketball. The NCAA first adopted the three-point line in the 1986-87 season, and it has since become a standard feature of the game at all levels. The line has also been adopted in international competitions, such as the Olympic Games, where it made its debut in 1988.

In conclusion, the three-point line has a rich history that spans over six decades, and it has had a profound impact on the game of basketball. From its humble beginnings in the collegiate level to its widespread adoption in professional and collegiate basketball, the three-point line has changed the game and created new scoring opportunities for players.
r1: A three-point field goal, or a 3-pointer, is a field goal in a basketball game made from beyond the three-point line. It was first tested at the collegiate level in 1945. The American Basketball League became the first basketball league to institute the rule in 1961 and then the NBA adopted it for a one-year trial in June of 1979. The first NCAA conference used the 3 point line during the 1980-81 season, leading to high schools, elementary schools, and middle schools in 1987. The Olympics decided to finally use it in 1988.
r2: The three-point line was first tested at the collegiate level in 1945, with a 21-foot line, in a game between Columbia and Fordham, but it was not kept as a rule. The American Basketball League became the first basketball league to institute the rule in 1961 and in June 1979, the NBA adopted the three-point line for a one-year trial. The 1980-81 season was the first time a NCAA conference used the 3 point line. The 3 point line was put in for high schools, elementary schools, and middle schools in 1987, and in 1988 it was first used in the Olympics.

The film is based on the true story of the Washington Post's publication of the Pentagon Papers, classified documents detailing the US government's involvement in the Vietnam War. Spielberg was attracted to the script, written by Liz Hannah and Josh Singer, because it was a story that needed to be told immediately, and he began working on the film shortly after reading the first draft.

As filming commenced, some figures associated with the New York Times, who were involved in the Pentagon Papers case, objected to the film's production due to the script's lack of emphasis on the Times' role in breaking the story. The film's title was initially "The Papers," but was later reverted to "The Post" in August 2017.

It grossed $179 million worldwide and received positive reviews, with critics praising the performances of the all-star cast, particularly those of Streep, Hanks, and Odenkirk. The film's references and allusions to the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Donald Trump were also noted by critics. 0.26035502551871437
a: The first literature of the Anglo-Saxons was Old English, which encompasses literature written in Old English in Anglo-Saxon England from the 7th century to the decades after the Norman Conquest of 1066. While all extant Old English poetry is written and literate, it is assumed that it was originally an oral craft performed by a "scop" accompanied by a harp. The primary three known Old English poets are Cædmon, Aldhelm, and Cynewulf, with Cædmon's "Hymn" being the oldest extant poem in English, composed in the 7th century. The literature of this period consists of sermons and saints' lives, biblical translations, translated Latin works of the early Church Fathers, Anglo-Saxon chronicles and narrative history works, laws, wills, and other legal works, and poetry. The most famous work of Old English literature is the epic poem "Beowulf", which is often considered the beginning of the traditional canon of English literature. Other notable works include the "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle" and the poem "The Grave", which presents a transitional text between Old and Middle English. In total, there are over 400 surviving manuscripts from this period, with about 189 considered "major". Besides Old English literature, the Anglo-Saxons also wrote a number of Anglo-Latin works.
r1: Old English literature, or Anglo-Saxon literature, encompasses literature written in Old English. Cædmon is considered the first Old English poet whose work still survives and "Cædmon's Hymn" is considered the first poem of the Anglo-Saxons. The poem "Beowulf", which often begins the traditional canon of English literature, is the most famous work of Old English literature.
r2: While the first poem of the Anglo-Saxons was Cædmon's Hymn, their first literature in the traditional canon was the poem Beowulf by an anonymous author. Cædmon's Hymn was composed between 658 and 680 by the Old English poet Cædmon. Beowulf's date of composition is a matter of contention among scholars. The only certain dating is for the manuscript, which was produced between 975 and 1025.

a: The genre of Louis Sachar's "Holes" can be classified as adventure fiction, as it embodies many of the key elements of this genre. The novel is filled with danger, excitement, and a sense of adventure, as the protagonist, Stanley Yelnats, is sent to Camp Green Lake, a juvenile detention camp in the Texas desert, and discovers a treasure and a curse that have been passed down through generations.

Adventure fiction is a broad category that encompasses a wide range of stories that feature danger and excitement. As defined by critic Don D'Ammassa, adventure stories focus on the element of danger as the central plot point, and the protagonists are often in constant danger of being imprisoned or killed. In "Holes," Stanley is falsely accused of theft and sent to Camp Green Lake, where he faces a harsh and dangerous environment, and must navigate a complex web of interconnected stories and secrets to uncover the truth about his family's past and break the curse that has plagued them for generations.

The novel also explores themes of racism, homelessness, illiteracy, and arranged marriage, which are woven into the adventure narrative to create a rich and complex story. The novel's success was not limited to the literary world, as it was adapted into a feature film of the same name by Walt Disney Pictures in 2003, which received generally positive reviews from critics and grossed $71 million.

0.24043715470632152
a: The second sound of the heartbeat, also known as the S2 sound, is produced by the closure of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) at the end of ventricular systole and the beginning of ventricular diastole. This sound is typically heard as a split second sound, with the A sound (the first heart sound) occurring before the P sound (the second heart sound). The S2 sound is caused by the sudden block of flow reversal as the pressure in the aorta and pulmonary artery falls below the pressure in the left and right ventricles, respectively. This blockage causes the blood to flow back through the valves, creating a reverberation that produces the S2 sound.

In a healthy adult, the S2 sound is normally heard as a single, high-pitched sound that is split into two components: the early (E) component and the late (A) component. The early component is produced by the closure of the pulmonary valve, while the late component is produced by the closure of the aortic valve. The split S2 sound is typically heard during inspiration, as the decrease in intrathoracic pressure increases the time needed for pulmonary pressure to exceed that of the right ventricular pressure.

However, a widely split S2 sound can be associated with several cardiovascular conditions, including left bundle branch block, pulmonary stenosis, and atrial septal defect. Additionally, the presence of extra heart sounds, such as gallop rhythms, can also be indicative of certain cardiac conditions. These sounds can be heard in both normal and abnormal situations, and their presence and characteristics can provide important diagnostic information for cardiologists and other healthcare professionals.
r1: The sound or noises that your heart makes is turbulence created when the heart valves snap shut. The first heart sound, or S1, forms the "lub" of "lub-dub" and is composed of components M1 (mitral valve closure) and T1 (tricuspid valve closure). The second heart sound, or S, forms the "dub" of "lub-dub" and is composed of components A (aortic valve closure) and P (pulmonary valve closure). The earlier component of the second sound is the A2 and the later component is P2. The acoustical phenomenon within blood that is associated with the second sound of the heartbeat is called reverberation or reverb.
r2: The second heart sound follows the first, but the cause of each is different. The first heart sound occurs when the atrioventricular valves close at the beginning of ventricular contraction, or systole, while the second heart sound occurs when the aortic valve and pulmonary valve close at the end of ventricular systole and the beginning of ventricular diastole. The second heart sound consists of aortic valve closure followed by pulmonary valve closure and is also associated with the acoustical phenomenon within blood called reverberation.
============================260=============================

a: England won the FIFA World Cup in soccer in the year 1966, defeating West Germany in the final match held at Wembley Stadium in London. This victory marked England's first and only World Cup title to date, and it remains one of the most memorable moments in English football history. The match was attended by 96,924 fans and was watched by a record 32.3 million viewers on television in the United Kingdom, making it the most-watched television event ever in the country. England's victory was secured through a hat-trick by Geoff Hurst, who scored the first and only hat-trick in a FIFA World Cup final to date. The match was also notable for the controversial third goal awarded to England, which was the subject of much debate and dispute.

Despite their success in the 1966 World Cup, England has struggled in subsequent major tournament finals, particularly in penalty shootouts. England has lost six of eight penalty shootouts in major tournament finals, including losses to Germany in the semi-finals of the 1990 FIFA World Cup and UEFA Euro 1996. England's poor record in penalty shootouts has been a source of frustration for the team and its fans, and it has prevented the team from achieving further success in major tournaments. However, England finally broke their losing streak in penalty shootouts at the 2018 World Cup, defeating Colombia in the round of 16 to progress to the quarter-finals for the first time in twelve years.

In contrast, the Netherlands has also struggled in penalty shootouts, losing four consecutive shootouts between 1992 and 2004. However, the Netherlands finally won a penalty shootout at Euro 2004, defeating Sweden to advance to the quarter-finals. 0.28318583636619943
a: When does daylight saving time end in Colorado?

In Colorado, daylight saving time (DST) ends on the first Sunday in November, which is when the clocks "fall back" one hour to return to standard time. This means that Coloradans will gain one hour of sleep as the clocks are set back from 2:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. local time. The state observes DST in accordance with the Uniform Time Act of 1966, which established a standardized system of DST throughout the United States. The practice of DST in Colorado lasts for 34 weeks (238 days) every year, accounting for about 65% of the entire year.
r1: Daylight saving time in the United States is the practice of setting the clock forward by one hour. In general, it ends on the first Sunday in November. In Colorado, daylight savings ended on November 1, 2015, November 6, 2016, and November 5, 2017. Generally it ends on the first Sunday in November.
r2: Starting in 2007, most of the United States and Canada observed DST from the second Sunday in March to the first Sunday in November. Daylight savings time in Colorado ended on November 1, 2015, on November 6, 2016, and November 5, 2017.

"Don't You Wish Your Girlfriend Was Hot Like Me" is a hit song by the American girl group The Pussycat Dolls, featuring rapper Busta Rhymes. The Pussycat Dolls' version of the song was released in 2005 as part of their debut studio album "PCD" and became a commercial success, reaching number two on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and number one on the US Hot Dance Club Play and Pop 100 charts. The song also topped the charts in fifteen other countries, including Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.

The song's success can be attributed to its catchy chorus, which interpolates Sir Mix-a-Lot's "Swass," and the unique blend of R&B and hip-hop styles. Busta Rhymes' feature on the track added a new dimension to the song, with his distinctive flow and energetic delivery. The music video, directed by Paul Hunter, also contributed to the song's popularity, showcasing the group's dance skills and playful energy.

Despite the success of the Pussycat Dolls' version of "Don't You Wish Your Girlfriend Was Hot Like Me," Tori Alamaze's original version of the song also received minor success, reaching several Billboard charts, including the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart at number 53 and the Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart at number two. However, it was the Pussycat Dolls' version that ultimately became a pop culture phenomenon, cementing the group's status as a top girl group of the early 2000s.
r1: "Don't Cha" is a song recorded by American girl group The Pussycat Dolls that features rapper Busta Rhymes. It was originally recorded by Tori Alamaze, a former backing vocalist for the hip hop duo OutKast, who gave up her rights to the song.
r2: Several people have sung the song Don't Cha, which has the lyrics "don't cha wish your girlfriend was hot like me". The group that famously sang it was The Pussycat Dolls, it being from their debut studio album PCD, while the rapper that did was Busta Rhymes, who is featured on the song. It was originally sung by singer Tori Alamaze, who released it as her first single but gave up her rights to the song.

The team has a rich history, with notable achievements including winning the inaugural Basketball Association of America (BAA) championship in 1947 and their third championship in 1975, which is considered one of the biggest upsets in NBA history.

In their early years in San Francisco, the Warriors were led by Hall of Famers Wilt Chamberlain and Rick Barry, who helped the team return to being title contenders. Today, the Warriors play their home games at the Oracle Arena in Oakland, and have a loyal fan base throughout the Bay Area. a: The artwork for Pink Floyd's album "The Wall" was created by cartoonist Gerald Scarfe, who had previously worked with the band on their "In the Flesh" tour. The album's cover features a sticker or printed lettering of the artist name and album title, with the eponymous wall in various stages of construction, accompanied by characters from the story. Scarfe also created the inside sleeve art and labels of both vinyl records, which showcase his signature style and further bring the album's themes to life.

The artwork for "The Wall" is particularly notable for its use of animation, which was translated into dolls for the band's "The Wall" tour and later into Scarfe's animated segments for the film based on the album. The use of animation not only adds a unique visual element to the album but also helps to further emphasize the album's themes of disillusionment and the breakdown of society.

The creation of the artwork for "The Wall" was not without its challenges, however. According to the wikipage, the album's release was initially met with indifference from some executives at Columbia Records, who were reportedly unimpressed by what they heard. Additionally, the band's bassist and songwriter Roger Waters had to negotiate with the label to secure smaller publishing rights, which he eventually did. Despite these challenges, the artwork for "The Wall" has become iconic and is widely regarded as one of the most distinctive and memorable album covers of all time.

a: The architect of the north and south blocks of the Central Secretariat in Delhi is a combination of two famous architects, Edwin Lutyens and Herbert Baker. Lutyens was responsible for the design of the Viceroy's House, now known as Rashtrapati Bhavan, while Baker designed the Secretariat buildings. The two architects worked together on the project, with Lutyens serving as the lead architect and Baker as the second in command. The construction of the Secretariat began in the 1910s, during the British colonial era, and was completed in the 1920s.

The Secretariat buildings are designed in a classical architectural style, with a blend of Mughal and Rajasthani motifs. The buildings are made of cream and red Dholpur sandstone from Rajasthan, with the red sandstone forming the base. The buildings are topped by giant domes and have broad corridors and wide stairways to the four floors. The use of "Jali", perforated screens, is a distinct feature of the building, providing shade from the hot Indian sun and monsoon rains. The "Chatri" structure, a unique design to India, is also incorporated in the building, providing relief to travelers.

The four "dominion columns" located in front of the main gates of the buildings were given by Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa, symbolizing the British dominion. However, India became independent in the next 17 years, and the Secretariat became the seat of power of a sovereign India. As the building ran out of accommodation, several extensions were made to the original structure.

The Central Secretariat metro station is a Delhi Metro station located near the Secretariat buildings, providing a same-level interchange between the Yellow and Violet lines. The station is situated near several landmarks, including the Parliament House and the Krishi Bhavan. The Secretariat Building is currently home to some of the most important ministries of the Cabinet of India, and is an important symbol of the Indian government.
r1: The term or phrase Central Secretariat is used for the name of where the Cabinet Secretariat is housed, which administers the Government of India and a building in Delhi Metro station in Delhi, India. The north and south block of the Secretariat Building in New Delhi was designed by the prominent British architect Herbert Baker in Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture. The architect of north and south blocks of Central Secretariat in Delhi was Kumagai-Skanska-HCC-Itochu Joint Venture (KSHI-JV).
r2: The architect of the north block of the Central Secretariat Metro Station in Delhi was the Kumagai-Skanska-HCC-Itochu Joint Venture, while the architect of the North Block and South Block of the Central Secretariat in New Delhi was prominent British architect Herbert Baker.

a: The player with the most points in one NHL game is Sam Gagner, who scored four goals and added four assists for a total of eight points on February 2, 2012, while playing for the Edmonton Oilers against the Chicago Blackhawks. This feat made him the 13th player in NHL history to achieve this milestone, and the first since Mario Lemieux did it in 1989. Gagner's impressive performance also set a new Oilers record for most points in a single game, surpassing the previous mark of ten points set by Wayne Gretzky. Two days later, Gagner continued his hot streak with two goals and an assist in the first period against the Detroit Red Wings, setting a new team record with 11 consecutive points. This remarkable stretch of form cemented Gagner's place as one of the most talented players in the NHL.

This performance made him the sixth player in NHL history to score five goals on five shots, and the first since Wayne Gretzky in 1984. Laine's impressive display of skill and scoring ability also made him the fourth-youngest player in NHL history to reach the milestone of 100 regular season goals.

Finally, Sidney Crosby, a highly skilled and accomplished player, has also recorded a high number of points in one game. This impressive performance was just one of many highlights in Crosby's dominant season, in which he won the scoring title, MVP, and Personality of the Year awards, and led his team to the President's Cup as QMJHL playoff champions.

Overall, these players have demonstrated exceptional skill and scoring ability, with each of them achieving impressive feats in one game that cemented their place as some of the most talented players in NHL history.

a: The President of the European Parliament is not elected by Lorenzo Sassoli de Bianchi or any other individual. Instead, the President of the European Parliament is elected by the members of the European Parliament (MEPs) themselves. The President is elected for a two-and-a-half-year term, and the election is held at the first meeting of the new parliamentary term. The President is chosen based on a secret ballot, and a two-thirds majority is required for the candidate to be elected. The President serves as the ceremonial head of the European Parliament and represents the institution at international events. However, the President does not have any formal executive powers and is not a member of the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union. The current President of the European Parliament is David Sassoli, who was elected in 2019 and is serving a two-and-a-half-year term.
r1: David Sassoli from Italy is the current president of the European Parliament. The party that elects the president is the European People's Party (EPP) and Party of European Socialists (PES). Members of Parliament elect the president.
r2: The President of the European Parliament presides over the debates and activities of the European Parliament. The president is elected by the members of Parliament for a two-and-a-half-year term, meaning two elections per parliamentary term, hence two presidents may serve during any one Parliamentary term. Since the 1980s, the two major parties in the Parliament, the European People's Party (EPP) and Party of European Socialists (PES), have had the custom of splitting the two posts between themselves.

0.1401869125128833
a: The first cassette tape was introduced by Philips in 1962, revolutionizing the way people listened to music and recorded audio. The Compact Cassette, as it was called, was a significant improvement over earlier magnetic tape formats, such as the reel-to-reel tapes and the Stereo 8-track cartridge. The cassette tape was more user-friendly, convenient, and portable, making it a popular choice for both personal and professional use.

The development of the cassette tape was a result of a race between Philips and other companies, such as Telefunken and Grundig, to establish a standard format for magnetic tape recording. Philips' decision to license the format free of charge helped the Compact Cassette become the dominant format, and it quickly gained popularity in the market. The first cassette player was introduced in 1968, and by the early 1970s, the cassette tape had become one of the two most common formats for prerecorded music, alongside the LP record.

The cassette tape's success can be attributed to its convenience and portability. Unlike reel-to-reel tapes, the cassette tape did not require the user to handle unruly tape ends or thread the tape through the machine before use. The tape was contained within a protective plastic shell, making it easy to handle and store. Additionally, the cassette tape's reversible design allowed for both sides to be played, and some models even had an auto-reverse mechanism that allowed the tape to run continuously.

The cassette tape's popularity peaked in the 1980s and 1990s, with the rise of portable cassette players and boomboxes. However, with the advent of digital technology and the introduction of the compact disc (CD), the cassette tape's popularity began to decline. Today, the cassette tape has largely been replaced by digital formats such as MP3s and streaming services, but it remains a nostalgic reminder of a bygone era in music and audio technology.
r1: The first compact cassette or musicassette (MC) tape was invented on 30 August 1963, and it was introduced in Europe in September 1963. It was not introduced in the United States until November 1964 though. The first large cassette tape, which failed, came out in 1958 after four years of development.
r2: The first compact cassette came out in Europe and the US on different dates and was preceded in 1958 by RCA Victor's release of the first large cassette that failed. The first compact cassette tape was invented in 1962 by Philips. It was introduced in Europe on 30 August 1963 at the Berlin Radio Show and to the United States under the Norelco brand in November 1964.

They were undefeated in the tournament and had only conceded one goal in the six matches leading up to the final. Japan, on the other hand, was making its second consecutive appearance in the final and was looking to become the first team to successfully defend their title since Germany in 2007.

0.22077921764209818
a: The ratio of the wave height to its wave length is called the wave steepness, and it is a fundamental parameter in the study of ocean waves. According to Stokes' third-order theory, the wave steepness is directly proportional to the non-linearity of the waves, as measured by the expansion parameter "ka". Specifically, the wave steepness is given by the ratio of the wave height "H" to the wave length "λ", and it is defined as the ratio of the wave height to the wave length.

In deep water, the wave steepness is determined by the balance between the gravitational force acting on the water and the viscous forces resisting the motion of the water. As the wave amplitude increases, the wave steepness also increases, and the waves become more non-linear. This is because the viscous forces resisting the motion of the water become less significant as the wave amplitude increases, allowing the waves to grow in amplitude and steepness.

The Stokes drift velocity, which is the velocity of the fluid parcels in the wave, is also affected by the wave steepness. As the wave steepness increases, the Stokes drift velocity decreases, and the fluid parcels begin to move more slowly. This is because the increased wave steepness results in a larger gradient in the velocity potential, which in turn leads to a smaller Stokes drift velocity.

In shallow water, the wave steepness is limited by the depth of the water. As the water depth decreases, the wave steepness increases, and the waves become more prone to breaking. This is because the decreased water depth reduces the amount of water available to support the wave, causing the wave to become more unstable and prone to breaking.

In addition to the wave steepness, the wave height is also affected by the ambient current. As the ambient current increases, the wave height also increases, due to the Doppler shift. This is because the increased current causes the wave crests to move faster, resulting in a higher wave height. However, if the ambient current opposes the waves, the wave height can actually decrease, due to the dissipative effects of the current on the wave energy.

In summary, the wave steepness is a fundamental parameter in the study of ocean waves, and it is directly proportional to the non-linearity of the waves. The wave steepness is affected by the balance between the gravitational force and the viscous forces resisting the motion of the water, as well as by the ambient current. In shallow water, the wave steepness is limited by the depth of the water, and the waves become more prone to breaking as the wave steepness increases.
r1: A Stokes wave is a nonlinear and periodic surface wave. The ratio of a wave's height and length is called wave steepness. The theory used to describe wave steepness is the airy wave theory.
r2: In fluid dynamics, a Stokes wave is a nonlinear and periodic surface wave on an inviscid fluid layer of constant mean depth. The ratio of a wave's height and length is called wave steepness. Airy wave theory describes the ratio of a wave's height and length.

a: Most star formation in the Milky Way occurs in the Scutum-Centaurus arm, which is one of the two major spiral arms of the galaxy. This is based on observations of the distribution of red giants, which are more abundant in this arm compared to the other arm, the Carina-Sagittarius arm. Additionally, surveys of near-infrared light have detected an overabundance of red giants in the Scutum-Centaurus arm, but not in the Carina-Sagittarius arm. This suggests that the Scutum-Centaurus arm is more active in terms of star formation compared to the other arm. Furthermore, the distribution of young stars and star-forming regions in the Milky Way matches the four-arm spiral description of the galaxy, indicating that the galaxy has four spiral arms in total, with two traced by old stars and two traced by gas and young stars. The Scutum-Centaurus arm is the most prominent arm in terms of star formation activity, and it is where most of the star formation in the Milky Way takes place.

0.28181817820826455
a: The Treaty of Versailles was signed by Germany on June 28, 1919, marking the end of World War I and the beginning of a new era of international relations. The treaty was signed by Hermann Müller and Johannes Bell, representatives of the German government, after the National Assembly voted in favor of signing the treaty by a margin of 237 to 138. The treaty was the result of six months of negotiations at the Paris Peace Conference, and it imposed significant penalties on Germany, including territorial concessions, reparations, and disarmament.

The signing of the Treaty of Versailles was a controversial event, with conservatives, nationalists, and ex-military leaders in Germany condemning the treaty as an unfair surrender to the Allied powers. These groups believed that the treaty betrayed the sacrifices made by German soldiers during the war and would weaken Germany's position in the world. In contrast, politicians of the Weimar Republic, socialists, communists, and Jews were seen as having played a role in selling out Germany to its enemies.

The treaty's Article 231, known as the War Guilt clause, was particularly contentious, as it required Germany to accept responsibility for causing all the loss and damage during the war. This provision was seen as a way for the Allied powers to shift the blame for the war onto Germany and to justify the harsh penalties imposed by the treaty. The treaty also required Germany to make significant territorial concessions, including the loss of Alsace-Lorraine to France and the dissolution of the German Empire.

Despite the controversy surrounding the treaty, it was ratified by the National Assembly on July 9, 1919, by a vote of 209 to 116. The treaty marked the end of Germany's role as a major world power and set the stage for the rise of the Weimar Republic, which struggled to come to terms with the terms of the treaty and the political and economic instability that followed. The Treaty of Versailles remains a significant event in modern history, as it marked the end of World War I and set the stage for the rise of new political and economic order in Europe and the world.
r1: Johannes Bell was the Colonial Minister who signed the Treaty of Versailles. The treaty was the most important of the peace treaties that help end World War 1. Hermann Müller was the Foreign Minister. Both Bell and Müller are from Germany.
r2: The Treaty of Versailles was the most important of the peace treaties that brought World War I to an end. The Treaty ended the state of war between Germany and the Allied Powers. Foreign minister Hermann Müller and colonial minister Johannes Bell travelled to Versailles to sign the treaty on behalf of Germany. The treaty was signed on 28 June 1919 and ratified by the National Assembly on 9 July by a vote of 209 to 116.
============================279=============================

a: The Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics were produced in 1992 by the Computer Ethics Institute, as introduced in the paper "In Pursuit of a 'Ten Commandments' for Computer Ethics" by Ramon C. Barquin. The commandments were created as a means to establish a set of standards for the ethical use of computers, building upon the Internet Advisory Board's memo on ethics from 1987. The Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics are notable for their archaic style, modeled after the Ten Commandments from the King James Bible. While they have been widely quoted in computer ethics literature, they have also been subject to criticism from both the hacker community and some academics. Dr. Ben Fairweather of the Centre for Computing and Social Responsibility has described them as "simplistic" and overly restrictive, while ISC2, a thought leader in the information security industry, has incorporated the commandments into its own ethics rules. Despite these criticisms, the Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics remain an influential framework for ethical computing practices.

a: The implantation of the fertilized ovum usually occurs in the uterus, specifically in the endometrium, which is the lining of the uterus. During the early stages of development, the fertilized egg, now called a zygote, undergoes several cell divisions and grows into a ball of cells called a blastocyst. Around 10 days after fertilization, the blastocyst implants itself into the endometrium, where it begins to receive nutrients and support from the mother's body. The endometrium is prepared for implantation through a process called decidualization, which involves the thickening and changing of the endometrial lining to create a suitable environment for the developing embryo.

The timing of implantation is critical, as the endometrium is only receptive to implantation during a specific window of time, known as the implantation window. This window is typically around day 10-12 after fertilization, and it is important to time the transfer of the embryo to the uterus accordingly to maximize the chances of successful implantation.

In the case of frozen embryo transfer, the endometrium must be prepared before the transfer to ensure that it is receptive to the implanting embryo. This can be done through hormonal preparation, such as estrogen and progesterone, to thicken and ready the endometrium for implantation. The timing of hormonal preparation is critical, as the endometrium is only receptive for a limited time period, and the embryo must be transferred during this window to maximize the chances of successful implantation.

In summary, the implantation of the fertilized ovum usually occurs in the uterus, specifically in the endometrium, and the timing of implantation is critical to ensure successful implantation. The endometrium is prepared for implantation through decidualization, and hormonal preparation can be used to ensure that the endometrium is receptive to the implanting embryo in the case of frozen embryo transfer.
r1: The implantation of a fertilized ovum occurs in the uterine lining. The fundus in the uterus is where in the human body a fertilized ovum is usually implanted, and a female is considered to be pregnant.
r2: The fertilized female reproductive cell, called an egg cell or ovum, is implanted in the uterine lining of a portion of the uterus called the fundus. The fundus is the uppermost rounded portion of the uterus, one of four anatomical portions of the uterus, including the fundus, the corpus, the cervix, and the cervical canal.

a: Florida stopped using the electric chair in 2000, following a series of high-profile executions in the 1990s that raised concerns about the method's reliability and humaneness. During Bob Butterworth's tenure as Attorney General, the state experienced several instances of malfunctions in the electric chair, including the notorious cases of Jesse Tafero, Pedro Medina, and Allen Lee Davis. These executions were marred by flames shooting out of the prisoners' heads, leading to questions about whether the method constituted cruel and unusual punishment. In response to these incidents, Butterworth commented that those who commit murder in Florida may face issues with the electric chair. In 2000, the state legislature voted to replace the electric chair with lethal injection, which was deemed a more humane and reliable method of execution. This change was made in response to the public's growing unease with the electric chair and the mounting evidence of its fallibility. Today, lethal injection is the sole method of execution in Florida, and the state has not carried out an execution by electric chair since 2000.

a: When do they stop selling beer in Wisconsin?

Wisconsin's alcohol laws have a rich history, with restrictions and regulations dating back to the state's early years. While the state has relaxed some of its laws over time, there are still limitations on when and where alcohol can be sold.

Prior to Prohibition, Wisconsin had relatively lax alcohol laws. However, with the passage of the 18th Amendment in 1919, the state banned the manufacture, sale, and transportation of alcohol. Prohibition lasted until 1933, when the 21st Amendment repealed it.

After Prohibition, Wisconsin's alcohol laws underwent significant changes. In 1926, voters approved a referendum allowing the manufacture of beer, and in 1929, the state repealed its law enforcing Prohibition. However, the state still prohibits the retail sale of liquor and wine between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and beer between midnight and 6:00 a.m.

Local municipalities in Wisconsin also have the power to restrict or ban the retail sale of alcohol. For example, the city of Sparta and the village of Ephraim previously banned the retail sale of alcohol, but voters in Sparta narrowly passed a referendum in 2014 to allow the sale of beer and wine in groceries and convenience stores. Ephraim voters passed a similar referendum in 2016 to allow the sale of beer and wine in restaurants and businesses.

In summary, the sale of beer in Wisconsin is allowed, but there are restrictions on the hours of sale and local municipalities may have additional regulations or bans in place. The state's alcohol laws have evolved over time, reflecting changing attitudes towards alcohol consumption and the influence of local communities.
r1: On January 17, 1920, Wisconsin stopped selling beer due to Prohibition. After Prohibition ended, beer is to be not sold after midnight.
r2: Prohibition in the United States was a nationwide constitutional ban on the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages from 1920 to 1933. Prohibition began on January 17, 1920, when the Volstead Act went into effect. Wisconsin state law prohibits retail sale of liquor and wine between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and beer between midnight and 6:00 a.m. In Wisconsin they stop selling beer at midnight each day.

a: The programmer of MS-DOS was Tim Paterson, an American computer programmer who created 86-DOS, an operating system for the Intel 8086 processor. 86-DOS was later developed into MS-DOS, which became the most widely used personal computer operating system in the 1980s. Paterson was educated in the Seattle Public Schools and graduated from the University of Washington with a degree in Computer Science in 1978. He went on to work for Seattle Computer Products, where he designed the hardware for Microsoft's Z-80 SoftCard and later the S-100 8086 board. Without a true operating system for the board, sales were slow, but Paterson's 86-DOS, which emulated the API of CP/M, was later adopted by IBM as PC DOS 1.0 and became the standard operating system for IBM PC compatible personal computers. Over time, MS-DOS went through eight versions, until development ceased in 2000, and was gradually replaced by graphical user interface (GUI) operating systems such as Microsoft Windows.
r1: The programmer of 86-DOS, the basis of the MS-DOS operating system, was Tim Paterson. MS-DOS is the acronym for Microsoft Disk Operating System.
r2: The MS-DOS operating system had several programmers. The company Microsoft, a multinational technology corporation, was the programmer of MS-DOS itself. American computer programmer Tim Paterson was the programmer of 86-DOS, an operating system for the Intel 8086 which later formed the basis of MS-DOS.

Samsung launched its first smart TV with Tizen in 2012, and has since integrated the OS into many of its smart devices. The Tizen operating system is designed to provide a seamless and intuitive user experience, with features such as voice control, motion control, and built-in apps for streaming content and accessing online services. Samsung's adoption of Tizen has helped to drive the growth of the smart TV market, and the company has become a major player in the smart home devices market.

a: The first voyage to circumnavigate the globe was led by Ferdinand Magellan, a Portuguese explorer, between 1519 and 1522. The expedition, known as the Magellan-Elcano circumnavigation, was commissioned by the Spanish crown to find a maritime route from Spain to East Asia through the Americas and the Pacific Ocean. The journey began in Seville, Spain, with five ships and 270 men, including Magellan as the captain general. The fleet crossed the Atlantic Ocean and wintered in South America before navigating the Strait of Magellan, which was discovered by the expedition, and entering the Pacific Ocean. The journey continued with the discovery of several islands, including Guam, before arriving in the Philippines.

After Magellan's death in the Philippines, the expedition was led by Juan Sebastian Elcano, a Basque navigator, who successfully completed the circumnavigation and returned to Spain in 1522. The Magellan-Elcano circumnavigation was a groundbreaking achievement that marked the first time in human history that a single expedition had circumnavigated the globe. The journey not only opened up new trade routes between Europe and Asia but also provided valuable knowledge of the world's oceans, geography, and cultures. The expedition's success paved the way for future explorations and established Spain as a major maritime power during the Age of Exploration.
r1: Ferdinand Magellan's Spanish expedition was the first to successfully circumnavigate the globe. Magellan led the voyage in 1519, but was killed in 1521. After his death, the voyage was completed under the leadership of Juan Sebastián Elcano, returning to Sanlúcar de Barrameda, Spain, on 6 September 1522.
r2: Ferdinand Magellan was leading the first voyage to circumnavigate the globe at the voyage's start, but Juan Sebastián Elcano was leading at its end. Magellan died in the Philippines at the hands of the natives in 1521, and, following several other short-lived leaderships, Elcano took command of the expedition to finally reach the Spice Islands. Elcano then decided to return to Spain across the Indian Ocean and up the Atlantic Ocean, resulting in the first circumnavigation of the world in 1522.

a: The federal student loan program in the United States has a long and complex history, with various legislative changes and updates over the years. The program was first introduced in 1958 under the National Defense Education Act (NDEA), which provided government-backed loans to students studying specific fields such as engineering, science, and education. The program was later expanded in the 1960s under the Higher Education Act of 1965, which aimed to encourage greater social mobility and equality of opportunity. The Act increased federal funding for universities, created scholarships, and provided low-interest loans for students.

In 1992, the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act eliminated guaranteed loans, which were seen as benefiting private student loan companies at the expense of taxpayers, and replaced them with the Federal Direct Loan Program. This program provides low-interest loans directly to students and parents, rather than through private lenders, and is now the sole government-backed loan program in the United States.

The Federal Direct Loan Program has seen significant funding increases over the years, with funding for new direct loans increasing from $12.6 billion in 2005 to $17.8 billion in 2008. Today, student loans are available for any college-related expenses, including tuition, room and board, books, computers, and transportation expenses. However, an unusual provision in the law prohibits student loans from being discharged through bankruptcy.

In summary, the federal student loan program in the United States has evolved over the years to provide low-interest loans directly to students and parents, with the goal of increasing access to higher education and reducing financial barriers. The program has undergone significant changes and updates, including the elimination of guaranteed loans and the expansion of the Federal Direct Loan Program. Today, student loans are a vital source of financial aid for millions of students and families seeking to pursue higher education.
r1: United States Government-backed student loans were first offered in 1958 under the National Defense Education Act (NDEA). However, they were only available to select categories of students, such as those studying engineering, science or education degrees. The Higher Education Act of 1965 was signed into law on November 8, 1965. It increased federal money given to universities, created scholarships, and gave low-interest loans to students, which gave greater college access to women and minorities. In 1992, the Federal Direct Student Loan Program started. This was an attempt to give universal access to education loans by creating an "unsubsidized" version of the loans. Loans were available to any student, regardless of whether the financial aid formulas determined that they had unmet need.
r2: Student loans are a form of financial aid used to help students access higher education. The United States Government started to offer student loans in 1958. On November 8, 1965 the federal low-interest student loan program began, with The Higher Education Act of 1965, as part of President Lyndon Johnson's Great Society domestic agenda, and in 1992 President George H. W. Bush authorized a pilot version of the Direct Loan program, by signing into law the 1992 Reauthorization of the Higher Education Act of 1965.

0.3883495100457159
a: To change a lead atom into a gold atom, a process known as nuclear transmutation would be required. Nuclear transmutation involves the conversion of one chemical element into another through changes to the nucleus of the atom, specifically by adding or removing protons or neutrons. However, this process is not a simple task and requires a significant amount of energy to achieve.

In nature, nuclear transmutation occurs through stellar nucleosynthesis, where stars fuse elements together to create heavier elements. This process can create elements up to iron, but elements heavier than iron require more energy to produce and are not feasible for stars to create. Therefore, the transmutation of lead into gold is not possible through natural processes.

In laboratory settings, nuclear transmutation has been achieved through nuclear reactions and radioactive decay. However, these processes are highly complex and expensive, and the energy required to transmutate lead into gold far exceeds any potential gain. For example, Glenn Seaborg was able to produce several thousand atoms of gold from bismuth through a complex process involving neutron capture and beta decay, but at a net loss.

Therefore, it is not currently possible to change lead into gold through nuclear transmutation, and any attempts to do so would be highly unlikely to be cost-effective or practical. The abundance of gold in the universe is largely due to the natural processes of stellar nucleosynthesis, and the idea of transmuting lead into gold through alchemical means remains a myth.
r1: There is more than one way to turn lead into gold. One of those ways is with a process called nuclear transmutation, by which one chemical element or an isotope is converted into another chemical element. This is an expensive process that exceeds what could be gained from selling the converted gold. And easier and cheaper way is via neutron capture and beta decay. Essentially, the conversion is achieved by leaving lead in a nuclear reactor for a long period of time.
r2: There are two different processes that can potentially change a lead atom into a gold atom. One process is nuclear transmutation, which is when the amount of protons or neutrons in an atom is changed. This changes the element because elements are defined by their number of protons and neutrons in its atom. While transmutation has successfully been used to turn lead into gold, it is far too expensive to provide any tangible benefit. The easier process to change lead to gold is neutron capture and beta decay, which is the process of one or more neutrons and a nucleus collide and merge to form a heavier nucleus.

The album "Eye in the Sky" was the last platinum record in the United States from the band, and it is reportedly their best-selling album. a: McCrory's, a chain of five and dime stores, went out of business in 2002 after a long history dating back to 1882. The company was founded by John Graham McCrorey in Scottdale, Pennsylvania, and it grew to operate over 1,300 stores across the United States by 1989. However, the company faced financial difficulties in the 1990s and filed for bankruptcy in 1992. It closed 300 stores in 1997 and converted some remaining stores to its Dollar Zone format, but these closed in early 2002. In December 2001, McCrory Stores announced that the remaining stores would begin liquidating, and by February 2002, the company had ceased operation.

The history of McCrory's can be traced back to the early 1900s when John Graham McCrorey founded the first store in Scottdale, Pennsylvania. The chain grew rapidly, and by 1925, it had over 180 stores across the eastern and southern United States. The company was known for its thrifty nature, and its stores typically sold a wide range of items, including shoes, clothing, housewares, fabrics, penny candy, toys, cosmetics, and often included a lunch counter or snack bar. McCrory's also exclusively sold Oriole Records, a popular 'dime store label' from 1921 to 1938.

However, the company faced financial difficulties in the 1930s, and it declared bankruptcy in 1933. The company was re-established as McCrory Stores and resumed operations, but it never fully recovered from the effects of the Great Depression. In the 1980s, the company purchased the remaining Kresge and Jupiter stores from the Kmart Corporation, which had long given up on the variety store division. This move reunited the companies and led to the conversion of all stores to the McCrory banner.

Despite this effort, McCrory's continued to face financial challenges, and by the 1990s, the company was struggling to compete with larger retailers like Walmart and Target. In 1992, the company filed for bankruptcy and closed over 300 stores. It converted some remaining stores to its Dollar Zone format, but these closed in early 2002. In December 2001, McCrory Stores announced that the remaining stores would begin liquidating, and by February 2002, the company had ceased operation.

Overall, McCrory's struggled to adapt to changing consumer preferences and the rise of larger retailers, leading to its eventual demise in 2002. The chain's legacy lives on, however, as a reminder of the importance of adapting to changing market conditions and the impact of economic downturns on even the most successful businesses.

However, they had to file for bankruptcy again in 1992 due to the changing retail landscape. Superstores such as Target and Walmart took the shoppers who once frequented the five and dime stores. The company finally had to close its doors in February 2002.

Lake Moke, located near the suburb of Closeburn in Queenstown, is a popular recreation spot known for its boating, camping, horseback riding, and swimming opportunities. The lake's tranquil atmosphere and breathtaking scenery made it an ideal location for the series, particularly for the scenes set in the women's commune. The track that encircles the lake also provided a convenient path for filmmakers to access the area.

The song sets the scene for the climactic sharpshooting contest between the two characters and showcases their growing romantic tension.

The lyrics of the song are notable for their witty and lighthearted banter, with each character attempting to one-up the other in increasingly impressive feats, such as singing softer, higher, sweeter, and holding a note for longer. However, despite their boasts, neither character can claim to be able to bake a pie, a humorous touch that adds to the playfulness of the scene.

Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, is currently sixth in line to the throne. It is worth noting that under the Perth Agreement, which came into effect in 2015, only the first six in line to the throne require the sovereign's consent before they marry, and without such consent, they and their children would be disqualified from succession.

It is also worth mentioning that, as Princess consort, the wife of a sovereign prince is accorded an official title or informal designation, and the term is only capitalized when the title is borne officially. Currently, there are two sovereign princesses consort in Europe: Marie, Princess of Liechtenstein and Charlene, Princess of Monaco. a: The United Kingdom conducts a census every ten years, with the most recent one taking place in 2011. This is in line with the tradition of conducting a census every ten years since 1801, with the exceptions of 1941 during World War II and Ireland in 1921. The census provides detailed information about the national demographics and plays an important role in the allocation of resources to regional and local service providers by both the UK and European Union governments. The results of the census are also used for other purposes such as urban and regional planning, education, and healthcare.

The history of the census in the UK can be traced back to Roman times, with tax assessments being made in Britain, but detailed records have not survived. In the 7th century, Dál Riata conducted a census, known as the "Tradition of the Men of Alba." England conducted its first formal census in 1086 under William the Conqueror for tax purposes. The modern national decennial censuses of the general population started in 1801, championed by the statistician John Rickman. The census has been an important tool for understanding the demographic changes and trends in the UK, and has played a significant role in shaping policies and resource allocation decisions.
r1: The UK has taken a census since 1801, except for a few years during war or other extenuating circumstances. The census in the United Kingdom is decennial, that is, held every 10 years, although there is provision in the Census Act 1920 for a census to take place at intervals of every 5 years or more. There have only been two occasions where the census has not been decennial: There was no census in 1941 due to the Second World War; and a mini-census using a ten percent sample of the population was conducted on 24 April 1966.
r2: In the UK, the census is normally done every 10 years. However, according to the Census act of 1920, the census could be take place every 5 years.

a: In 1830, the ruler of France was Louis Philippe I, who ascended to the throne after his cousin Charles X was forced to abdicate during the July Revolution. Louis Philippe was born on October 6, 1773, as the son of Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans, who had supported the French Revolution but later fled the country after the execution of his cousin King Louis XVI. Louis Philippe spent 21 years in exile before returning to France during the Bourbon Restoration. He was proclaimed king on August 9, 1830, and his reign, known as the July Monarchy, was marked by conservative policies and close ties with Britain. He also sponsored colonial expansion, particularly the French conquest of Algeria. However, his popularity declined in 1847 as economic conditions in France deteriorated, and he was forced to abdicate after the outbreak of the French Revolution of 1848. He lived out the rest of his life in exile in the United Kingdom.

Louis Philippe's ascension to the throne was the result of a complex series of events, including the abdication of his cousin Charles X and the July Revolution. Charles X, who had succeeded his brother Louis XVIII as king in 1824, was a conservative who opposed the principles of the French Revolution and sought to reverse many of the reforms that had been implemented during the Revolution. This led to widespread discontent and eventually to the July Revolution, which forced Charles X to abdicate and flee to exile. Louis Philippe, who was supported by wealthy industrialists and bankers, was chosen as the new king due to his liberal leanings and his reputation as a moderate.

Despite his initial popularity, Louis Philippe's reign was marked by political and economic instability. His policies, which were influenced by the French statesman François Guizot, were seen as too conservative by many, and his support for colonial expansion and the French conquest of Algeria was controversial. Additionally, the economic downturn of 1847 and the subsequent revolution of 1848 further eroded his popularity, leading to his abdication and exile.

Overall, Louis Philippe's reign was marked by a complex set of political and social factors that ultimately led to his downfall. His legacy is still debated among historians, with some viewing him as a progressive and modernizing force, while others see him as a conservative who failed to address the social and economic problems of his time.
r1: Charles Philippe was the King of France from September 16, 1825, until August 2, 1830. After him, his cousin, Louis-Philippe, I reigned from August 9, 1830, until he was overthrown in 1848.
r2: Charles X (born Charles Philippe, Count of Artois) was King of France from 16 September 1824 until 2 August 1830. His reign of almost six years proved to be deeply unpopular from the moment of his coronation in 1825. France faced urban riots which led to the July Revolution of 1830, which resulted in his abdication and the election of Louis-Philippe I as King of the French. Louis-Philippe was sworn in as King Louis-Philippe I on 9 August 1830. Linking the monarchy to a people instead of a territory was aimed at undercutting the legitimist claims of Charles X and his family.

a: The last woolly mammoths died out approximately 10,000 years ago, during the late Pleistocene and early Holocene periods. This is evident from the fact that the species coexisted with early humans, who used its bones and tusks for various purposes, and the remains of butchered mammoths have been found in several locations. However, the exact cause of their extinction is still a topic of debate among scientists. Some believe that hunting by humans, which was likely intensified as the mammoth population declined, was the primary factor, while others argue that climate change and the subsequent shrinkage of the mammoth's habitat were the main causes.

It is worth noting that different woolly mammoth populations did not die out simultaneously across their range, but rather gradually became extinct over time. Isolated populations survived on remote islands such as St. Paul Island and Wrangel Island for a longer period, with the last ones disappearing around 5,600 and 4,000 years ago, respectively.

The woolly mammoth was a remarkable creature, with a distinctive coat of fur, long curved tusks, and a diet of mainly grasses and sedges. It shared many behavioral characteristics with modern elephants, and its intelligence and social structure were likely similar as well. The mammoth's habitat was the mammoth steppe, a vast expanse of grasslands that stretched across northern Eurasia and North America.

Despite their extinction, the woolly mammoths have left a lasting legacy, with their ivory being used for art, tools, and dwellings by early humans, and the tradition of using mammoth ivory continues to this day. The study of woolly mammoths has also provided valuable insights into the Earth's climate history and the evolution of large mammals, and their extinction serves as a reminder of the delicate balance of ecosystems and the impact of human activities on the natural world.
r1: Most woolly mammoth populations disappeared from its mainland range (across northern Eurasia and North America) between the late Pleistocene and early Holocene periods 10,000 years ago. Isolated populations survived on St. Paul Island until 5,600 years ago and on Wrangel Island until 4,000 years ago.
r2: Most wooly mammoth populations disappeared over a period of several thousand years, but some survived well after, while mainland and island populations became extinct at different times. Most populations disappeared between 14,000 and 10,000 years ago during the Late Pleistocene and early Holocene. The last mainland population existed in Siberia 9,650 years ago, while a small population survived on St. Paul Island in Alaska until around 5,600 BP, or years before present. The last known population remained on Wrangel Island in the Arctic Ocean until 4,000 years ago.

Regardless of its original function, the Bocca della Verità has become a symbol of truth and honesty, with visitors flocking to test their integrity.

Established as a national park in 1938, it was originally designated as a national monument by President Theodore Roosevelt in 1909. The park features three distinct ecosystems, including subalpine forest and wildflower meadows, temperate forest, and rugged Pacific coastline. The coastal region is characterized by rugged sandy beaches and dense forests, with native communities at the mouths of the Hoh and Quileute rivers. The park has been recognized for its unique biodiversity, designated as an International Biosphere Reserve in 1976 and a World Heritage Site in 1981. In addition, 95% of the park has been designated as the Olympic Wilderness, offering untouched wilderness areas for hiking and exploration. The Olympic Peninsula is also home to the Wild Olympics campaign, which aims to protect additional wilderness areas, salmon streams, and provide opportunities for the park to purchase land from willing sellers. a: The distinctive smell of vanilla comes from the fruit of the vanilla orchid plant, which is a seed capsule that ripens and dries, releasing the characteristic aroma as it crystallizes. The fruit contains tiny black seeds, and both the pod and the seeds are used in cooking. The smell of vanilla is a result of the presence of phenolic compounds, which are responsible for the aroma and flavor of the plant. The unique scent of vanilla is highly prized and widely used in the food and cosmetics industries, and is often used to enhance the flavor of other ingredients such as chocolate, custard, and caramel. However, the use of artificial vanilla-like flavorings and substitutes, such as methyl and ethyl vanillin, is common due to the high cost of true vanilla. These substitutes are often used in baked goods and other applications, but the flavor of natural vanilla is generally considered to be superior.
r1: Vanilla is a spice derived from orchids of the genus Vanilla, primarily obtained from pods of the Mexican species, flat-leaved vanilla. It is widely used aroma and flavor compound for foods, beverages and cosmetics. The chemicals that give off the aroma are called phenolic compounds. They are found in the fruit, a seed capsule, if left on the plant. The fruit ripens and opens at the end. As it dries, the phenolic compounds crystallize, giving the fruits a diamond-dusted appearance, and releases the distinctive vanilla smell.
r2: Vanilla is a spice derived from orchids of the genus Vanilla, primarily obtained from pods of the Mexican species, flat-leaved vanilla (V. planifolia). The fruit, a seed capsule, if left on the plant, ripens and opens at the end; as it dries, the phenolic compounds crystallize, giving the fruits a diamond-dusted appearance, which the French call "givre" (hoarfrost). It then releases the distinctive vanilla smell.

a: The idea of representative government can be traced back to ancient civilizations, such as Mesopotamia and India, where councils and assemblies existed to provide guidance to kings and other leaders. However, the modern concept of representative democracy as we know it today originated in the Western world during the Middle Ages. The Roman Republic, which was the first known government in the Western world to have a representative government, despite taking the form of a direct government in the Roman assemblies, was a significant influence on the development of representative democracy. The Roman model of governance, which held supreme power in the hands of the people and their elected representatives, inspired many political thinkers over the centuries.

In Europe, the concept of representative government evolved through the medieval tradition of selecting representatives from various estates to advise and control monarchs. This led to the development of parliamentary systems, with the first parliaments dating back to the 9th century in Iceland and the 12th century in León, Spain. However, it was not until the Dutch revolt in the 16th century that the modern concept of parliamentary government emerged, with the States General of the Netherlands taking over sovereign, legislative, and executive powers from the monarch.

The modern concept of representative democracy, as we know it today, developed in the Kingdom of Great Britain in the 18th century and in Sweden during the Age of Liberty. The idea of representative government was that the people would elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf, rather than having direct control over the government. This allowed for a more efficient and effective governance system, as the representatives could focus on the needs of the people and make decisions based on their best interests.

In conclusion, the idea of representative government has a long history, dating back to ancient civilizations, but the modern concept of representative democracy as we know it today originated in the Western world during the Middle Ages and evolved over time through the development of parliamentary systems. The Roman Republic and the Dutch revolt were significant influences on the development of representative democracy, and the idea of representative government has continued to evolve and adapt to the needs of societies over time.
r1: The first parliaments date back to the Middle Ages. In 930, the first assembly of the Alþingi was convened at Þingvellir in Iceland, becoming the earliest version of a formalized parliamentary system. The Roman Republic was the first known state in the western world to have a representative government, despite taking the form of a direct government in the Roman assemblies.
r2: The Roman Republic was the first known government in the western world to have a representative government, this model of governance inspired many political thinkers over the centuries, and today's modern representative democracies imitate it because supreme power was held by the people and their elected representatives, and which had an elected or nominated leader. Representative democracy is a form of democracy in which people vote for representatives who then vote on policy initiatives as opposed to a direct democracy, a form of democracy in which people vote on policy initiatives directly. On the other hand, the more recent version of the song was recorded by Jamie T in 2007, as part of his debut album "Panic Prevention." This version features a sample from the Inner Circle song "Sweat (A La La La La Long)" and was released as a single, reaching number 13 on the UK Singles Chart.

0.2631578911567261
a: The first foreigner to receive the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian award, was Mother Teresa, who was awarded the honor in 1980. Although the award is usually conferred on India-born citizens, Mother Teresa, a naturalized citizen of India, was recognized for her exceptional service to the country's poor and marginalized communities. She was followed by two other non-Indians, Pakistan national Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan and former South African President Nelson Mandela, who were awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1997 and 1998, respectively. These exceptions to the usual criteria highlight the extraordinary contributions made by these individuals to India and the world at large.

The Bharat Ratna, instituted in 1954, is conferred "in recognition of exceptional service/performance of the highest order" in any field of human endeavor, without distinction of race, occupation, position, or sex. The award is recommended by the Prime Minister to the President, with a maximum of three nominees being awarded per year. Recipients receive a Sanad signed by the President and a peepal-leaf-shaped medallion, but there is no monetary grant associated with the award.

Over the years, the Bharat Ratna has been bestowed upon 45 individuals, including 12 who were awarded posthumously. The original statutes did not provide for posthumous awards, but were amended in January 1955 to permit them. Former Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri became the first individual to be honored posthumously.

The Bharat Ratna, along with other personal civil honors, was briefly suspended from July 1977 to January 1980, during the change in the national government, and for a second time from August 1992 to December 1995, when several public-interest litigations challenged the constitutional validity of the awards. In 1992, the government's decision to confer the award posthumously on Subhas Chandra Bose was opposed by those who had refused to accept the fact of his death, including some members of his extended family. Following a 1997 Supreme Court decision, the press communiqué announcing Bose's award was cancelled, making it the only time when the award was announced but not conferred.

In conclusion, the Bharat Ratna is the highest civilian award of the Republic of India, and its recipients are chosen for their exceptional service/performance of the highest order in any field of human endeavor. While the award is usually conferred on India-born citizens, exceptions have been made for foreigners who have made extraordinary contributions to the country, such as Mother Teresa, Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, and Nelson Mandela. The award has been bestowed upon 45 individuals, including 12 who were awarded posthumously, and has been subject to temporary suspensions and controversies over the years.
r1: Instituted on 2 January 1954, the Bharat Ratna Award in India is given to those who have been an example of exceptional service/performance of the highest order, without distinction of race, occupation, position, or sex. There is no formal provision that recipients of the Bharat Ratna should be Indian citizens. However, it did take almost three decades for the award to go to a non-native recipient. The first non-Indian born person to get the award was Mother Teresa in 1980. In 1987 India awarded it to Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
r2: The Bharat Ratna is the highest civilian award of the Republic of India. There is no formal provision that recipients of the Bharat Ratna should be Indian citizens. It has been awarded to a naturalised Indian citizen, Mother Teresa in 1980, and to two non-Indians, Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan of Pakistan in 1987 and the former South African president Nelson Mandela in 1990.

a: According to the provided factoids, the philosophers Epicurus and Democritus, who lived in ancient Greece in the 4th and 5th centuries BCE, believed in the existence of atoms and the void as the fundamental constituents of reality. Epicurus, a student of Democritus, was less certain about the ability of atomism to explain specific natural phenomena such as earthquakes, lightning, comets, or the phases of the Moon. Despite this, he was convinced of the existence of atoms and the void, and his ideas were represented in the works of his follower Lucretius, who wrote "On the Nature of Things". Democritus, on the other hand, was a prolific writer who proposed that all matter was composed of small indivisible particles called atoms, and he believed that atoms were too small for human senses to detect, they were infinitely many, they come in infinitely many varieties, and that they had always existed.

The factoids highlight the contrast between atomism and substance theory, wherein a prime material continuum remains qualitatively invariant under division. Additionally, the factoids mention that Indian Buddhists, such as Dharmakirti, also developed distinctive theories of atomism, involving momentary (instantaneous) atoms that flash in and out of existence.

In summary, the factoids provide a comprehensive overview of the beliefs of Epicurus and Democritus regarding atoms and the void as the fundamental constituents of reality, and how their ideas were influenced by the broader philosophical and cultural context of ancient Greece. The factoids also highlight the significance of Democritus' contributions to the development of atomic theory and his influence on later scientific thought.
r1: The ancient Greek philosopher, Leucippus, is thought to have developed the theory of atomism—the idea that everything is composed entirely of various imperishable, indivisible elements called atoms. Democritus studied under Leucippus and is well known for his formulation of an atomic theory. Another philosopher of the time, was Epicurus. He was greatly influenced by Democritus. Together, the three proposed the earliest views on the shapes and connectivity of atoms.
r2: Several philosophers thought atoms and the void comprised all of reality. The Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher Democritus, a pupil of Leucippus, originally did. In the 5th century BCE, Democritus and his mentor, Leucippus, proposed that all matter was composed of small indivisible particles called atoms. As a student of Democritus, the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus also believed atoms and the void comprised all of reality.

0.3401360500717294
a: The name of the time zone for London is Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), also known as Western European Time (WET). This time zone is used in the United Kingdom and is based on the mean solar time at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London. Prior to the adoption of GMT, the United Kingdom used Local Mean Time (LMT), which varied by location. The use of GMT was first adopted by the Great Western Railway in 1840, and it gradually became the standard time for the entire country. In 1880, the Statutes (Definition of Time) Act legally established GMT as the standard time for the island of Great Britain. Ireland adopted GMT in 1916, supplanting Dublin Mean Time. The United Kingdom observes daylight saving time, also known as British Summer Time (BST), which is set forth in the Energy Policy Act of 2005. During daylight saving time, the time in the United Kingdom is one hour ahead of GMT. The time zone for London is part of the Eastern Time Zone, as defined by the Code of Federal Regulations, and is observed in sync with the United States, with localized exceptions.
r1: The United Kingdom, which includes London, uses Greenwich Mean Time (UTC±00:00 (GMT)) and British Summer Time (UTC+01:00 (BST)). Greenwich Mean Time was legally adopted throughout the island of Great Britain under the Statutes (Definition of Time) Act 1880. However, London, Ontario in Canada uses the Eastern Time Zone
r2: There are different time zones across the world. The United Kingdom uses Greenwich Mean Time or Western European Time, UTC±00:00 (GMT), and British Summer Time, UTC+01:00 (BST), or Western European Summer Time. Greenwich Mean Time was legally adopted throughout the island of Great Britain under the Statutes (Definition of Time) Act 1880. London, Ontario in Canada is in the Eastern Time Zone.
