0.19014084169733195
a: The first rocket to go into space was the V-2, which was developed by Wernher von Braun and was launched by Nazi Germany during World War II. However, the first man-made object to orbit the Earth was Sputnik 1, launched by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957, during the International Geophysical Year. Sputnik 1 was a small, beach-ball-sized satellite that weighed only 83 kg (184 lbs) and was equipped with a radio transmitter that beeped out a continuous signal at 20.005 and 40.002 MHz. It completed one orbit of the Earth every 96.2 minutes, reaching a maximum altitude of 255 km (158 miles) and a top speed of 29,000 km/h (18,000 mph).

The development of modern rockets can be traced back to the work of Konstantin Tsiolkovsky, a Russian engineer and mathematician who published a paper in 1903 titled "The Exploration of Cosmic Space by Means of Reaction Devices." Tsiolkovsky's work was not widely known outside of Russia at the time, but it influenced later pioneers of rocketry such as Robert H. Goddard and Hermann Oberth. Goddard, an American engineer, published a paper in 1919 titled "A Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes" that proposed the use of liquid fuel rockets to achieve high speeds and altitudes. He also proved in the laboratory that rockets could work in the vacuum of space, but his work was not taken seriously by the public.

The first crewed spacecraft to orbit the Earth was the Soviet Union's Vostok 1, which carried cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin into space in 1961. Gagarin's flight marked a major milestone in the Space Race between the Soviet Union and the United States, and it paved the way for future human spaceflight missions. The United States' first crewed spacecraft was the Freedom 7, which was launched in 1961 and carried astronaut Alan Shepard on a sub-orbital flight to an altitude of 187 km (116 miles).

Overall, the development of modern rockets and spacecraft has been a collaborative effort by scientists and engineers from around the world, with significant contributions from pioneers such as Tsiolkovsky, Goddard, Oberth, and von Braun. Their work has enabled humanity to explore the vastness of space and to achieve incredible feats such as sending humans to the Moon and establishing permanent human presence in space.
r1: The first object in human history to reach space was a rocket launched by the Third Reich during World War II in June 1944. The first manned rocket reached space on April 12, 1961.
r2: The first rocket reached space in June 1944. The V-2 rocket MW 18014 reaches an altitude of 176 km, becoming the first man-made object in space. The first manned rocket went into space on April 12, 1961. A Mercury capsule named Freedom 7 with Alan B. Shepard, spacecraft was launched by a Redstone rocket on a ballistic trajectory suborbital flight. It was the first human space mission that landed with pilot still in spacecraft, thus the first complete human spaceflight by FAI definitions.

Principal photography began on July 14, 1986, and took place over six weeks, with various locations used to capture the picturesque New England setting. The exterior of the Lenox Mansion was filmed at Castle Hill in Ipswich, while the main hall was recreated at the Wang Center in Boston. Other interiors were filmed at the Greystone Mansion in Beverly Hills, with sets built on the Warner Bros. backlot for the swimming pool and Daryl's library. To add a touch of authenticity, a small carving shop was commissioned to hand-carve all the wooden signs for the businesses in the film, including the newspaper where Michelle Pfeiffer's character worked, which was named "The Eastwick Word." a: The first cellular phone was demonstrated in 1973 by Motorola, with the first commercial automated cellular network (1G) analog launching in Japan in 1979. The first handheld mobile phone, the DynaTAC 8000X, was released in the US in 1983, but it was not until the launch of the second-generation (2G) digital cellular technology in Finland in 1991 that the industry saw widespread adoption. This sparked competition and innovation, leading to the development of third-generation (3G) technology in 2001, which offered higher data transfer speeds and capacity. However, as bandwidth-intensive applications such as streaming media became more popular, it became clear that 3G networks would soon be overwhelmed, leading to the development of fourth-generation (4G) technologies. Today, mobile phone subscriptions have grown to over seven billion worldwide, with smartphones representing 78% of total mobile phone sales. The advances in mobile telephony have been traced in successive "generations," starting with the early zeroth-generation (0G) services, and have led to the development of feature phones and the modern smartphones we use today.

The development of the first cellular phone was a collaborative effort between various countries and companies, with the first handheld mobile phone being demonstrated by Motorola in 1973. The first commercial automated cellular network (1G) analog was launched in Japan in 1979, and the first handheld mobile phone, the DynaTAC 8000X, was released in the US in 1983. However, it was not until the launch of the second-generation (2G) digital cellular technology in Finland in 1991 that the industry saw widespread adoption. This sparked competition and innovation, leading to the development of third-generation (3G) technology in 2001, which offered higher data transfer speeds and capacity.

The growth of mobile phone subscriptions has been exponential, with worldwide subscriptions growing to over seven billion by 2014, enough to provide one for every person on Earth. Today, smartphones represent 78% of total mobile phone sales, with the top smartphone developers worldwide being Samsung, Apple, and Huawei. The advances in mobile telephony have been traced in successive "generations," starting with the early zeroth-generation (0G) services, and have led to the development of feature phones and the modern smartphones we use today.

However, the development of mobile technology has not been without its challenges. The early analog cellular systems were unencrypted and vulnerable to eavesdropping, and the first handheld mobile phone, the DynaTAC 8000X, had a talk time of just thirty-five minutes and took ten hours to charge. Despite these challenges, consumer demand for mobile technology has been strong, with waiting lists for the first mobile phones reaching into the thousands. Today, mobile technology is an essential part of modern life, with smartphones offering a wide range of features and applications that have revolutionized the way we communicate, work, and live.

The song was first recorded and included on the band's independent album "The Worship Project" in 1999, but it gained mainstream success after being re-recorded and included on their major-label debut album "Almost There" in 2001. The song was released as the album's lead single in 2001 and gained significant airplay on Christian radio formats before crossing over to mainstream radio formats in 2003 and 2004. It peaked at number 5 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart and number 71 on the Hot 100 chart. The song's success led to a surge in sales for the album, which debuted at number 184 on the Billboard 200 chart and eventually reached the top ten on the Christian Albums chart and the Heatseekers Albums chart.

In contrast, "I Can Only Imagine" by French DJ David Guetta, featuring vocals from American singer Chris Brown and rapper Lil Wayne, is a completely different song with a different style and context. It was released as the sixth single from Guetta's fifth studio album "Nothing but the Beat" in 2012 and charted in the lower regions of the charts in several countries before its official release. The song was performed live for the first time at the 54th Grammy Awards and the music video was released later that year. The video features futuristic images and focuses more on the visual aspects of the song rather than a plot.

Overall, "I Can Only Imagine" by MercyMe is a powerful Christian ballad that has had significant success on Christian and mainstream radio formats, while "I Can Only Imagine" by David Guetta is a more upbeat and futuristic dance track that has had less mainstream success but has still been popular in certain music charts.

Cologna, the defending champion from Vancouver, was able to maintain his lead throughout the race, pulling away from the pack after the halfway mark and never looking back. Olsson and Richardsson had a close race for the silver and bronze medals, with Olsson eventually pulling ahead of Richardsson in the final stretch.

The race was started at 14:00 and was held at the Laura Biathlon & Ski Complex. The qualification period for the event began in July 2012, and athletes with a maximum of 100 FIS distance points were allowed to compete in both the sprint and distance events.

0.2513088961760917
a: Pax Romana, or the Roman Peace, refers to the prolonged period of relative stability and prosperity experienced by the Roman Empire from the accession of Caesar Augustus in 27 BC to the death of Marcus Aurelius in 180 AD. This period of approximately 206 years saw the Roman Empire reach its greatest territorial extent and a population of up to 70 million people, a third of the world's population at the time. The Pax Romana was a "miracle" in the sense that there had never been such a long period of peace in recorded history prior to this time. However, this peace was not without its challenges and the empire faced numerous internal conflicts and external threats during this period.

Despite the stability and prosperity brought about by the Pax Romana, the empire was not without its challenges. The reign of Commodus, who ruled from 180 to 192 AD, was marked by a period of dictatorial rule and the "Year of the Five Emperors," a time of political instability and conflict. This period marked the beginning of the decline of the Roman Empire, as described by historian Cassius Dio as a descent "from a kingdom of gold to one of iron and rust." The Pax Romana is a testament to the resilience and strength of the Roman Empire, but it also highlights the fragility of even the greatest empires and the challenges they face in maintaining stability and prosperity over extended periods of time.
r1: Pax Romana is Latin for "Roman Peace." It's used to describe the roughly 200-year-long period with sustained inner hegemonial peace and stability. This timespan of Roman history is identified as a period of increased as well as sustained Roman imperialism, order, prosperous stability, and expansion, despite a number of revolts, wars and continuing competition with Parthia. During this period of time, the Roman Empire achieved its greatest territorial extent and its population reached a maximum of up to 70 million people.
r2: The Pax Romana (Latin for "Roman Peace") is a roughly 200-year-long period with sustained inner hegemonial peace and stability. It is timespan of Roman history which is identified as a period and golden age of increased as well as sustained Roman imperialism, order, prosperous stability, hegemonial power and expansion, despite a number of revolts, wars and continuing competition with Parthia. During this period of approximately two centuries, the Roman Empire achieved its greatest territorial extent and its population reached a maximum of up to 70 million people.

0.14559386775649213
a: The Indian higher education system is the third largest in the world, with a vast network of universities, colleges, and institutions offering a wide range of courses and programs. However, despite its size and growth, the system still lags behind universities such as Harvard, Cambridge, and Oxford in terms of quality and standards. The main governing body at the tertiary level is the University Grants Commission (UGC), which enforces standards, advises the government, and coordinates between the center and the states. Accreditation for higher learning is overseen by 15 autonomous institutions established by the UGC.

India has 799 universities, including 44 central universities, 540 state universities, 122 deemed universities, 90 private universities, and 5 institutions established and functioning under the State Act. In addition, there are 39,071 colleges, including 1800 exclusive women's colleges, functioning under these universities and institutions. The system has expanded rapidly over the past decade, with the addition of nearly 20,000 colleges and more than 8 million students.

However, despite this growth, Indian higher education is in need of radical reforms. The system is plagued by issues such as lack of transparency, poor quality of education, and a focus on rote learning rather than critical thinking and innovation. The rise of IT sector and engineering education has boxed students into a linear path without giving them the opportunity to explore and discover their passions. Concerted and collaborative efforts are needed to broaden student choices through liberal arts education.

The history of higher education in India can be traced back to ancient times, with evidence of functioning learning centers as early as 1000 B.C. These centers were primarily concerned with dispersing Vedic education. The modern Indian education system finds its roots in the colonial legacy of the British Government, which used the university system as a tool of cultural colonization. The British East India Company set up the first institution of higher learning in 1781, followed by the Asiatic Society of Bengal, Benaras Sanskrit College, and Fort William College. With the Charter Act of 1813, the British Parliament officially declared Indian education as one of the duties of the state.

In conclusion, the Indian higher education system is the third largest in the world, with a vast network of universities, colleges, and institutions offering a wide range of courses and programs. However, the system still lags behind universities such as Harvard, Cambridge, and Oxford in terms of quality and standards. Radical reforms are needed to address issues such as lack of transparency, poor quality of education, and a focus on rote learning rather than critical thinking and innovation. By broadening student choices through liberal arts education and focusing on enforcing higher standards of transparency, strengthening the vocational and doctoral education pipeline, and professionalizing the sector through stronger institutional responsibility, India can reprioritize efforts and work around the complexities to provide a world-class education to its citizens.
r1: India's higher education system is the third largest in the world, after the United States and China. It's believed that Indian has ad a functioning system of higher education as early as 1000 B.C.
r2: India's higher education system is the third largest in the world, next to the United States and China.

0.30344827153008325
a: The British parliament is a bicameral legislative body consisting of three parts: the Sovereign (the Queen-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons. The House of Lords is made up of two types of members: Lords Spiritual and Lords Temporal. The Lords Spiritual are the most senior bishops of the Church of England, while the Lords Temporal are appointed by the Sovereign on the advice of the Prime Minister, and include hereditary peers and life peers. The House of Commons is the primary chamber of parliament and is made up of elected members. The Queen-in-Parliament, or the Crown-in-Parliament, refers to the Crown acting with the advice and consent of parliament, and is responsible for passing laws through the process of Royal Assent. The Palace of Westminster, located in central London, serves as the meeting place of both houses of parliament and is owned by the monarch in right of the Crown. The palace has a long history dating back to the 11th century and has been the primary residence of the Kings of England, the seat of the Royal Courts of Justice, and the site of the Parliament of England.
r1: The British Parliament is considered a bicameral government. However, it consists of 3 houses, the Monarch, the House of Lords, and the House of Commons. The Monarchy, or Crown-in-Parliament, has a legislative role, acting with the advice and consent of the parliament (including the lower house and upper house). The lower 2 houses meet at the Palace of Westminster to carry out legislative business.
r2: The Parliament of the United Kingdom is the supreme legislative body of the United Kingdom, the Crown dependencies and the British overseas territories. Parliament is bicameral but has 3 parts, consisting of the sovereign, otherwise known as Crown-in-Parliament or monarch, the House of Lords, and the House of Commons, which is the the primary chamber. British Parliament would consist of 2 parts if the monarch, or Crown-in -Parliament was not included.

0.2981366429304425
a: The name of the tower in which Big Ben is located is the Elizabeth Tower, previously known as the Clock Tower. This information can be found on the Wikipedia page for Big Ben, which states that the tower was renamed in 2012 to mark the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II. The renaming of the tower was done to honor the 60th anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's accession to the throne, which was celebrated throughout 2012 with commemorative events held throughout the Commonwealth of Nations. The Elizabeth Tower was designed by Augustus Pugin in a neo-gothic style and was completed in 1859. It stands tall, with a base that is square in shape, measuring on each side, and the climb from ground level to the belfry is 334 steps. The clock is the largest and most accurate four-faced striking and chiming clock in the world, with Big Ben being the largest of five bells and weighing over 13 tons. The origin of the bell's nickname, Big Ben, is open to question, with some attributing it to Sir Benjamin Hall, who oversaw its installation, while others believe it may be named after the heavyweight boxing champion Benjamin Caunt. The clock uses its original Victorian mechanism, but an electric motor can be used as a backup.
r1: Commonly referred to as Big Ben (in reference to the large clock it displays), the tower at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in England, was recently renamed Elizabeth Tower in 2012. It was formerly known just as the Clock Tower. The change in name was to mark the 60th anniversary, or the Diamond Jubilee, of Elizabeth II's accession to the throne.
r2: The original official name of the tower Big Ben is in was the Clock Tower, but it was renamed in 2012 to mark the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II, and its name has been Elizabeth Tower since 2012.

a: When did they start filming Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2?

Principal photography for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 began on February 17, 2016, with director James Gunn confirming that many of the crew members from the first film, including cinematographer Ben Davis and production designer Charles Wood, had signed on to work on the sequel. However, due to a late change in the production schedule for Doctor Strange, several crew members were unable to work on Vol. 2. The film was shot at Pinewood Atlanta, using all 18 stages available, which was an increase from the number of stages used for the first film. Gunn noted that the sequel required more sets than the first film, and he preferred to have practical sets to balance out the CGI elements. The sets included the Sovereign planet, the Ravager's main ship, and the Iron Lotus establishment on the "pleasure planet" of Contraxia. The film was also shot using an 8K resolution camera, the Red Weapon 8K.

The film's storyline picks up shortly after the events of the first film, exploring the characters' new roles as the Guardians and the storyline of Quill's father, which was established in the previous film. The film featured an all-star cast, including Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Dave Bautista, Vin Diesel, and Bradley Cooper, among others. The film was well-received by audiences and critics, grossing over $863 million worldwide and receiving praise for its visuals, soundtrack, humor, and cast. It also received a nomination for Best Visual Effects at the 90th Academy Awards. However, the sequel's production was put on hold after the firing of director James Gunn in 2018.
r1: There are currently two Guardians of the Galaxy movies, Vol. 1 and Vol. 2. A third one is expected in 2023. Filming of the first movie in the series took place on July 6, 2013 in London. Pre-shooting for Vol.2 started on February 11, 2016 in Georgia, and principle photography started on February 17, 2016.
r2: Guardians of the Galaxy, retroactively referred to as Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 1, is a 2014 American superhero film based on the Marvel Comics superhero team of the same name. Principal photography began around July 6, 2013 in London, United Kingdom. Pre-shooting for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2, the sequel to the 2014 Guardians of the Galaxy, began on February 11, 2016, at Pinewood Atlanta Studios in Fayette County, Georgia, and principal photography began on February 17, 2016.

0.2558139507105944
a: The United States purchased the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803, acquiring approximately 828,000 square miles of land west of the Mississippi River for $15 million. This significant expansion of American territory was made possible through the efforts of President Thomas Jefferson, who had long been interested in acquiring the territory for the United States. The purchase was facilitated by the Baring family, a prominent British banking dynasty, which helped to finance the transaction and underwrite the bonds issued by the U.S. government to pay France for the territory.

The purchase of the Louisiana Territory was not without controversy, as many Federalists opposed the move, fearing that it would lead to the creation of new Western states that would be dominated by Republican politics and dilute the power of New England Federalists. Additionally, the purchase was made at a time when the United States was already facing challenges from Great Britain and Native American tribes in the region.

Despite these challenges, the Louisiana Purchase marked a significant turning point in the history of the United States, as it effectively doubled the size of the country and provided new opportunities for westward expansion. The purchase also set the stage for the Lewis and Clark Expedition, which was established to explore and chart the newly acquired territory.

The Senate approved the treaty with a vote of 24 to 7, with the majority of Federalists opposing the purchase. However, President Jefferson and his Democratic-Republican Party were able to secure the necessary votes to ratify the treaty. On October 21, 1803, the Senate authorized Jefferson to take possession of the territory and establish a temporary military government.

The transfer of ownership of the territory from France to the United States took place on December 20, 1803, at the Cabildo in New Orleans, and was marked by a flag-raising ceremony. The U.S. military took control of the territory, and plans were put in place to establish a system of local government and explore the region.

Over time, the U.S. government built or expanded forts along the Mississippi and Missouri rivers, including Fort Bellefontaine, Fort Armstrong, Fort Edwards, Fort Crawford, Fort Snelling, and Fort Atkinson. These forts were used to protect American interests in the region and to maintain order.

In conclusion, the Louisiana Purchase was a significant event in American history that marked the beginning of the country's westward expansion and set the stage for the growth of the United States into a major world power. The purchase was facilitated by the Baring family and was marked by controversy and challenges, but ultimately it provided new opportunities for the United States and paved the way for the country's future growth and development.
r1: The Louisiana Territory was purchased by America in 1803 through the Louisiana Purchase Treaty between the U.S. and France. The treaty was signed on April 30, 1803 at the Hôtel Tubeuf in Paris. On October 21, 1803 the Senate authorized Jefferson to take possession of the territory and establish a temporary military government.
r2: The United States, under President Thomas Jefferson, acquired the Louisiana territory from France in 1803 through the Lousiana Purchase, with the treaty signing and taking of possession on different dates. The Louisiana Purchase Treaty was signed on April 30, 1803, by Robert Livingston, James Monroe, and François Barbé-Marbois. Later in the year, on October 21, 1803, the Senate authorized Jefferson to take possession of the Louisiana territory and establish a temporary military government.

0.23628691635884566
a: The first person to land a ratified quadruple jump in figure skating competition was Canadian Kurt Browning in 1988. However, the quadruple jump has become increasingly common among World and Olympic level men's single skaters to the point that not having one in a program is now seen as a severe handicap. The jump had become so common that it was viewed as a deciding element in a winning program, and the lack of it almost a handicap. In fact, many skaters attempted to include the quad in their skating arsenal to remain competitive. However, the quad controversy came to a head at the Vancouver Olympic Games when Jeffrey Buttle won the World Figure Skating Championships without a quad, disproving the long-standing notion that a quad was needed to win the big titles.

The difficulty of landing a quadruple jump is evident in the fact that only two women have successfully landed a ratified quad in competition, Miki Ando being the first in 2002. The precision and skill required for a quadruple jump are immense, as even the smallest error can make the difference between success and failure. As Max Aaron, a figure skater, stated, "The minute your left arm is behind you, or your three-turn is too fast, if your hips don't turn in time, if your foot isn't in the right place, anything will throw you off." The pressure to include a quad in a program has become so great that some skaters have resorted to using a jump harness in training to perfect the jump.

Despite the challenges of landing a quadruple jump, the jump has become an essential element in men's figure skating. The fact that only two skaters have won the World Figure Skating Championships without a quad in the past twelve years, and that Jeffrey Buttle's win at the 2008 Worlds disproved the notion that a quad was needed to win the big titles, highlights the importance of the quad in modern figure skating. The quest for perfection in the quadruple jump continues to drive skaters to push the limits of what is possible, and the jump remains a defining feature of elite figure skating competition.
r1: The first person known to land a quadruple jump in figure skating was Mark Cockerell, during his trainings in 1983. He decided not to attempt these jumps during his performances, though. The first ratified quadruple jump went to Kurt Browning in the 1988 World Championships. In 2002, Miki Ando became the first woman to land this jump. She remains one of only five women to have landed a ratified quadruple jump in international competition.
r2: Mark Cockerell and Kurt Browning landed the first quad jumps in figure skating, while Miki Ando was the first woman to do so. In 1983, Cockerell landed quads in training at the US National Sports Festival but decided not to try it during his performance. In 1988, Browning became the first person to land a ratified quadruple jump in competition, while in 2002 Ando became the first woman to do so.

a: The last episode of the popular 1950s sitcom "I Love Lucy" aired on May 6, 1957, after a successful run of six seasons and 180 half-hour episodes. The show, which starred Lucille Ball, Desi Arnaz, Vivian Vance, and William Frawley, followed the life of Lucy Ricardo, a middle-class housewife in New York City, and her schemes to mingle with her bandleader husband Ricky and their best friends, Fred and Ethel Mertz. The show was a groundbreaking success, becoming the most watched show in the United States in four of its six seasons and ending its run at the top of the Nielsen ratings.

After the series ended, a modified version of the show continued for three more seasons as "The Lucy–Desi Comedy Hour," with 13 one-hour specials airing from 1957 to 1960. These specials featured the same cast members and were produced by Desilu Productions, with a more relaxed production schedule that avoided the grind of a regular weekly series. The show was shot on 35 mm film in front of a studio audience and was the first scripted television program to do so.

"I Love Lucy" was a critical and commercial success, winning five Emmy Awards and receiving numerous nominations and honors. It is often regarded as one of the greatest and most influential sitcoms in history, and its legacy continues to be felt in the television industry today. In 2012, it was voted the "Best TV Show of All Time" in a survey conducted by ABC News and "People" magazine. The show's success can be attributed to its talented cast, clever writing, and innovative filming techniques, which helped to set it apart from other sitcoms of the time.

Despite the show's end in 1957, its popularity has endured, with episodes still being syndicated in dozens of languages around the world and attracting an estimated 40 million viewers each year. In 2013, a colorized version of the show's Christmas episode drew over 8 million viewers when it aired on CBS in prime time, 62 years after the show first premiered. The show's impact on television history and its continued popularity are a testament to the timeless appeal of its characters, writing, and humor.
r1: I Love Lucy was a popular American television sitcom starring Lucille Ball and her husband Desi Arnaz. It originally ran on CBS from October 15, 1951, to May 6, 1957. It still remains popular with American audiences today. A few months after its last show aired, the husband and wife, comedy duo created a spin-off show called, The Lucy–Desi Comedy Hour. The show is a collection of thirteen black-and-white one-hour specials airing occasionally from November 6, 1957, to April 1, 1960.

The song's success was a surprise to the band, and it has since become a classic of 70s pop music. The song's lyrics are a dismissive tale of a music industry cocktail party, written as a parody of Bob Dylan's paranoia. The song features a distinctive guitar solo played on a guitar played flat with an empty beer bottle used as a slide.

a: The end of Roman rule in Britain was a gradual process that occurred over several decades, marked by a series of political and military developments that ultimately led to the withdrawal of Roman troops and the establishment of post-Roman Britain. According to the wikipage "End of Roman rule in Britain," the transition began in 383 when the usurper Magnus Maximus withdrew troops from northern and western Britain, leaving local warlords in charge. This move was likely prompted by the need to address threats in other parts of the empire, such as the Visigoths' siege of Rome. The Romano-British later expelled the magistrates of the usurper Constantine III in response to his failures to protect the island, and Roman Emperor Honorius replied with the "Rescript of Honorius," effectively granting temporary self-government to Britain.

However, by the mid-6th century, the Roman Empire was unable to defend itself against external threats, and Britain was left to fend for itself. The situation was further complicated by the rise of the usurper Victor, who was elevated to "augustus" of the Western Roman Empire in either 383/384 or 387. Victor's father, Magnus Maximus, had previously risen up against the legitimate emperor Gratian and was recognized as the legitimate emperor in the west by Theodosius I. Victor's brief reign was marked by his father's invasion of Italy to depose Valentinian II, the brother and successor of the late Gratian. Theodosius eventually defeated Maximus and executed him, along with Victor, in 388.

The death of Victor and Maximus marked the end of Roman rule in Britain, as the empire was unable to recover from the internal rebellion and external threats that had weakened its defenses. The subsequent establishment of post-Roman Britain was characterized by the rise of local warlords and the emergence of new kingdoms, such as the Kingdom of Essex and the Kingdom of Kent. These kingdoms were eventually united under the Heptarchy, a group of seven Anglo-Saxon kingdoms that ruled Britain until the 10th century. Overall, the end of Roman rule in Britain was a complex and gradual process that was marked by political and military developments that ultimately led to the establishment of post-Roman Britain.
r1: Roman rule ended in different parts of Britain at different times, and under different circumstances. In 383, the usurper Magnus Maximus (Roman emperor in the western portion of the Empire from 383 to 388) withdrew troops from northern and western Britain. Then around 410, the Romano-Britains expelled the magistrates of the usurper Constantine III.
r2: The end of Roman rule in Britain was the transition from Roman Britain to post-Roman Britain. In 383, the usurper Magnus Maximus withdrew troops from northern and western Britain, probably leaving local warlords in charge. Around 410, the Romano-Britains expelled the magistrates of the usurper Constantine III, ostensibly in response to his failures to use the Roman garrison he had stripped from Britain to protect the island. By the early 5th century, the Roman Empire could no longer defend itself against either internal rebellion or the external threat posed by Germanic tribes expanding in Western Europe. This situation and its consequences governed the eventual permanent detachment of Britain from the rest of the Empire.

a: New York became a free state in 1827, after a long history of slavery dating back to 1626 when the Dutch West India Company brought enslaved Africans to New Amsterdam, present-day New York City. The state's gradual emancipation process began in 1799, with a law that freed children born to slave mothers, but required them to serve as indentured servants until their mid-twenties. Existing slaves were not freed until July 4, 1827, when the last 2,800 enslaved individuals were emancipated. This process was the result of efforts by the New York Manumission Society, founded in 1785, and other abolitionist groups, as well as the impact of the American Revolution and the subsequent Treaty of Paris, which ended the Revolutionary War.

During the Revolutionary War, Britain negotiated separate treaties with Spain, France, and the Dutch Republic, and Spain offered to relinquish its conquests in West Florida, Menorca, and the Bahamas in exchange for Gibraltar, but these terms were refused by Britain. Instead, Britain ceded East Florida, West Florida, and Menorca to Spain, and France gained the island of Tobago in the Caribbean and Senegal in Africa. The Treaty of Paris, signed in 1784, recognized American independence and established the boundaries of the new nation.

After the war, the US government constructed Fort Montgomery in upstate New York, but it was discovered that the border with Canada was not accurately surveyed, leading to the Webster-Ashburton Treaty in 1842, which resolved the issue by leaving the border on the meandering line as surveyed. Slavery continued to exist in New York until 1827, despite efforts by the New York Manumission Society and other abolitionist groups. Sojourner Truth, a famous abolitionist and former slave, was born in 1797 and held as a slave in the Hudson Valley until she escaped in 1826.

Overall, the history of New York's transition to a free state was shaped by a combination of factors, including the American Revolution, the Treaty of Paris, and the efforts of abolitionist groups like the New York Manumission Society. While slavery persisted in the state for many years after the Revolution, the gradual emancipation process and eventual abolition of slavery in 1827 marked an important milestone in the state's history.

In 1980, the Walk of Fame's creator, Johnny Grant, introduced a fee of $2,500 for each star, payable by the person or entity nominating the recipient. This fee was instituted to fund the Walk of Fame's upkeep and minimize the taxpayer burden. Over time, the fee has increased incrementally, reaching $15,000 in 2002 and $30,000 in 2012. As of 2017, the current fee is $40,000.

Grant's innovative approach to funding the Walk of Fame through nomination fees has had a significant impact on its success. By requiring recipients to personally attend their star's unveiling ceremony, Grant was able to generate publicity and encourage international press coverage. This helped to revitalize the Walk of Fame, which was struggling to recover from a period of decline in the 1970s.

Grant's contributions to the Walk of Fame extend beyond his role as creator and fundraiser. He was also a dedicated advocate for the Walk, hosting the majority of unveiling ceremonies during his tenure as chairman of the Selection Committee and Honorary Mayor of Hollywood. His unique special-category star, with its stylized "Great Seal of the City of Hollywood" emblem, is located at the entrance to the Dolby Theatre adjacent to Johnny Grant Way.

In conclusion, the fee for a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame has evolved over time, from $2,500 in 1980 to $40,000 in 2017. This fee, along with Grant's innovative approach to funding and promoting the Walk, has played a significant role in its success and enduring popularity.

0.30366491792001316
a: The clear and present danger test, which was established in the 1919 case of Schenck v. United States, was replaced in 1969 by the imminent lawless action test in the case of Brandenburg v. Ohio. The clear and present danger test was a standard used to determine the constitutionality of limits on First Amendment rights, and it was based on the idea that speech that posed a clear and present danger to society could be restricted. However, the test was criticized for being overly broad and vague, and it was replaced by the imminent lawless action test, which requires that speech must be likely to cause imminent lawless action in order to be restricted.

The imminent lawless action test refined the clear and present danger test by focusing on the likelihood of immediate harm, rather than the potential for future harm. This change in the legal standard was a response to concerns that the clear and present danger test was too broad and could be used to restrict a wide range of speech that was not actually harmful. The imminent lawless action test has been used in a number of cases since its introduction, and it has been interpreted to allow for the restriction of speech that is likely to cause immediate harm, such as inciting violence or causing a breach of the peace.

Despite the replacement of the clear and present danger test, the bad tendency test, which was rooted in English common law, remains a relevant legal standard in the United States. The bad tendency test permits speech to be outlawed if it has a tendency to harm public welfare. However, the Supreme Court has limited the application of the bad tendency test in recent years, and it is now primarily used in cases involving obscenity and defamation.

Overall, the evolution of the legal standard for restricting First Amendment rights has been shaped by changing societal values and concerns about the potential harm that speech can cause. The clear and present danger test was replaced by the imminent lawless action test in order to provide a more nuanced and balanced approach to regulating speech, and the bad tendency test remains a relevant standard in certain contexts.
r1: "Clear and present danger" was a test adopted by the Supreme Court to determine under what circumstances limits can be placed on First Amendment freedoms of speech, press, or assembly. The "clear and present danger" was replaced in 1969 by "Brandenburg v. Ohio", and the test refined to determining whether the speech would provoke an "imminent lawless action".
r2: Clear and present danger was a doctrine adopted by the Supreme Court of the United States to determine under what circumstances limits can be placed on First Amendment freedoms of speech, press, or assembly. The test was replaced in 1969 with Brandenburg v. Ohio's "imminent lawless action" test.

"I Can't Let Maggie Go" is a hit song by the British pop group Honeybus, which was released in early 1968. The song was written by the band's lead vocalist and keyboardist Pete Dello and became an international Top 20 hit, reaching number 13 in New Zealand, number 11 in Ireland, and number eight in the UK Singles Chart. The song was included on the group's later compilation LPs, "Honeybus at Their Best" and "Old Masters Hidden Treasures". The song has been covered by several artists, including J. Vincent Edwards in 1974 and the Sideburns in 1993. Most recently, David Essex included his own version on the 2005 compilation album, "The Complete Collection". The enduring appeal of "I Can't Let Maggie Go" is a testament to the timelessness of Honeybus's catchy and heartfelt songwriting.

a: During World War II, a total of 1,056,841 African American registrants were inducted into the United States armed forces through Selective Service, accounting for approximately 11% of all registrants liable for service. Of these, 141,294 African Americans were inducted during the period of July 1, 1944 - December 31, 1945, comprising 9.6% of all inductions. Despite making up a significant proportion of inductees, African Americans were disproportionately represented in certain branches of the military, with the Army being the primary branch where they served.

The Tuskegee Airmen, the 761st Tank Battalion, and the 452nd Anti-Aircraft Artillery Battalion were among the famous segregated units that proved their value in combat, leading to the desegregation of all U.S. armed forces by President Harry S. Truman's Executive Order 9981 in July 1948. Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. served as the commander of the Tuskegee Airmen during the war and later became the first African-American general in the United States Air Force. Other notable African American servicemen during World War II included Doris Miller, who was the first African-American recipient of the Navy Cross, and Samuel L. Gravely, Jr., who became the first African American to command a U.S. warship and the first to be an admiral.

The contributions of African American soldiers during World War II were significant and paved the way for future generations of African Americans in the military. Their bravery and sacrifice, despite facing discrimination and segregation, helped to break down racial barriers and prove the value of diversity in the armed forces. Today, their legacy continues to be celebrated and honored, serving as a reminder of the importance of equality and inclusivity in the military and society as a whole.

0.27118643705831663
a: The term that refers to linking a currency value to the value of gold is "gold standard." A gold standard is a monetary system in which a region's common medium of exchange is paper notes that are normally freely convertible into pre-set, fixed quantities of gold. The standard specifies how the gold backing would be implemented, including the amount of specie per currency unit. Under a gold standard, the currency itself has no "innate value," but is accepted by traders because it can be redeemed for the equivalent specie. This system is different from a fixed exchange rate, where a currency's value is fixed against the value of another single currency or a basket of currencies, but is not backed by gold.

The gold standard has been used in the past as a way to stabilize currency values and control inflation. For example, many countries in South America reverted to a gold standard in the later part of the 20th century as part of an attempt to control inflation. However, the gold standard has also been criticized for limiting the ability of governments to use domestic monetary policy to achieve macroeconomic stability. Under the Bretton Woods agreement, most countries around the world had currencies that were fixed to the U.S. dollar, which limited inflation in those countries but also exposed them to the danger of speculative attacks.

In conclusion, the gold standard is a monetary system that links a currency's value to the value of gold, and it has been used in the past as a way to stabilize currency values and control inflation. However, it has also been criticized for limiting the ability of governments to use domestic monetary policy to achieve macroeconomic stability.
r1: A fixed exchange rate, sometimes called a pegged exchange rate, is a type of exchange rate where a currency's value is fixed against the value of another currency, or another measure of value, such as gold. A "gold exchange standard" refers to when a government guarantees a fixed exchange rate, not to a specified amount of gold, but to the currency of another country that uses a gold standard.
r2: "Gold standard" is the term that refers to linking a currency's value to only the value of gold, while "fixed exchange rate" is the term that refers to linking it to the value of gold or to another currency or basket of currencies. A fixed exchange rate is also sometimes called a pegged exchange rate.
============================362=============================

The two musicians had originally met as background performers in a school musical production, and they soon began working together on their own material. Over the years, they honed their craft, writing a series of songs that eventually became the basis for their first musical, "Edges." 0.32804232435934044
a: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, which ended the Mexican-American War, took place on February 2, 1848, in Villa de Guadalupe Hidalgo, Mexico City. The treaty was signed between the United States and Mexico, and it had far-reaching consequences for both countries. The treaty called for the U.S. to pay $15 million to Mexico and to pay off the claims of American citizens against Mexico up to $5 million. Additionally, the treaty gave the U.S. ownership of California and a large area comprising roughly half of New Mexico, most of Arizona, Nevada, and Utah, and parts of Wyoming and Colorado. Mexicans in these annexed areas had the choice of relocating to within Mexico's new boundaries or receiving American citizenship with full civil rights. The treaty was ratified by the U.S. Senate by a vote of 38-14 on March 10, 1848, and by Mexico through a legislative vote of 51-34 and a Senate vote of 33-4 on May 19, 1848. The treaty was formally proclaimed on July 4, 1848. However, the U.S. would later ignore a protocol that was signed alongside the treaty, which confirmed the legitimacy of land grants pursuant to Mexican law. This protocol was signed by A. H. Sevier, Nathan Clifford, and Luis de la Rosa, and it was accepted by the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Mexican government. The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo had a profound impact on the geography and demographics of both countries, and it remains a significant event in the history of the United States and Mexico.
r1: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is the peace treaty signed on February 2, 1848, in the Villa de Guadalupe Hidalgo between the United States and Mexico that ended the Mexican–American War. The treaty came into force on July 4, 1848 and became effective on 30 May 1848.
r2: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is the peace treaty that was signed on February 2, 1848, in the Villa de Guadalupe Hidalgo (now a neighborhood of Mexico City) between the United States and Mexico that ended the Mexican–American War (1846–1848). The treaty was ratified by the United States on 10 March and by Mexico on 19 May. The ratifications were exchanged on 30 May 1848, and the treaty was proclaimed on July 4, 1848.

a: The New International Version (NIV) of the Bible was first published in 1978 by Biblica, with the New Testament released in 1973 and the full Bible in 1978. The project was initiated in 1956 by a small committee of biblical scholars from the Christian Reformed Church, the National Association of Evangelicals, and a group of international scholars. The initial "Committee on Bible Translation" consisted of 15 scholars representing various denominations, who worked from the oldest and most reliable manuscripts in Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek to produce a modern translation that was both accurate and easy to understand. The NIV underwent a minor revision in 1984 and a more significant update in 2011, which addressed translational issues with Paul's letters and modified some of the gender-neutral language of the previous version. Additionally, an "easy-reader" version called the New International Reader's Version (NIrV) was published in 1996, written at a third-grade reading level. The NIV has become one of the most popular and best-selling modern translations, with editions published by Zondervan in the United States and Hodder & Stoughton in the UK. In 1979, a Spanish version of the NIV was begun, based on the historic manuscripts and titled La Santa Biblia, Nueva Versión Internacional (NVI). A complete Spanish NVI Bible was published in 1999, following a translation from the historic manuscripts directly into Spanish bypassing English.
r1: The NIV version of the bible's has been written and published in multiple languages. The New Testament was released in 1973 and the full Bible in 1978. The complete version was published in Portuguese in 1993 and in Spanish in 1999. And an updated English version was published in 2011.
r2: The New International Version (NIV) began in 1956 with the formation of a small committee to study the value of producing a translation in the common language of the American people. The New Testament was released in 1973 and the full Bible was first published in 1978 by Biblica, formerly the International Bible Society. The NIV was written and published in Portuguese in 1993. A complete Spanish NIV Bible was produced in 1999. The newest English version was written and published in 2011.

0.3394495372948405
a: The capital of Virginia was moved from Williamsburg to Richmond in 1780, during the American Revolutionary War. This decision was made by Governor Thomas Jefferson, who urged the legislature to relocate the capital to a more central and secure location, away from the coastal city of Williamsburg, which was vulnerable to British attack. The Virginia General Assembly adjourned on December 24, 1779, and reconvened in Richmond on May 1, 1780, meeting in a makeshift building near Shockoe Bottom. The decision to move the capital was motivated by the need for a more secure and central location, as well as the desire to distance the state government from the coastal city, which was seen as vulnerable to British attack.

The Virginia State Capitol in Richmond was designed by Thomas Jefferson, together with French architect Charles-Louis Clérisseau, and was inspired by the Maison Carrée at Nîmes in southern France, an ancient Roman temple. The building was constructed between 1785 and 1792, and is one of only twelve Capitols in the United States without an external dome. It served as the capital of the Confederacy during the American Civil War, and is now a National Historic Landmark and a symbol of Virginia's rich history and heritage.

Williamsburg, the previous capital of Virginia, was founded in 1632 as Middle Plantation, a fortified settlement on high ground between the James and York rivers. The city served as the capital of the Colony and Commonwealth of Virginia from 1699 to 1780, and was the center of political events in Virginia leading to the American Revolution. Today, Williamsburg is a popular tourist destination, known for its restored Historic Area and its association with the College of William & Mary, which was established in 1693 and is the second-oldest institution of higher education in the United States.
r1: Williamsburg, Virginia, was the capital of the Colony and Commonwealth of Virginia from 1699 to 1780 and the center of political events in Virginia leading to the American Revolution. The capitol building was last used as a capital on December 24, 1779, when the Virginia General Assembly adjourned to reconvene in 1780 at the new capital, Richmond. When it convened in Richmond on May 1, 1780, the legislature met in a makeshift building near Shockoe Bottom. The new capitol building was sufficiently completed for the General Assembly to meet there in October 1792.
r2: During the American Colonial period, Virginia's first capital was Jamestown, where the first legislative body, the Virginia House of Burgesses, met in 1619. With the decision to relocate the government inland to Williamsburg in 1699, a grand new Capitol building was completed in November 1705. The Capitol at Williamsburg served until the American Revolutionary War began, when Governor Thomas Jefferson urged that the capital be relocated to Richmond. The building was last used as a capitol on December 24, 1779, when the Virginia General Assembly adjourned to reconvene in Richmond, and on May 1, 1780, the legislature met in a makeshift building near Shockoe Bottom.

a: The national anthem of Trinidad and Tobago, "Forged from the Love of Liberty," has a rich history and was composed by Patrick S. Castagne in 1962. Castagne, a renowned West Indian songwriter and diplomat, was born in British Guiana but grew up in Trinidad and Tobago. He composed the anthem for the West Indies Federation, which was established in 1958 and collapsed in 1962. When Trinidad and Tobago gained independence in 1962, the country adopted Castagne's anthem as its own.

Castagne's composition was chosen as the national anthem after a competition that received 834 word-only entries, 33 music-only entries, and 306 word and music entries. He won the prize of $5,000 in government bonds and a gold medal inscribed with the Coat of Arms of Trinidad and Tobago. The anthem's lyrics reflect the country's struggle for independence and the love of liberty that fueled that struggle.

Castagne was not only a talented composer but also a diplomat who served as the Trinidad and Tobago high commissioner in London. He worked with the BBC to promote West Indian talent on a weekly radio show and composed several other songs that became popular in Trinidad and Tobago. His song "Goodnight" was used as the sign-on and sign-off signal by Radio Trinidad for many years.

Overall, Patrick Castagne's composition of "Forged from the Love of Liberty" is a significant part of Trinidad and Tobago's history and identity. The anthem's powerful lyrics and memorable melody have made it a beloved symbol of the country's struggle for independence and its ongoing commitment to freedom and self-determination.
r1: Patrick S. Castagne composed the words and music to the National Anthem of Trinidad and Tobago in 1962.
r2: Patrick S. Castagne wrote both the lyrics and the music for the national anthem of Trinidad and Tobago, entitled Forged from the Love of Liberty, in 1962. Castagne was a Guyanese-born Trinidadian composer best known for composing Forged from the Love of Liberty.

a: Neil Armstrong received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Richard Nixon on September 14, 1969, just over two months after he and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the moon during the Apollo 11 mission. This prestigious award is the highest civilian honor bestowed by the United States government, and it recognizes Armstrong's exceptional contributions to the fields of science, technology, and exploration. The Presidential Medal of Freedom is given to individuals who have made "an especially meritorious contribution to the security or national interests of the United States, world peace, cultural or other significant public or private endeavors."

Armstrong's historic moonwalk on July 20, 1969, marked a major milestone in the space race between the United States and the Soviet Union, and his bravery and skill during the mission made him an American hero. The Presidential Medal of Freedom was a fitting tribute to Armstrong's achievements, and it acknowledged the significant impact that his work had on the world.

In addition to the Presidential Medal of Freedom, Armstrong was also awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor in 1978 and the Congressional Gold Medal in 2009, both of which recognize his contributions to the space program. He was also honored with numerous other awards and accolades during his lifetime, including the NASA Distinguished Service Medal, the National Geographic Society's Hubbard Medal, and the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics' Von Braun Trophy.

Armstrong's achievements on the moon and his contributions to the space program are widely recognized as among the most significant in the history of exploration, and his legacy continues to inspire future generations of scientists, engineers, and explorers.
r1: Neil Armstrong received the Presidential Medal of Freedom on August 13, 1969, at an official state dinner with President Nixon.
r2: On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong and Apollo 11 Lunar Module (LM) pilot Buzz Aldrin became the first people to land on the Moon. Along with Collins and Aldrin, Armstrong was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Richard Nixon on August 13, 1969 at an official state dinner.

0.3085106349479403
a: The War on Poverty was a policy and slogan used during the Great Society era of the 1960s, aimed at eliminating poverty and racial injustice in the United States. President Lyndon B. Johnson first introduced the term in his State of the Union address on January 8, 1964, as a response to the high poverty rate of around 19% at the time. The Economic Opportunity Act was passed soon after, establishing the Office of Economic Opportunity (OEO) to administer federal funds targeted against poverty. As part of the Great Society, Johnson believed in expanding the federal government's roles in education and healthcare as poverty reduction strategies. These policies built upon the New Deal and Four Freedoms of Franklin D. Roosevelt and continued with the efforts of John F. Kennedy's New Frontier.

The War on Poverty led to the creation of programs such as Head Start, VISTA, TRiO, and Job Corps, which continue to exist today. However, the policy faced challenges in the 1980s and 1990s due to deregulation, criticism of the welfare state, and a shift towards reducing federal aid to impoverished people. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act of 1996, signed by President Bill Clinton, marked a significant change in the approach to poverty reduction, shifting the focus towards personal responsibility and work requirements. Despite these changes, the legacy of the War on Poverty remains in the continued existence of these federal programs and the ongoing efforts to address poverty and inequality in the United States.
r1: The Great Society was a set of domestic programs in the United States launched by Democratic President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964–65. The war on poverty was a policy and slogan used in response to a national poverty rate. Johnson first used the slogan in the State of the Union address on Wednesday, January 8, 1964.
r2: The war on poverty was a policy and slogan used in a number of things. It was used in referring to legislation in response to a national poverty rate. It was used in President Lyndon B. Johnson's rhetoric and in conjunction with a larger set of domestic programs launched by LBJ called The Great Society. Also, it was used in the State of the Union address on Wednesday, January 8, 1964, a speech by Johnson.

0.3310344781583829
a: The triangular shaped area at each end of a Greek temple is called a pediment. The pediment is a significant feature of ancient Greek architecture and is often the most important location for monumental sculpture on the exterior of the building. The pediment is framed by the cornice, which is the upper band of the entablature, and is typically decorated with sculptural decoration. The entablature, which is the superstructure of moldings and bands that lies horizontally above columns, is a major element of classical architecture and is divided into the architrave, frieze, and cornice. The proportions of the subdivisions of the entablature are defined by the proportions of the column in the order, and in classical Greek and Roman temples, the pediment is often approximately a quarter of the height of the column. The pediment is supported by the stylobate, which is the masonry base of the temple, and is often decorated with sculptural decoration, such as reliefs or statues, that reflect the religious or mythological themes of the temple. In medieval French architecture, the tympanum is often supported by a decorated pillar called a "trumeau".
r1: Greek temples have multiple triangular shapes. The triangular decorative surface on the each end of Greek temples are called tympanon. And at the front and rear of each temple, the entablature which is the structure that lies horizontally above columns, supports a triangular structure called the "pediment".
r2: The triangular elements at the ends of Greek temples have multiple sections. The columns of a temple support the entablature, a horizontal structure that rests on the columns' topmost members. At the front and rear of each temple, the entablature in turn supports a triangular area called the pediment. The triangular wall surface within the pediment is the tympanum, which is often decorated with sculpture or other imagery or ornaments.
============================380=============================

a: The Jeep Wrangler, known for its rugged and versatile design, has a rich history that spans over four decades. The first Wrangler was introduced in 1986, based on a new set of design parameters that differentiated it from the previous CJ-7 model. The Wrangler YJ, as it was called, featured a wider track, improved suspension, and a more comfortable and handling-focused design. Over the years, the Wrangler has undergone several revisions and redesigns, with the third-generation JK model being introduced in 2006. This model marked a significant shift in the Wrangler's design, with the addition of a four-door "Unlimited" model that offered more room and comfort.

The four-door Wrangler Unlimited proved to be a highly successful model, with three quarters of all new Wranglers sold being the four-door variant by mid-2017. This shift towards four-door models can be attributed to the changing preferences of consumers, who are increasingly looking for vehicles that offer more space and practicality without sacrificing the iconic Wrangler's off-road capabilities.

The Jeep Wrangler's success can be attributed to its ability to balance rugged capability with modern comfort and technology. a: Sure! Here is a comprehensive, well-structured paragraph that answers the question "Where is the Ferris wheel located in Myrtle Beach?" and integrates the given factoid context:

The Myrtle Beach SkyWheel is located in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, and can be found near the northern end of the city's new boardwalk, next to Plyler Park. This iconic Ferris wheel is the tallest wheel in the United States east of the Mississippi River and the second-tallest extant Ferris wheel in North America, standing at an impressive 200 feet tall. Designed by Ronald Bussink Professional Rides and manufactured by Chance Morgan, the SkyWheel features 42 glass-enclosed, temperature-controlled gondolas that can seat six passengers each. The wheel operates year-round, but gondolas must be removed during high winds, a process that takes eight to ten hours. The Myrtle Beach SkyWheel is a popular attraction for both locals and tourists, offering stunning views of the Atlantic Ocean and the surrounding area. Its prime location next to the boardwalk and park makes it an iconic feature of the city's skyline.

r2: The Ferris wheel in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, is located at the Oceanfront Boardwalk and Promenade at coordinates 33.692035°N 78.87954°W. The Myrtle Beach Skywheel is a 187-foot-tall observation wheel that opened May 20, 2011.

0.23529411389705887
a: Most of your taste buds are located on your tongue, specifically on raised protrusions called papillae. There are three types of papillae that contain taste buds: fungiform, foliate, and circumvallate. The fungiform papillae are found on the front and back of the tongue and contain taste buds that detect sweet, salty, and sour tastes. The foliate papillae are found on the back of the tongue and contain taste buds that detect bitter tastes. The circumvallate papillae are found on the back of the tongue near the entrance to the throat and contain taste buds that detect umami tastes. However, it's important to note that the tongue does not have specific areas for specific tastes, as a popular myth suggests. Instead, all areas of the tongue can detect all five tastes, and the taste receptors are distributed throughout the tongue. The taste receptors are located on top of the taste buds, which are clusters of cells that contain specialized receptors and ion channels. These receptors and channels transmit information about the taste of food to the brain through the seventh, ninth, and tenth cranial nerves. On average, the human tongue has 2,000-8,000 taste buds, and they play a crucial role in our ability to experience and enjoy the flavors of food and drink.
r1: Papillae, commonly referred to as taste buds, are small structures on the upper surface of the tongue. They are also found on the soft palate, the upper esophagus, the cheeks, and on the epiglottis. Taste buds contain taste receptor cells involved in detecting saltiness, sourness, bitterness, sweetness and umami.
r2: The taste buds on the tongue sit on raised protrusions on the tongue surface, small structures known as papillae. Taste buds contain the taste receptor cells, which are located around the papillae found on the upper surface of the tongue, soft palate, upper esophagus, cheek, and epiglottis.

The opening of the popular 1970s-80s sitcom "Three's Company" was filmed at two different locations. The first, seventh, and eighth seasons were taped at Metromedia Square and ABC Television Center, while the second through sixth seasons were taped in Studio 31 at CBS Television City. The show's cast would receive the script on Monday, rehearse from Tuesday to Thursday, and shoot on Friday, with each episode being shot twice in a row using a multicamera setup of three cameras. The taping was done in sequence, and the producers were strict, as Priscilla Barnes once noted that they were "very, very controlling" and that her hair had to be just right, or she would be called into the office.

The scenes in the opening credits featuring the trio frolicking on a boardwalk and riding bumper cars were shot at the Santa Monica Pier before a larger amusement park was built adjacent to the pier. A later opening sequence featuring the new threesome and other cast members riding a zoo tram and looking at various animals around the zoo was filmed at the Los Angeles Zoo in Griffith Park.

Interestingly, when Priscilla Barnes joined the show in the sixth season, she was given opening-credits billing, while her predecessor, Jenilee Harrison, was end-credits billed and appeared less frequently in the series. Harrison's character, Cindy Snow, eventually disappeared from the show, and she went on to portray the recurring character Jamie Ewing Barnes in the drama "Dallas" from 1984 to 1986.
r1: The original opening scene of Three's Company (the trio are frolicking on a boardwalk and riding bumper-cars) was filmed at Santa Monica Pier. A new opening sequence was shot after Priscilla Barnes had joined the cast as the new roommate, Terri. This was filmed at the Los Angeles Zoo in Griffith Park. The exterior shots of the apartment building in the new opening were shot at 2912 4th Street in Santa Monica.
r2: Three's Company is an American sitcom television series that aired for eight seasons on ABC from March 15, 1977, to September 18, 1984. 0.2424242380314509
a: The process that releases nitrogen gas into the atmosphere is denitrification, which is carried out by facultatively anaerobic bacteria in anaerobic conditions, such as waterlogged soils. These bacteria use nitrates in the soil to carry out respiration, producing nitrogen gas (N2) as a byproduct. This process is an important part of the nitrogen cycle, as it converts nitrate (NO3-) into nitrogen gas, making it unavailable to plants. The denitrifying bacteria compete with nitrate-ammonifying bacteria for nitrate in the environment, but while the latter process conserves bioavailable nitrogen as soluble ammonium, denitrification releases nitrogen gas into the atmosphere. This process is particularly significant in the oceans, where it makes up a major proportion of nitrogen conversion. The balanced formula for this process, known as anammox, is: NH + NO → N + 2HO (ΔG° = -217 kJ/mol).
r1: The nitrogen cycle takes place in the atmosphere, on land and in aquatic environments. The conversion of nitrogen can be carried out through both biological and physical processes. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification. The last process, denitrification, is the part of the cycle that actually releases nitrogen gas (N) back into the atmosphere.
r2: The nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which nitrogen is converted into multiple chemical forms as it circulates among atmosphere, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification. The majority of Earth's atmosphere (78%) is atmosphere nitrogen, making it the largest source of nitrogen. Denitrification is the reduction of nitrates back into nitrogen gas (N), and back into the atmosphere, completing the nitrogen cycle.

The statue was then spared, but the temple and the statue were eventually destroyed in a fire in 425 AD or 475 AD, as recorded by the 11th-century Byzantine historian Georgios Kedrenos. The statue was made of ivory plates and gold panels over a wooden framework, and it was commissioned by the Eleans in the latter half of the 5th century BC for their recently constructed Temple of Zeus. The statue was one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, but no copy of it has ever been found, and details of its form are known only from ancient Greek descriptions and representations on coins.

0.1712062221859529
a: Ragtime flourished in the United States during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, specifically between 1895 and 1918. This musical style, characterized by its syncopated or "ragged" rhythm, originated in African-American communities in cities such as St. Louis. Ernest Hogan, a pioneer of ragtime, was the first composer to have his works published as sheet music, beginning with the song "La Pas Ma La" in 1895. Ben Harney, another Kentucky native, helped popularize the style with his composition "You've Been a Good Old Wagon But You Done Broke Down," published in 1896. Ragtime was a modification of the march style popularized by John Philip Sousa, with additional polyrhythms derived from African music.

The peak of ragtime's popularity was marked by the publication of Scott Joplin's "Maple Leaf Rag" in 1899, which heavily influenced subsequent composers and became a hit. Joplin's subsequent works, such as "The Entertainer" (1902), cemented his status as a leading figure in the genre. However, ragtime fell out of favor as jazz claimed the public's imagination after 1917, and it was largely forgotten until the 1940s and 1950s, when revivals of the style began to take place. These revivals saw the release of new recordings and the rediscovery of ragtime compositions from the past, including Joplin's work. In 1971, Joshua Rifkin brought out a compilation of Joplin's work, which was nominated for a Grammy Award. The New England Ragtime Ensemble, then a student group, recorded "The Red Back Book," a compilation of Joplin's rags in period orchestrations, in 1973.

Overall, ragtime flourished in the United States for over two decades, leaving a lasting impact on American music and influencing the development of jazz and other musical styles. Its resurgence in popularity during the 1940s, 1950s, and 1970s is a testament to its enduring appeal and the timelessness of its unique sound.
r1: The musical style ragtime, flourished and peaked popularity in the united states between 1895 and 1919. But in the early 1970s, there was a major ragtime revival.
r2: In the United States, ragtime has flourished at different times, with numerous revivals having occurred since newer styles supplanted ragtime in the 1920s. Ragtime first flourished and reached peak popularity in the US between 1895 and 1919. By the start of the 20th century, it had become widely popular throughout North America, enjoyed by people of many different subcultures. Ragtime flourished again in the US in revivals in the 1940s and 1950s, followed by a major revival in the early 1970s.
