0.3153526927174119
a: The question asks where the highest temperatures on Earth have been recorded, and provides a factoid about the WMO decertifying the previous record holder, 'Aziziya, Libya, in 2012. The factoid also mentions that temperatures measured directly on the ground may exceed air temperatures by 30-50 degrees Celsius, and that the theoretical maximum possible ground surface temperature has been estimated to be between 90-100 degrees Celsius.

In response to the question, it can be stated that the highest recorded air temperature on Earth is currently held by Death Valley, California, with a reading of 134 degrees Fahrenheit (56.7 degrees Celsius) on July 10, 1913. However, this record is disputed by some weather historians, who argue that the reading may have been influenced by a sandstorm and is not an accurate representation of the true air temperature. If this record were to be decertified, the next highest recorded air temperature would be 130 degrees Fahrenheit (54.4 degrees Celsius), recorded in both Death Valley on June 20, 2013, and in Mitribah, Kuwait on July 21, 2016.

It is important to note that temperature measurements taken directly on the ground may be significantly higher than air temperatures, due to the fact that the ground absorbs and retains heat more than the air. The highest recorded ground temperature is allegedly 93.9 degrees Celsius (201 degrees Fahrenheit), recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch on July 15, 1972. However, this reading is not considered to be an official record by the WMO.

Satellite measurements of ground temperature have also recorded extremely high temperatures, with the highest recorded temperature being 70.7 degrees Celsius (159.3 degrees Fahrenheit), recorded in the Lut Desert, Iran in 2005. The Lut Desert has also been found to have the highest maximum temperature in 5 of the 7 years measured between 2003 and 2009.

In conclusion, while the highest recorded air temperature on Earth is currently held by Death Valley, California, there is some debate about the accuracy of this reading. If decertified, the next highest recorded air temperature would be from Death Valley in 2013, or from Mitribah, Kuwait in 2016. However, ground temperatures measured directly may be significantly higher than air temperatures, and satellite measurements have recorded even higher temperatures in certain locations.
r1: The highest temprature on Earth is recorded by three different ways, by air, ground, and via satellite observation, with air being the most accurate. The highest ground and air temperature recorded on Earth was at Furnace Creek Ranch, California in the Death Valley desert. While, the highest temperature on Earth recorded via satellite was of Lut Desert, Iran.
r2: The standard measuring conditions for temperature are in the air, 1.5 meters above the ground, and shielded from direct sunlight. According to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), the highest registered air temperature on Earth was 56.7 °C (134.1 °F) in Furnace Creek Ranch, California, located in the Death Valley desert in the United States, on July 10, 1913, but the validity of this record is challenged. Other satellite measurements of ground temperature taken between 2003 and 2009 found a maximum temperature of 70.7 °C (159.3 °F), which was recorded in 2005 in the Lut Desert, Iran.
============================398=============================
0.2318840539802563
a: The United States was taken off the gold standard in 1933, during the Great Depression, as part of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal policies. The gold standard, which linked the value of currency to the value of gold, had been in place since the late 19th century, but it was abandoned by many countries, including the United States, during the Great Depression. The Bank of England was one of the first to abandon the gold standard in 1931, and other countries soon followed, as speculators demanded gold in exchange for currency, threatening the solvency of their monetary systems. In the United States, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to protect the gold standard, but this only worsened domestic economic pressures.

In early 1933, the United States faced severe deflation, bank runs, and hoarding of gold coins, which led to a crisis in the monetary system. To address these issues, Congress and President Roosevelt implemented a series of Acts of Congress and Executive Orders, including Executive Order 6073, the Emergency Banking Act, Executive Order 6102, and the Gold Reserve Act. These actions suspended the gold standard for the US dollar, revoked gold as universal legal tender for debts, and banned private ownership of significant amounts of gold coin. The Supreme Court upheld these actions in the "Gold Clause Cases" in 1935.

President Roosevelt's decision to take the United States off the gold standard in April 1933 was a significant departure from the traditional gold standard, and it allowed him to pursue inflationary policies to address the economic crisis. The United States' departure from the gold standard was also a key factor in the development of the Bretton Woods system, which established the US dollar as a global reserve currency and created the modern international monetary order.

In 1971, the United States unilaterally terminated convertibility of the US dollar to gold, effectively bringing the Bretton Woods system to an end and rendering the dollar a fiat currency. This action, known as the Nixon shock, created the situation in which the US dollar became a reserve currency used by many states, while many fixed currencies became free-floating. The political basis for the Bretton Woods system was the shared experiences of two World Wars and the concentration of power in a small number of states, which facilitated the decisions reached by the Bretton Woods Conference.
r1: America was taken off the gold standard, but still allowed foreign governments to trade dollars for gold in 1933. In 1944, with the the Bretton Woods system, America started using the gold exchange standard. On 15 August 1971, the United States brought the Bretton Woods system to an end, ending the convertibility of the US dollar to gold.
r2: The Gold Standard Act of the United States was passed in 1900 and established gold as the only standard for redeeming paper money, stopping bimetallism (which had allowed silver in exchange for gold). During the Great Depression, every major currency abandoned the gold standard. On April 19, 1933, the United States domestically abandoned the gold standard, but still allowed foreign governments to trade dollars for gold. The 1944 Bretton Woods Agreement led to the US adopting the gold exchange standard. On August 15, 1971, Nixon issued Executive Order 11615, which "closed the gold window", making the dollar inconvertible to gold directly, except on the open market.

0.4387755052061641
a: The instrument that is blown into with a keyboard is the melodica, a free-reed instrument similar to the pump organ and harmonica. The melodica has a musical keyboard on top and is played by blowing air through a mouthpiece that fits into a hole in the side of the instrument. Pressing a key opens a hole, allowing air to flow through a reed, producing a sound. The melodica is known by various names, such as the pianica, blow-organ, key harmonica, free-reed clarinet, face piano, or melodyhorn. It is small, light, and portable, making it a popular instrument in music education, especially in Asia. The modern form of the instrument was invented by Hohner in the 1950s, but similar instruments have been known in Italy since the 19th century. The melodica has been used in a variety of musical genres, including classical, jazz, and popular music, and has been associated with musicians such as Steve Reich, Hermeto Pascoal, and Augustus Pablo.
r1: Mouth organs are a type of instrument that's played by blowing into a chamber or holes in the instrument, and blowing or sucking air to create a sound. Mouth organs are found all around the world and are known by multiple names and seen in different traditions. Some examples are the Melodica and the Claviola. The Melodica is a free-reed instrument similar to the pump organ and harmonica. It has a musical keyboard on top, and is played by blowing air through a mouthpiece attached to the instrument. The modern form of the instrument was invented by Hohner in the 1950s, though similar instruments have been known in Italy since the 19th century. The Claviola was designed in the 1960s, also by Hohner, and designer Ernst Zacharias. The instrument was produced for a few months in the 1990s before being discontinued. It's similar to a melodica, but worn like an accordion, the claviola has a set of piano keys on the right side that range 2½ octaves.
r2: There are several instruments that you blow into with a keyboard. Invented by Hohner in the 1950s, the melodica is a free-reed instrument that is played by blowing air through a mouthpiece that fits into a hole in the side of the instrument. It has a musical keyboard on top. Similar to the melodica, the claviola, designed in the 1960s by Ernst Zacharias, has a set of piano keys on the right side and the left side has a set of pipes that range in length depending on the corresponding pitch.

This show of strength and capability persuaded the United States and other nations to support the Jewish community and its aspirations for a state. The victory over the Palestinian Arabs in the 1948 Arab-Israeli War not only gave the Haganah the experience and self-confidence to confront invading Arab armies but also solidified the Jewish presence in the region. On April 12, 1948, the Arab League announced that Arab armies would enter Palestine to rescue it, but this attempt was ultimately unsuccessful. The establishment of the State of Israel marked the beginning of a long and complex history of conflict and negotiation with neighboring countries and the Palestinian people, who were displaced and lost their homeland as a result of the creation of the new state.

Chapman's backstory, as revealed throughout the series, is one of privilege and naivety. Five years later, she was named as part of the drug ring and eventually pleaded guilty, serving 13 months in a Danbury, Connecticut women's prison, FCI Danbury.

0.28994082341094507
a: The first helicopter to be made and flown was the Focke-Wulf Fw 61, designed by Henrich Focke and flown by Hanna Reitsch on June 26, 1936, in the Deutschland Hall Stadium in Germany. This achievement came after Focke was inspired by Juan de la Cierva's autogyros and designed the world's first practical helicopter. However, Focke was ousted from the Focke-Wulf company shortly after, and the Air Ministry took over the company and issued him with a requirement for an improved helicopter design.

Prior to the Fw 61, there were several other inventors and engineers who experimented with helicopter designs, including Edison, Bahýľ, and the French brothers Jacques and Louis Breguet. Edison built a helicopter using a gasoline engine and box kites attached to a mast, but it never flew. Bahýľ's helicopter reached a height of in 1901 and flew for over , while the Gyroplane No. 1 designed by the French brothers lifted its pilot into the air for a minute in 1907. Cornu's helicopter used two counter-rotating rotors driven by an Antoinette engine and achieved a height of nearly , but it proved to be unstable and was abandoned.

The Fw 61 was a significant milestone in helicopter design and development, as it was the first helicopter to use a single main rotor and a tail rotor for stability. It had a maximum speed of 25 mph and a range of 20 miles. Although the Fw 61 was not widely produced or used during World War II, it paved the way for modern helicopter designs and inspired further innovation in the field.

In summary, the first helicopter to be made and flown was the Focke-Wulf Fw 61, designed by Henrich Focke and flown by Hanna Reitsch in 1936. However, other inventors and engineers had experimented with helicopter designs before, including Edison, Bahýľ, and the French brothers. The Fw 61 was a significant milestone in helicopter design and development, and it laid the foundation for modern helicopter technology.
r1: The first helicopter was created in 1861 by the French inventor, Gustave de Ponton d'Amécourt. However, his model never took flight. The Italian engineer, Enrico Forlanini, build an unmanned version of the helicopter in 1878 that rose to a height of 12 meters (39 feet), where it hovered for about 20 seconds after a vertical take-off. The first helicopter model to carry a pilot was in 1907. Two French brothers, Jacques and Louis Breguet, built the "Gyroplane No.1" sometime between 14 August and 29 September 1907. It lifted its pilot 2 ft into the air for about a minute. The Gyroplane No.1 proved to be extremely unsteady and required a man at each corner of the airframe to hold it steady. On 13 November 1907, another French inventor, Paul Cornu, designed and built the Cornu helicopter. It lifted its inventor off the ground and remained aloft for 20 seconds. Even though this flight did not surpass in height the flight of the Gyroplane No. 1, it was reported to be the first truly free flight with a pilot as it did not need to be held steady. Almost three decades later, German aviation pioneer and co-founder of the Focke-Wulf company, invented the Fw 61. This was the world's first practical transverse twin-rotor helicopter. It first flew on 26 June 1936 to more than 8,000 feet (2,400 m) at speeds of 120 miles per hour (190 km/h). A few years later, on 11 December 1951, turbine engines started being used in helicopters. This meant the helicopter could fly with a large amount of power and a low weight penalty.
r2: There are a number of helicopters, including twin-rotor, turbine-powered, manned, and truly free helicopters. The first helicopter was made in 1861, while the first helicopter flew in 1878. The first manned helicopter was made and flown at a height of 2 ft for 1 minute in 1907, and the first truly free helicopter was made and flown with a pilot on 13 November 1907. The first transverse twin-rotor helicopter was made and successfully flown on 26 June 1936, and the first turbine-powered helicopter was made and flown on 11 December 1951.

0.27272726870932334
a: The three types of enzymes involved in digestion are lipases, trypsin, and enterokinase. Lipases are responsible for breaking down triglycerides into smaller monoglyceride units, while trypsin cleaves peptide bonds on the carboxyl side of basic amino acids. Enterokinase activates trypsinogen into trypsin, allowing it to perform its digestive functions. These enzymes play crucial roles in lipid metabolism and protein digestion, respectively.

Lipases are secreted by the pancreas and are responsible for breaking down triglycerides into smaller monoglyceride units. This process begins in the mouth, where lingual lipase continues the chemical digestion of fats that began in the stomach. The majority of lipid digestion and absorption occurs in the small intestines, where pancreatic lipase and bile salt-dependent lipase break down triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol. These fatty acids are then absorbed into the small intestine's epithelial cells.

Trypsin, on the other hand, is responsible for cleaving peptide bonds on the carboxyl side of basic amino acids. It is activated by enterokinase, which is produced by the mucosa of the duodenum. Trypsin is released by the pancreas and works in conjunction with other enzymes to break down proteins into smaller peptides and amino acids.

Enterokinase is a key enzyme in the digestive process, as it activates trypsinogen into trypsin. This allows trypsin to perform its digestive functions, cleaving peptide bonds on the carboxyl side of basic amino acids. Enterokinase is produced by the mucosa of the duodenum and is specific to the small intestine, making it an essential component of the digestive process.

In conclusion, the three types of enzymes involved in digestion are lipases, trypsin, and enterokinase. These enzymes play crucial roles in lipid metabolism and protein digestion, respectively. Lipases break down triglycerides into smaller monoglyceride units, while trypsin cleaves peptide bonds on the carboxyl side of basic amino acids. Enterokinase activates trypsinogen into trypsin, allowing it to perform its digestive functions. These enzymes work together to ensure proper digestion and absorption of nutrients in the small intestine.
r1: Digestive enzymes are classified by the substance they breakdown. The main four types are, lipases, proteases, amylases, and nucleases. The first, lipase, is produced in the mouth and helps break down fatty acids in food. Protease breaks down protein. It's found in the duodenum, the first section of the small intestine in mammal and other higher vertebrates. Amylase is also produced in the mouth. It's secreted by the salivary glands. This enzyme is great at breaking down complex carbohydrates into simple sugars. The last digestive enzyme, nuclease, can be found in the pancreatic juice. Nuclease helps the body break down nucleic acids, like DNAase and RNAase, in the food one consumes.
r2: Digestive enzymes are a group of enzymes that break down polymeric macromolecules into their smaller building blocks, in order to facilitate their absorption by the body. Lipases split fatty acids off of fats and oils. Proteases and peptidases split proteins into small peptides and amino acids. Amylases split carbohydrates such as starch and sugars into simple sugars such as glucose. Nucleases split nucleic acids into nucleotides.

a: A simple gear train can be found in a wind turbine, specifically in the gearless or direct drive configuration. In this design, the rotor shaft is directly connected to the generator, eliminating the need for a gearbox. This simplifies the system and reduces the risk of reliability issues and maintenance costs associated with the gearbox. The direct drive generator uses permanent magnets to generate electricity, which are attached to the rotor and spin at the same speed as the blades. This design allows for increased efficiency, reduced noise, and a longer lifetime compared to traditional gear-based wind turbines. To compensate for the slower spinning rate of the direct drive generator, the rotor diameter is larger, providing more magnets to generate the required power and frequency. While gearless wind turbines are often heavier than gear-based turbines, the benefits of increased efficiency and reliability make them an attractive option for wind energy production.

The concept of gear trains can be traced back to ancient civilizations, with examples found in the Antikythera mechanism of Greece and the south-pointing chariot of China. The involute tooth design was later developed, providing a standard gear design that ensures a constant speed ratio. Gears and gear trains are characterized by the meshing of teeth on two or more gears, which transmit torque and change the speed and direction of a power source. The velocity of the point of contact on the pitch circles is the same on both gears, and the gear ratio can be computed based on the radii of the pitch circles and the number of teeth on each gear. Gears can be found in a variety of devices, including transmissions, bicycles, motorcycles, and cars, where they are used to produce a mechanical advantage and change the speed and torque of the power source.
r1: A gear train is a mechanical system formed by mounting gears on a frame with rotating, interlocking teeth. The gears can change the speed, torque, and direction of a power source, and are considered a simple machine. Gear trains are used in a variety of machines, and are typically found in the gearbox, which is a form of a simple transmission. You can also find a gear train on non-motorized machines, such a bicycle.
r2: A transmission is a machine in a power transmission system, which provides controlled application of power. Often the term 5-speed transmission refers simply to the gearbox, that uses gears and gear trains to provide speed and torque block conversions from a rotating power source to another device. Simple gear trains are often found in gearboxes on machines as well as on non-motorized bicycles.

a: Here's the comprehensive answer to your question:

When was soccer first introduced in the Olympics?

Soccer, or association football, was first introduced in the Olympics at the 1900 Summer Olympics in Paris, France. However, it was not an official Olympic sport at that time, and the tournament was not recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC). The IOC considers the 1900 and 1904 tournaments to be official Olympic events, but they are not recognized by FIFA. The first official Olympic soccer tournament was held at the 1908 Summer Olympics in London, which was organized by the Football Association. Women's soccer was added to the Olympic program in 1996, and the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, featured the sixth edition of the women's tournament.

The history of soccer in the Olympics is complex and has evolved over time. Although soccer was not included in the first modern Olympic Games in 1896, there is evidence that an unofficial tournament was organized during the games, with a team representing Athens losing to a team from Smyrna (now part of Turkey). The sport has since grown in popularity and has become one of the most popular team sports in the world. Today, soccer is played by both men and women at the Olympic Games, with the women's tournament featuring 12 teams at the 2016 Games.

It is worth noting that there are different forms of football, including association football (soccer), gridiron football (American football), Australian rules football, rugby football, and Gaelic football. Each of these variations has its own set of rules and is popular in different regions of the world. The history of soccer in the Olympics is specific to the association football version of the sport.
r1: Soccer, most globally known as football, was first introduced to the Olympic Games in 1900. However, only men's teams were allowed to compete until 1996. The United States women's team won the 1996 tournament after a 2–1 victory against China in the gold medal game.
r2: Soccer, also known as football or association football, was first introduced in the Olympics in 1900 and in 1996. Men's soccer was introduced at the Olympics in 1900 and has been included in every Summer Olympic Games except 1896 and 1932. Women's soccer was first introduced at the Olympics in 1996 at the 1996 Atlanta Games.

a: The game of cricket in India can be traced back to the British Raj, specifically to the East India Company, which was granted a Royal Charter by Queen Elizabeth I on December 31, 1600. The company was established to trade in the Indian Ocean region, including Mughal India and the East Indies, and later became involved in governance and military functions. As the East India Company's influence grew in India, so did the popularity of cricket among the native population. The company's trading settlements in Madras (founded in 1639), Bombay (acquired in 1661), and Calcutta (established in 1690) became leading centers of cricket.

The introduction of cricket in India was largely due to the British officers and soldiers who were stationed in the country. They introduced the game to the local population, who quickly took to it, and it became a popular pastime among the British and the native Indians. The game was initially played in the compounds of the East India Company's trading settlements, but soon spread to other parts of the country.

The popularity of cricket in India grew rapidly, and by the mid-19th century, it had become a popular sport throughout the country. The first cricket club in India, the Calcutta Cricket Club, was established in 1792, and the first international cricket match was played between India and England in 1864. The East India Company's involvement in cricket was not limited to just introducing the game to India, but also to other parts of the world, including the East Indies and China.

a: Here's the comprehensive answer to the question:

The song "God Bless America" has a rich history that dates back to World War I. The song was written by Irving Berlin in 1918 while he was serving in the U.S. Army at Camp Upton in Yaphank, New York. However, the song was initially set aside as it didn't fit in a revue called "Yip Yip Yaphank." The original version of the song had different lyrics, including the line "Make her victorious on land and foam, God bless America..." and "Stand beside her and guide her to the right with the light from above."

The song was later revised by Berlin in 1938, ahead of World War II, and it became a patriotic anthem for the United States. The revised version, which is the one commonly known today, takes the form of a prayer for God's blessing and peace for the nation. The song has been recorded by many artists, including Kate Smith, who made it her signature song.

Interestingly, music critic Jody Rosen has pointed out that a 1906 Jewish dialect novelty song, "When Mose with His Nose Leads the Band," contains a six-note fragment that is "instantly recognizable as the opening strains of 'God Bless America.'" This suggests that the melody of "God Bless America" may have been influenced by earlier Jewish music.

Overall, "God Bless America" is a beloved patriotic song that has been a part of American culture for over a century. Its origins can be traced back to World War I and the early 20th century Jewish music, and its revised version has become a symbol of American patriotism and a prayer for peace and blessings for the nation.
r1: "God Bless America" is an American patriotic song written by Irving Berlin during World War I in 1918 and revised by him in the run up to World War II in 1938. Originally the song was supposed to be performed at Camp Upton in Yaphank, New York.
r2: God Bless America was written by Irving Berlin during World War I and was originally supposed to be performed at Camp Upton in Yaphank, New York. Berlin wrote the song in 1918 while serving in the U.S. Army at Camp Upton. Berlin was an American composer and lyricist widely considered one of the greatest songwriters in American history.

a: The Blue Lagoon geothermal spa in Iceland is a popular tourist destination known for its warm, mineral-rich waters that are said to have healing properties for skin conditions such as psoriasis. The water used in the spa comes from the nearby Svartsengi geothermal power plant, which is located in a lava field near Grindavík on the Reykjanes Peninsula. The plant uses superheated water from the ground to generate electricity, and the heat is also used to provide warm water for the nearby municipal water heating system. The Blue Lagoon is a man-made lagoon that is renewed every two days with fresh water from the power plant, making it the largest geothermal spa in the world.

Interestingly, the Blue Lagoon is not the only notable water feature in the area. The nearby Umgeni River, which flows through the city of Durban in South Africa, is a major river that supports a variety of wildlife and is known for its picturesque waterfalls and canoeing opportunities. The river is also home to the Umgeni River Bird Park, which is a popular destination for birdwatchers and nature enthusiasts.

In contrast to the geothermal waters of the Blue Lagoon, the Umgeni River is a freshwater river that supports a diverse range of aquatic life. The river is approximately long and has a catchment area of , making it an important source of water for the surrounding region. The river is also home to a number of notable tributaries, including the Msunduzi River, which joins the Umgeni near the city of Pietermaritzburg.

Overall, the Blue Lagoon and the Umgeni River are two unique and interesting water features that offer visitors a range of opportunities for relaxation, recreation, and wildlife viewing. Whether you're looking to soak in the warm, mineral-rich waters of the Blue Lagoon or explore the picturesque Umgeni River and its surrounding wildlife, there's something for everyone in this beautiful region of Iceland and South Africa.

Another body of water known as The Blue Lagoon is the Umgeni River estuary. 0.3980099454775873
a: The Virginia Plan, proposed by James Madison and officially presented by Edmund Randolph at the Constitutional Convention of 1787, aimed to establish a strong national government with a bicameral legislature. The plan called for a legislative branch consisting of two houses: the lower house would be composed of members elected directly by the people, while the upper house would be composed of members chosen by state legislatures. This proposed structure gave more power to the larger states, as they would have a greater number of representatives in the lower house based on their population. However, the plan also provided for a check on the power of the larger states by giving each state an equal number of representatives in the upper house.

The Connecticut Compromise, reached later in the convention, modified the Virginia Plan by retaining the bicameral legislature but altering the representation in the upper house. Each state would have two representatives in the upper house, regardless of its population. This compromise allowed for a balance between the interests of large and small states, as both would have an equal number of representatives in the upper house.

Overall, the Virginia Plan and the Connecticut Compromise gave more power to the larger states in the legislative branch of the national government, as they would have a greater number of representatives in the lower house based on their population. However, the compromise also ensured that smaller states had a voice in the upper house, preventing the larger states from dominating the government. This balance of power was a key aspect of the Constitution and has continued to shape the government of the United States to this day.
r1: The Virginia Plan which proposed the creation of a supreme national government with three branches and a bicameral legislature, gave more power to larger states, additionally the plan proposed that the legislative branch would have the power to veto state laws.
r2: The Virginia Plan, also known as the Randolph Plan, after its sponsor, or the Large-State Plan, was a proposal to the United States Constitutional Convention for the creation of a supreme national government with three branches and a bicameral legislature. This would provide large states, like Virginia, more representation than they had under the Articles of Confederation, which gave each state equal representation regardless of population. For this reason, the plan was called the "large-state plan". Additionally, the plan proposed that the legislative branch would have the power to veto state laws if they were deemed incompatible with the articles of union, or the states were deemed incompetent.

0.29959513790030984
a: The Amazon River, the largest river in the world by discharge volume, has a complex and disputed origin. For nearly a century, the most distant source of the Amazon was believed to be in the Apurímac river drainage, with the snowcapped Nevado Mismi peak in Peru considered the most distant source. However, a 2014 study by Americans James Contos and Nicolas Tripcevich in the journal "Area" challenged this long-held belief, instead identifying the most distant source of the Amazon as being in the Río Mantaro drainage.

The study used a variety of methods to compare the lengths of the Mantaro river and the Apurímac river from their most distant source points to their confluence, showing that the Mantaro river is significantly longer than previously thought. The most accurate measurements were obtained by direct GPS measurement obtained by kayak descent of each of the rivers, which revealed that the Cordillera Rumi Cruz was the most distant source of water in the Mantaro basin and, therefore, in the entire Amazon basin. This finding means that the Amazon river is approximately 80 kilometers longer than previously thought, with its source located nearly 80 kilometers farther upstream than the previously identified source in the Apurímac drainage.

The Amazon river is formed by the confluence of several rivers, including the Rio Negro, which is the largest left tributary of the Amazon and the largest blackwater river in the world. The Rio Negro rises in Colombia and flows in an east-northeasterly direction through the Puinawai National Reserve, passing several small indigenous settlements before forming the border between Colombia and Venezuela. The river then turns southwest and receives the Casiquiare canal from the right-hand, forming a unique link between the Orinoco and the Amazon river basin.

Daming the Amazon river could potentially bring about the "end of free-flowing rivers" and contribute to an "ecosystem collapse" that will cause major social problems, highlighting the importance of preserving this vital waterway and its surrounding ecosystem. Understanding the true source of the Amazon river is crucial for effective river management and conservation efforts, as well as for ensuring the long-term health and sustainability of this vital resource.
r1: The Amazon River, located in South America, is the largest river by discharge volume of water in the world. It is also one of the world's longest rivers. For nearly a century, the start and end of the river was considered to be the Apurímac River on Nevado Mismi and Atlantic Ocean. However, a 2014 study identified the most distant source of the Amazon as actually being in the Río Mantaro, located in the central region of Peru. This means the Amazon River starts and ends in the Mantaro River and Atlantic Ocean, respectively.
r2: The Amazon River in South America is the largest river by discharge volume of water in the world, and the disputed longest river in the world. The Amazon River starts and ends at the Mantaro River and Atlantic Ocean. The Mantaro River, or Río Mantaro, runs through Huancayo Province in Peru. It is commonly believed that the Amazon River started and finished at the Apurímac River on Nevado Mismi and Atlantic Ocean. The mouth of the Amazon River is in Brazil at the Atlantic Ocean.

a: The forest fire that occurred in Swall Meadows, California did not start on a specific date, as it was part of the larger Cedar Fire that burned in San Diego County, California in October and November 2003. The Cedar Fire was a massive wildfire that burned over 282,000 acres of land, destroyed 2,820 buildings, including 2,232 homes, and killed 15 people, including one firefighter. The fire's rapid growth was driven by the Santa Ana winds, which caused the fire to spread at a rate of 100 acres per hour. The Cedar Fire remains one of the largest wildfires in California history, causing over $1.3 billion in damages and ranking as the third-deadliest and fourth most destructive wildfire in state history. It is worth noting that the Camp Fire (2018) and the Mendocino Complex Fire's Ranch Fire have since surpassed the Cedar Fire in terms of destructive power and acreage burned.
r1: California has had many forest fires. In February 6, 2015, Round Fire burned 7,000 acres including Swall Meadows and the neighboring community of Paradise. In December 25, 2015 another fire broke out and exceeded 1000 acres. Then in May 18, 2016, another large fire broke out. In 2017, there was again multiple large fires, including a fire that started on April 20, 2017 and a fire that started on December 7, 2017.
r2: There have been a number of California forest fires, which started on different dates. The forest fire named Liberty started in California in 2017 on December 7, 2017. The first forest fires over 1,000 acres started in the state in 2017, 2016, and 2015 on April 20, 2017, May 18, 2016, and February 6, 2015, respectively. The last in the state over 1,000 acres in 2015 started on December 25, 2015.

This can lead to situations where a player who has not won a major championship in the past year can still be ranked number one if they have accumulated a significant number of points from previous events.

Furthermore, the OWGR also takes into account the strength of the field in each event, which can affect a player's ranking. For example, a player who wins a major championship against a strong field may be ranked higher than a player who wins a less prestigious event against a weaker field.

In terms of nationality, the top 100 players in the OWGR are representative of several countries, with the United States, England, and Australia being the most represented. This suggests that there is no one dominant country in golf, and that the best golfers come from a variety of backgrounds.

a: The music for the iconic film "The Bridge on the River Kwai" was composed by British composer Malcolm Arnold, who had only ten days to write around forty-five minutes of music for the film. Despite the tight deadline, Arnold's score was a critical and commercial success, and it won him an Academy Award for Best Original Score. The score features a memorable march, "The River Kwai March," which is accompanied by the whistling of the Colonel Bogey strain. The film's use of music is notable for its effectiveness in enhancing the emotional impact of the film's dramatic scenes, such as the famous bridge explosion sequence. In contrast to the film's sweeping orchestral score, many scenes feature only the sounds of nature, emphasizing the tension and desperation of the characters. The film's use of music and sound is a testament to the skill of its composers and the power of music to enhance the emotional impact of a film.

The Bridge on the River Kwai is a 1957 British-American epic war film directed by David Lean and based on the novel "Le Pont de la Rivière Kwaï" (1952) by Pierre Boulle. The film's historical setting is the construction of the Burma Railway in 1942-1943, and it features an all-star cast including William Holden, Jack Hawkins, Alec Guinness, and Sessue Hayakawa. The film was initially scripted by screenwriter Carl Foreman, who was later replaced by Michael Wilson. The film's success was not without controversy, as it was criticized for its historical inaccuracies and its portrayal of the conditions endured by the prisoners of war who built the Burma Railway. Despite these criticisms, the film was widely praised and won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture, at the 30th Academy Awards. It has since been deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" and selected for preservation in the National Film Registry by the United States Library of Congress.
r1: "The Bridge on the River Kwai" is a 1957 epic war film directed by David Lean and based on the 1952 novel written by Pierre Boulle. Malcolm Arnold is the British composer who wrote the music for the film, and recalled that he had "ten days to write around forty-five minutes worth of music" - much less time than he was used to. Despite this, he won an Oscar and a Grammy. The soundtrack Arnold composed was musically based on a march that was written in 1914 by Kenneth J. Alford.
r2: The Bridge on the River Kwai is a 1957 epic war film directed by David Lean and based on the 1952 novel written by Pierre Boulle. British composer Malcolm Arnold recalled that he had "ten days to write around forty-five minutes worth of music". Despite this, he won an Oscar and a Grammy. A memorable feature of the film is the tune that is whistled by the POWs, the first strain of the march "Colonel Bogey", when they enter the camp. The march was written in 1914 by Kenneth J. Alford, a pseudonym of British Bandmaster Frederick J. Ricketts.

a: Sure! Here is a comprehensive, well-structured, and focused paragraph that answers the question about the famous street in New Orleans, incorporating the provided factoid context:

Bourbon Street, located in the heart of New Orleans' French Quarter, is the city's most famous street, attracting 17.74 million visitors in 2017 alone. Founded in 1718 by Jean Baptiste Le Moyne de Bienville and named after the French royal house of Bourbon, the street stretches 13 blocks from Canal to Esplanade Avenue and is known for its numerous bars and strip clubs. Although the street has undergone significant changes over the centuries, it still retains much of its French and Spanish colonial architecture and culture. The street's history is reflected in its naming, as Adrien de Pauger, the royal engineer who designed the city's street layout, paid homage to France's ruling family with the naming of Bourbon Street. However, the street's influence is not limited to its French heritage, as the Great New Orleans Fire of 1788 and the subsequent rebuilding efforts by the Spanish have also left their mark on the street's architecture and character. Today, Bourbon Street is a testament to the city's rich history and cultural diversity, offering visitors a unique glimpse into the past as they explore its many bars, clubs, and historic landmarks.
r1: There are two historically famous streets in the city of New Orleans. Bourbon Street is a street in the heart of the French Quarter of New Orleans. Extending thirteen blocks from Canal Street to Esplanade Avenue, Bourbon Street is famous for its many bars and strip clubs. Canal Street is a major thoroughfare in the city of New Orleans. Forming the upriver boundary of the city's oldest neighborhood, the French Quarter or Vieux Carré, it served historically as the dividing line between the colonial-era (18th-century) city and the newer American Sector, today's Central Business District.
r2: There are several famous streets in New Orleans, including Canal Street and Bourbon Street. Canal Street divides the 18th-century city and the newer business district, the Central Business District. Bourbon Street is a historic street in the heart of New Orleans' French Quarter known for its many bars and strip clubs.

a: In the beloved children's novel "Charlotte's Web," the pig named Wilbur is the central character and the focus of the story. Wilbur is a runt pig who is saved by a little girl named Fern and raised as a pet on her father's farm. When Wilbur is sent to her uncle's barnyard, he is befriended by a wise and resourceful barn spider named Charlotte. As Wilbur faces the threat of being slaughtered, Charlotte devises a plan to save his life by weaving words of praise for Wilbur into her web, making him a local celebrity and convincing the farmer to spare his life.

The story of "Charlotte's Web" has been praised for its timeless themes of friendship, compassion, and the power of words. The novel's dry, low-key style, as described by E.B. White, adds to its charm and accessibility for both children and adults. The description of the experience of swinging on a rope swing at the farm is a notable example of rhythm in writing, as the pace of the sentences reflects the motion of the swing. The novel has been adapted into several films, including an animated feature in 1973 and a live-action film in 2006, as well as a video game in 2006.

Despite its classic status, "Charlotte's Web" has not been without criticism. Some reviewers have noted that the story's depiction of farm life and animal characters can be seen as idyllic and sanitized, glossing over the harsh realities of industrial farming and the treatment of animals in such systems. Additionally, some have criticized the story's focus on the human characters, particularly Fern, at the expense of the animal characters, such as Wilbur and Charlotte.

Overall, "Charlotte's Web" remains a beloved and enduring children's classic, with its themes of friendship, compassion, and the power of words continuing to resonate with readers of all ages.
r1: Charlotte's Web is a book of children's literature by American author E. B. White and illustrated by Garth Williams; it was published on October 15, 1952, by Harper & Brothers. In the story, Wilbur is a rambunctious pig, and is the runt of his litter. He is often strongly emotional. Uncle is a large pig whom Charlotte disdains for coarse manners and Wilbur’s rival at the fair.
r2: Charlotte's Web is a book of children's literature by American author E. B. White and illustrated by Garth Williams published on October 15, 1952, by Harper & Brothers that tells the story of a livestock pig named Wilbur and his friendship with a barn spider named Charlotte. Uncle, another character, is a large pig whom Charlotte disdains for coarse manners and is Wilbur’s rival at the fair.

a: In Greek mythology, the god of fire was Hephaestus, the son of Zeus and Hera, or in some accounts, Hera's parthenogenous child. He was the god of blacksmiths, metalworking, carpenters, craftsmen, artisans, sculptors, metallurgy, fire, and volcanoes. Hephaestus was revered as the blacksmith of the gods and was worshiped in the manufacturing and industrial centers of Greece, particularly in Athens. His symbols include a smith's hammer, anvil, and a pair of tongs. He was also associated with the Linear B inscription "A-pa-i-ti-jo", found at Knossos, which is believed to be a theophoric name, indicating his worship at that time. Hephaestus was rejected by his mother Hera because of his deformity and was thrown off Mount Olympus and down to earth. Despite this, he became a skilled craftsman and created all the weapons of the gods, including Zeus' lightning bolts. Hephaestus' association with fire and volcanoes further solidified his role as the god of fire in Greek mythology. His cult was based in Lemnos, and his worship was widespread in the manufacturing centers of Greece.
r1: Hephaestus is the Greek god of blacksmiths, metalworking, carpenters, craftsmen, artisans, sculptors, metallurgy, fire (compare, however, with the Greek goddess of fire, Hestia), and volcanoes.
r2: Hephaestus is the Greek god of blacksmiths, metalworking, carpenters, craftsmen, artisans, sculptors, metallurgy, fire, and volcanoes. In the Ancient Greek religion, Hestia is the virgin goddess of the hearth, the right ordering of domesticity, the family, the home, and the state. Hestia's name means "hearth, fireplace, altar".

0.20083681702701286
a: In 1989, the Oakland Athletics, led by manager Tony La Russa, swept the San Francisco Giants in the World Series, winning the series 4-0. This was the first World Series sweep since 1976 and marked the fourth time in World Series history that a team never trailed in any game. The Athletics, who were managed by La Russa in his first year with the team, won the American League West division and then defeated the Toronto Blue Jays in the American League Championship Series. The Giants, managed by Dusty Baker, won the National League West division and then defeated the Chicago Cubs in the National League Championship Series.

The 1989 World Series was notable for being played during a time of great turmoil in the Bay Area. Just before the series began, a devastating earthquake struck the Loma Prieta region, causing widespread damage and loss of life. The earthquake forced the cancellation of Game 3, which was scheduled to be played at Candlestick Park in San Francisco. The series resumed with Game 4, which was played at the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum.

Despite the challenges posed by the earthquake and the disruption to the series, the Athletics played some of the best baseball of their lives, winning all four games of the series. The team's dominant performance was led by pitchers Dave Stewart, Mike Moore, and Dennis Eckersley, who combined to throw a shutout in Game 2 and allowed only one run in the final three games. The Athletics' offense was led by Mark McGwire, who hit .385 with two home runs and five RBIs in the series.

The 1989 World Series was also notable for the respectful manner in which the Athletics chose not to celebrate their victory. Out of respect for the victims of the earthquake, the team decided not to pour champagne on each other after the final game, as is customary for the winning team in the World Series. Instead, the team held a low-key celebration in their clubhouse.

Overall, the 1989 World Series was a remarkable achievement for the Oakland Athletics, who overcame incredible adversity to win the championship. a: Sure! Here's the answer to the question "Who defeated the New York Jets on the first televised Monday Night Football game?" based on the provided factoid context:

The first televised Monday Night Football game was played between the Cleveland Browns and the New York Jets on September 21, 1970. The game was broadcast on ABC, and the Cleveland Browns emerged victorious with a score of 31-21. The game was a significant milestone in the history of Monday Night Football, as it marked the beginning of a long-running tradition of broadcasting NFL games on Monday nights and set the stage for the growth of the league's popularity on television.

The fact that the game was televised on Monday night was a departure from the traditional Saturday afternoon games that were typically played during the NFL season. The idea of playing a game on Monday night was first proposed by NFL Commissioner Pete Rozelle in the early 1960s, but it was not until 1970 that the league decided to give it a try. The game was played at Cleveland Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio, and it drew a sellout crowd of 82,000 fans.

The Browns were led by quarterback Brian Sipe, who threw for 276 yards and three touchdowns in the victory. The Jets, on the other hand, were led by quarterback Joe Namath, who threw for 237 yards and one touchdown. Despite the loss, the Jets would go on to have a successful season, finishing with a 10-4 record and making it to the AFC Championship Game.

Overall, the first televised Monday Night Football game was a significant moment in the history of the NFL, marking the beginning of a long-running tradition of broadcasting games on Monday nights and setting the stage for the growth of the league's popularity on television.
r1: Beginning in the 1970 NFL season, the National Football League began scheduling a weekly regular season game on Monday night before a national television audience. The team who defeated the New York Jets on the first televised monday night football game was the Cleveland Browns with their coach Blanton Collier.
r2: Beginning in the 1970 NFL season, the National Football League began scheduling a weekly regular season game on Monday night before a national television audience. In the first game, the Cleveland Browns, coached by Blanton Collier, defeated the New York Jets.

a: The name of the river in Salzburg, Austria is the Salzach River. The Salzach River is a right tributary of the Inn River and flows through the Austrian state of Salzburg, as well as a small portion of Germany, before joining the Danube River. The river is approximately 225 kilometers long and has a drainage basin that covers large parts of the Northern Limestone and Central Eastern Alps. The river's name is derived from the German word "Salz" meaning "salt" and "Aach" meaning "stream". Historically, the river was an important transportation route for shipping salt, which was a vital commodity in the local economy. However, with the construction of the parallel Salzburg-Tyrol Railway line in the 19th century, the river's significance as a transportation route declined. Today, the Salzach River is the main river in the Austrian state of Salzburg and is known for its picturesque scenery and white water rapids.

The Taugl River, also known as the Tauglbach, is a tributary of the Salzach River. It rises near the Gennerhorn peak in the Kitzbühel Alps and flows south to north through the Hintersee before emptying into the Salzach River. The Taugl River is classified as a dangerous white water river and is popular for rafting and other water sports.

The Fischach River is another tributary of the Salzach River, flowing through the town of Bergheim before joining the Salzach. It is a right tributary and is known for its picturesque scenery and trout fishing. Overall, the Salzach River and its tributaries, including the Taugl and Fischach Rivers, are important waterways in the Austrian state of Salzburg and offer a range of recreational and economic opportunities.
r1: The Salzach is the main river in the Austrian state of Salzburg. The source is located on the edge of the Kitzbühel Alps near Krimml in the western Pinzgau region. The Almbach is a river of the same state and is approximately 11 miles long. It is the drain of the lake Hintersee. There is also the Fischach, which is a river of the state Salzburg in Austria. It is a right tributary of the Salzach near Bergheim.
r2: There are several rivers in Salzburg, Austria. The Salzach river is the main river. The right tributary of the Salzach is the Fischach river. The Almbach river in Salzburg is 11 miles long.

0.3937823791747429
a: The landmark Supreme Court case of Brown v. Board of Education took place in Topeka, Kansas, in 1954. The case was brought by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) on behalf of Oliver Brown, a African American father who sought to enroll his daughter in a white-only elementary school. The case challenged the constitutionality of state laws that established separate public schools for black and white students, and it effectively overturned the "Plessy v. Ferguson" decision of 1896, which allowed for state-sponsored segregation in public education. The Supreme Court's unanimous decision, delivered on May 17, 1954, declared that "separate educational facilities are inherently unequal" and violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The ruling paved the way for integration and was a major victory for the Civil Rights Movement, but it did not provide a clear method for ending racial segregation in schools, and it was followed by the Court's second decision in "Brown II" which only ordered states to desegregate "with all deliberate speed." For much of the sixty years preceding the "Brown" case, race relations in the United States had been dominated by racial segregation.
r1: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, KS, was a landmark decision of the U.S. Supreme Court in which the Court ruled that U.S. state laws establishing racial segregation in public schools are unconstitutional, even if the segregated schools are otherwise equal in quality. Handed down on May 17, 1954, the Court's unanimous (9–0) decision stated that "separate educational facilities are inherently unequal", and therefore violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.
r2: Brown v Board of Education originated in the city of Topeka, KS, the capital city of the U.S. state of Kansas, and took place in the U.S. Supreme Court, the highest court in the United States federal judiciary.

a: The biggest gold nugget ever found was the Welcome Nugget, discovered in 1858 in Ballarat, Victoria, Australia. It weighed an impressive 2,217 troy ounces (68.98 kg) and was roughly shaped like a horse's head. The nugget was found in the roof of a tunnel 55 meters underground by a group of twenty-two Cornish miners. Despite being eclipsed by the discovery of the larger Welcome Stranger eleven years later, the Welcome Nugget remains the second largest gold nugget ever found. The extreme variability in gold size and distribution, known as the "nugget effect," has made gold exploration in the Goldboro mineralized belts of Nova Scotia, Canada, a challenging endeavor. However, the successful mining of narrow quartz vein gold deposits in Australia, similar to those in Nova Scotia, demonstrates that low-grade concentrations of gold can be mined as economically viable deposits. The Samira Hill Gold Mine in Niger, Africa, is expected to produce 135,000 troy ounces of gold in its first year of operation, with a mine life of six years and estimated reserves of 10,073,626 tons at an average grade of 2.21 grams per ton. The mine's ore processing involves crushing, grinding, and carbon leaching, and it is expected to recover 618,000 troy ounces of gold over its six-year mine life. The Koma Bangou deposit, located within the Samira Horizon gold belt, is estimated to contain 315,000 ounces of gold in reserves.
r1: Gold nuggets of various sizes have been found throughout the world. Two gold nuggets are claimed as the largest in the world, with the first one being the Welcome Stranger. Considered by most authorities to be the biggest gold nugget ever found, it was found at Moliagul, Victoria, Australia in 1869 by John Deason and Richard Oates, and weighed in at 214.15 pounds. The second one, the Canaã nugget, was found in the State of Para, Brazil, and is the largest surviving natural nugget on record weighing in at 156.6 pounds. In the United States, the largest nugget ever found was in Sierra Buttes, California, and weighed 109.2 pounds.
r2: Most authorities consider the Welcome Stranger to be the biggest gold nugget ever found, measuring 24 by 12 in and weighing 97.14 kilograms. It was found in 1869 in Moliagul, Victoria, Australia, and is also the biggest gold nugget ever found in Australia. The biggest gold nugget found in Brazil was found in the State of Para. The biggest one found in the United States was found in Sierra Buttes.

a: During World War II, the United States fought against three main Axis powers: Germany, Italy, and Japan. The war began for the United States on December 7, 1941, with the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor by Japan, which led to the United States' formal entry into the conflict. Prior to this, the United States had maintained a policy of neutrality, while still providing military aid to Britain, the Soviet Union, and China through the Lend-Lease Act. The U.S. military played a significant role in the war, particularly in the Pacific Theater, where U.S. forces replaced British invasion forces in Iceland and engaged in early combat activities such as those carried out by the Flying Tigers.

The U.S. military was led by key civilian advisors to President Roosevelt, including Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, who mobilized the nation's industries and induction centers to supply the Army, and General George Marshall and Admiral Ernest King, who commanded the Army and Navy, respectively. The U.S. military suffered significant losses during the war, with over 405,000 killed in action and 671,000 wounded. Additionally, 130,000 American prisoners of war were taken, of whom 116,000 returned home after the war.

The U.S. fought against Germany and Italy in Europe and North Africa, and against Japan in the Pacific. The war in Europe saw a series of defeats for Germany, including the siege of Stalingrad and the Battle of Kursk. In December 1941, Germany declared war on the United States after Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor. The Allied Forces, including the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union, eventually gained the upper hand and defeated Germany, Italy, and Japan. The war in Europe ended in May 1945, with Germany's surrender, and the war in the Pacific ended in September 1945, with Japan's surrender following the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

World War II was the deadliest conflict in human history, causing between 50 and 80 million deaths, with the majority being civilians. The war was also marked by systematic genocide, including the Holocaust, which resulted in the murder of six million Jews and millions of others deemed undesirable by the Nazi regime. The United States' involvement in World War II had a profound impact on the country's economy, society, and politics, and helped to shape the world as we know it today.

r2: The Tripartite Pact, also known as the Berlin Pact, was an agreement between Germany, Italy, and Japan signed in Berlin on 27 September 1940. The Axis powers, originally called the Rome–Berlin Axis, was a military coalition that fought in World War II against the Allies, and the United States.

0.44585986778206016
a: The type of cell that contributes to the blood-brain barrier in the central nervous system (CNS) is the endothelial cell. The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is composed of specialized endothelial cells that form tight junctions, restricting the passage of solutes from the bloodstream into the CNS. These tight junctions are composed of transmembrane proteins such as occludin, claudins, junctional adhesion molecule (JAM), and ESAM, which are anchored into the endothelial cells by protein complexes that include ZO-1 and associated proteins. The BBB is unique compared to other capillaries in the body, as it is composed of high-density cells that restrict the passage of substances more effectively. Additionally, astrocyte cell projections called astrocytic feet surround the endothelial cells of the BBB, providing biochemical support to these cells. The BBB is distinct from other barriers in the CNS, such as the blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier, which is formed by choroidal cells of the choroid plexus, and the blood-retinal barrier, which is a part of the whole realm of such barriers.
r1: The blood-brain barrier is composed of high-density cells restricting passage of substances from the bloodstream much more than do the endothelial cells in capillaries elsewhere in the body. Astrocyte cell projections called astrocytic feet (also known as "glia limitans") surround the endothelial cells of the BBB, providing biochemical support to those cells.
r2: The blood–brain barrier (BBB) is a highly selective semipermeable border of endothelial cells that prevents solutes in the circulating blood from non-selectively crossing into the extracellular fluid of the central nervous system where neurons reside. The blood-brain barrier is composed of high-density cells restricting passage of substances from the bloodstream much more than do the endothelial cells in capillaries elsewhere in the body. Astrocyte cell projections called astrocytic feet (also known as "glia limitans") surround the endothelial cells of the BBB, providing biochemical support to those cells.

a: The history of personal computers as mass-market consumer electronic devices began in the 1980s with the microcomputer revolution. Prior to this time, computers were primarily mainframe systems or single-user minicomputers that were too expensive and complex for individual consumers. The first personal computer was the IBM Personal Computer, launched in 1981, which popularized the term "Personal Computer" and coined the abbreviation "PC." Early personal computers were sold in electronic kit form and were of interest mostly to hobbyists and technicians. However, with the introduction of the Altair 8800 in 1975, the first commercially successful personal computer, the industry began to take off. The Altair spawned an entire industry of clones and add-on kits, and the market for personal computers grew rapidly. By 1979, over half a million microcomputers had been sold, and the youth of the day had a new concept of the personal computer. The introduction of the IBM Personal Computer in 1981 further solidified the concept of the personal computer as a mass-market consumer electronic device, and the market for PCs has continued to grow and evolve since then.

The history of personal computers can be traced back to the development of the microprocessor, which made it possible to produce individual computers that were low enough in cost to be affordable for individual consumers. The first personal computer, the Altair 8800, was sold in kit form and was relatively difficult to use, requiring machine language programs to be entered by hand via front-panel switches. However, the success of the Altair spawned an entire industry of clones and add-on kits, and the market for personal computers grew rapidly.

The IBM Personal Computer, launched in 1981, was a significant milestone in the history of personal computers. It popularized the term "Personal Computer" and coined the abbreviation "PC." The IBM PC was designed to be user-friendly and accessible to a wide range of users, and it quickly became a bestseller. The success of the IBM PC helped to solidify the concept of the personal computer as a mass-market consumer electronic device, and the market for PCs has continued to grow and evolve since then.

In conclusion, the history of personal computers as mass-market consumer electronic devices began in the 1980s with the microcomputer revolution. The Altair 8800 was the first commercially successful personal computer, and the IBM Personal Computer further solidified the concept of the personal computer as a mass-market consumer electronic device. The market for personal computers has continued to grow and evolve since then, with advances in technology and decreasing costs making personal computers more accessible and user-friendly for individuals.
r1: The history of the personal computer as a mass-market consumer electronic device began with the microcomputer revolution of the 1970s. In 1968, a manufacturer took the risk of referring to their product as a "personal computer", when Hewlett-Packard advertised their "Powerful Computing Genie" as "The New Hewlett-Packard 9100A personal computer". The Altair was introduced in a "Popular Electronics" magazine article in the January 1975 issue. In keeping with MITS's earlier projects, the Altair was sold in kit form, although a relatively complex one consisting of four circuit boards and many parts. In 1977, three new pre-assembled small computers hit the markets which "Byte" would refer to as the "1977 Trinity" of personal computing. The Apple II and the PET 2001 were advertised as "personal computers", while the TRS-80 was described as a microcomputer used for household tasks including ""personal" financial management".
r2: Kits and preassembled versions of personal computers were introduced at different times, while other products were marketed as personal computers prior to actual personal computers being sold. Hewlett-Packard had the first product marketed to the public as a personal computer in 1968 when they referred to one of their programmable calculators in ads as "The New Hewlett-Packard 9100A personal computer," but they later changed the ad. The first actual personal computer sold to the public, in kit form in 1975, was the Altair 8800. a: Galvanized metals have been covered with a thin sheet of zinc to prevent rusting, a process known as galvanization. The most common method of galvanization is hot-dip galvanizing, where the metal parts are submerged in a bath of molten zinc. This process protects the underlying steel or iron in several ways, including providing a physical barrier against corrosion, sacrificing the zinc coating to prevent the steel from corroding, and reacting with the steel to form a protective layer of zinc oxide. The use of zinc coatings has been widely adopted due to its effectiveness in extending the lifespan of metal structures and reducing maintenance costs. The term "galvanized" has also been used metaphorically to describe any stimulus that results in activity, as the original application of the term in scientific research and medical practice referred to the stimulation of muscles by electric current. The history of galvanization can be traced back to the 17th century, with the earliest known example of galvanized iron encountered by Europeans on Indian armor in the Royal Armouries Museum collection. Over time, the term "galvanizing" has come to be associated almost exclusively with zinc coatings, and has become a widely recognized and widely adopted method of protecting metal structures from corrosion.
r1: Galvanization is the process of applying a protective zinc coating to steel or iron, to prevent rusting. The most common method is hot-dip galvanizing, in which the parts are submerged in a bath of molten hot zinc iron alloys.
r2: Galvanization or galvanizing is the process of applying a protective zinc coating to steel or iron, to prevent rusting. The most common method is hot-dip galvanizing, which deposits a thick, robust layer of zinc iron alloys on the surface of a steel item.

a: Elizabeth Loftus is a prominent pioneer in the field of eye witness research, who has made significant contributions to the understanding of the malleability of human memory and the limitations of eyewitness testimony. Building upon the work of Hugo Münsterberg, who was one of the first psychologists to question the reliability of eyewitness accounts, Loftus has conducted extensive research on the factors that can influence memory and lead to false or inaccurate recall.

Loftus' work has focused particularly on the concept of the "misinformation effect," which refers to the way in which exposure to false or misleading information can alter an individual's memory of an event. She has demonstrated through numerous studies that even seemingly innocuous information, such as the presence of a leading question or the presence of a witness, can significantly alter an individual's memory of an event.

In addition to her research on the misinformation effect, Loftus has also studied the creation and nature of false memories, including recovered memories of childhood sexual abuse. Her work in this area has been controversial, as it has challenged the validity of such memories and raised questions about the reliability of memory in general.

Loftus' contributions to the field of eye witness research have been widely recognized, and she has been ranked as one of the most influential psychological researchers of the 20th century. Her work has had a significant impact on the legal system, and she has consulted or provided expert witness testimony for hundreds of cases.

Hugo Münsterberg, another pioneer in the field of eye witness research, was one of the first psychologists to question the reliability of eyewitness accounts. His work, which was published in the early 20th century, challenged the long-held belief that eyewitness testimony was a credible and reliable form of evidence. Münsterberg's research demonstrated that eyewitness accounts could be influenced by a variety of factors, including the witness's own biases and expectations, and that memories could be distorted or altered over time.

Despite the significant contributions of Münsterberg and Loftus, the reliability of eyewitness testimony remains a contentious issue in the legal system. However, the work of these pioneers has helped to shed light on the limitations of eyewitness testimony and has led to the development of new techniques and strategies for evaluating the reliability of eyewitness accounts.
r1: Eyewitness testimony is the account a bystander or victim gives in the courtroom, describing what that person observed that occurred during the specific incident under investigation. It's a topic that is researched, and psychologists have probed the reliability of eyewitness testimony since the beginning of the 20th century. Elizabeth F. Loftus is an American cognitive psychologist and expert on human memory, and is known for her pioneering of research in the field. Another prominent pioneer from the early 20th century was German-American psychologist Hugo Münsterberg, whose controversial book "On the Witness Stand" demonstrated the fallibility of eyewitness accounts, but met with fierce criticism, particularly in legal circles.
r2: There have been several pioneers in the field of eyewitness research. A female pioneer in the field was Elizabeth Loftus, an American cognitive psychologist and expert on human memory. Psychologist Hugo Münsterberg was a prominent German-American pioneer in eyewitness testimony in the 20th century.

a: In Chinese philosophy, yin and yang (or yīnyáng) represents the idea that seemingly opposite or contrary forces are actually complementary, interconnected, and interdependent in the natural world. This concept is often depicted in the taijitu symbol, which shows a balance between two opposites with a portion of the opposite element in each section. According to Taoist metaphysics, distinctions between good and bad, as well as other dichotomous moral judgments, are perceptual, not real; therefore, the duality of yin and yang is considered an indivisible whole. In contrast, Confucianism attaches a moral dimension to the idea of yin and yang, with "yin" representing the "shady side" and "yang" representing the "sunny side."

The Chinese terms "yin" and "yang" are analyzable in terms of their etymology, meanings, topography, and loanwords. The Traditional Chinese characters for the words "yīn" and "yáng" are both classified as radical-esphonetic characters, combining the semantically significant "mound; hill" radical with the phonetic indicators "ying" and "yang." The first phonetic "yīn" "cloudy" ideographically combines "jīn" "now; present" and "yún" "cloud," denoting the "今 presence of clouds."

In Chinese cosmology, the universe creates itself out of a primary chaos of material energy, organized into the cycles of Yin and Yang and formed into objects and lives. Yin is the receptive principle, while Yang is the active principle, and they are seen in all forms of change and difference, such as the annual cycle, the landscape, sexual coupling, the formation of both men and women as characters, and sociopolitical history. The material energy, which the universe is made of, is also referred to as qi, and it is believed that the organization of qi in this cosmology of Yin and Yang has formed many things, including humans.

In conclusion, the concept of yin and yang in Chinese philosophy represents the idea that seemingly opposite forces are actually complementary and interconnected. This concept is depicted in the taijitu symbol and is analyzable in terms of etymology, meanings, topography, and loanwords. It is a fundamental aspect of Chinese cosmology, where it is believed that the organization of qi in the cycles of Yin and Yang has formed the universe and all things within it, including humans.

a: Vikram Samvat is the official calendar of Nepal and is also widely recognized in North and East India, as well as among Hindus in Gujarat. This ancient Hindu calendar, also known as the Bikrami calendar or Hindu calendar, has been in use for centuries and is based on lunar months and solar sidereal years. The Vikram Samvat calendar is notable for its association with many ancient and medieval era inscriptions, and is said to be named after the legendary king Vikramaditya. However, the origins of the calendar are not well-documented before the 9th century, and it is believed that the current era was established in the 9th century as Vikram Samvat, replacing earlier calendars such as "Krita" and "Malava."

The Vikram Samvat calendar is still widely used today, particularly in North and East India, and is an important part of Hindu religious festivals. The new year in Vikram Samvat begins in mid-April, and is celebrated with great fanfare in many parts of India and Nepal. The calendar is also associated with the Buddhist and Jain communities, who use it to commemorate important events such as Buddha's birth, enlightenment, and passing. In Gujarat, the second day of Diwali is celebrated as the first day of the Vikram Samvat calendar.

Overall, the Vikram Samvat calendar is an important part of South Asian cultural heritage and is still widely used today, both as a religious calendar and as a way of connecting with the past. Its association with ancient and medieval era inscriptions, as well as its continued use in modern times, make it a valuable tool for understanding the history and culture of the region.
r1: Vikram Samvat or Bikram Sambat and also known as the Vikrami calendar, is the historical Hindu calendar used in some but not all states of the Indian subcontinent. It is also the official calendar of Nepal.
r2: Vikram Samvat is the historical Hindu calendar in India but is the official calendar of Nepal. All states of Nepal use the Vikram Samvat, but only some parts of India use it as the official calendar. The calendar remains in use by people in north, west and central India. In south India and portions of east and west India, the Indian national calendar is widely used.

a: Sure, here is a comprehensive, well-structured paragraph that answers the question "Who sang the song 'Bette Davis Eyes'?" and provides a thorough explanation of the song's history and success:

"Bette Davis Eyes" is a hit song that was written and composed by Donna Weiss and Jackie DeShannon, but it was American singer Kim Carnes who brought the song to commercial success in 1981. DeShannon recorded the song in 1974 on her album "New Arrangement," but it was Carnes's synthesizer-based arrangement that made the song a chart-topper. Carnes's version spent nine non-consecutive weeks at No. 1 on the "Billboard" Hot 100, was "Billboard"s biggest hit of 1981, and reached No. 5 on the Top Tracks charts and No. 26 on the Dance charts. The song's success was rewarded with two Grammy Awards for Song of the Year and Record of the Year. The song's enduring popularity is a testament to the timeless appeal of its catchy melody and the iconic status of Bette Davis, whose eyes were immortalized in the song's title.
r1: "Bette Davis Eyes" is a song written and composed in 1974 by Donna Weiss and Jackie DeShannon. However, it was made popular by American singer Kim Carnes in 1981 when it spent nine non-consecutive weeks on top of the US Billboard Hot 100.
r2: "Bette Davis Eyes" is a song written and composed by Donna Weiss and Jackie DeShannon, and made popular by American singer Kim Carnes. DeShannon recorded the song that same year on her album "New Arrangement." However, it was not until March 1981, when Kim Carnes recorded her version of the song in a radically different synthesizer-based arrangement, that "Bette Davis Eyes" became a commercial success where it spent nine non-consecutive weeks at No. 1 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 and was "Billboard"'s biggest hit of 1981.
