a: Who sang "What Is Love baby don't hurt me"?

The song "What Is Love" was recorded by Trinidadian-German Eurodance artist Haddaway for his debut album "The Album". The song was a massive hit in Europe, reaching number one in at least 13 countries and becoming a cultural phenomenon. The refrain of the song, "What is love? Baby don't hurt me, don't hurt me... no more," has become iconic and has been featured in various forms of media, including the "Saturday Night Live" sketch "Roxbury Guys" and the video game "Saints Row IV".

The song was written and produced by German music producers Dee Dee Halligan (Dieter Lünstedt a.k.a. Tony Hendrik) and Junior Torello (Karin Hartmann-Eisenblätter a.k.a. Karin van Haaren) of Coconut Records in Cologne. They were searching for the right singer for the song and eventually chose Haddaway, who was a producer, dancer, and choreographer before being signed to Coconut Records.

The song was released in Europe in May 1993 and in the US in August 1993. It was a moderate success outside of Europe, reaching number 11 in the US, number 12 in Australia, number 17 in Canada, and number 48 in New Zealand. However, its enduring popularity has made it a staple of dance clubs and a cultural touchstone to this day. In 2009, German DJ Klaas remixed the song under the title "Klaas meets Haddaway – What Is Love 2K9", which charted in several European countries. In 2016, Belgian DJ Lost Frequencies released a cover of the song, titled "What Is Love 2016", which was produced back in 2014 as a remix for Jaymes Young's cover version of "What Is Love".

Overall, "What Is Love" is a classic dance hit that has stood the test of time and continues to be a beloved anthem for dance floors and pop culture enthusiasts around the world.
r1: "What Is Love" is a song recorded by Trinidadian-German Eurodance artist Haddaway for his debut album, The Album. The song was released on 8 May 1993 as the album's lead single. It was a massive hit in Europe, becoming a number-one hit in at least 13 countries and reaching number two in Germany, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. In 2013, it was sang by Foolstop, and in 2014, Kiesza released their version of the song. In 2009, German DJ Klaas remixed the song under the title "Klaas meets Haddaway – What Is Love 2K9". This remix charted in several European countries.
r2: "What Is Love" is a song recorded by Trinidadian-German Eurodance artist Haddaway for his debut album, The Album. In 2009, German DJ Klaas remixed the song under the title "Klaas meets Haddaway – What Is Love 2K9". In 2013, Foolstop sang "What Is Love". in 2014, Kiesza, a Canadian singer and multi-instrumentalist from Calgary, sang "What is Love".

The record for most passing yards in a season is held by Drew Brees, who threw for an astonishing 5,477 yards in 2011. This impressive feat not only earned him the Associated Press NFL Offensive Player of the Year Award but also broke the previous record of 5,084 yards set by Dan Marino in 1984. Marino's record had stood for 27 years before Brees's record-breaking season. Interestingly, Brees's achievement came just a year after Peyton Manning set league single-season records for passing yards (5,477) and passing touchdowns (55) in 2013. These remarkable performances by Brees and Manning showcase the high level of skill and competition among quarterbacks in the NFL, and they continue to push the boundaries of what is possible in the sport.
r1: Passing for 5,000 yards in a single regular season is a rare achievement in the National Football League (NFL). Eight different quarterbacks have accomplished the feat, Dan Marino was the first when he set an NFL record with 5,084 yards passing in 1984. Peyton Manning currently holds the record with 5,477 passing yards in 2013, with Drew Brees being exactly one yard short of this mark. Drew Brees is the only NFL quarterback to reach 5,000 yards more than once, having done so five times.
r2: Several people have held the record for most passing yards in a season. Peyton Manning currently holds the NFL record with 5,477 in 2013. Drew Brees holds the NFL record for reaching 5,000 passing yards more than once and held the record for most passing yards in a season in 2011. Dan Marino held the record for most in a season in 1984, when he became the first quarterback to pass 5,000 yards in a single regular season, with 5,084.

a: Italy entered the First World War on May 23, 1915, after a long period of political and social unification. The country had been divided into various states since the fall of the Roman Empire, and the process of unification began in 1815 with the Congress of Vienna. However, some territories, known as "terre irredente," did not join the Kingdom of Italy until after World War I. The movement for unification was marked by the romantic, nationalist, and patriotic ideals of an Italian renaissance, which sought to conquer a unified political identity and restore the ancient Roman roots of the country.

The political and social changes proposed by Sidney Sonnino, a prominent figure in the unification movement, provoked opposition from the ruling groups, and he was eventually succeeded by Giovanni Giolitti. Despite initially supporting the Triple Alliance with Germany and Austria-Hungary, Sonnino later sided with the Entente powers and sanctioned the secret Treaty of London in April 1915, which aimed to fulfill Italy's irredentist claims. This led to Italy's declaration of war against Austria-Hungary on May 23, 1915.

The unification of Italy was a complex and prolonged process that spanned several centuries, and it was marked by significant political and social changes. The movement was driven by the desire to create a unified Italian state and to restore the country's ancient Roman roots. However, the process was not without its challenges, and it was marked by opposition from the ruling groups and the struggle for power among different political factions. Ultimately, Italy's entry into World War I was a significant turning point in the country's history, and it marked the completion of the unification process that had begun over a century earlier.
r1: Italy entered into the First World War with the aim of completing national unity: for this reason, the Italian intervention in the First World War is also considered the Fourth Italian War of Independence. It began when the Treaty of London was signed on 26 April 1915 and Italy declared war against Austria-Hungary on 23 May 1915.
r2: Italy entered the First World War in 1915 by signing the Treaty of London on 26 April 1915 and by declaring war on Austria-Hungary on 23 May 1915. The Treaty of London was a secret agreement between the United Kingdom, France, Russia, and the Kingdom of Italy with the aim of enticing Italy to enter the First World War on the side of the Triple Entente.

a: The Sahara Desert, which covers much of North Africa, is a vast and diverse ecosystem that is characterized by two main types of climates: desert and steppe. The North Saharan steppe and woodlands ecoregion, located along the northern edge of the Sahara, forms an ecotone between the Mediterranean climate regions to the north and the hyper-arid Sahara Desert to the south. This ecoregion experiences hot and dry summers, but cooler winters with some rainfall, and is characterized by a variety of habitats, including sandy systems, rocky plateaus, wadis, depressions, and mountains. The Sahara Desert itself is the largest hot desert in the world, covering an area comparable to the size of China or the United States, and is divided into several regions, including the western Sahara, the central Ahaggar Mountains, the Tibesti Mountains, the Aïr Mountains, the Ténéré desert, and the Libyan Desert. The Sahara has alternated between desert and savanna grassland over the past several hundred thousand years due to changes in the Earth's axis as it rotates around the sun, which affect the location of the North African Monsoon. This diverse ecosystem is home to a wide range of plants and animals, with many species being endemic to the area.
r1: The Sahara is a desert on the African continent, with an area of 9,200,000 square kilometres (3,600,000 sq mi). It is the largest hot desert in the world and the third largest desert overall, smaller only than the deserts of Antarctica and the northern Arctic. The North Saharan steppe and woodlands is along the northern desert, next to the Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub ecoregions of the northern Maghreb and Cyrenaica. To the south, it is bounded by the Sahel, a belt of semi-arid tropical savanna around the Niger River valley and the Sudan Region of Sub-Saharan Africa.
r2: The Sahara is a desert on the African continent. To the south, it is bounded by the Sahel, a belt of semi-arid tropical savanna around the Niger River valley and the Sudan Region of Sub-Saharan Africa. The North Saharan steppe and woodlands is along the northern desert, next to the Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub ecoregions of the northern Maghreb and Cyrenaica. Winter rains sustain shrublands and dry woodlands that form a transition between the Mediterranean climate regions to the north and the hyper-arid Sahara proper to the south.

a: The Makkah Royal Clock Tower, located within the Abraj Al Bait complex in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, was built in 2012. The tower stands at a height of 601 meters (1,972 feet), making it the third-tallest building and fifth-tallest freestanding structure in the world. The tower's construction was part of the King Abdulaziz Endowment Project, which aimed to modernize the city and provide better accommodations for pilgrims visiting the holy city. The tower's design incorporates four clock faces, two of which are the largest in the world, with a diameter of 46 meters (151 feet) each. The Abraj Al Bait complex is located just meters away from the Grand Mosque of Mecca, Islam's holiest site, and was built after the demolition of the historic Ajyad Fortress in 2002. The controversial demolition sparked international outcry, particularly from Turkey, which had previously owned the site. The tower's construction was undertaken by the Saudi Binladin Group, the kingdom's largest construction company, at a cost of US$15 billion, making it the world's most expensive building. The Makkah Royal Clock Tower is not only an impressive architectural feat but also a testament to the kingdom's commitment to modernization and religious tourism.

In contrast, the Blue Water Hotel in Wadduwa, Sri Lanka, is a 5-star boutique hotel that was built in 1998. The hotel was designed by renowned architect Geoffrey Bawa and was one of his last projects before his death. The hotel is situated on a former coconut plantation and features a minimalist design that blends seamlessly into its coastal surroundings. The hotel suffered damage during the 2004 Boxing Day tsunami but was renovated and reopened in 2008. The hotel's design is notable for its careful orchestration of spaces between the land and the ocean, creating a serene and peaceful ambiance for guests.

While the two buildings are vastly different in terms of their purpose, location, and design, they both showcase the attention to detail and commitment to excellence that is characteristic of luxury architecture. The Makkah Royal Clock Tower stands as a testament to Saudi Arabia's commitment to modernization and religious tourism, while the Blue Water Hotel represents a masterful blend of minimalist design and natural beauty.
r1: The Abraj Al-Bait is a government-owned complex of seven skyscraper hotels in Mecca, Saudi Arabia. The central hotel tower, the Makkah Clock Royal Tower, began construction in 2004, and has the world's largest clock face and is the third-tallest building and fifth-tallest freestanding structure in the world. The clock tower contains the Clock Tower Museum that occupies the top four floors of the tower. Construction of the tower was completed in 2012, and cost a total of $15 billion.
r2: The Makkah Royal Clock Tower was built between 2004 and 2012, with construction starting in 2004 and ending in 2012. a: India's rank in the World Bank's ease of doing business index is an important indicator of the country's progress in creating a business-friendly environment. According to the World Bank's report, India's rank has improved significantly over the years, from 130th in 2016 to 100th in 2017. This improvement is a result of the government's efforts to reform the business environment, including the introduction of the Business Reforms Action Plan (BRAP) in 2015. The BRAP is an annual plan that outlines specific action items to be completed by states and union territories to improve the ease of doing business.

The BRAP covers eight key areas, including starting a business, dealing with construction permits, getting credit, protecting minority investors, paying taxes, trading across borders, enforcing contracts, and resolving insolvency. Each of these areas has a number of action points that must be completed by the states and union territories. The World Bank ranks the states and union territories based on their completion of these action points, and the rankings are published annually.

The ease of doing business ranking of states of India is not based on the level of business-conducive nature of the states, but rather on the willingness of the states to reform and attract investments. The ranking is an important tool for investors to assess the business environment of different states and make informed decisions about investing in India.

The improvement in India's ease of doing business rank is a result of the government's efforts to simplify regulations, reduce bureaucracy, and increase transparency. For example, the government has introduced the "Make in India" initiative, which aims to attract foreign investment and promote domestic manufacturing. Additionally, the government has introduced the "Digital India" initiative, which aims to promote digital governance and reduce paperwork.

The World Bank's ease of doing business ranking is not only an important indicator of India's progress, but also a benchmark for other countries to follow. The ranking has been cited as an important factor in attracting foreign investment, and has helped to promote competition among states to improve their business environments.

In conclusion, India's rank in the World Bank's ease of doing business index is an important indicator of the country's progress in creating a business-friendly environment. The improvement in the rank is a result of the government's efforts to reform the business environment, and the ranking is an important tool for investors to assess the business environment of different states. The government's efforts to simplify regulations, reduce bureaucracy, and increase transparency have contributed to the improvement in the rank, and the World Bank's ease of doing business ranking is an important benchmark for other countries to follow.
r1: The ease of doing business index is an index created jointly by Simeon Djankov, Michael Klein and Caralee McLiesh, three leading economists at the World Bank Group. Higher rankings (a low numerical value) indicate better, usually simpler, regulations for businesses and stronger protections of property rights. In 2015, India was ranked 142 on the scale. From 2016 to 2017, they move up ranks to 130.
r2: The ease of doing business index is an index created jointly by Simeon Djankov, Michael Klein and Caralee McLiesh, three leading economists at the World Bank Group. In 2015, India was ranked 142 in the world in the ease of doing business. From 2016 to 2017, India was ranked 130 in the world.

0.28378377911340397
a: The Latin word "camera obscura" refers to the natural optical phenomenon where an image of a scene on the other side of a screen is projected as a reversed and inverted image on a surface opposite the opening. The term "camera obscura" also refers to devices that utilize this principle, such as boxes or tents with a small hole or lens that project the image. The camera obscura was used as a drawing aid and to study eclipses without damaging the eyes. The device was first referred to as "camera obscura" in 1604, but other terms such as "cubiculum obscurum" and "pinhole camera" have also been used. The image formed by the camera obscura is created by rays of light that travel through the small opening in the screen and are collected on a surface opposite the opening. The image is reversed and inverted due to the nature of the optics involved. This phenomenon has been used to create highly accurate representations of scenes, especially in the field of drawing and painting.
r1: A camera obscura, from the Latin word camera obscūra or "dark chamber", is a darkened room with a small hole or lens at one side through which an image is projected onto a wall or table opposite the hole. A camera obscura without a lens but with a very small hole is sometimes referred to as a pinhole camera or pinhole image, although this more often refers to simple (homemade) lensless cameras where photographic film or photographic paper is used.
r2: The literal meaning of the Latin word camera obscura is "dark chamber," while its meaning in common photography is "pinhole image." Camera obscura is also the Latin name of the original device for projecting an image of external reality onto a flat surface. The modern photographic camera evolved from the camera obscura.
============================482=============================

0.3137254863033449
a: Adipose tissue can be found in various locations throughout the body, but one of the most significant deposits of adipose tissue is found in the abdominal cavity, specifically in the region known as visceral fat or abdominal fat. This type of fat is located between the organs in the abdominal cavity, such as the stomach, liver, intestines, and kidneys, and is composed of several adipose depots, including mesenteric, epididymal white adipose tissue (EWAT), and perirenal depots. Visceral fat is distinct from subcutaneous fat, which is found beneath the skin, and intramuscular fat, which is interspersed within skeletal muscles.

Visceral fat is particularly important because it is associated with a number of health risks, including central obesity, type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, inflammatory diseases, and other obesity-related diseases. In fact, excess visceral fat is often referred to as "belly fat" and is linked to a higher risk of mortality. To measure the amount of visceral fat in the body, new developments such as the Body Volume Index (BVI) have been created to measure abdominal volume and abdominal fat.

In addition to visceral fat, adipose tissue can also be found in other areas of the body, such as the thighs, buttocks, and neck. However, the adipose tissue found in these areas is typically subcutaneous fat, which is not as closely linked to health risks as visceral fat. Adipose tissue is composed of adipocytes, which are specialized cells that store energy in the form of lipids, as well as other cells such as preadipocytes, fibroblasts, vascular endothelial cells, and immune cells. Adipose tissue also produces hormones such as leptin, estrogen, resistin, and the cytokine TNFα, highlighting its importance as a major endocrine organ in the body.
r1: Adipose tissue, body fat, or simply fat is a loose connective tissue composed mostly of adipocytes, and is found beneath the skin, around internal organs, in bone marrow, intermuscular, and in the breast. In addition to adipocytes, adipose tissue contains the stromal vascular fraction (SVF) of cells including preadipocytes, fibroblasts, vascular endothelial cells and a variety of immune cells such as adipose tissue macrophages. Adipose depots are areas in the body where adipose tissue can be found.
r2: Adipose tissue, body fat, or simply fat is a loose connective tissue composed mostly of adipocytes. Adipose tissue can be found beneath the skin, around internal organs, in bone marrow, intermuscular, and in the breast. Adipose tissue is found in specific locations, which are referred to as adipose depots.

a: Sure, here's a comprehensive answer to the question "How much did it cost Rio to host the Olympics?" based on the provided factoid context:

Rio de Janeiro hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics at a cost of US$14.4 billion, after three failed attempts to host the Games in 1936, 2004, and 2012. This was the city's first successful bid, which was concluded with the election of Rio de Janeiro as the host city during the 121st IOC Session held in Copenhagen, Denmark, on October 2, 2009. The cost of hosting the Games included the construction of 30 competition venues in four Olympic zones—Barra, Copacabana, Deodoro, and Maracanã—as well as venues for golf and rugby union, which were added to the Olympic program after the election. Additionally, football matches were held in the cities of Belo Horizonte, Brasília, Salvador, and São Paulo. The proposed dates for the Olympic Games were from August 5 to 21, while the Paralympic Games were held from September 7 to 18.

Rio de Janeiro's bidding process began on July 28, 2006, when the Executive Council of the Brazilian Olympic Committee (COB) met to consider the possibility of nominating a Brazilian city to host the 2016 Summer Olympics and Paralympics. The city's initial budget for the Games was estimated at US$10.4 billion, but it eventually rose to US$14.4 billion due to various factors such as inflation, currency fluctuations, and the need for additional infrastructure projects. Despite the high cost, Rio de Janeiro's successful bid to host the Games marked a significant milestone for South America and the city, bringing international recognition and economic benefits to the region.
r1: The Olympic Games, considered to be the world's foremost international sporting event with over 200 nations participating, has historically had the highest costs and expenses for the hosts, with the final operating budget of the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro being at approximately US$13,100,000,000, and a taxpayer contribution of US$11.6 billion.
r2: The final operating budget in Rio to host the Olympics was US$13,100,000,000, and hosting the Olympics cost the Rio taxpayers US$11.6 billion. The current highest cost of hosting the Olympic Games was the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Summer Games. Also, the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Summer Games experienced the biggest net loss recorded at approximately US$2 billion.

a: The primary objective of the Tour de France is to determine the most efficient and skilled road bicycle rider in a multi-stage race that spans over 23 days, covering a distance of approximately 3,500 kilometers. The race is designed to test the endurance, speed, and climbing abilities of the riders as they navigate through a variety of terrain, including flat roads, mountain ranges, and individual time trials. The race is also a showcase for the latest technology and innovation in the world of cycling, with teams and riders constantly seeking to gain an edge over their competitors through advances in equipment, training methods, and strategy.

In addition to determining the overall winner of the race, the Tour de France also serves as a platform for promoting the sport of cycling and showcasing the beauty and culture of France and other countries along the route. The race has become a global event, attracting millions of viewers and fans from around the world, and is widely considered to be one of the most prestigious and challenging cycling events in the world.

The race is organized by the Amaury Sport Organisation and is a UCI World Tour event, which means that the teams and riders that compete in the race are among the top-level professionals in the sport. The race is held primarily in the month of July, with the route changing each year but maintaining the traditional format of time trials, mountain stages, and the final finish on the Champs-Élysées in Paris. The race is a test of physical and mental endurance, with riders facing a variety of challenges, including grueling mountain stages, high-speed descents, and the constant pressure of competition. The winner of the Tour de France is awarded the famous yellow jersey, or maillot jaune, and is recognized as one of the greatest cyclists in the world.
r1: The Tour de France is an annual men's multiple-stage bicycle race primarily held in France, while also occasionally passing through nearby countries. Like the other Grand Tours (the Giro d'Italia and the Vuelta a España), it consists of 21 stages, each a day long, over the course of 23 days. The race was first organized in 1903 to increase sales for the newspaper L'Auto and is currently run by the Amaury Sport Organisation. The current objective is to win the world’s most prestigious and most difficult bicycle race.
r2: The current objective of the Tour de France is to win the world’s most prestigious and most difficult bicycle race, but the original objective when it was first organized in 1903 was to increase sales for the newspaper L'Auto, who originated the Tour de France cycling stage race in 1903 as a circulation booster.

a: Here's the comprehensive answer to the question "Who has the most home runs in the home run derby?" based on the given factoid context:

The player with the most home runs in the home run derby is Aaron Judge, who won the 2017 Major League Baseball Home Run Derby with a total of 20 home runs. Judge, a rookie at the time, became the first rookie to win the event outright, defeating Miguel Sano in the final round. The derby was held on July 10, 2017, at Marlins Park in Miami, Florida, as part of the MLB All-Star Game.

Giancarlo Stanton, who won the derby in 2016 with a total of 20 home runs, holds the record for the most home runs in a single round, with 20 home runs in the final round. Stanton also hit the most home runs in a single minute, with 17 home runs in the final minute.

Joc Pederson, who participated in the 2015 and 2017 home run derbies, is the only player to have hit a home run off a T-Mobile Ball in the final minute, which resulted in a $10,000 donation to charity by T-Mobile & MLB to the Boys & Girls Clubs of America.

In the 2015 Major League Baseball Home Run Derby, Joc Pederson, who had the most total home runs in the Home Run Derby over multiple years, made it to the final round, but lost to Cincinnati Reds third baseman Todd Frazier. Then in the 2016 Home Run Derby, Giancarlo Stanton won by defeating defending champion Todd Frazier 20–13. The next year during the 2017 Home Run Derby, Aaron Judge won, becoming the first rookie to win the event outright. In terms of most home runs in a single Derby ever, the current overall record is held by Vladimir Guerrero Jr. at a mark of 91, set in 2019. In the TV show "Home Run Derby", the most home runs was held by Mickey Charles Mantle.
r2: Mickey Mantle, had the most home runs in the TV show Home Run Derby, a 1960 television show, filmed in December 1959, held at Wrigley Field in Los Angeles pitting the top sluggers of Major League Baseball against each other in nine-inning home run contest which helped inspire the Home Run Derby event that is now held the day before the annual Major League Baseball All-Star Game. 0.31343283226442414
a: The history of unemployment benefits in the UK can be traced back to the Poor Relief Act of 1601, which established a system of poor relief distribution in England and Wales. This system was not a centralized government policy but rather a collection of laws passed between the 16th and 18th centuries that made individual parishes responsible for poor relief legislation. The Act saw a move away from punishing paupers towards methods of "correction." (1)

Fast forward to the 20th century, and the first unemployment benefit scheme was introduced in the UK with the National Insurance Act of 1911, under the Liberal Party government of H. H. Asquith. This Act gave the British working classes a contributory system of insurance against illness and unemployment, but only applied to wage earners, their families, and the unwaged had to rely on other sources of support. (2)

In the present day, Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA) is an unemployment benefit paid by the Government of the United Kingdom to people who are unemployed and actively seeking work. It is part of the social security benefits system and is intended to cover living expenses while the claimant is out of work. To be eligible for JSA, claimants must state that they are actively seeking work by filling in a "Jobseeker's Agreement" form and attending a New Jobseeker interview (NJI). They must also go to a Job Centre every two weeks to "sign on," that is, to certify that they are still actively seeking work. (3)

Unemployment benefits in the UK have evolved over time to provide financial support to those who have lost their jobs through no fault of their own. The current system, which includes JSA and other forms of support, is designed to help individuals while they are looking for work and to provide a safety net for those who are struggling financially.

References:

(1) "Poor Relief Act 1601." Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 27 Jan. 2023, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poor_Relief_Act_1601.

(2) "National Insurance Act 1911." Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 11 Jan. 2023, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Insurance_Act_1911.

(3) "Jobseeker's Allowance." Wikipedia, Wikimedia Foundation, 27 Jan. 2023, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jobseeker's_Allowance.
r1: The Poor Relief Act 1601 was an Act of the Parliament of England. The Act for the Relief of the Poor 1601, popularly known as the Elizabethan Poor Law, "43rd Elizabeth" or the Old Poor Law was passed in 1601 and created a poor law system for England and Wales. It is considered to be the first unemployment benefit program in the UK. Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA) is an unemployment benefit paid by the Government of the United Kingdom to people who are unemployed and actively seeking work, and was established on 16 December 1911.
r2: Unemployment benefits started in the UK on different dates, with the Act for the Relief of the Poor starting in 1601 and the Jobseeker's Allowance starting on December 16, 1911. The Act for the Relief of the Poor, popularly known as the Elizabethan Poor Law, 43rd Elizabeth, or the Old Poor Law was passed in 1601 and created a poor law system for England and Wales. The Jobseeker's Allowance is an unemployment benefit paid by the Government of the United Kingdom to people who are unemployed and actively seeking work.

a: The Major League Baseball record for most hits in a row is held by Joe DiMaggio, who had a streak of 56 consecutive games in 1941. During this streak, DiMaggio hit .408 with 15 home runs and 55 runs batted in. This record has stood the test of time, and there have been only 55 instances in MLB history where a player has had a hitting streak of at least 30 games. Additionally, there have been several instances of multiple players achieving streaks of at least 30 games in the same season, such as in 1922, 1987, 1997, 1999, 2006, and 2011.

Joe DiMaggio's streak is all the more impressive when considering the context of the time period in which he played. The 1941 season was marked by the United States' entry into World War II, and many players were away serving in the military. Additionally, the Yankees played 24 games in 24 days during DiMaggio's streak, which put a strain on his body and made it even more impressive that he was able to maintain his hitting streak.

DiMaggio's hitting streak was not just a product of his individual talent, but also of the era in which he played. The 1940s were a time of high scoring in baseball, with the average runs per game increasing from 4.3 in the 1930s to 5.1 in the 1940s. Additionally, the Yankees were a powerful team with a strong lineup, which provided DiMaggio with plenty of opportunities to hit.

Despite the impressive nature of DiMaggio's streak, it is worth noting that there have been other notable hitting streaks in MLB history. For example, Johnny Kling, a catcher for the Chicago Cubs in the early 20th century, had a streak of 12 consecutive hits in August 1902, which was a record at the time. Additionally, there have been several players who have had streaks of at least 30 games, including Paul Molitor, Benito Santiago, Nomar Garciaparra, and Luis Gonzalez.

Overall, the record for most hits in a row in Major League Baseball is held by Joe DiMaggio, who had a streak of 56 consecutive games in 1941. This streak is all the more impressive when considering the context of the time period in which he played, and it stands as one of the most iconic moments in baseball history.
r1: In baseball, a hitting streak is the number of consecutive official games in which a player appears and gets at least one base hit. The MLB record for most games with a hit in a row is 56, and is by Joe DiMaggio of the New York Yankees. The MLB record for most plate appearances with hits in a row is 12, and is tied by Johnny Kling of the Chicago Cubs, and Walt Dropo of the Detroit Tigers.
r2: In baseball, a hitting streak is the number of consecutive official games in which a player appears and gets at least one base hit. According to the Official Baseball Rules, such a streak is not necessarily ended when a player has at least 1 plate appearance and no hits. Joe DiMaggio holds the Major League Baseball record with a streak of 56 consecutive games in 1941 which began on May 15 and ended July 17. The MLB record for the most plate appearances with hits in a row is 12.

0.4021739081433129
a: The group of cells that control the natural resting heart rate are located in the sinoatrial node (SA node), which is situated in the right atrium of the heart. The SA node is a banana-shaped structure that produces electrical impulses spontaneously, setting the heart's rhythm and acting as the heart's natural pacemaker. The rate of action potential production and therefore the heart rate is influenced by nerves that supply the SA node. If the SA node fails to function or the impulse is blocked, the atrioventricular node (AV node) or Purkinje fibers can act as the default or "escape" pacemaker. The SA node is responsible for producing action potentials at a constant rate, which are then transmitted through the electrical conduction system of the heart, causing it to contract. The action potentials are generated due to the movement of charged atoms (ions) across the cell membrane, and the SA node does not have a resting phase, instead, it produces a pacemaker potential that reaches a set value, known as the threshold value, to initiate an action potential. The SA node is a critical component of the heart's electrical conduction system and plays a vital role in regulating the heart's rhythm and rate.
r1: The main role of a sinoatrial node cell, or SA node, is to initiate action potentials of the heart, so that it can pass throughout the heart and cause contraction. If the SA node does not function, or the impulse generated in the SA node is blocked before it travels down the electrical conduction system, a group of cells further down the heart will become its pacemaker. This center is typically represented by cells inside the atrioventricular node (AV node), which is an area between the atria and ventricles, within the atrial septum.
r2: The sinoatrial node (also known as the SA node or the sinus node) is a group of cells located in the wall of the right atrium of the heart. In a healthy heart, the SA node continuously produces action potential, setting the rhythm of the heart and so is known as the heart's natural pacemaker. The normal resting heart rate is based on the at-rest firing rate of the heart's sinoatrial node. If the SA node does not function, or the impulse generated in the SA node is blocked before it travels down the electrical conduction system, a group of cells further down the heart will become its pacemaker. This center is typically represented by cells inside the atrioventricular node (AV node), which is an area between the atria and ventricles, within the atrial septum.

a: Sir Robert Borden was the Prime Minister of Canada in 1920. He led the country during World War I and its aftermath, and his government passed significant legislation such as the "War Measures Act" and introduced compulsory military service, which sparked the 1917 conscription crisis. Additionally, his government introduced women's suffrage for federal elections and used the North-West Mounted Police to break up the 1919 Winnipeg general strike. Borden was the last Prime Minister to be knighted, as the House of Commons indicated its desire for the discontinuation of the granting of any future titles to Canadians in 1919. He retired from office in 1920 and was succeeded by Arthur Meighen, who led the Conservative Party from 1920 to 1926 and again from 1941 to 1942.
r1: Sir Robert Borden was a Canadian lawyer and politician who served as the eighth prime minister of Canada, in office from 1911 to 1920. Arthur Meighen was a Canadian lawyer and politician who served as the ninth prime minister of Canada, in office from July 1920 to December 1921 and from June to September 1926.
r2: Canada had more than one prime minister in 1920. Sir Robert Borden, elected on September 21, 1911, served as Canada's eighth prime minister until July 10, 1920, before retiring from active political life. Arthur Meighen succeeded Borden and was prime minister from July 10, 1920, to December 29, 1921, when he was defeated by the new Liberal leader William Lyon Mackenzie King in the 1921 election.

0.24675324284617983
a: The dna-directed synthesis of an rna molecule is called transcription. This process is facilitated by an enzyme called RNA polymerase (RNAP), which reads the dna template and adds nucleotides to a growing rna chain. Transcription is the first step of gene expression and is essential for the synthesis of proteins, as well as the production of other types of rna molecules such as microRNA and ribosomal RNA. RNAP is a highly specific enzyme that can only bind to specific dna sequences called promoters, and it requires the presence of a transcription factor to initiate transcription. Once the transcription is initiated, RNAP unwinds the dna double helix and moves along the template strand, adding nucleotides to the growing rna chain. The resulting rna molecule is called a primary transcript, and it may undergo further processing before being transported out of the nucleus and into the cytoplasm for translation. In eukaryotic cells, RNAP can synthesize rna chains as long as 2.4 million nucleotides. Overall, transcription is a crucial step in the central dogma of molecular biology, as it allows cells to convert genetic information encoded in dna into functional rna molecules that can be used for protein synthesis and other cellular processes.
r1: Transcription is the process of copying a segment of DNA into RNA. The segments of DNA transcribed into RNA molecules that can encode proteins are said to produce messenger RNA (mRNA). Other segments of DNA are copied into RNA molecules called non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs). RNA polymerase (ribonucleic acid polymerase), abbreviated RNAP or RNApol, officially DNA-directed RNA polymerase, is an enzyme that synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.
r2: RNA polymerase (ribonucleic acid polymerase), abbreviated RNAP or RNApol, officially DNA-directed RNA polymerase, is an enzyme that synthesizes RNA from a DNA template. RNAP locally opens the double-stranded DNA so that one strand of the exposed nucleotides can be used as a template for the synthesis of RNA in a process called transcription.
============================497=============================

0.3090128715518798
a: Texas became part of the United States on December 29, 1845, when it was admitted as the 28th state. The Republic of Texas declared independence from Mexico on March 2, 1836, and the vast majority of the Texian population favored annexation by the United States. However, the leadership of both major political parties, the Democrats and the Whigs, opposed annexation due to the political climate of the pro- and anti-slavery sectional controversies in Congress. Additionally, Mexico refused to acknowledge the sovereignty of its rebellious northern province, and the U.S. President at the time, John Tyler, pursued annexation as a bid to gain popular support for his presidency and to outmaneuver suspected diplomatic efforts by the British government to emancipate slaves in Texas, which would undermine slavery in the U.S.

The annexation of Texas was a complex and contentious process that involved negotiations with Mexico, the U.K., and the U.S. government. William H. Bourland, a prominent figure in Texas politics during this period, introduced legislation that incorporated Paris, the county seat of Lamar County, and later served as Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives. Texas County, Oklahoma, was formed in 1907 from the central one-third of "Old Beaver County" and was named after the state that adjoins it to the south. The county's economy is largely based on farming and cattle production, and it is one of the top producing counties in the U.S. for wheat, cattle, and hogs.

In conclusion, Texas became part of the United States in 1845 after a complex and contentious annexation process that involved negotiations with Mexico, the U.K., and the U.S. government. The annexation was driven by a variety of factors, including political and economic interests, as well as the desire to outmaneuver diplomatic efforts by the British government to emancipate slaves in Texas. Today, Texas is a thriving state with a strong economy and a rich history, and its annexation remains a significant event in the history of the United States.
r1: The Texas annexation was the 1845 annexation of the Republic of Texas into the United States of America. Texas was admitted to the Union as the 28th state on December 29, 1845. Texas City, TX incorporated as part of the United States in 1911 with a mayor and commission form of government. Texas County, OK was formed at Oklahoma statehood on 16 November 1907, from the central one-third of "Old Beaver County". Texas County, Missouri was originally created in 1843, but was later organized on February 14, 1845, when it also was renamed for the Republic of Texas.
r2: In the United States, there is a state, a city, and more than one county named Texas. The state of Texas became part of the United States on December 29, 1845, when the US Congress admitted Texas to the US as a constituent state of the Union. Texas City, Texas, become incorporated as part of the US in 1911. Texas County, Missouri, become part of the US by changing its name to Texas on February 14, 1845, while Texas County, Oklahoma, become part of the US on 16 November 1907.

The team's history in the Fall Classic dates back to 1906, when they won the championship, but then went on to lose in four consecutive World Series from 1910 to 1914. The Cubs then made it back to the World Series in 1918, 1929, 1932, 1935, 1938, and 1945, but failed to win the championship each time. The team's longest drought without a World Series appearance was a record 71 years, which was finally broken in 2016 when the Cubs won the National League Championship Series and went on to win the World Series. This drought was the longest in Major League Baseball history, and it was finally ended when the Cubs defeated the Cleveland Indians in Game 7 of the World Series.

The Cubs' history in the World Series is marked by a mix of success and heartbreak. In 1906, the team won the championship with a then-modern-era record winning percentage of .763, but then lost the World Series to the Chicago White Sox in 1906 and 1917. The Cubs then made it back to the World Series in 1929, 1932, and 1935, but were defeated each time by the New York Yankees. The team's most recent World Series appearance before their 2016 victory was in 1945, when they were defeated by the Detroit Tigers.

The Cubs' rivalry with the White Sox is also notable, as the two teams have a long history of competition and have often been the only two Major League Baseball teams in Chicago. The teams have played each other in the World Series twice, in 1906 and 1917, with the Cubs winning both times. The rivalry is unique in that the teams have had relatively little success for a long time, with the White Sox winning the World Series only once, in 2005, and the Cubs not winning a championship since 1908. However, the teams have recently experienced more success, with the Cubs winning the World Series in 2016 and the White Sox making it to the playoffs in 2005 and 2008.

0.21198156369852836
a: The confluence of River Niger and River Benue is located at Lokoja, the capital of Kogi State in central Nigeria. Kogi State is known as the Confluence State due to the meeting point of these two major rivers. The Niger River flows through several countries in West Africa, including Guinea, Mali, Niger, Benin, and Nigeria, before emptying into the Gulf of Guinea. The Benue River, which is the main tributary of the Niger River, flows through Nigeria, Cameroon, and Chad before joining the Niger River at Lokoja. The Niger River is the third-longest river in Africa, after the Nile and the Congo River, and is an important source of water, transportation, and commerce for the regions it flows through.

The Niger River is also known for its seasonal flooding, which begins in September and peaks in November, providing fertile soil for agriculture and fishing. However, the river loses a significant amount of water due to seepage and evaporation, particularly in the Inner Niger Delta region, which is characterized by braided streams, marshes, and lakes. The average loss of water in the Niger River is estimated to be around 31 kilometers per year, with some years experiencing higher or lower losses.

In Nigeria, the Niger River is an important source of water for irrigation, agriculture, and drinking water, as well as a transportation route for people and goods. The state of Kogi is located at the confluence of the Niger and Benue rivers, and its economy is largely based on agriculture, with the main crops being rice, cassava, and yams. The state is also rich in mineral resources, including coal, petroleum, and steel. The diverse ethnic groups in Kogi State, including the Igala, Ebira, and Okun, have their own unique languages and cultures, adding to the rich cultural heritage of the state.

Overall, the confluence of the Niger and Benue rivers at Lokoja, Kogi State, is a significant geographical feature that supports the economy, culture, and way of life of the people in the region. The Niger River, with its seasonal flooding and rich mineral resources, plays a vital role in the development and prosperity of Kogi State and the surrounding regions.
r1: The Niger River is the principal river of West Africa, extending about 4,180 km (2,600 mi). The Benue River, previously known as the Chadda River or Tchadda, is the major tributary of the Niger River. The two major rivers meet in the city of Lokoja in the Kogi state, in the Federal Republic of Nigeria, making it the confluence state.
r2: The main rivers in Nigeria are the Niger and the Benue, which converge and empty into the Niger Delta. The River Niger and River Benue also meet in Kogi State, one of the 36 States of Nigeria, located in the Nigerian Northern Nigeria. Kogi State is nicknamed the "Confluence State" due the fact that the confluence of the River Niger and the River Benue occurs in its capital, Lokoja.

0.34920634466112377
a: The speech "Ain't I a Woman?" was delivered by Sojourner Truth in 1851 at the Women's Convention in Akron, Ohio. The speech was not given a title at the time of its delivery, but was later titled "Ain't I a Woman?" after its oft-repeated refrain. The speech was first reported in two contemporary newspapers and later published in the "Anti-Slavery Bugle" on June 21, 1851. The speech gained wider publicity during the American Civil War when it was published again in 1863 by Frances Dana Barker Gage, who made several additions to Truth's original speech. Gage's version of the speech, which is the one most widely known today, was published in 1875, 1881, and 1889.

The speech "Ain't I a Woman?" is significant not only for its powerful message, but also for its historical context. Truth's speech was delivered during a time when women, particularly black women, were fighting for their rights and facing discrimination and oppression. The speech challenged the gender and racial stereotypes of the time, as Truth spoke out against the injustices faced by black women and highlighted their strength and resilience.

The phrase "Am I not a man and a brother?" had been used by British abolitionists since the late 18th century to decry the inhumanity of slavery. However, Truth's speech turned this male motto into a female one, declaring "Am I not a woman and a sister?" This shift in language was significant, as it challenged the notion that women, particularly black women, were inferior to men and highlighted their shared humanity and suffering.

Truth's speech also highlighted the unique experiences of black women during slavery, as they were subjected to both gender and racial discrimination. Truth spoke out against the stereotypes that black women were promiscuous and immoral, and instead emphasized their strength and resilience in the face of oppression.

In 1981, bell hooks wrote the book "Ain't I a Woman?," which examines the effect of racism and sexism on black women and the civil rights and feminist movements. Hooks argues that the convergence of sexism and racism during slavery contributed to black women having the lowest status and worst conditions of any group in American society. She also highlights the stereotypes that were set during slavery and how they still affect black women today.

Overall, "Ain't I a Woman?" is a powerful speech that challenged the gender and racial stereotypes of the time and highlighted the experiences and struggles of black women. The speech has become a symbol of the fight for women's rights and racial equality, and its message continues to resonate today.
r1: "Ain't I a Woman?" is a speech, delivered extemporaneously, by Sojourner Truth, (1797–1883), born into slavery in New York State. She later became a well known anti-slavery speaker. Her speech was delivered at the Women's Convention in Akron, Ohio, on May 29, 1851, and did not originally have a title. Almost a month later, the speech was briefly reported in two contemporary newspapers, and a transcript of the speech was published in the "Anti-Slavery Bugle" on June 21, 1851. Twelve years later, in May 1863, Frances Dana Barker Gage published a very different transcription. In it, she gave Truth many of the speech characteristics of Southern slaves, and she included new material that Robinson had not reported. In 1981, the book "Ain't I a Woman? Black Women and Feminism" was published by Bell Hooks, where she examines the effect of racism and sexism on black women, the civil rights movement, and feminist movements from suffrage to the 1970s.
r2: "Ain't I a Woman?" is a speech, delivered extemporaneously by Sojourner Truth. Her speech was delivered at the Women's Convention in Akron, Ohio, on May 29, 1851. The speech was briefly reported in two contemporary newspapers, and a transcript of the speech was published in the "Anti-Slavery Bugle" on June 21, 1851. Twelve years later, in May 1863, Frances Dana Barker Gage published a very different transcription. "Ain't I a Woman? Black Women and Feminism" is a 1981 book by Bell Hooks titled after Sojourner Truth's "Ain't I a Woman?" speech.

a: GVWR stands for Gross Vehicle Weight Rating, which is the maximum operating weight of a truck, including the vehicle's chassis, body, engine, engine fluids, fuel, accessories, driver, passengers, and cargo, but excluding any trailers. The term is used for motor vehicles and trains, and it is important to note that the weight of a vehicle can be influenced by various factors such as passengers, cargo, and fuel level. There are different terms used to express the weight of a vehicle in a designated state, including Gross Combined Weight Rating (GCWR), which refers to the total mass of a vehicle and all trailers, and Gross Trailer Weight Rating (GTW), which specifies the maximum weight of a trailer.

When it comes to truck campers, the GVWR of the truck is an important factor in determining the maximum size camper that can be carried. The GVWR minus the weight of the truck with passengers and fuel is the payload that the truck may legally carry. To improve stability, additional features such as sway bars, overload springs, and inflatable airbags may be added to the rear suspension. It is important to consider the dry weight of the camper, which is the weight of the camper less any fluids, possessions, and add-ons, when determining the maximum size camper that can be carried. Additionally, tires and braking capacity are crucial factors in determining the maximum payload, as they can affect the safety of the vehicle. It is important to note that the total axle capacity is always higher than the GVWR, and tires and braking are frequently the rate-determining factor from a safety perspective.
r1: The gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), or gross vehicle mass (GVM), is the maximum operating weight/mass of a vehicle as specified by the manufacturer including the vehicle's chassis, body, engine, engine fluids, fuel, accessories, driver, passengers and cargo but excluding that of any trailers.
r2: The gross vehicle weight rating, GVWR, or gross vehicle mass, GVM, is the maximum operating weight/mass of a vehicle as specified by the manufacturer including the vehicle's chassis, body, engine, engine fluids, fuel, accessories, driver, passengers and cargo but excluding that of any trailers. The term is used for motor vehicles and trains.

The story was later included in the short-story collections "A Medicine for Melancholy" and "S is for Space". Set in the near future on Mars, the story follows the Bittering family, who are among the first wave of colonists sent by the United States to establish an outpost on the red planet. Initially disquieted by the Martian environment, Harry Bittering takes comfort in the fact that the family can return to Earth when resupply ships arrive. However, strange events begin to occur, such as seeded grass sprouting purple, the family cow growing a third horn, and other anomalies in the vegetable garden. These events have a profound impact on the family and the colony, and raise questions about the nature of reality and the effects of human presence on the Martian environment.

The story was later selected for inclusion in the collection "Selected from Dark They Were, and Golden-Eyed", which was published in 1991 by Signal Hill Publications as part of their Writers' Voices Series for students. This collection includes the story as well as several essays about it, providing insight into Bradbury's writing style and the themes and motifs present in the story. Overall, "Dark They Were, and Golden-Eyed" is a thought-provoking and imaginative tale that explores the human experience of colonization and the impact of human presence on the environment, and is a classic example of Bradbury's unique blend of science fiction and social commentary.

Madonna's version, released in 1985, was written by the artist and Steve Bray and was initially intended to be included in her second studio album "Like a Virgin." However, the song was held back due to the continued success of her debut album, and it was eventually released as the third single from the album. The song was an ode to "a heavenly love" and was inspired by Madonna's Catholic upbringing. The track was a success, reaching the top-five in several countries, including Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom.

Sarah McLachlan's version of "Angel," released in 1997, was written about the heroin overdose death of Jonathan Melvoin, a Smashing Pumpkins touring keyboard player. The song was a hit, reaching the top-five on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and remaining in the top-ten for nineteen weeks. It was one of the most successful songs of 1999 and was inspired by articles that McLachlan read in Rolling Stone about musicians turning to heroin to cope with the pressures of the music industry.

Shaggy's version of "Angel," released in 2000, featured Rayvon and was a follow-up to his international hit "It Wasn't Me." The song was a success, reaching number one in several countries, including Australia, Germany, Ireland, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The song uses the bass line from "The Joker" by Steve Miller and the chorus melody from "Angel of the Morning," which has been recorded by numerous artists over the years. The song debuted at number 81 on the Billboard Hot 100 and eventually peaked at number one on the chart, becoming the 17th most successful song of 2001 in the United States.

In conclusion, "Angel" is a song with a rich history and multiple versions, each with its own unique story and success. Madonna's version was held back due to the success of her debut album, while Sarah McLachlan's version was inspired by the heroin overdose death of a musician. Shaggy's version was a follow-up to his international hit and featured a sample from a classic rock song. Each version of "Angel" has left a lasting impact on the music industry and continues to be remembered as a powerful and emotive song.

0.3192488222857017
a: The blastocyst, after being fertilized and undergoing several cell divisions, implants itself in the female human reproductive system, specifically in the uterine wall. This process of implantation is crucial for the continuation of pregnancy and is facilitated by hormonal changes in the mother, such as a peak in luteinizing hormone (LH), which prepares the endometrium to receive the blastocyst. Once the blastocyst attaches to the extracellular matrix of the endometrium, trophoblast cells secrete enzymes and other factors that allow the blastocyst to invade the endometrium and establish a connection with the maternal blood supply. This process of implantation also triggers the formation of the placenta, which will provide nutrients and oxygen to the developing embryo and remove waste products.

Interestingly, there are cases of abdominal pregnancy, also known as extra-uterine pregnancy, where the blastocyst implants outside of the uterus, usually in the abdominal cavity. This condition was first recognized by Arab Muslim physician Albucasis in the 10th century and was later described in detail by Italian physician Jacopo Berengario da Carpi in the 16th century. Abdominal pregnancy is rare and can be dangerous for both the mother and the developing embryo, as it can lead to complications such as bleeding, infection, and premature delivery. However, it can also serve as a model for studying human male pregnancy or for females who lack a uterus.

In conclusion, the blastocyst implanted in the female human reproductive system undergoes a complex process of implantation, which involves the interaction of hormonal changes, cellular differentiation, and the formation of the placenta. Any disruptions in this process can lead to complications such as abdominal pregnancy, which can be dangerous for both the mother and the developing embryo.
r1: The blastocyst is a structure formed in the early development of mammals. It possesses an inner cell mass (ICM) which subsequently forms the embryo. Implantation establishes a connection between the mother and the early embryo which will continue through the remainder of the pregnancy, and is made possible through structural changes in both the blastocyst and endometrial wall. In an ectopic pregnancy, which is when the embryo attaches outside the uterus, it can become implanted in the fallopian tube, cervix, ovaries, or within the abdomen.
r2: Implantation is critical to the survival and development of the early human embryo. It establishes a connection between the mother and the early embryo which will continue through the remainder of the pregnancy. Once bound to the extracellular matrix of the endometrium, trophoblast cells secrete enzymes and other factors to embed the blastocyst into the uterine wall. Ectopic pregnancy is a complication of pregnancy in which the embryo attaches outside the uterus. In an ectopic pregnancy the blastocyst can be implanted in the fallopian tube, cervix, ovaries, or within the abdomen.

Keith Veney holds the record for the most three-pointers made in an NCAA game with 15, which he achieved on December 14, 1996, while playing for Marshall University. This record is particularly impressive given that it has stood the test of time, with no other player has been able to match or surpass it in the over two decades since Veney set the record. Additionally, Veney's 409 career three-pointers are currently in the top 10 all-time in Division I history, highlighting his prolific shooting ability and consistent success from beyond the arc. The game in which Veney set the record, a 120-81 victory over Morehead State, also set several other records, including the most combined points in an NCAA game and the most three-pointers made in a Georgetown game. While Veney's record has stood the test of time, it is worth noting that the game itself was not without its challenges, as Veney's team, the Hoyas, faced a tough opponent in California just six days later and were unable to repeat their success, ultimately falling in the second round of the NIT. Nonetheless, Veney's record remains an impressive achievement and a testament to his skill and dedication as a collegiate basketball player.
r1: Through December 18, 2019, only 19 players have made at least 12 three-point field goals in a single game. The all-time record is 15, which had only occurred one time between 1986–87 and 2017–18, by Marshall's Keith Veney. On December 14, 1996, he set the record against Morehead State. Then, within a two-night span in November 2018, two other players tied Veney's record. On November 14, Robert Morris' Josh Williams made 15, and then on November 15 Furman's Jordan Lyons matched it. Only three other players have made 14 three-pointers: Ronald Blackshear, Dave Jamerson and Askia Jones.

a: The Portuguese called the region that is now known as Mumbai by several different names during their colonial period. According to Gaspar Correia's "Lendas da Índia" (1508), the name "Bombaim" was used, which is believed to have originated from the Galician-Portuguese phrase "bom baim," meaning "good little bay." This name was still commonly used in Portuguese in the 16th and 17th centuries. Other variations of the name recorded during this time include "Tana-Maiambu," "Mombayn," "Bombay," "Bombain," "Bombaym," "Monbaym," "Mombaim," "Mombaym," "Bambaye," "Bombaiim," "Bombeye," "Boon Bay," and "Bon Bahia." After the English gained possession of the city in the 17th century, the Portuguese name was anglicized as "Bombay," which is the name that has endured to the present day.

This name possibly originated as the Galician-Portuguese phrase "bom baim", meaning "good little bay", and "Bombaim" is still commonly used in Portuguese. In 1516, Portuguese explorer Duarte Barbosa used the name "Tana-Maiambu": "Tana" appears to refer to the adjoining town of Thane and "Maiambu" to "Mumbadevi".

a: Scooter Gennett holds the record for the most RBIs in a single game in Major League Baseball history, with 10 RBIs on June 6, 2017, against the St. Louis Cardinals. This achievement is all the more impressive considering that Gennett hit four home runs in the game, including a grand slam, and set a club record with 17 total bases. In addition to his impressive offensive performance, Gennett is also known for his unique nickname, which he earned as a child after a run-in with the police.

According to the rules of baseball, errors can affect the number of RBIs a player earns in a game. For example, if a batter hits a ball that should have been a sacrifice fly but the outfielder drops the ball, the batter will still receive credit for the sacrifice fly and the run batted in. However, if a play should have resulted in a fielder's choice with a runner being put out and the batter reaching base safely, but the runner is safe due to an error, the play will be scored as a fielder's choice with no hit being awarded to the batter and an error charged against the fielder.

One curious loophole in the rules on errors exists for catchers. If a catcher makes a "wild throw" in an attempt to prevent a stolen base and the runner is safe, the catcher is not charged with an error, even if it could be argued that the runner would have been put out with "ordinary effort." This "no fault" condition for the catcher attempting to prevent a steal is a unique aspect of the rules that can affect the number of RBIs a player earns in a game.

In comparison to other great power hitters in baseball history, such as Hack Wilson, who hit 56 home runs in 1930, Gennett's 10 RBIs in a single game are truly exceptional. Wilson's accomplishments, like Gennett's, were marked by both impressive offensive performance and a unique personality. However, while Wilson's achievements were widely recognized during his playing career, it was not until after his death that he was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1979.

Overall, Scooter Gennett's record-tying performance on June 6, 2017, is a testament to his exceptional offensive skills and his ability to come through in clutch situations. While errors can affect the number of RBIs a player earns in a game, the unique loophole for catchers and the context of Gennett's achievement make his 10 RBIs all the more impressive.

r2: A run batted in is a statistic in baseball and softball that credits a batter for making a play that allows a run to be scored. For example, if the batter bats a base hit which allows a teammate on a higher base to reach home and so score a run, then the batter gets credited with an RBI. Hank Aaron has the most career RBIs with 2,297. Hank Wilson has the most RBIs in a single season with 191. The 2017 wildfire season was the most destructive on record in California at the time, with a total property damage of $3.5 billion, including $2.2 billion in insured losses and $300 million in fire suppression costs.

The fires started in October, during severe fire weather conditions, with multiple wildfires breaking out throughout Napa, Lake, Sonoma, Mendocino, and Butte counties. The fires rapidly grew to become massive conflagrations, spanning from 1,000 to well over 20,000 acres within a single day, and destroyed an estimated 8,900+ structures. The fires also forced over 20,000 people to evacuate and burned over 2.2 million acres of land.

In December, a series of wildfires ignited across Southern California, with six of the fires becoming significant wildfires and leading to widespread evacuations and property losses. The largest of the wildfires was the Thomas Fire, which grew to over 281,000 acres, becoming the largest wildfire in modern California history, until it was surpassed by the Ranch Fire in the Mendocino Complex in the following year. The December wildfires burned over 230,000 acres, caused traffic disruptions, school closures, hazardous air conditions, and power outages, and forced over 230,000 people to evacuate.

The 2017 California wildfires were exacerbated by unusually powerful and long-lasting Santa Ana winds, as well as large amounts of dry vegetation, due to a then-far unusually dry rainy season. The fires occurred at the end of an unusually active and destructive wildfire season, with the total property damage surpassed by the 2018 California wildfires. a: France was occupied by Germany in World War II on May 10, 1940, following the German military invasion of the country. The occupation lasted until December 1944, with the German military administration in France formally existing from May 1940 to December 1944. However, most of France had been liberated by the Allies by the end of summer 1944. The German military administration in France was established after the Second Armistice at Compiègne, which was signed on June 22, 1940, and divided France into an occupied northern zone and an unoccupied southern zone. The Vichy government, led by Marshal Philippe Pétain, remained in existence but with limited authority, and the military administration in the occupied zone was a Nazi dictatorship. The Italian occupation zone was also occupied by Germany and added to the "zone sud" after Italy's surrender in September 1943, except for Corsica, which was liberated by the landings of Free French forces and local Italian troops that had switched sides to the Allies. The German military administration in France was responsible for civilian affairs in the wide "zone interdite" along the Atlantic coast and the "forbidden zone" in north-eastern France, and it was intended for German settlers and annexation in the coming Nazi New Order ("Neue Ordnung"). War refugees were prohibited from returning to their homes, and the German military administration also re-annexed Alsace-Lorraine, which had been annexed by the German Empire after the Franco-Prussian War in 1871.
r1: The Military Administration in France was an interim occupation authority established by Nazi Germany during World War II to administer the occupied zone in areas of northern and western France. It started on 22 June 1940 with the signing of The Armistice of 22 June 1940, following defeats in May and early June, and spanned from 1940–1944. However, this agreement didn't come into effect until after midnight on 25 June. By summer 1944, most of France's territory had been liberated by the Allies.

Germany occupied France over the years 1940–1944, with the start of the occupation being on 22 June 1940, though the occupation officially began through armistice after midnight on 25 June 1940. Most of France was liberated and no longer occupied by Germany in summer 1944, but France was only officially no longer occupied in December 1944.

a: The song "If I Ruled the World" has a rich history, with multiple versions and interpretations spanning across different genres and generations. The original version was composed by Leslie Bricusse and Cyril Ornadel for the 1963 West End musical "Pickwick," based on Charles Dickens's "The Pickwick Papers." The song was later popularized by Sir Harry Secombe, who reached No. 18 on the UK charts with his rendition. The song has since been covered by various artists, including Tony Bennett, Stevie Wonder, and Celine Dion.

In the hip-hop world, the song was famously sampled by Nas in his 1996 hit "If I Ruled the World (Imagine That)," featuring Lauryn Hill. Produced by Trackmasters and featuring an uncredited input from Rashad Smith, the song was Nas's first Top 20 R&B hit and was nominated for a 1997 Grammy Award for Best Rap Solo Performance. Lauryn Hill's verse interpolates the song "Walk Right Up To The Sun" by The Delfonics. The lyrics feature Nas discussing the various things he would do if he "ruled the world and everything in it."

The song is considered one of the greatest rap songs of all time, with many publications ranking it as such. It was also ranked 88 on XXL's Best Songs of the 90's. The high-budget music video directed by Hype Williams helped bring the single mainstream attention, reaching No. 53 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 chart, No. 17 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks chart, and No. 15 on the Billboard Hot Rap Tracks chart.

Lauryn Hill, the featured artist on the song, is an American singer, rapper, and songwriter known for her work with Fugees and her solo album "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill." Raised in South Orange, New Jersey, Hill began singing with her music-oriented family during her childhood and rose to prominence with her African-American and Caribbean music influences, her rapping and singing, and her rendition of the hit "Killing Me Softly." Her tumultuous romantic relationship with Wyclef Jean led to the split of the band Fugees in 1997, after which she began to focus on solo projects. "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill" remains her only solo studio album, showcasing a representation of life and relationships and locating a contemporary voice within the neo soul genre.

In conclusion, "If I Ruled the World" is a timeless song with multiple interpretations and versions, spanning across different genres and generations. From its origins in the 1963 West End musical "Pickwick" to its hip-hop reinterpretation by Nas and Lauryn Hill, the song has left a lasting impact on music history. The song's themes of imagination and aspiration continue to resonate with listeners, making it a classic that will be remembered for years to come.

There was also another song released with the same name by Nasir Jones on June 4, 1996, which featured American singer, songwriter, rapper, record producer and actress Lauryn Hill.

0.2662337626861613
a: Plywood has been used in furniture production for over a century, with its introduction in the early 1900s revolutionizing the industry. The use of plywood in furniture making dates back to the 1850s, when flexible plywood was first used to create curved parts. However, it wasn't until the early 20th century that plywood became widely used in furniture production, particularly in the aviation industry. The fuselage of aircraft was one of the first applications of plywood in the industry, with the use of bonded ply-balsa-ply 'sandwich' construction providing exceptional rigidity and strength. This construction method, which involves bonding layers of wood together with adhesives, has since become a standard practice in furniture making.

Aviation-grade plywood, which is manufactured to specifications outlined in the Germanischer Lloyd Rules and MIL-P-607, is a type of plywood that is particularly popular in the furniture industry. This type of plywood is made from African mahogany, spruce, or birch veneers that are bonded together in a hot press over hardwood cores of basswood or poplar. Basswood is another type of aviation-grade plywood that is lighter and more flexible than mahogany and birch plywood but has slightly less structural strength.

In recent years, there has been a growing trend towards sustainable and eco-friendly furniture production. To address this demand, certification programs such as the Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC), Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED), Sustainable Forestry Initiative (SFI), and Greenguard have been established to ensure that production and construction practices are sustainable. Many of these programs offer tax benefits to both the manufacturer and the end user.

Plywood is available in a range of thicknesses and sizes, with the most commonly used thickness range being from 1/4 inch to 3/4 inch. The sizes of the most commonly used plywood sheets are 4 x 8 feet (1220 x 2440 mm), which was first used by the Portland Manufacturing Company. A common metric size for a sheet of plywood is 1200 x 2400 mm. Plywood is also available in specialized sizes for concrete-forming, with sizes ranging from 15 x 24 inches (381 x 610 mm) to 24 x 48 inches (610 x 1220 mm).

In terms of thickness, aircraft plywood is available in thicknesses of 3 ply construction and upwards, with veneers typically ranging from 0.5 mm to 1.5 mm in thickness. Thinner veneers, such as 0.1 mm, are also used in the construction of some thinner panels. The use of thinner veneers allows for the creation of lighter and more flexible panels, which can be beneficial in certain furniture applications.

Overall, plywood has been a popular choice in furniture production for over a century due to its strength, versatility, and sustainability. With the rise of certification programs and eco-friendly production methods, plywood is likely to remain a popular choice in the furniture industry for years to come.
r1: Plywood is a material manufactured from thin layers or "plies" of wood veneer that are glued together with adjacent layers having their wood grain rotated up to 90 degrees to one another. Flexible plywood is designed for making curved parts, a practice which dates back to the 1850s in furniture making. The sizes of the most commonly used plywood sheets are 4 x 8 feet which was first used by the Portland Manufacturing Company, who developed what we know of as modern veneer core plywood for the 1905 Portland World Fair.
r2: Plywood is a material manufactured from thin layers or "plies" of wood veneer that are glued together with adjacent layers having their wood grain rotated up to 90 degrees to one another. Flexible plywood is designed for making curved parts, a practice which dates back to the 1850s in furniture making. The Portland Manufacturing Company developed what we know of as modern veneer core plywood for the 1905 Portland World Fair.

0.2631578909868421
a: In a covalent bond, electrons are located between the atoms involved in the bond, and are shared by both atoms. This sharing of electrons is the defining characteristic of a covalent bond, and it is what allows the atoms to form a stable and strong bond. The idea of covalent bonding was first proposed by Gilbert N. Lewis in 1916, and the term "covalence" was later introduced by Irving Langmuir in 1919. According to Lewis's theory, atoms form covalent bonds by sharing electron pairs with their neighbors, and this sharing of electrons allows each atom to attain a stable electronic configuration with a full outer shell.

In a covalent bond, the shared electrons are not localized between the atoms, but are delocalized and distributed over the bond. This delocalization of electrons is what allows covalent bonds to be so strong and stable. The delocalization of electrons also allows for the formation of multiple bonds, such as double and triple bonds, which are formed by the sharing of more than two electron pairs between atoms.

The strength of a covalent bond depends on the electronegativity of the atoms involved. Electronegativity is a measure of an atom's ability to attract electrons, and atoms with high electronegativity values are more likely to form covalent bonds with atoms that have lower electronegativity values. This is because the high electronegativity atom will exert a stronger pull on the shared electrons, causing the bond to be stronger.

In summary, electrons in a covalent bond are located between the atoms involved and are shared by both atoms. The delocalization of these electrons allows for the formation of strong and stable bonds, and the strength of the bond depends on the electronegativity of the atoms involved.
r1: A covalent bond is a chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms. These electron pairs are known as shared pairs or bonding pairs, and the stable balance of attractive and repulsive forces between atoms, when they share electrons in their outer shell, is known as covalent bonding.
r2: A covalent bond is a chemical bond in which electron pairs are shared between atoms. These electron pairs, called shared pairs or bonding pairs, are located in the outer shell of each atom in the bond.
============================535=============================
