a: The Byzantine Empire began to decline in the 7th century, following the Muslim conquests of the 6th century. During the reign of Maurice (r. 582–602), the Empire's eastern frontier was expanded and the north was stabilized, but his assassination led to a two-decade-long war with the Sassanid Persia, which exhausted the Empire's resources and contributed to significant territorial losses. The Empire lost its richest provinces, Egypt and Syria, to the Arabs in a matter of years. The Macedonian dynasty (10th–11th centuries) saw a brief renaissance for the Empire, but it came to an end with the loss of much of Asia Minor to the Seljuk Turks after the Battle of Manzikert in 1071. This battle marked the beginning of a period of decline for the Empire, as the Turks settled in Anatolia as a homeland and the Empire lost control of its territories. The Komnenos dynasty in the 12th century managed to restore some stability, but the Empire was eventually captured and partitioned by the Crusaders in the Fourth Crusade in 1204. The Empire was eventually conquered by the Ottoman Empire in 1453, marking the end of the Byzantine Empire.

The process of decline for the Byzantine Empire can be traced back to the Muslim conquests of the 7th century, which weakened the Empire and led to significant territorial losses. The Battle of Manzikert in 1071 marked a turning point in the Empire's decline, as it lost control of Anatolia and was unable to recover. The Komnenos dynasty's attempts to restore stability were ultimately unsuccessful, and the Empire was eventually conquered by the Ottoman Empire. The decline of the Byzantine Empire was a gradual process that spanned several centuries, marked by a series of territorial losses, political instability, and external threats.
r1: The Byzantine Empire experienced several cycles of growth and decay over the course of nearly a thousand years, including major losses during the Arab conquests of the 7th century. However, modern historians generally agree that the start of the empire's final decline began in the 11th century

According to David Coverdale, the song was co-written with John Sykes, who also played guitar on the track. The song was released as the lead single from Whitesnake's self-titled album in 1987 and reached the top 20 on the US Mainstream Rock Tracks chart. The guitar work on the song is a perfect blend of the blues origins of the band and the more distorted, harder sound that drives the song, making it a standout track in Whitesnake's discography. Interestingly, the song was recorded in Munich after a night of partying, with Coverdale improvising the vocals in a live "jam" style to inspire the band during recording. The final version of the song features guitar work by Sykes, who replaced Mel Galley's guitar parts, as well as drumming by Cozy Powell and bass by Neil Murray. The song's success can be attributed to the combined talents of these musicians, as well as the powerful lyrics and memorable chorus that have made it a fan favorite.

r2: "Still of the Night" is a song by the English band Whitesnake. Beauregard. The Union brigade, led by Colonel Richardson, was met with heavy fire and retreated, causing a wave of panic to spread through the Union line. The Confederates, led by Colonel Jubal A. Early, took advantage of the confusion and delivered a crushing blow that completed the Confederate victory. The failed reconnaissance-in-force at Blackburn's Ford led McDowell to abandon his plan for a frontal assault and instead attempt to cross the stream beyond the Confederate left flank, which ultimately led to the disastrous defeat at the First Battle of Bull Run on July 21. The battle at Blackburn's Ford not only gave the Confederates confidence in themselves, but also set the stage for the larger conflict that would unfold in the coming days.

a: Sure! Here's the comprehensive answer to the question:

When did New Zealand first win the America's Cup?

New Zealand first won the America's Cup in 1995, when Team New Zealand, skippered by Russell Coutts, won the challenger series in "NZL 32", a yacht dubbed "Black Magic" due to its black hull and impressive speed. The team then went on to defeat Dennis Connor's Stars & Stripes team 5-0, securing the coveted trophy for New Zealand. This victory marked a significant milestone in the history of the America's Cup, as it was the first time that the cup had been won by a team from outside the United States since the competition began in 1851.

The 1995 America's Cup was notable not only for New Zealand's victory, but also for the controversy that surrounded the event. The defending champion, San Diego Yacht Club (SDYC), had their win overturned on appeal, leading to a reinstatement of the cup for the challenger, Team New Zealand. The controversy continued into the following year, with Fay, the owner of SDYC, appealing to New York's highest court and ultimately losing.

The 1995 victory marked the beginning of a successful era for Team New Zealand, who would go on to defend the cup several times over the next two decades. In 2000, the team, now led by Dean Barker, won the cup again, defeating Italy's Prada Challenge 5-0. However, their eight-year reign came to an end in 2003, when they were defeated 5-0 by Swiss-based challenger Alinghi. Despite this setback, Team New Zealand continues to be a dominant force in the America's Cup, with a loyal fan base and a reputation for innovative design and skilled sailing.
r1: The America's Cup, informally known as the Auld Mug, is a trophy awarded in the sport of sailing. It is the oldest international competition still operating in any sport. The 1995 America's Cup took place from 6–13 May 1995, during which time the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron syndicate Team New Zealand, skippered by Russell Coutts, first won the challenger series in NZL 32, dubbed "Black Magic" because of her black hull and uncanny speed.
r2: The America's Cup, informally known as the Auld Mug, is a trophy awarded in the sport of sailing, and it's the oldest international competition still operating in any sport. America's Cup match races are held between two sailing yachts: one from the yacht club that currently holds the trophy, known as the defender, and the other from the yacht club that is challenging for the cup, the challenger. In the1995 America's Cup, Team New Zealand, won the challenger series on 13 May 1995.

a: Sure! Here's a comprehensive paragraph-long answer to the question:

India is the seventh largest producer of hydroelectric power in the world, with an installed capacity of 44,594 MW as of April 2017, accounting for 13.5% of its total utility power generation capacity. Additionally, smaller hydroelectric power units with a capacity of 4,380 MW, equivalent to 1.3% of its total utility power generation capacity, have been installed. The country has an estimated hydroelectric power potential of 148,700 MW at a 60% load factor. In the fiscal year 2016-17, India generated 122.31 TWh of hydroelectric power, with an average capacity factor of 33%. India has been a dominant player in global hydroelectric power development, with the first hydroelectric power plants established in Asia as early as 1898 in Darjeeling and 1902 in Shivanasamudram. Today, India imports surplus hydroelectric power from Bhutan and has identified 56 sites for pumped storage schemes with an aggregate installed capacity of 94,000 MW. With an economically exploitable and viable hydroelectric potential of 148,701 MW and an additional 6,780 MW from smaller hydro schemes, India has a significant opportunity to increase its reliance on clean and renewable hydroelectric power.
r1: India is 5th globally for installed hydroelectric power capacity. As of 31 March 2020, India's installed utility-scale hydroelectric capacity was 46,000 MW, or 12.3% of its total utility power generation capacity. In 2019, the total share of hydroelectric power in total captive electricity power produced was 0.09%. In 2017, the share of utility-scale hydroelectric power in total electricity production capacity was 13.5%. In the same year, the share of smaller scale hydroelectric power produced was 1.3%.
r2: India is 5th globally for installed hydroelectric power capacity. In 2017, the share of smaller scale hydroelectric power in total electricity produced in India was 1.3%. The share of utility-scale hydroelectric power in total electricity production capacity in India in 2017 was 13.5%. In 2019, the share of hydroelectric power in total capacity electricity power produced in India was 0.09%.
============================550=============================

a: The first no-hitter in Orioles history was pitched by Ernie Koob on May 5, 1917, against the Chicago White Sox. This was also the first no-hitter of Koob's career, and he accomplished the feat just one day after his teammate Bob Groom pitched a no-hitter against the same opponent in the second game of a doubleheader. This unique occurrence makes Koob and Groom the only teammates to pitch no-hitters on consecutive days in Major League history. The Orioles, then known as the St. Louis Browns, were a relatively new team at the time, having joined the American League in 1901. They had yet to experience much success, and this no-hitter was a highlight in their early years. The team would go on to experience more success in the 1960s and 1970s, winning three World Series titles, but the no-hitter pitched by Koob remains a significant moment in the team's history.
r1: The Baltimore Orioles are a Major League Baseball franchise based in Baltimore, Maryland. They play in the American League East division, and were previously known in earlier years as the “Milwaukee Brewers” and “St. Louis Browns”. The pitchers for the Orioles have thrown a total of ten no-hitters in franchise history. The first one was pitched by Earl Andrew Hamilton on August 30, 1912. After the team became the Baltimore Orioles, the first no-hitter pitched was by James Hoyt Wilhelm. The first no-hitter pitched at home was by Ernest Gerald Koob on May 5, 1917.
r2: Earl Hamilton threw the first no-hitter in Orioles franchise history on August 30, 1912, with the St. Louis Browns, which the Orioles were known as from 1902 to 1953. In the franchise's history, Hamilton also threw the first no-hitter on the road, while Ernie Koob threw the first no-hitter at home, and Hoyt Wilhelm threw the first no-hitter after the team became the Baltimore Orioles.

The Panthers have a rich history in the NFL, having played their first season at Memorial Stadium in Clemson, South Carolina before moving to Bank of America Stadium in 1996. a: In the novel "The Day of the Locust" by Nathanael West, the protagonist Tod Hackett is originally from the East Coast, specifically from New England. This is revealed in the text when it states that Tod "had come from the East, from New England, where his family had lived for generations" (West 1). This information is significant because it highlights the contrast between Tod's origins and his current surroundings in Hollywood, California. As a native of the East Coast, Tod brings a different perspective to the glamorous and superficial world of Hollywood, and his outsider status allows him to see the darker underbelly of the city and its inhabitants.

Tod's background also informs his artistic vision and his desire to create something meaningful and authentic in the face of the shallow and commercialized culture of Hollywood. His longing for a more profound connection to life and his frustration with the empty materialism of the Hollywood lifestyle are reflected in his painting, "The Burning of Los Angeles," which he sees as a way to express his disillusionment with the American dream.

The fact that the novel was not well-received during West's lifetime and only gained recognition later, as noted in the factoids, highlights the prescience of West's critique of American society and the enduring relevance of his themes. The novel's exploration of the darker aspects of the American dream and the disillusionment of those who seek to achieve it continue to resonate with readers today, making it a classic of American literature.
r1: The Day of the Locust is a 1939 novel by American author Nathanael West set in Hollywood, California. In 1975, it was adapted into a film by the same name. Both the novel and the film follow a young artist from the Yale School of Fine Arts named Tod Hackett, who has been hired by a Hollywood studio to do scene design and painting.
r2: "The Day of the Locust" is a 1939 novel by American author Nathanael West set in Hollywood, California. The novel follows a young artist from the Yale School of Fine Arts named Tod Hackett, who has been hired by a Hollywood studio to do scene design and painting. Similarly, in the 1975 film "The Day of the Locust", aspiring artist and recent Yale graduate Tod Hackett arrives in 1930s Hollywood to work as a painter at a major film studio. The film screenplay by Waldo Salt is based on the 1939 novel of the same title.

MC Hammer's hit single "U Can't Touch This" was released in 1990 as part of his album "Please Hammer, Don't Hurt 'Em." The song, which features a catchy sample of Rick James' "Super Freak" riff and showcases Hammer's rap skills, quickly became a chart-topper and a cultural phenomenon. It peaked at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks chart and received numerous awards and nominations, including Best R&B Song and Best Rap Solo Performance at the 33rd Annual Grammy Awards in 1991. The song's success was not limited to the United States, as it also reached the top of the charts in several other countries. The song's enduring popularity has been evident in its continued use and reference in various forms of media, including television shows, films, commercials, and other forms of media.

The band's version of the song was well-received, with Katy Perry herself describing it as "inspiring." 0.2169811281879673
a: The Everly Brothers, known for their pristine and soulful harmonies, were the first singing brothers to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1986. The duo, comprised of Don and Phil Everly, had a profound impact on the birth of rock and roll, with their unique blend of country and R&B styles. Their impressive discography includes 35 Billboard Top 100 singles, 26 of which reached the top 40, and 12 Top 40 albums between 1960 and 2009. The Everly Brothers hold the record for the most Top 100 singles by any duo and trail only Hall & Oates for the most Top 40 singles. Their influence can be seen in the many musical groups that have attempted to replicate their harmonies, as noted by Neil Young, who introduced the duo at their Hall of Fame induction. The Everly Brothers have also been honored with a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award and have been inducted into the Iowa Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame.

In contrast, the Louvin Brothers, while also influential in the country and gospel music genres, are perhaps better known for their unusual album cover art. Their 1959 album, "Satan Is Real," features a plywood rendition of the Devil in a rock quarry, with the brothers standing in front of it. The cover has become an iconic example of religious album art and has been celebrated and parodied on various websites and in popular culture. While the Louvin Brothers are not as widely recognized for their musical contributions as the Everly Brothers, they have still had a lasting impact on the country and gospel music scenes, and their unique album cover art has become a memorable aspect of their legacy.
r1: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, established in 1983 and located in Cleveland, Ohio, United States, is dedicated to recording the history of some of the best-known and most influential musicians, bands, producers, and others that have in some major way influenced the music industry, particularly in the area of rock and roll. The Everly Brothers were among the first 10 artists inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1986. In 2001, The Louvin Brothers were inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.
r2: The first singing brothers in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame were The Everly Brothers, inducted in 1986. The first singing brothers in the Country Music Hall of Fame were the Louvin Brothers, the Everly Brothers, and the Delmore Brothers, who were all inducted in 2001.

0.4049079706906546
a: Greenland is the largest island in the world, situated in the continent of North America, specifically in the Arctic region. Although physiographically a part of North America, Greenland has been politically and culturally associated with Europe, specifically Norway and Denmark, for over a millennium. The island has a unique history of human settlement, with the Inuit people migrating from the Canadian mainland in the 13th century and gradually settling across the island. With a population of approximately 56,480 people, Greenland is the least densely populated territory in the world, with about a third of the population living in the capital and largest city, Nuuk. The island has been inhabited off and on for at least the last 4,500 years by Arctic peoples, with Norsemen settling the southern part of Greenland in the 10th century. Despite its size and historical significance, Greenland is not considered a continental landmass, but rather an island, due to its geographical characteristics and the fact that it is surrounded by water on all sides.
r1: Greenland is the world's largest island, located between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans, east of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. It is an autonomous territory within the Kingdom of Denmark. Though physiographically a part of the continent of North America, Greenland has been politically and culturally associated with Europe (specifically Norway and Denmark, the colonial powers, as well as the nearby island of Iceland) for more than a millennium.
r2: Greenland is the world's largest island, located between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans, east of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, and it is physiographically a part of the continent of North America. Politically and culturally Greenland is associated with Europe, specifically Norway and Denmark, the colonial powers, as well as the island of Iceland, for more than a millennium, beginning in 986. The majority of its residents are Inuit, whose ancestors migrated from Alaska through Northern Canada, gradually settling across the island by the 13th century.

a: Network address translation (NAT) is a technique used to conserve global IPv4 address space by remapping one IP address space into another. It works by modifying the IP address information in packets as they pass through a traffic routing device, replacing the original source and destination IP addresses with new ones. This allows a single Internet-routable IP address to be used to represent an entire private network, hiding the private IP addresses of the devices behind it. This technique is commonly used to conserve IPv4 address space, as the limited number of available IPv4 addresses has become a pressing concern. However, NAT has serious consequences on the quality of Internet connectivity, and its implementation can vary widely, affecting network traffic in different ways.

NAT is often used in conjunction with IP masquerading, which hides an entire IP address space behind a single public IP address. In this case, the address that needs to be hidden is changed to the public IP address of the NAT gateway as the "new" source address of the outgoing IP packet, making it appear as if the packet is originating from the NAT gateway rather than the hidden host. This technique is widely used to conserve IPv4 address space and is often referred to simply as "NAT."

The implementation of NAT can have significant consequences on network traffic, and care must be taken to ensure that it is properly configured and managed. NAT can cause issues with network connectivity, including problems with inbound and outbound traffic, and can also affect the ability of certain applications to function properly. As a result, it is important to carefully consider the specific needs of a network and the potential impact of NAT before implementing it. Despite these challenges, NAT remains a popular and essential tool in conserving global IPv4 address space, and ongoing research and development is focused on improving its functionality and addressing its limitations.
r1: Network address translation, or NAT, is a method of remapping one IP address space into another by modifying network address information in the IP header of packets while they are in transit across a traffic routing device. The technique was originally used to avoid the need to assign a new address to every host when a network was moved, or when the upstream Internet service provider was replaced, but could not route the networks address space.
r2: In networking, the full form of NAT is network address translation, and in relation to function, NAT is remapping one IP address space into another. This is done by modifying network address information in the IP header of packets while they are in transit across a traffic routing device.
============================565=============================

Tolkien's "The Lord of the Rings," Arthurian legend, and the Spaghetti Western "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." King has also cited Clint Eastwood's "Man with No Name" character as an inspiration for the protagonist, Roland Deschain. a: The highest recorded temperature on Earth is a topic of much debate and scrutiny, with several locations around the world claiming to have reached extreme temperatures. According to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), the highest recorded air temperature on Earth was recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch, California, on July 10, 1913, at 134°F (56.7°C). However, this record has been disputed due to concerns about the accuracy of the measurement, with some historians and weather experts suggesting that the reading may have been influenced by a sandstorm that occurred at the time.

If the 1913 record is decertified, the highest recorded air temperature on Earth would be 129.2°F (54°C), which was recorded in Death Valley, California, on June 20, 2013, and in Mitribah, Kuwait, on July 21, 2016. These readings were taken using standard measuring conditions, 1.5 meters above the ground, and shielded from direct sunlight.

However, when considering ground surface temperatures, the highest recorded temperature is allegedly 201°F (93.9°C), which was recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch on July 15, 1972. This reading was taken using a ground-based thermometer, and while it is not considered an official record by the WMO, it is widely cited as the highest recorded ground surface temperature.

It is important to note that temperature measurements can vary significantly depending on the location and method of measurement. Satellite measurements have captured higher temperatures than ground-based measurements, with a maximum temperature of 70.7°C (159.3°F) recorded in the Lut Desert, Iran, in 2005, using the MODIS infrared spectroradiometer on the Aqua satellite. However, these satellite measurements are considered less reliable than ground-based measurements due to complications involving atmospheric friction.

In summary, while the highest recorded air temperature on Earth is a matter of debate, the highest recorded ground surface temperature is 201°F (93.9°C), recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch, California, in 1972. However, it is important to note that temperature measurements can vary significantly depending on the location and method of measurement, and the accuracy of these readings should be carefully considered when evaluating extreme temperature records.
r1: The highest temperature recorded on Earth has been measured in three major ways: air, ground, and via satellite observation. The former of the three is used as the standard measurement due to persistent issues with unreliable ground and satellite readings. The current official highest registered air temperature on Earth is 56.7 °C (134.1 °F), recorded on 10 July 1913 at Furnace Creek Ranch, in Death Valley in the United States. If this record were to be decertified, then the holder would be a tie at 54.0 °C (129.2 °F), recorded both at Furnace Creek, and in Kuwait. While there is no highest confirmed ground temperature, a reading of 93.9 °C (201.0 °F) was allegedly recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch on 15 July 1972. The hottest recorded satellite temperature on earth is 66.8 °C (152.2 °F).
r2: The highest temperature recorded on Earth has been measured in three major ways: air, ground, and via satellite observation. The current official highest registered air temperature on Earth is 56.7 °C (134.1 °F), recorded on 10 July 1913 at Furnace Creek Ranch, in Death Valley in the United States. If the current record were to be decertified then the holder would be a tie at 54.0 °C (129.2 °F), recorded both at Furnace Creek, and in Kuwait. The highest recorded temperature taken by a satellite is 66.8 °C (152.2 °F), which was measured in the Flaming Mountains of China in 2008. While there is no highest confirmed ground temperature, a reading of 93.9 °C (201.0 °F) was allegedly recorded in Furnace Creek Ranch on 15 July 1972.

Who got the most rebounds in one game?

However, this does not answer the question of who got the most rebounds in one game.

a: When do you buy a rosca de reyes? The answer to this question depends on the country and region you are in, as the tradition of eating rosca de reyes, a sweet bread-based ring-shaped dessert filled with guava paste, varies across different cultures and celebrations. In Spain, rosca de reyes are traditionally eaten on January 6, during the celebration of Epiphany, which commemorates the arrival of the three Magi or Wise Men. In some Hispanic communities in the United States, the tradition is also observed. In Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay, the day is called "Día de Reyes" and the night of January 5 into the morning of January 6 is known as "Noche de Reyes." Children leave their shoes by the door, along with grass and water for the camels, and wake up early on January 6 to find gifts left by the "Reyes." In Bulgaria, Epiphany is celebrated on January 6 and is known as "Bogoyavlenie" or "Krashtenie Gospodne."

In terms of when to buy a rosca de reyes, it is best to purchase it a few days before January 6, as it is a traditional dessert that is often baked fresh and in limited quantities. Many bakeries and pastry shops offer pre-ordered rosca de reyes, so it is a good idea to place your order in advance to ensure availability. Additionally, some grocery stores may carry pre-made rosca de reyes, so you may be able to find them on sale in the bakery or international foods section.

It's worth noting that the tradition of including a small figure inside the rosca de reyes, such as a baby Jesus or a toy, is not universal and may vary depending on the region. In Spain, for example, it is common to find a small figure inside the rosca de reyes, while in Argentina, there is no such tradition. Ultimately, the best time to buy a rosca de reyes is when it is freshly baked and before it sells out, as it is a popular and delicious dessert that is an important part of many cultural celebrations around the world.
r1: The roscón de reyes is celebrated in Spain and other Hispanic countries, such as Mexico. Recipes vary from country to country and between cultures but tend to be similar. The sweet bread-based ring-shaped dessert is usually bought or baked during the Epiphany, or in Mexico City, "Día de Reyes", commemorating the arrival of the Magi to confirm Jesus as son of God. The night of January 5 into the morning of January 6 is known as "Noche de Reyes", or the Night of Kings, and children leave their shoes by the door, along with grass and water for the camel, horse and elephant.
r2: The roscón de reyes is celebrated in Spain and other Hispanic countries, such as Mexico. A rosca de reyes is traditionally eaten on January 6, during the celebration of the "Kings' Day", which commemorates the arrival of the three Magi or Wise Men. In Western Christian tradition, Epiphany (also known as "Three King's Day") celebrates the visit of the Magi to the Christ Child.

a: The stern of a boat is located at the back or aft-most part of the vessel, extending upwards from the counter rail to the taffrail. The stern is technically defined as the area built up over the sternpost, and it is opposite to the bow, the foremost part of the ship. The stern end of a ship is marked with a white navigation light at night. The design of the stern has evolved over time, with two main forms being the "square" or "transom" stern and the "elliptical", "fantail", or "merchant" stern. These designs were developed in that order, with the latter being the most common. The hull sections before the stern are composed of a series of U-shaped rib-like frames set in a sloped or "cant" arrangement, with the last frame before the stern being called the "fashion timber(s)" or "fashion piece(s)". This frame supports the various beams that make up the stern. In 1817, the British naval architect Sir Robert Seppings introduced the concept of the round or "circular" stern, which has since become a popular design.
r1: The stern is the back or aft-most part of a ship or boat, technically defined as the area built up over the sternpost, extending upwards from the counter rail to the taffrail. According to the original definition, it is located at the aft port section of the ship.
r2: The stern is the back or aft-most part of a ship or boat, technically defined as the area built up over the sternpost, extending upwards from the counter rail to the taffrail. The stern lies opposite the bow, the foremost part of a ship. Originally, the term only referred to the aft port section of the ship, but eventually came to refer to the entire back of a vessel.

a: Sure! Here's a comprehensive, well-structured paragraph that answers the question:

"Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" is a beloved Christmas song that was written by Johnny Marks based on the 1939 story of the same name published by Montgomery Ward. The song was first recorded by crooner Harry Brannon on New York City radio in early November 1949, but it was Gene Autry's version that hit No. 1 on the U.S. charts during Christmas 1949. Autry's recording of the song sold 1.75 million copies its first Christmas season and eventually sold a total of 12.5 million copies, with cover versions bringing the total to over 150 million. The song's success not only helped establish Autry as a popular singer but also gave support to his subsequent Easter song, "Here Comes Peter Cottontail." Interestingly, Autry's version of the song is the only chart-topping hit to fall completely off the chart after reaching No. 1, with the official date of its No. 1 status being the week ending January 7, 1950, making it the first No. 1 song of the 1950s. The song's enduring popularity has led to numerous cover versions and mishearings of the lyrics, including the well-known mondegreen "Olive, the other reindeer" instead of "All of the other reindeer." In December 2018, Autry's version of the song entered the Billboard Hot 100 at #36, nearly 70 years after it first charted, further testifying to its timeless appeal.
r1: The song "Rudolph The Red Nosed Reindeer," based on the 1939 story, was originally recorded on June 27, 1949 and then first sung by crooner Harry Brannon on New York City radio in early November 1949.
r2: "Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Reindeer" is a song by songwriter Johnny Marks based on the 1939 story "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" published by the Montgomery Ward Company. Gene Autry recorded the song on June 27, 1949, and the recording hit No. 1 on the U.S. charts the week of Christmas 1949. The song was first sung by crooner Harry Brannon on New York City radio in early November 1949.

a: The division of Korea into North and South Korea can be traced back to the end of World War II in 1945, when the Soviet Union occupied the north of the peninsula, and the United States occupied the south, along the 38th parallel. The Allied powers had intended to establish a joint trusteeship over Korea, but the worsening Cold War and the emergence of local political leaders aligned with either the Soviet Union or the United States led to the division of the country. The Soviet Union supported the Korean Communists in the north, while the United States supported the anti-Communist Syngman Rhee in the south. In 1948, UN-supervised elections were held in the south only, resulting in the establishment of the Republic of Korea, while Kim Il-sung was appointed as the leader of North Korea. The subsequent Korean War, which lasted from 1950 to 1953, ended with a stalemate and left the two Koreas separated by the Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) to this day. Diplomatic initiatives have failed to end the division, and the two countries remain technically at war. The division of Korea was a direct result of the Cold War and the conflicting interests of the Soviet Union and the United States in the region, and it has had far-reaching consequences for the people of Korea and the geopolitical landscape of East Asia.
r1: The Division of Korea began at the end of World War II in 1945 then in 27 July 1953, South Korea separated from north Korea along the military demarcation line, completing their separation.
r2: There was more than one separation of North Korea and South Korea, one along the 38th Parallel and the other along the Military Demarcation Line. The division of Korea began at the end of World War II in 1945, with North Korea separating from South Korea along the 38th parallel the same year. However, the separation of the countries wasn't completed until 27 July 1953, the day South Korea separated from North Korea along the Military Demarcation Line, the current land border between the countries.

0.2614379043177838
a: The invention of the first handheld camera can be traced back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with several pioneers in the field of photography and filmmaking contributing to its development. The first silent film era movie cameras, while portable, were bulky and not practical for use by the cameraman. However, the brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière developed the Cinematograph in the 1890s, which was more compact and could be mounted on a tripod or carried by the cameraman. This camera also served as a film projector. In 1908, Wilbur Wright filmed his flight using a handheld Lumière camera, showcasing the versatility of this new technology.

Thomas Edison developed a portable film camera in 1896, but it was not reliable. Polish inventor Kazimierz Prószyński demonstrated a handheld film camera in 1898, but it was not widely adopted. It wasn't until the early 1900s that handheld cameras became more practical and widely used. Directors Francesco Bertolini and Adolfo Padavan, with assistant director Giuseppe de Liguoro, used handheld cameras to shoot scenes for "L'Inferno" (1911), based on Dante's "The Divine Comedy." This film included innovative camera angles and special effects, showcasing the potential of the handheld camera.

The development of the handheld camera was also influenced by the rise of mass-market photography, made possible by George Eastman's Kodak camera in 1888. This simple box camera with a fixed-focus lens and single shutter speed was affordable and accessible to the average consumer. Eastman expanded his lineup to include several models, including both box and folding cameras. In 1900, he introduced the Brownie, a very inexpensive box camera that popularized the concept of the snapshot.

Despite the advances in low-cost photography made possible by Eastman, plate cameras remained popular well into the 20th century, offering higher-quality prints. To compete with rollfilm cameras, many inexpensive plate cameras were equipped with magazines to hold several plates at once. Special backs for plate cameras allowing them to use film packs or rollfilm were also available.

In conclusion, the development of the handheld camera was a gradual process that spanned several decades, influenced by advances in mass-market photography and the rise of filmmaking. The Lumière brothers' Cinematograph, Thomas Edison's portable film camera, and the Brownie all played a significant role in the evolution of the handheld camera, paving the way for the versatile and practical cameras used today.
r1: In the 1890s, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière developed the first fairly compact Cinematograph, which could be mounted on a tripod or carried by the cameraman. The first hand held, sync-sound camera was invented in 1960.
r2: Hand-held camera or hand-held shooting is a filmmaking and video production technique in which a camera is held in the camera operator's hands as opposed to being mounted on a tripod or other base. The first silent film era movie cameras that could be carried by the cameraman were bulky and not very practical to simultaneously support, aim, and crank by hand, so in the 1890s, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière developed the fairly compact Cinematograph which could be mounted on a tripod or carried by the cameraman, and it also served as the film projector. The first hand held, sync sound camera was invented in 1960. Michel Coutant at Éclair was working with Brault and Rouch's input to create prototypes that eventually led to the self-blimped Eclair 16, the first successful lightweight sync-sound movie camera.

a: The "Hannibal Lecter" franchise, which originated with Thomas Harris' novel "Red Dragon" in 1981, has since expanded into a successful series of films and television shows. The franchise is centered around the brilliant and cannibalistic serial killer, Hannibal Lecter, who has been portrayed by Anthony Hopkins in multiple adaptations. The series began with the 1986 film "Manhunter," directed by Michael Mann, which was an adaptation of "Red Dragon." The next adaptation was the critically acclaimed and commercially successful "The Silence of the Lambs" (1991), directed by Jonathan Demme, which won several Academy Awards, including Best Actor for Hopkins.

Hopkins reprised his role as Lecter in the next two films, "Hannibal" (2001) and "Red Dragon" (2002), which were respectively directed by Ridley Scott and Brett Ratner. In 2007, "Hannibal Rising" was released, which explores Lecter's backstory and was the only film in the series not to feature Hopkins in the lead role.

The franchise has also expanded into television, with the NBC series "Hannibal" (2013-2015), which was developed by Bryan Fuller and starred Mads Mikkelsen as Lecter. The series was praised for its atmospheric visuals, intricate plotting, and strong performances, but was cancelled after three seasons due to low ratings.

The novels that make up the franchise include "Red Dragon," "The Silence of the Lambs," and "Hannibal," all written by Thomas Harris. "Red Dragon" introduces the character of Will Graham, an FBI profiler who seeks the help of Lecter to catch a serial killer known as the "Tooth Fairy." "The Silence of the Lambs" follows FBI trainee Clarice Starling as she seeks the help of Lecter to catch another serial killer, Buffalo Bill. "Hannibal" takes place seven years after the events of "The Silence of the Lambs" and follows Starling as she seeks revenge against Lecter, who has been manipulating her from behind the scenes.

Overall, the "Hannibal Lecter" franchise has established itself as a successful and enduring brand in popular culture, with a wide range of adaptations and a devoted fan base. The franchise's exploration of themes such as obsession, power dynamics, and the nature of evil has made it a fascinating and terrifying journey for audiences.
r1: The first book of the series by author Thomas Harris, is Red Dragon with The Silence of the Lambs being the second. The third book in the series is Hannibal. The forth book written, Hannibal Rising, is a prequel to his three previous books.
r2: The Hannibal Lecter franchise is an American media franchise based around the titular character, Hannibal Lecter, a brilliant, cannibalistic serial killer whose assistance is routinely sought out by law enforcement personnel to aid in the capture of other criminals. He originally appeared in a series of novels (starting with Red Dragon in 1981) by Thomas Harris. The Silence of the Lambs is a psychological horror novel by Thomas Harris. First published in 1988, it is the sequel to Harris's 1981 novel Red Dragon. The third book in the series is Hannibal, and the fourth book is Hannibal Rising.

a: The king size bed, a popular choice for many homeowners, has a fascinating history that spans across different countries and continents. The origins of the king size bed can be traced back to the mid-1950s in the United States, where the bedding industry introduced this larger-than-standard size as a response to the growing demand for more comfortable and spacious sleeping arrangements. Unlike other bed sizes, the king size bed is unique in its implementation, as it is not common to have a king-sized box spring. Instead, two smaller box springs are used under a king-sized mattress. This design choice allows for more support and comfort, especially for taller individuals or those who prefer a more spacious sleeping surface.

The introduction of the king size bed in the United States was a departure from the traditional double size, which had been the standard in English-speaking countries for centuries. The double size, measured at 4 feet 6 inches by 6 feet 3 inches (137 cm x 190 cm), had been the usual citizen's bed in England until the middle of the 19th century. However, with the rise of industrialization and the increasing availability of affordable, high-quality mattresses, the demand for larger and more comfortable beds grew. The king size bed, with its spacious dimensions of 76 inches wide by 80 inches long (193 cm x 203 cm), was a welcome addition to the bedding market.

Despite its widespread popularity in the United States, the king size bed is not a standard size in other countries. In fact, mainland European sizes differ from those in the United States, not only because of the use of the metric system but also due to unique cultural preferences and historical influences. For example, in Japan, the traditional futon mattress is often placed on a tatami mat, which is made of woven grass or straw, and is much larger than the standard king size bed. Similarly, in Australia, the popularity of platform beds and mattresses has led to the development of unique bed sizes, such as the "King Koil" and the "Super King," which are larger than the standard king size but smaller than the California king.

In conclusion, the king size bed, introduced in the mid-1950s in the United States, has become a popular choice for many homeowners seeking more comfort and space in their bedrooms. Its unique design and spacious dimensions have made it a staple in the bedding industry, but its history and popularity vary across different cultures and continents.
r1: The king size bed first came out in the mid-1940s and then became standardized in North America in the 1950s and 1960s.
r2: Standard bed sizes are based on standard mattress sizes, which vary from country to country. The sizes of mattresses use non-numeric labels such as a "king" or "full", but are defined in inches. Historically most beds were "twins" or "doubles" but in the mid-1940s larger mattresses were introduced by manufacturers. These were later standardised as "queen" and "king" in the mid-1950s and 1960s and first made a significant impact on the market during this time period.

a: The name Benjamin has a rich history and cultural significance, dating back to the biblical era. The name is derived from the Hebrew word "Binyāmīn," which means "Son of my right hand," or "Son of my strength." This name was given to the youngest son of Jacob and Rachel, who was born in Canaan. According to the Hebrew Bible, the name was chosen by Jacob as a way of honoring his beloved wife Rachel, who died shortly after giving birth to Benjamin. The name is also associated with the Israelite Tribe of Benjamin, which was named after the youngest son.

In addition to its biblical origins, the name Benjamin has been popularized in many cultures and religions. In the Christian tradition, Benjamin is seen as a symbol of purity and innocence, and is often associated with the righteous young child who remained with Jacob when his older brothers plotted against Joseph, as mentioned in the Quran. In the Jewish tradition, Benjamin is considered one of four ancient Israelites who died without sin, along with Chileab, Jesse, and Amram.

The name Benjamin has been popularized in many forms, including the shortened forms "Ben" and "Benny," and the diminutive form "Benji." It has also been used as a patronymic surname, and has been adopted by people of many different backgrounds and cultures.

In conclusion, the name Benjamin has a rich history and cultural significance, dating back to the biblical era. a: The excretory system is responsible for removing waste products from the body, and it plays a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis. In marine invertebrates, diffusion through the skin is the primary means of excreting waste products such as ammonia, as they do not have a liver to convert ammonia into urea like mammals do. The skin is also responsible for regulating body temperature and releasing pheromones. In contrast, mammals excrete sweat through sweat glands throughout their body, which helps to regulate body temperature and maintain salt levels. However, the primary function of sweat glands in the excretory system is minimal.

In amphibians, the skin plays a crucial role in excretion, as the lungs are simple and lack the ability to exhale like other tetrapods. The moist, scale-less skin helps to rid the blood of carbon dioxide and allows for urea to be expelled through diffusion when the amphibian is submerged.

The urinary bladder is the primary organ for excreting waste products in the excretory system. It is a hollow, muscular, and distensible organ that sits on the pelvic floor. Urine enters the bladder through the ureters and exits through the urethra. The bladder is derived from the urogenital sinus and is initially continuous with the allantois. In humans, the base of the bladder lies between the rectum and the pubic symphysis, and it is separated from the rectum by the rectovesical excavation.

One of the main functions of the lungs is to diffuse gaseous wastes, such as carbon dioxide, from the bloodstream as a normal part of respiration. The lungs also play a role in regulating the pH of the blood by removing excess hydrogen ions. The kidneys, on the other hand, are responsible for filtering waste products and excess fluids from the blood and regulating electrolyte levels.

Plasma osmolality is an important factor in the excretory system, as it helps to regulate the amount of water in the body. Increased osmolality in the blood can stimulate the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which results in increased water reabsorption and more concentrated urine. A low serum osmolality, on the other hand, can suppress the release of ADH, resulting in decreased water reabsorption and more concentrated plasma.

In conclusion, the excretory system plays a crucial role in maintaining homeostasis in the body by removing waste products and regulating electrolyte levels. Diffusion through the skin and the urinary bladder are the primary means of excreting waste products in marine invertebrates and mammals, respectively. The lungs and kidneys also play important roles in regulating the pH of the blood and filtering waste products from the blood. Plasma osmolality is an important factor in regulating the amount of water in the body and is closely linked to the functioning of the excretory system.
r1: Diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide occur in the human excretory system in the lungs, diffusion of salt, water, and waste occur in the kidneys and diffusion of calcium occur in the intestines. In marine invertebrates, diffusion occurs through the skin. And in the amphibian excretory system diffusion also occurs through the skin when submerged.
r2: The excretory system is a passive biological system that removes excess, unnecessary materials from the body fluids of an organism, so as to help maintain internal chemical homeostasis and prevent damage to the body. The kidneys remove from the blood the nitrogenous wastes such as urea, as well as salts and excess water, and excrete them in the form of urine. One of the main functions of the lungs is to diffuse gaseous wastes, such as carbon dioxide, from the bloodstream as a normal part of respiration. Invertebrates lack a liver, but most terrestrial groups, like insects, possesses a number of blind guts that serve the similar functions. Marine invertebrates do not need the ammonia conversion of the liver, as they can usually expel ammonia directly by diffusion through the skin. Most excretion of excess calcium is via the bile and feces, from the intestines, because the plasma calcitriol levels (which ultimately depend on the plasma calcium levels) regulate how much of the biliary calcium is reabsorbed from the intestinal contents.

The number of teams that can play in the Champions League is determined by a combination of factors, including the association ranking based on the UEFA country coefficients and the performance of the teams in previous European competitions. For the 2018-19 season, the top four teams from the leagues of the four top-ranked national associations, as determined by the UEFA country coefficients, will qualify automatically for the group stage. Additionally, the previous season's UEFA Europa League winners will also qualify automatically for the group stage, regardless of their domestic league ranking.

In total, six teams will qualify for the group stage via the qualification rounds, down from ten in the previous season. The remaining 79 teams from 54 of the 55 UEFA member associations will participate in the qualification rounds, with the exception of Liechtenstein, which does not organize a domestic league.

The Champions League title holders will also qualify for the group stage, regardless of their domestic league ranking. This is a change from previous seasons, where the Champions League title holder would only qualify for the group stage if the berth was vacated.

The 2015-16 Champions Hockey League, a European ice hockey tournament, featured 48 teams from twelve different European first-tier leagues. The teams were decided based on different licenses for the founding teams, leagues, and wildcards. The regular season was expanded to 48 teams, divided into 16 groups with three teams in each group. The two first teams in each group advanced to the play-offs (round of 32), and the group stage began on August 20 and ended on September 6, 2015.

In summary, the number of teams that can play in the Champions League is determined by a combination of factors, including the association ranking based on the UEFA country coefficients and the performance of the teams in previous European competitions. The Champions League title holders will also qualify automatically for the group stage, and the remaining teams will participate in the qualification rounds. 0.32558139150381593
a: The Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox split, also known as the Great Schism, occurred in the 11th century due to a combination of theological and political differences that had been developing over several centuries. At the heart of the schism were disagreements over the procession of the Holy Spirit, the use of leavened or unleavened bread in the Eucharist, the Bishop of Rome's claim to universal jurisdiction, and the place of the See of Constantinople in the Pentarchy.

One of the key issues was the use of Latin practices in the Greek churches of southern Italy, which were forced to conform to Latin traditions or be closed. In response, the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, Michael I Cerularius, ordered the closure of all Latin churches in Constantinople. This led to the papal legate sent by Leo IX refusing to recognize Cerularius as the Ecumenical Patriarch and insisting that he acknowledge the Pope's claim to be the head of all the churches.

These differences had been simmering for centuries, with the Eastern Orthodox churches viewing the Bishop of Rome as having too much authority and the Roman Catholic Church seeing the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople as having too much influence. The tensions finally came to a head in 1054, when the papal legate and Cerularius engaged in a heated exchange that ended with the formal schism between the two churches.

The East-West Schism had far-reaching consequences, not only for the two churches but also for the wider Christian world. It marked the beginning of a period of division and isolation for the Eastern Orthodox churches, which would last for centuries. The schism also had significant political implications, as it weakened the influence of the Byzantine Empire and paved the way for the rise of the Latin Empire in the 13th century.

Despite the long history of tensions and disagreements, there have been efforts in recent years to heal the rift between the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches. In 1988, the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, Demetrius I, and the Pope John Paul II signed a joint statement acknowledging the shared faith and traditions of the two churches and calling for greater understanding and cooperation. While the schism remains unhealed, these efforts suggest that there may be a way forward towards greater unity and cooperation between the two churches in the future.
r1: In general, the roman catholic and eastern orthodox churches split because of theological and political differences. More specifically the disagreements were the procession of the Holy Spirit, whether leavened or unleavened bread should be used in the Eucharist, the Bishop of Rome's claim to universal jurisdiction, and the place of the See of Constantinople in relation to the Pentarchy.
r2: The East–West Schism (also the Great Schism or Schism of 1054) is the break of communion since the 11th century between the Catholic Church and Eastern Orthodox Church. The schism was the culmination of theological and political differences which had developed during the preceding centuries between Eastern and Western Christianity. The specific doctrinal reasons for why the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox church split include the procession of the Holy Spirit, whether leavened or unleavened bread should be used in the Eucharist, the Bishop of Rome's claim to universal jurisdiction, and the place of the See of Constantinople in relation to the Pentarchy.

0.1538461506029771
a: The United States maintains an emergency stockpile of oil in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR), located in the Gulf of Mexico. The SPR is stored in four sites, each near a major center of petrochemical refining and processing. The reserve is held in artificial caverns created in salt domes below the surface, which provides a cost-effective and secure storage solution. The caverns are located at depths of up to 1,000 meters below the surface, with average dimensions of 60 meters wide and 600 meters deep. The capacity of each cavern ranges from 10 to 40 million barrels of oil. The SPR has a total storage capacity of 634.8 million barrels, with a maximum removal rate of 4.4 million barrels per day.

The decision to store oil in caverns was made to reduce costs and provide additional advantages such as no leaks and a constant natural churn of the oil due to a temperature gradient in the caverns. The caverns were created by drilling down and then dissolving the salt with water. The SPR management office is located in Elmwood, Louisiana, a suburb of New Orleans.

The United States has spent almost $4 billion on the facilities and infrastructure of the SPR, and the reserve has been used several times in response to supply disruptions, including during the 1970s oil embargo and more recently in 2011 after Hurricane Katrina. The SPR is managed by the Department of Energy, and the access to the reserve is determined by the conditions written into the 1975 Energy Policy and Conservation Act (EPCA), primarily to counter a severe supply interruption. The price paid for the oil is $20.1 billion, averaging $28.42 per barrel. Purchases of crude oil resumed in January 2009 using revenues available from the 2005 Hurricane Katrina emergency sale.
r1: The United States keep an emergency stockpile of oil in reserves in four locations along the Gulf of Mexico, in Bryan Mound in Freeport, Texas, Big Hill, in Winnie, Texas, West Hackberry in Lake Charles, Louisiana and in Bayou Choctaw in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
r2: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) is a supply of petroleum held by the United States for emergency fuel and is the largest emergency supply in the world. The reserve is stored at four sites: the Bryan Mound facility in Freeport, Texas, the Big Hill facility in Winnie, Texas, the West Hackberry facility in Lake Charles, Louisiana, and the Bayou Choctaw facility in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

a: Sure, here is a comprehensive answer to the question "Who won gold in Rio Paralympic high jump?" based on the provided factoids:

Mariyappan Thangavelu, an Indian Paralympic high jumper, won the gold medal in the men's high jump T-42 category at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games held in Rio de Janeiro. This was India's first Paralympic gold medal since 2004. Mariyappan was born in Periavadagampatti village, Tamil Nadu, and suffered a permanent disability in his right leg at the age of five when he was run over by a drunk bus driver. Despite this setback, he completed his secondary education and began participating in sports events, eventually representing India at the Paralympic Games.

The athletics events at the 2016 Summer Paralympics were held at the Estádio Olímpico João Havelange in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, from September 2016. A total of 177 events were held across two genders, with 1100 athletes competing. The high jump and long jump events were classified as "T" events, with athletes given a classification depending on the type and extent of their disability. Mariyappan was classified as T-42, which means he had a leg length difference of less than 30 mm.

Other notable athletes who won gold medals in the high jump event at the 2016 Rio Paralympics include Maciej Lepiato of Poland, who won the men's high jump - F46 event, and Roderick Townsend-Roberts of the United States, who won the men's high jump - F44 event.

Overall, Mariyappan Thangavelu's gold medal win in the men's high jump T-42 category at the 2016 Rio Paralympic Games was a significant achievement, not only for India but also for the global Paralympic community. His success serves as an inspiration to others with disabilities, demonstrating that with determination and hard work, anything is possible.
r1: There were multiple events where gold for high jump was won in the 2016 Summer Paralympics. For T42 Mariyappan Thangavelu won gold, representing India. In T44, Maciej Lepiato from Poland won gold in high jump. And in T47, Roderick Townsend-Roberts representing the Roderick Townsend-Roberts.
r2: In the Paralympics, there are different classifications and competitions for different types of disabilities. In the Rio Paralympics, there were three different winners for the high jump. For the T42 category, which is for single above knee amputees, Mariyappan Thangavelu of India won the gold medal for the high jump. For the T44 category, which is for single below knee amputees, Maciej Lepiato of Poland won the gold medal for the high jump. For the T47 category, which is for below elbow or wrist amputees, Roderick Townsend-Roberts of the United states won the gold medal for the high jump.

The phrase is a testament to the enduring bond between humans and domestic dogs, which can be traced back to the early days of human civilization.

According to historical accounts, humans and wolves formed a working relationship thousands of years ago, with wolves providing their superior tracking abilities and humans providing their superior hunting skills. This partnership allowed early humans to thrive in their hunting and gathering activities, and over time, the wolves that were most adept at working with humans began to evolve into the domestic dogs we know today.

Before the 19th century, breeds of dogs were largely functional, performing activities such as hunting, guarding, and watching. The language used to describe dogs often reflected these roles, highlighting their importance in human society. However, with the rise of urbanization and the decline of hunting as a primary means of survival, the role of dogs shifted towards companionship and entertainment.

Despite the controversy surrounding the exact nature of the transition from wolves to dogs, one thing is clear: humans and dogs have been inextricably linked for millennia. The phrase "man's best friend" is a testament to this enduring bond, and it continues to be a common colloquialism used to describe the special relationship between humans and their canine companions. Whether through hunting, guarding, or simply providing comfort and companionship, dogs have been an integral part of human society for thousands of years, and their importance cannot be overstated.

a: The Count of Monte Cristo, a famous novel by Alexandre Dumas, has had a rich and diverse publication history. The first edition in book form was published in Paris by Pétion in 18 volumes, with the first two volumes released in 1844 and the remaining 16 volumes released in 1845. However, many early editions featured a misspelling of the title with "Christo" instead of "Cristo". The first edition to feature the correct spelling was the "L'Écho des Feuilletons" illustrated edition, published in Paris in 1846, which also included plates by Paul Gavarni and Tony Johannot.

The novel has been translated into many languages, including Japanese, where it is known as "Shigai Shiden Gankutsu-ou" (史外史伝巌窟王) or "Monte Cristo-haku" (モンテ・クリスト伯). The first Japanese translation, by Kuroiwa Shūroku, was serialized in the Yorozu Chouhou newspaper from 1901-1902 and released in book form in four volumes by Aoki Suusandou in 1905. The title "Gankutsu-ou" (巌窟王) has become highly associated with the novel in Japan and is often used as an alternative title.

The Count of Monte Cristo has been the inspiration for many other works, including science fiction retellings and contemporary adaptations. The novel's success coincides with France's Second Empire, and Dumas's conflicted attitude towards "bonapartisme" is reflected in the novel's themes. The novel has been adapted into numerous films, including a 2002 film with the title "Monte Cristo", and has spawned numerous sequels and spin-offs, such as the novels Meiji Gankutsu-ou by Taijirou Murasame and Shin Gankutsu-ou by Kaitarō Hasegawa. Overall, the publication history of The Count of Monte Cristo is a testament to the enduring popularity of this classic novel.

Other notable winners on Jeopardy! include Brad Rutter, who won $2,115,200 during his 20-game winning streak in 2002, and Roger Craig, who won $1,000,000 in the Battle of the Decades in 2014. Julia Collins holds the record for the most money won by a female contestant on the show, with $429,100 over 21 games.

The audition process for Jeopardy! is highly competitive, with potential contestants first taking an online screener test and then being selected for an in-person audition if they pass the test. Contestants must be 18 years of age or older, with some exceptions for special tournaments such as the College Championship and the Teen Tournament. Employees of Sony Pictures Entertainment and its subsidiaries, as well as television stations that broadcast the show, are ineligible to compete.

r2: James Holzhauer, a professional sports gambler from Las Vegas, Nevada and a native of Naperville, Illinois, set the single-game "Jeopardy!" winnings record of $110,914 during his fourth appearance on the show in April 2019, beating the previous record of $77,000 previously held by Roger Craig. He is now the second-highest winning contestant in regular game (non-tournament) winnings, surpassed only by Ken Jennings. a: Ribeye steak is a premium cut of beef that originates from the rib section of the animal, specifically from the longissimus dorsi muscle, as well as the complexus and spinalis muscles. The rib section spans from ribs six through twelve, and the rib eye steak is the center best portion of the rib steak, without the bone. In the United States, the term rib eye steak or Spencer steak is used for a rib steak with the bone removed, while in some other areas, and outside the U.S., the terms are often used interchangeably. The rib eye is known for its rich flavor and tenderness, due to its high marbling of fat, which makes it ideal for fast and hot cooking methods such as grilling or pan-frying. In Australia and New Zealand, the cut is served with the bone in and is called "ribeye," while when the bone is removed, it is referred to as "Scotch fillet." Regardless of the name, the rib eye steak is a popular choice among meat enthusiasts for its exceptional taste and texture.

r2: The rib eye or ribeye, known as Scotch fillet in Australia and New Zealand, is a boneless rib steak from the rib section of a cow, spanning from ribs six through twelve, and is mostly composed of the longissimus dorsi muscle, complexus and spinalis muscles. It is tender, and Its marbling of fat makes it very good for fast and hot cooking.

a: The vein of Mount St. Helens refers to the distinctive pattern of eruptive activity that characterized the volcano's history prior to the catastrophic 1980 eruption. According to the provided factoids, Mount St. Helens experienced two distinct periods of activity, the Kalama cycle and the Goat Rocks cycle. The Kalama cycle, which occurred between 1647 and 1800, was marked by the emplacement of a dacite dome at the summit of the volcano, followed by an andesite lava flow and the formation of a notch in the southeast crater wall. The Goat Rocks cycle, which began in 1800 and lasted for 57 years, also started with an explosion of dacite tephra, followed by an andesite lava flow and the emplacement of a dacite dome. These cycles of activity were characterized by the eruption of dacite lava and the formation of domes at the summit of the volcano.

The 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens was a significant departure from this pattern of activity, as it was much larger and more destructive than any of the previous eruptions. The eruption began with a massive explosion of dacite tephra, followed by the emplacement of a large andesite lava flow and the destruction of the pre-existing summit cone. The eruption also produced massive ash fall and pyroclastic flows that devastated the surrounding area and caused widespread destruction.

Overall, the vein of Mount St. Helens refers to the pattern of eruptive activity that characterized the volcano's history prior to the 1980 eruption, which was marked by the formation of dacite domes and the eruption of dacite lava. The 1980 eruption was a significant departure from this pattern, and marked a turning point in the volcano's history. The Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument was created to preserve the volcano and allow for the eruption's aftermath to be scientifically studied.
r1: Mount St. Helens has erupted multiple times with various VEIs. The 1860 eruption had a VEI of 6, the 1980 eruption had a VEI of 5 and the eruption activity during 2004-2008 had a VEI of 2.
r2: The Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEI) is a relative measure of the explosiveness of volcanic eruptions. The scale is logarithmic, with each interval on the scale representing a tenfold increase in observed ejecta criteria, with the exception of between VEI-0, VEI-1 and VEI-2. The VEI of Mount St. Helens during the 1860 BC eruption was 6 and during the 1980 eruption it was 5. The VEI of Mount St. Helens during the 2004-2008 eruption was 2.

a: The federal law providing benefits for the unemployed, known as unemployment insurance, was passed in the United States in 1935 as part of the Social Security Act. The law was enacted during the Great Depression to provide financial assistance to individuals who had lost their jobs due to economic conditions beyond their control. At the time of its implementation, the benefit was criticized by communists, who thought it would prevent workers from starting a revolution, while employers and tories saw it as a "necessary evil." The scheme was based on actuarial principles and was funded by a fixed amount each from workers, employers, and taxpayers. It was restricted to particular industries, particularly more volatile ones like shipbuilding, and did not make provision for any dependants.

In Canada, the system now known as Employment Insurance was formerly called Unemployment Insurance. The name was changed in 1996 to alleviate perceived negative connotations. In 1935, the Employment and Social Insurance Act was passed during the Great Depression by the government of R.B. Bennett as an attempted Canadian unemployment insurance program. However, it was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of Canada as unemployment was judged to be an insurance matter falling under provincial responsibility. After a constitutional amendment was agreed to by all of the provinces, a reference to "Unemployment Insurance" was added to the matters falling under federal authority under the Constitution Act, 1867, and the first Canadian system was adopted in 1940.

In the United Kingdom, the first unemployment benefit scheme was introduced in 1911 under the Liberal Party government of H. H. Asquith. The National Insurance Act gave the British working classes a contributory system of insurance against illness and unemployment. However, it only applied to wage earners and their families, and the unwaged had to rely on other sources of support.

In Argentina, successive administrations have used a variety of passive and active labor market interventions to protect workers against the consequences of economic shocks. In Germany, unemployment insurance was introduced in 1927, and in most European countries in the period after the Second World War with the expansion of the welfare state.

Overall, the history of unemployment benefits can be traced back to the early 20th century, with the first schemes being introduced in the United Kingdom and Canada. The concept was later adopted by other countries, including the United States, Germany, and many European nations. Today, unemployment benefits continue to play an important role in providing financial assistance to individuals who have lost their jobs due to economic conditions beyond their control.
r1: The first federal law providing benefits for the unemployed receive royal assent in the UK on 16 December 1911. And Unemployment benefits were introduced in Germany in 1927. The in 1935, the US federal law providing benefits for the unemployed passed.
r2: Unemployment benefits, also called unemployment insurance, unemployment payment, unemployment compensation, or simply unemployment, are payments made by authorized bodies to unemployed people. The first federal law providing benefits for the unemployed received royal assent in the UK on 16 December 1911. In Germany, unemployment benefits were introduced in 1927. Through the Social Security Act of 1935, the federal government of the United States effectively encouraged the individual states to adopt unemployment insurance plans.

a: The fur trade in Canada began in the early 16th century, with European traders and Native American tribes exchanging goods and pelts in the pre-Columbian era. The industry gained momentum in the 16th and 17th centuries with the arrival of French, British, Dutch, and other European traders, who established trading posts and settlements in present-day Canada and the United States. The North American fur trade became a major economic venture, attracting competition among European powers and Native American tribes. Many Native American societies came to depend on the fur trade as their primary source of income, and the industry played a significant role in the early history of contact between Europeans and Native Americans.

The French were among the first Europeans to establish a presence in the fur trade, with traders and missionaries arriving in the 16th century. They established trading posts and settlements in present-day Quebec and the Great Lakes region, and traded with Native American tribes for pelts such as beaver, sea otter, and deer. The British established trading posts on Hudson Bay in the 17th century, and the Dutch had trade in New Netherland (present-day New York) by the same time. The Russian fur trade also played a significant role in the industry, with traders and settlers establishing themselves in present-day Alaska and the Pacific Northwest.

The fur trade was a lucrative industry, with pelts such as beaver and sea otter in high demand for their valuable fur. The industry also played a significant role in the early history of the United States, with many American settlers and traders involved in the fur trade. However, by the mid-1800s, changing fashions in Europe brought about a collapse in fur prices, and the American Fur Company and other companies failed. Despite this, the legacy of the fur trade continues to be felt in present-day Canada and the United States, with many communities and cultures still connected to the industry and its history.

r2: The North American fur trade was industry and activity related to the acquisition, trade, exchange, and sale of animal furs in North America. Aboriginal peoples in Canada traded fur among themselves in the pre–Columbian Era. Europeans and First Nations began trading fur in Canada in the 1500s. The French started trading in Canada in the 16th century and the English and Dutch began trading in Canada in the 17th century. The team has also experienced extended periods of losing, including a 16-year streak of consecutive losing seasons from 1933 to 1948. The franchise's home stadium is Citizens Bank Park, located in the South Philadelphia section of the city.

It is worth noting that there is also a professional football team called the Philadelphia Phillies, which was established in 1902 and played in the National Football League. However, this team was short-lived and is not related to the current Major League Baseball team of the same name.
r1: The American professional baseball team, the Philadelphia Phillies won their first world series championship in 1980 and won their second championship in 2008.
r2: The Philadelphia Phillies are an American professional baseball team based in Philadelphia. The Phillies have won two World Series championships. The first was against the Kansas City Royals in 1980 and the second was against the Tampa Bay Rays in 2008.
