0.21890546861711346
a: The practice of baptism in early Christianity can be traced back to the Jewish tradition of ritual washing, specifically the practice of tevilah, which involved full body immersion in a mikveh. This practice was codified in various codes of Jewish law and tradition, such as Maimonides' "Mishneh Torah" and Joseph Karo's "Shulchan Aruch." The concept of baptism was also mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, where it was referred to as a purification rite, and was elaborated upon in the Mishnah and Talmud.

During Jesus' ministry, he likened his own baptism by John the Baptist to the baptism that his followers would undergo, which was seen as a form of purification and a preparation for the coming kingdom. This idea was recorded in the New Testament, specifically in the Gospel of Mark, which states that those who believe and are baptized will be saved, but those who do not believe will be condemned. This idea of baptism as a form of purification and salvation was likely influenced by the Jewish tradition of ritual washing, and was seen as a way to cleanse oneself of sin and become a follower of Jesus.

The practice of baptism in early Christianity was not only a physical act of immersion, but also a spiritual one, as it symbolized the believer's death to sin and their new life in Christ. The idea of baptism as a form of purification and salvation was not limited to Jesus' teachings, but was also reflected in the teachings of the early Church Fathers, such as St. John Chrysostom, who saw baptism as a means of washing away sin and being reborn in Christ.

In conclusion, the practice of baptism in early Christianity was deeply rooted in the Jewish tradition of ritual washing, and was seen as a form of purification and salvation. The idea of baptism as a means of cleansing oneself of sin and becoming a follower of Jesus was central to the teachings of Jesus and the early Church, and continues to be an important practice in Christianity today.
r1: The practice of baptism comes from John the Baptist and originated in the Middle East, while the ritual of baptism also has its roots in a Tevilah, which is a full-body immersion in a mikveh and one of two main forms of ritual washing in Judaism.
r2: John the Baptist, who is considered a forerunner to Christianity, used baptism as the central sacrament of his messianic movement. Christians consider Jesus to have instituted the sacrament of baptism. Although the term "baptism" is not used to describe the Jewish rituals, the purification rites in Halakha Jewish law and tradition, called tvilah or tevilah, a full body immersion, have some similarity to baptism, and the two have been linked. The practice of baptism originated in the Middle East.

The Miracles' version, released in 1975, is a disco-infused track with a growling vocal by Bobby Rogers and a repetitive "Yeah Baby" refrain by Ronnie White. The song's lyrics compare a lover to an electronic device, and the seven-minute track was split into two parts for its release as a single, with "Part 1" receiving the most attention. This version was a #1 Pop smash and the biggest-selling hit of The Miracles' career. In contrast, Girls Aloud's version, released in 2004, is an uptempo synthpop track with a joyful and exhilarating atmosphere, inspired by The Smiths. The single debuted at number 2 on the UK Singles Chart and peaked inside the top ten in Europe and Ireland. Both versions of "Love Machine" showcase the respective groups' ability to create catchy and memorable pop songs that have stood the test of time.

This single was one of two Billboard Hot 100 Top 20 hits recorded by The Miracles with Billy Griffin as lead vocalist; the other is 1973's Do It Baby. Griffin had replaced Miracles founder Smokey Robinson as lead singer in 1972. The background vocals are sung by Bobby Rogers, Ronnie White and Pete Moore. Love Machine is a song recorded by British girl group Girls Aloud from their second studio album, What Will the Neighbours Say? (2004).
r2: There are several songs entitled Love Machine. The 1975 song Love Machine was sung by Motown group The Miracles with Billy Griffin singing lead vocals and Bobby Rogers, Ronnie White and Pete Moore singing background vocals. Ronnie White sings the "yeah baby" vocals on the song. The 2004 song Love Machine was sung by the British girl group Girls Aloud, comprised of Cheryl Cole, Nadine Coyle, Sarah Harding, Nicola Roberts and Kimberley Walsh.

a: Sure! Here's a comprehensive paragraph that answers the question "Who wrote Harry Styles' 'Sign of the Times' lyrics?" while incorporating the provided factoid context:

Harry Styles' debut single "Sign of the Times" was written by the singer himself, along with Jeff Bhasker, Mitch Rowland, Ryan Nasci, Alex Salibian, and Tyler Johnson. The song was produced by Bhasker, Salibian, and Johnson and released on April 7, 2017, as the lead single from Styles' self-titled debut studio album. The fact that Styles, who was previously a member of the boy band One Direction, was writing his own solo material was first reported in 2015, when it was rumored that Sony Music was interested in him releasing a solo album. Four new songs written and performed by Styles were registered on the ASCAP online database that year, leading to further speculation about his solo plans. After signing with Columbia Records and appearing on the cover of "Another Man" magazine in September 2016, the CEO of Columbia Records, Rob Stringer, confirmed that Styles' album was close to being finished and called it "authentic." The lyrics of "Sign of the Times" reflect Styles' introspective and emotionally charged songwriting style, which has been praised for its maturity and depth.
r1: Sign of the Times is the debut single by English singer Harry Styles from his self-titled debut studio album. Released on 7 April 2017 by Columbia Records, it was written by Styles from Redditch, Jeff Bhasker from Kansas City, Mitch Rowland, Ryan Nasci, Alex Salibian from Long Beach, and Tyler Johnson, and produced by Bhasker, Salibian, and Johnson. Musically, it was described by critics as a pop rock and soft rock ballad. Its accompanying music video was released on 8 May 2017. Sign of the Times reached number one on the UK charts and number four in the United States. In 2018, the single won a BMI Pop Award, and the video won a Brit Award for British Artist Video of the Year. In 2021, Rolling Stone placed it at number 428 on its list of The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.
r2: Several people wrote the lyrics to English singer Harry Styles' 2017 debut single Sign of the Times, including Harry Styles, Jeff Bhasker, Mitch Rowland, Ryan Nasci, Alex Salibian, and Tyler Johnson.
